DOC.NOTE: For Release at 3:40 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Days of Drug Lords `Are Numbered'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``At the,'' with crowd estimate; Chuck Norris announcement, Bush breaks news of local bust
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday claimed progress in the war on drugs, saying ``The days of the drug lords ... are numbered,'' and asking TV producers to help portray the destructive potential of narcotics. Bush compared anti-drug efforts to nations casting out oppressive governments, saying, ``people across America are casting off the oppression of drugs.'' ``Week by week, day by day, millions of Americans in thousands of towns are standing up to make the same courageous choice: drug-free neighorhoods, drug-free schools. Drug-free kids,'' he told several thousand school children at a rally sponsored by Orange County's ``Drug Use is Life Abuse'' program. Earlier, in Los Angeles, Bush urged television industry producers to make anti-drug themes part of their programming. He called on the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences to make TV ``a force for positive change.'' At the celebrity-studded Santa Anna rally attended by 15,000 people, movie star Chuck Norris pledged to conquer drug traffickers in his next film. The president broke the news of a massive local drug bust, nearly a half ton of cocaine worth $30 million on the street. The Orange County sheriff's office said it would not be able to release details on the street, but according to Lt. Dick Olson, Bush's remarks would not hurt the prosecution. Bush told the Santa Ana rally that the ``Drug Abuse is Life Abuse'' message ``is beginning to sink in.'' ``Recently we have seen some scattered but hopeful new signs of progress against the horror of drugs,'' he said, citing anti-drug community efforts around the country. He said cases against 14 accused international drug traffickers are pending in U.S. courts following their extraditions. ``The days of the drug lords may not be over yet. But their days are numbered,'' Bush said. Bush's optimistic assessment on drug-war progress comes as his administration seeks $10.6 billion from Congress to combat drugs in fiscal 1991. Administration officials including Bush's drug policy director, William Bennett, recently have been claiming there are signs of a turnaround in the country's drug abuse problem. ``We've covered a lot of ground in the drug war. But tough challenges remain,'' Bush told the Santa Ana rally. ``Drug abuse in this country is still far too widespread.'' Continuing his lobbying for widespread community support, Bush praised the television industry for anti-drug commercials and for programming that portrays the negative side of drugs. ``Thank goodness the days when popular culture glorified and glamorized drug use are fading fast,'' he said. He said he did not seek TV depiction of ``a fantasy world where drugs don't exist,'' but rather treatment of drugs ``with the same degree of realism TV brings to so many other subjects ... To show in the real world how drugs destroy.'' Bush sandwiched the anti-drug events into a four-day California trip that was primarily oriented to Republican Party politicking and a meeting with Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Friday's rally featured appearances by Los Angeles Rams cheerleaders and remarks by TV evangelist Robert Schuller. The anti-drug events Friday followed Bush's appearance at a California Chamber of Commerce dinner Thursday night where he called on businesses to pre-screen job applicants for drug use. ``We need to make it very clear, to every American, that if you do drugs, you don't get hired,'' he said. ``So-called casual users and their money keep these merchants of death in business,'' he said. ``America now condemns what has too long been condoned. The country has had enough,'' he declared.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Authority To Change Policies Regarding Unmarried Couples
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, 8th graf, `Brown hailed...,' to clarify that policy affects all public housing.
DOC.TEXT: A housing policy that denied an unmarried couple a place to live because of their relationship will be revised, the state's American Civil Liberties Union chapter said Thursday. The tentative agreement with the Woonsocket Housing Authority, which needs the approval of U.S. District Judge Ronald R. Lagueux, would consider unmarried couples a ``family'' if they meet certain criteria, including the length of the relationship, whether the applicants have children together, and the existence of joint bank accounts. ``We're going to review our policies and make some changes,'' said Ernest Lafond, the housing authority's director, who rferred other questions to his attorney. The new policy stems from a lawsuit filed by Susan Arseneau and Dana Dagnese, who sued after they were denied emergency housing in December 1988 following their eviction from an unsafe apartment. ``A married couple in the same building was given emergency housing by the WHA, while the plaintiffs were turned down for such housing solely because the agency did not consider them a `family,''' said Steve Brown, executive director of the ACLU's Rhode Island affiliate. Arseneau and Dagnese had lived together for six years and were expecting their third child when they were evicted. The case drew national attention when Lagueux, at a hearing a year ago at which he denied an emergency restraining order against enforcement of the policy, said, ``Here's a couple in an illicit relationship who are creating children for the welfare rolls, while others who qualify for housing are shunted aside.'' Brown hailed the pending agreement, which affects all public housing, as a blow to discrimination against unmarried couples. ``Resolution of this lawsuit will simply affirm a growing trend across the country, in which housing authorities are recognizing that discrimination on the basis of marital status is unfair and inappropriate,'' he said. But the attorney for the housing authority, Steve Rodio, said the main reason the couple was evicted was because Dagnese was legally married to another woman at the time. Rodio said Dagnese's marriage to someone else prompted Lagueux to cite the state's criminal statute against bigamy, and said if the agency had let the couple stay in the apartment it would have ``encouraged'' a potentially bigamous relationship. ``Whether he was single or not wouldn't have mattered,'' said John Dineen, the couple's lawyer. ``The existing rule is you have to be married to each other'' to live together. Dagnese was awaiting his divorce in Massachusetts after having been ``separated for many years'' when he and Arseneau were evicted, said Dineen. The lawsuit, filed by the ACLU and Rhode Island Legal Services on behalf of Arseneau and Dagnese, claimed the agency's action violated the couple's constitutional rights to freedom of association, family privacy and equal protection under the law. Dineen also said the policy was in violation of federal and state housing laws. Dineen and Rodio didn't know when Lagueux would rule on the agreement, nor whether the couple still wanted to live in city housing. ``They're still seeking housing, and they continue to want to be together,'' Dineen said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Offers Assurances on Troop Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 16-17: ``Shigeo Takenaka,'' Japanese comments. Minor editing to trim. Should stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, opening a two-day desert summit, assured Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Friday that a cutback of U.S. troops in Asia will not undermine stability or security there, an official said. The two leaders avoided discussing Japan's huge trade surplus and the growing trade tensions between the world's largest economic powers, leaving those subjects for Saturday. ``Welcome, sir,'' a smiling Bush said as he shook hands with Kaifu across a conference table at a posh country club. Despite the economic conflicts, Bush emphasized the positive in his opening remarks, noting, ``There are so many areas of common interest where we have such a strong relationship with Japan.'' The very fact that Kaifu responded to his invitation for the hastily arranged meeting was an ``important display of your feelings about our relationship,'' Bush said. ``Certainly my inviting you here is a strong indication from us about the importance of this relationship,'' Bush said. The two leaders met for an hour before gathering again for dinner at the heavily guarded estate of millionaire publisher Walter Annenberg. Emerging from a one-on-one meeting, Bush said, ``We had a very good discussion.'' There was no sign of friction, although White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would warn the prime minister that Congress was in ``very tough mood'' in insisting that Japan lower barriers to U.S. goods and services. In a statement afterward, Fitzwater said the opening session was devoted to security issues. The United States is considering reducing its 120,000 troops in Asia by about 10 percent. That would mean a reduction of 5,000 troops in Japan. In addition, Washington is pressing Tokyo for a sizeable increase in Japan's $2.4 billion annual support for American troops stationed in the country. Bush told Kaifu that the changes in the U.S. defense posture ``will not affect either deterrence or stability, nor its commitment to its Asian allies,'' Fitzwater said. Referring to U.S. hopes that Japan will increase defense spending, Fitzwater said, ``The two leaders discussed the issue of burden sharing, noting the need for suitable arrangements for balanced cost-sharing.'' Fitzwater said Kaifu ``stressed the importance to coordinate our policies and tackle the issues from the standpoint of mutual cooperation.'' Shigeo Takenaka, deputy spokesman for the Japanese foreign ministry, said that to solve the difficult trade issues, ``We must continue to strengthen cooperation in other areas,'' such as aid to Latin America and the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. ``We certainly didn't sense any ambush here,'' he said when asked whether the Americans were coming down hard on Tokyo over trade. The meeting room at Morningside Country Club was decked out in two large floral arrangements and overlooked landscaped gardens and manicured lawns that contrasted sharply with the barren nearby desert and snow-covered mountains in the distance. The meeting room at Morningside Country Club was decked out in two large floral arrangements and overlooked landscaped gardens and manicured lawns that contrasted sharply with the barren nearby desert and snow-covered mountains in the distance. Bush and his guest were to dine informally at the sprawling, heavily guarded estate of millionaire publisher Walter Annenberg. Bush and Kaifu both arrived in nearby Palm Springs Los Angeles within minutes of each other and rode in from the airport together in the president's armored limosine. During the 25-minute ride Bush congratulated Kaifu on his election victory last month and ``emphasized the importance of our security relationship,'' Fitzwater said. The president will stress the importance of opening Japan's markets and emphasize the possibility of U.S. sanctions if action isn't forthcoming to cool tensions between the world's largest economic powers, Fitzwater said. In Los Angeles earlier, Bush himself said of Kaifu, ``We've got to convince him that we've got to move forward with some of the tough problems.'' Still, there was concern in both Washington and Tokyo that the hastily arranged meeting had raised unrealistic expectations about a breakthrough in trade conflicts. Economists of all persuasions and the administration admit that even if Japan abolished all trade restrictions of which the United States has complained, the major part of Japan's $49 billion annual trade surplus with the United States would remain because of American appetites for cars, electronics and other high-quality Japanese goods. ``I don't think we expect any action on the major issues before us,'' Fitzwater said. ``I could be surprised.'' U.S. business leaders also said they expected no breakthrough but raised the possibility that the discussions could set the stage for a full-fledged trade summit between the two leaders later in the year. Congressional sources said they understood Kaifu might be prepared to offer some small concessions in an effort to show progress in the trade talks. One congressional source, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said that Kaifu was expected to propose lower tariffs on a portion of U.S. finished wood products although the reduction would cover only a small portion of U.S. lumber sales to Japan. Wood products, satellites and supercomputers are three key areas where negotiators have been focusing their attention in an effort to lower Japanese barriers to sales of American products. Kaifu flew to Palm Springs in response to an invitation issued by Bush during a middle-of-the-night telephone call last Friday. Asserting itself, Congress has imposed deadlines for talks on a dozen issues ranging from supercomputers to lumber and even the cultural foundations of the two societies. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said this week the U.S.-Japanese relationship was ``at a difficult point and needs to have the highest level of attention.'' For its part, Japan wants the United States to reduce its huge budget deficit and increase Americans' savings rate, thus reducing demands for Japanese imports. Kaifu's standing in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party is considered tenuous, and a successful summit could bolster his status. Last May, the United States put Japan on a trade ``hit list'' for alleged unfair barriers to American wood products, satellites and supercomputers. The administration has until June 16 to negotiate a removal of the barriers. If negotiations fail, the administration can impose retaliatory tariffs which Japan argues would violate international rules on fair trade.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescu's Planned Headquarters Open to Public
DOC.TEXT: The doors of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's palatial planned headquarters were opened to the public for the first time, evoking awe and outrage from the visitors. About 2,000 Romanians paid about 25 cents each on Thursday to enter the unfinished, monumental House of the Republic, one of the world's largest buildings, situated on a man-made hill in the heart of the capital. In groups and individually, they shuffled through the mammoth ballrooms, meeting halls, amphitheatres, living suites and offices. They gawked at hundreds of marble columns, red velvet drapes, extensive gold ornamentation and diamond-studded chandeliers, including one said to be the biggest in Europe, in 800-seat Column Hall. Ushers urged visitors not to touch the elegant furniture. The massive building, built entirely with local materials, was meant to house the leading bodies of the state and Communist Party, and included imperial suites for the dictatorial couple, Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. The municipality has not yet decided what to do with the building, which has cost $1 billion over six years of construction. One of the reasons for the open house, which is to last two months, is to solicit suggestions from the public. So far, according to Chief Engineer Alexander Baumgarten, ``The most popular suggestions are making it an international conference and exhibition center, or a sort of home for Romania's artists.'' Some people, finding the building's extravagance offensive in this impoverished country, have also proposed destroying it. But Baumgarten, who headed the building's quality-control team until construction ceased when Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22, is lobbying hard for the building to be finished. He said it can be completed in two years with another $200 million to $250 million. ``In addition to food and shelter, we need beauty in our lives. What would the world be without art museums and palaces?'' ``We admit the exterior is less attractive, because the former president imposed his views on the architects,'' sighed Baumgarten. ``But if you take an architecture textbook and inspect the ornaments and columns in the interior, you will see that this is, in fact, a monumental work of art.'' He proudly reeled off the building's vital statistics: two huge halls, two amphitheatres, 60 large salons, 540 offices, and another thousand-odd smaller rooms. Including its three underground levels, the building reaches a maximum height of 100 yards. The total surface area of the sprawling structure, at 360,000 square yards, is ``three times bigger than the Versailles Palace and also bigger than the Pentagon,'' said Baumgarten. The palace, wryly dubbed the House of the People by the Romanian press, is only one of several unfinished buildings in an area known as the Civic Center, encompassing several square miles where 15,000 buildings once stood. They were razed over the past decade by Ceausescu's master builders. At the height of the construction, 20,000 workers a day entered the building, with en estimated million workers in the project over the past six years. But for the average citizen, the building site was strictly off-limits. On Thursday, they shuffled through on wooden planks laid out on the wall-to-wall carpeting, most staring in silent awe at the extravagant luxury, which evoked both angry indignation and patriotism. In the vast, empty Romania Hall, an old woman commanded foreign journalists to ``write more, take more pictures ... to show what beautiful things we, Romanians, can create.'' Others were less enthusiastic. One middle-aged man silently shook his head in Ceausescu's huge ``relaxing room,'' last visited by the dictator on Dec. 10. ``While we starved, while we had no heating at night, he built this unbelievable monument to himself and Elena.'' Mrs. Ceausescu's adjacent room was slightly smaller but more ornate, with lace curtains and elaborate wood carvings rimmed with gold studs. ``Monstrous,'' said another man. ``He must have hated us horribly.'' ``No, it wasn't hate,'' said another woman. ``We were in the grip of an unspeakable insanity.''

DOC.HEAD: Economist Named For New Superministry in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: An economist who favors selling off state enterprises and cutting the number of public employees has been named to Brazil's most powerful Cabinet post. The newly created Economy Ministry was created by merging the finance and planning ministries. Zelia Cardoso de Mello, an advocate of free-market reforms, was named Thursday by President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello. The two are not related. ``This is a sign of confidence, not only in me personally but in a new generation,'' said Ms. Cardoso de Mello, 36. At a news conference called to announce the appointment, the president-elect said, ``This is an unprecedented challenge. For the first time in Latin American history, a woman will steer the economic destiny of a great nation.'' He said her top priority will be to fight inflation, now running at more than 70 percent per month. Ms. Cardoso de Mello said the new administration's economic program will include cuts in government subsidies, selling off of a number of state-run companies, cracking down on tax cheats and a tough new law to punish ``abusers of economic power.'' She gave few details. Ms. Cardoso de Mello said the number of ministries would be reduced from 23 to 12, and an undisclosed number of public employees would be fired. She said Brazil's $114 billion foreign debt, largest in the Third World, could be reduced through ``debt-for-equity swaps,'' whereby creditors receive shares in publicly owned firms in exchange for debt. She promised better relations with the International Monetary Fund and a renegotiation of debt payments ``based on new instruments of reducing debt service, refinancing of late interest payments and new money.'' Brazil stopped paying capital on the debt in 1983 and quietly suspended interest payment last September to protect its international currency reserves. Her appointment was widely expected. Cardoso de Mello was the president-elect's chief economic adviser during last year's campaign and has headed a team preparing economic measures to be put into effect after he takes office March 15. She has no previous government experience except a brief stint at a midlevel post in the Finance Ministry during the administration of Jose Sarney.

DOC.HEAD: Former Air Force Pilot Pleads Guilty To Espionage
DOC.TEXT: An ex-Air Force pilot who admitted selling high-level secrets to an FBI undercover officer posing as a Soviet agent has pleaded guilty to espionage charges. Authorities said Ronald Craig Wolf, 34, received only a partial payment before his arrest in Dallas. He entered the plea Wednesday to the federal charges of selling secrets in mid-1989 to a government agent he knew by the code name ``Sergei Kitin.'' U.S. District Judge Sidney Fitzwater has set sentencing for April 20. Discharged from the Air Force in 1981 for ``financial irresponsibility,'' Wolf had earlier pleaded innocent to the charges. Wolf, a Waco native, agreed to plead guilty in exchange for a reduction in the severity of the charges. He now faces a maximum of 10 years in prison but could have received life imprisonment before the plea bargain. The former pilot was arrested nine months ago after contacting a man he thought represented the Soviet Embassy in Washington, D.C., more than 15 times between March 9 and May 5. Federal court records show Wolf relayed classified documents concerning top-secret signal intelligence. Wolf told the purported Soviet agent that he wanted to sell classified military documents ``for monetary gain and to get revenge for his treatment by the United States government,'' according to an affidavit filed in connection with the case.

DOC.HEAD: Facts About the Seabrook Nuclear Plant
With PM-Seabrook License, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts about the Seabrook nuclear plant: PROJECT ANNOUNCED: After shelving an earlier proposal in 1969, Public Service Company of New Hampshire announced Feb. 1, 1972, that it planned to build two nuclear reactors at Seabrook, the first to start operating commercially in 1979, the second in 1981. The utility initially estimated the entire project would cost less than $1 billion. LOCATION: On land surrounded by marshes less than two miles from Hampton Beach, little more than two miles north of Massachusetts and about 40 miles north of Boston. CONSTRUCTION BEGAN: July 7, 1976. CONSTRUCTION COMPLETED: Unit 1: July 31, 1986, at cost of more than $4.3 billion; Unit 2: canceled 1986, 25 percent complete. NUCLEAR FUEL LOADED: October 1986. COST TO DATE: $6.5 billion as of Thursday; post-completion costs have been for financing and operations. DESIGN: Pressurized-water reactor. MANUFACTURERS: Reactor and steam supply system: Westinghouse. Generator: General Electric. OUTPUT: 1,150 megawatts, enough electricity for about 1 million homes. WORK FORCE: During peak construction, more than 8,000; now, 1,475, including some contract employees. DEMONSTRATIONS: Began before ground-breaking in 1976, peaked in late 1970s, continue to present. Overall, there have been more than 3,200 arrests in anti-Seabrook protests.

DOC.HEAD: Other Nuclear Power Plants Troubled
With PM-Seabrook License, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's decision to issue a license to the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear plant, many other reactors in the United States remain candidates for closure. No utility has planned a new plant since the 1970s. Here is a list of some other troubled nuclear plants in the United States:

SHOREHAM: A fully licensed plant on heavily populated Long Island about 50 miles east of New York City, Shoreham has never operated commercially. The plant would be scrapped without ever operating under an agreement reached in May 1988 between New York State and the Long Island Lighting Co. The Bush administration, fighting the plan, wants Shoreham mothballed _ left intact with radioactive material in place _ rather than torn down.

THREE MILE ISLAND: Cleanup operations continue on TMI's damaged reactor more than 10 years after the nation's worst commercial nuclear accident. The undamaged sister reactor, TMI Unit 1, which was shut down during the March 1979 accident, was restarted in 1985.

SHIPPINGPORT: The nation's first commercial reactor, which began operations in 1957, has become the world's first commercial reactor to be dismantled. Federal officials intend to remove all radioactive material so the site in western Pennsylvania can be returned to unrestricted use. The reactor was sealed in concrete, loaded aboard a barge and sent on a 8,100-mile journey via the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers and the Panama Canal to a disposal site in Hanford, Wash., last year.

PILGRIM: This Massachusetts plant, cited by the NRC in April 1986 as ``one of the worst-run'' nuclear plants in the country, was authorized to begin a gradual restart in December 1988, more than two years after the NRC shut the facility due to maintenance and management problems. State officials since have asked the NRC to suspend the plant's operating license, citing inadequate evacuation plans and potential health problems for nearby residents.

RANCHO SECO: Voters in the Sacramento, Calif., area decided in a June 1988 referendum to close the long-plagued Rancho Seco plant and the operating utility shut down operations a day later. Recent proposals to revive the reactor by selling the plant to another operator have been rejected.

PEACH BOTTOM: The two Peach Bottom reactors in Pennsylvania were shut down by the NRC in March 1987 after federal investigators found plant operators sleeping on duty. A month earlier, a nuclear industry watchdog group had called the plant a national embarrassment, citing poor procedures and management. The Philadelphia Electric Co. overhauled plant operations and the reactors went back into service in last year.

TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY: All five of TVA's operating reactors were shut down in 1985 for safety improvements and the first one back in operation, Sequoyah Unit 2, did not restart until May 1988. TVA had to cancel plans to build eight other reactors and construction already under way on four others was slowed.

PALO VERDE: Licensed in 1985, Palo Verde was the first nuclear plant of what was hoped would be a standardized design that would speed the regulatory process. But management and training deficiencies led to problems that have shut down the three reactors almost as often as they have been running. The NRC has fined the Arizona Nuclear Power Project $810,000 since 1983 for deficiencies in plant operations, and sent a special diagnostic team last fall to study the facility's problems.

DIABLO CANYON: Diablo Canyon began commercial operation in 1985, 13 years behind schedule and at 17 times its originally planned cost. Design errors, the discovery of the magnitude of an earthquake fault nearby, federal licensing problems and legal challenges all contributed to the delay.

TURKEY POINT: The NRC has hit Turkey Point, operated by Florida Power & Light Co., with about $1 million in fines over the past five years for safety and security violations, identifying the plant as one of the nation's 10 worst. Ralph Nader's environmental group, Public Citizen, has also called it one of the worst-managed commercial facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Lose Leftist Ally With Sandinista Defeat
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The opposition victory in Nicaragua strips El Salvador's leftist rebels of their only government ally in Central America and tests the mettle of the regional peace process. The Nicaraguan conflict has absorbed most of the energy of the negotiations since their outset in 1987. Suddenly the war is all but over _ and that leaves El Salvador in the spotlight. The full implications of the Sandinista defeat remain to be seen, but it is clearly a blow to the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. El Salvador's rightist president, Alfredo Cristiani, was elated by the outcome of the Nicaraguan election. ``The FMLN is going to be left isolated like Mr. (Fidel) Castro in Cuba,'' he said of the rebel front that has been battling a series of U.S.-backed governments in El Salvador since 1979. The FMLN has long counted on Managua for logistical and political support. The Salvadoran rebel front has offices in Managua, uses Nicaragua for safe haven and, according to U.S. officials, maintains a vital radio installation that serves as a command and control center for guerrillas in the field. Nicaragua, which has the only leftist government in Central America, is also a source of arms for the FMLN, although the details are hotly debated. The United States and the Salvadoran government insist that Nicaragua is a crucial source of weapons. The Sandinistas and the FMLN dispute this. The FMLN, one of the best-organized and highly motivated rebel forces in the world, can fight on if Nicaragua's new, pro-U.S. government evicts them after taking office April 25. But the battle will be harder. ``The loss of the only sympathetic government in the region clearly is serious for the FMLN,'' Richard Fagen, the director of Ltin American Studies at Stanford University and an international observer during the election. Some observers say the end of the Nicaraguan war and the electoral loss of the Sandinistas might pave the way for a negotiated solution in El Salvador, where a decade of war has claimed an estimated 73,000 lives. Others say it might make the situation even more intractable. ``Maybe there will be a new focusing of attention, a high priority on Salvadoran peace prospects,'' said former President Jimmy Carter, another election observer. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., said he was afraid the Sandinistas would pour arms into El Salvador before leaving office on April 25. Dodd, an election observer, also said he feared hard-liners in the Salvadoran military and government might abandon the idea of negotiating, assuming the Sandinista loss was such a blow to the FMLN that battlefield victory is now possible. Much depends on Washington, which has poured $4 billion into El Salvador in a decade to fend off an FMLN victory. Fagen said the United States will have to pressure the rightist government into serious talks with the FMLN. ``The only way to do this is to take a very active role with the Salvadoran army,'' he said. ``The United States in Central America has never been able to exercise its full power over local governments when it didn't have substantial control over the army.'' One good sign for the peace process is the prospect of better relations between Honduras and Nicaragua if the 10,000-man U.S.-financed Contra army in Honduran border camps demobilizes. If the new Nicaraguan government manages to exert control over the Sandinista army _ a 150,000-member giant armed by the Soviet bloc _ regional tensions also should cool. Another strong motivation to continue the process is economic recovery. War has sapped the regional economies and frightened away investors, condemning millions of people to poverty. New Honduran President Rafael Callejas has been hoping get his nation's staggering economy going again, but like everyone elese in the region, the fundamental condition is peace. The prime mover of the Central American peace process, Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, will be leaving office soon, but a peaceful transition of power in Nicaragua could go a long way towards helping the region reach the goal for which he won the Nobel Peace Prize. After the election, Arias said El Salvador should follow Nicaragua's example and seek a negotiated solution to the war that has claimed an estimated 73,000 lives. He said events in Nicaragua should ``send a message to El Salvador: there is no sympathy in the world for those seek power through violence.'' Both the Cristiani government and the FMLN have said they are willing to talk but they are poles apart. The last attempt at negotiations ended in mid-November when the rebels launched a month-long offensive. The FMLN high command has praised the Sandinistas and President Daniel Ortega for holding the election here and advancing the cause of democracy. ``We will redouble our struggle for an authentic democracy in El Salvador, for which so much blood has been shed by our people,'' the high command said after the election.

DOC.HEAD: Kids to Supreme Court: `You're Better Than `Night Court''
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court is even better than ``Night Court'' on TV, and it would be neat to be a member, say some of the hundreds of school kids who wrote to the court to help celebrate its 200th anniversary. The court received multicolored and hand-printed cards from elementary school students around the country as it marked its bicentennial last month. ``Roses are red, violets are blue. Supreme Court is great, and a happy birthday to you,'' wrote Brandi Bryant, a fourth-grader from Grafton, Va. Classmate Billy Francavilla told the justices, ``You're better than `Night Court,''' a television show. And Grafton fourth-grader Kristi Downs, who probably doesn't know anyone who's 200, wrote to say, ``You're lucky to still be around.'' Perhaps the biggest compliment came from Blytheville, Ark., where Presbyterian Christian Academy sixth-grader Scott Green wrote: ``It would be neat to be in the highest court. Even though she's a girl, I would still want to be Sandra Day O'Connor.''

Even a Supreme Court justice can slip up when offering an off-the-cuff summary of a 7-year-old ruling. O'Connor recently erred in describing a free-speech decision stemming from demonstrations at the court's imposing building on Capitol Hill. O'Connor's mistake came during oral arguments over a federal regulation that bans soliciting donations on Postal Service property, and was sparked by Justice Antonin Scalia's questioning of a lawyer. After the lawyer contended that the areas outside all post offices are free-speech zones, Scalia asked, ``What about us? Would we have to let people demonstrate outside'' on court property? In what seemed to be an effort to get back to the case at hand, O'Connor interrupted to say the court already has ruled ``there is no right to picket on court property'' but only on the surrounding public sidewalks. Well, not exactly. Whether federal law can make the court's property off limits to demonstrators remains an open question. In a case called United States vs. Grace, the court in 1983 unanimously struck down as unconstitutional part of a federal law that banned demonstrators from court property and the public sidewalks surrounding it. The court said the public has a constitutional right, guaranteed by the First Amendment, to use a city sidewalk as one long soapbox subject to reasonable time, place and manner regulations. But the decision specifically left unanswered whether the federal law's ban on demonstrators could be applied to the court's property within the city sidewalks. ``We need not make that judgment at this time,'' Justice Byron R. White wrote for the court back then, ``because (the ban imposed by Congress) covers the public sidewalks as well as the building and grounds inside the sidewalks.'' O'Connor joined White's opinion. The Supreme Court is infallible when interpreting the Constitution because no one can second-guess it, but the court's nine justices are only human _ sometimes they make mistakes.
DOC.HEAD: New Poll, Same Results: Americans Don't Know Much About Court
DOC.TEXT: The National Law Journal recently polled 805 citizens and concluded, as have previous polls, that Americans do not know very much about their highest court. Fewer than one-fourth of those asked knew that the court has nine members. Only one in three could name one of the nine. Among the justices, John Paul Stevens is the least known by Americans. Only 1 percent of those asked could name him. O'Connor is the best-known justice, with a 33 percent rating. The polling was conducted among people over 18; the results might have been more encouraging if elementary schoolchildren were included.

DOC.HEAD: Fowler Says Bush Tree Planting Rhetoric Outrunning Reality
DOC.TEXT: The administration is letting ``rhetoric outrun the reality'' by proposing spending cuts in forestry programs needed to implement President Bush's plan to plant a billion new trees, Sen. Wyche Fowler says. The Georgia Democrat, chairman of the Senate agriculture subcommittee on conservation and forestry, told administration officials Thursday that Bush's ``America the Beautiful'' tree-planting proposal won't succeed without the support of private landowners. Those landowners, he said, won't support the program if they're hit by new expenses that were covered by the forestry assistance programs the administration wants to cut. ``One thing we cannot do is let the rhetoric outrun the reality,'' Fowler said. ``If we tell people we're going to plant a billion trees, the resources have to be there.'' Patricia M. Kearney, acting assistant secretary of agriculture for natural resources and environment, said Bush's $175 million initiative ``will help demonstrate America's commitment to address worldwide concerns about deforestation and global climate change.'' She said it includes $110 million to provide matching funds to private rural landowners for tree planting and forest improvements, $30 million for a community tree-planting program that will rely on volunteers, and $35 million to start a private foundation to promote tree planting. But Fowler argued that the program cannot be reconciled with other proposals in the administration's fiscal 1991 budget, such as a nearly 50 percent cut in state and private forestry assistance funds _ including a reduction funding for the seedlings and nursery program. ``With all the new tree planting, where are you going to get the trees?'' he asked. Dale Robertson, chief of the U.S. Forest Service, said most of the seedlings for the Bush initiative will come from commercial and state programs. The federal program provides only about 5 percent of the nation's tree seedlings, he said. The administration budget also would reduce funding for pest management on private forests from $51.4 million this year to $41.7 million next year, and would slash fire protection spending for private forests from $13.3 million to $4 million. ``It's hard to see how that would be consistent with increased tree planting and maintaining healthy forests,'' Fowler said. Robertson said the proposed spending cuts for pest and fire protection were consistent with past administration efforts to shift those costs to the states and to private landowners. ``We need to do the job with fire protection and insect protection, but it gets down to the question of who pays for it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook: Last Hurrah or New Beginning For Nuclear Industry?
An AP News Analysis
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The two-decade battle over the Seabrook, N.H., power plant helped cripple the nuclear power industry. Pro- and anti-nuclear advocates agreed on that much Thursday as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved Seabrook for commercial operation. What remained unclear was whether the approval would mark the industry's last hurrah or bring about a second life for nuclear power. The facts are plain enough. No utility has applied for a nuclear power license since 1978 and more than 100 reactor orders have been canceled in that time. Accidents at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania and Chernobyl in the Soviet Union spread concern about nuclear power from activists to the general public. ``The industry is so much in defeat that there's not likely any utility that's ever again going to want to order one of these machines,'' said Robert Backus, counsel to the Seacoast Anti-Pollution League, a New Hampshire-based group opposed to Seabrook. ``We feel like we have been instrumental in the collapse of nuclear power in this country and perhaps even around the world,'' Backus said. Seabrook owners waited 17 years from their application for a construction permit to the approval of a full-power license. And junk bonds used to help finance the plant through the long wait likely will not be available in future nuclear projects. Still, there were optimists Thursday after the NRC's 3-0 vote in favor of a Seabrook license. ``As our demand for electricity keeps growing, we fully expect that we'll get back to building more new nuclear plants,'' said Harold B. Finger of the U.S. Council for Energy Awareness, an association representing the nuclear industry. ``Today's vote means utilities can look with more confidence to nuclear energy as a part of their total strategy for providing America's fast-growing electricity needs.'' Seabrook's own top executives were either uncertain or downright pessimistic about the industry's future. New Hampshire Yankee President Edward Brown said ``I can't predict'' whether Seabrook will become ``a bellwether for the future of the entire nuclear industry in the United States.'' Brown's top deputy, Ted Feigenbaum, said the two-decade regulatory gauntlet run by Seabrook must be changed if nuclear energy is to grow. ``It's taken too long,'' he said. The NRC has tried to address the problem with a new set of rules enacted last year. They would allow a utility to receive advance approval if it chose a pre-approved site and used a standard reactor design that had passed NRC muster, said commission spokesman Frank Ingram. But, NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr said, ``I don't have any orders for new plants.'' And he said the decline of nuclear power could lead to darker days and nights ahead. ``As a private citizen, it worries me that nobody's building power plants out there of any kind,'' Carr said. ``Power in the United States is not going to be sufficient in the next 10 years and we'll see the rolling blackouts that we saw in Florida and Texas over the winter. They'll spread.'' Organized opposition was one key ingredient that discouraged utilities from building nuclear plants, Carr said. The other was public utility regulators' refusal to allow construction costs to be passed on to ratepayers until a plant was finished. Such a ruling in New Hampshire led Public Service Company of New Hampshire, owner of the largest Seabrook share, to abandon one of two reactors in 1986 and declare bankruptcy in 1988. Some members of Congress appear to be moving in the direction of even tougher rules. A House subcommittee plans to open hearings March 15 into the NRC's procedures in reaching the Seabrook decision. Members of the Massachusetts congressional delegation called the hearings after accusing the NRC of running roughshod over its own regulations to ram through the Seabrook approval. Thursday was a day of mixed emotions for combatants in the Seabrook fight. Proponents celebrated the licensing decision and worried about the nuclear power industry. Opponents hissed the NRC as it issued its ruling but declared victory in the war on nuclear power. For pro-nuclear activists, there is the hope that the Seabrook experience will lead to a streamlined licensing process. The attitude of opponents was typified by Scott Denman of the Safe Energy Communication Council, a Washington-based group. ``Seabrook is the last hurrah for a crippled industry,'' Denman said. ``The nuclear power industry has failed to rally support on Wall Street or Main Street.''

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Debate Heads to Senate Floor
DOC.TEXT: A new agreement on sweeping air pollution controls is expected to ease Senate passage of the measure, although the accord with the White House is prompting criticism from environmentalists and industry _ not to mention some senators. Senate leaders and the Bush administration announced agreement Thursday on the most contentious parts of the bill, including controls on acid rain, automobile emissions and toxic chemical releases by industry. ``We have reached agreement on sound and comprehensive legislation that expands and strengthens the clean air laws and have done it in the most cost-effective way possible,'' declared Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Mitchell said he plans to bring the bill to the Senate floor Monday. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole called the proposal a ``giant step forward'' in improving federal air pollution laws for the first time in 13 years. President Bush urged senators to move swiftly to pass the measure. He had called the original Senate clean air bill too expensive and at one point suggested he might veto it if Congress passed it. ``President Bush is extraordinarily pleased with the agreement. It is a milestone, an enormous step forward,'' said Roger Porter, the president's chief domestic policy adviser and head of the administration team that helped negotiate the agreement. Although not as tough as the original Senate bill, the compromise calls for broad-ranging new air pollution controls on automobiles, factories and electric power plants. It aims to: _Cut in half the acid rain pollutants from coal-burning electric power plants by the end of the decade. Annual sulfur dioxide releases would be cut by 10 million tons by 2000. _Tighten automobile emission controls so that hydrocarbon emissions are cut by one-fifth and nitrogen oxides by nearly two-thirds. The two emissions are key components of urban smog. _Require industry for the first time to install the best available technology to control the release of 192 toxic chemicals including a variety of carcinogens. Plants would have to impose further controls to meet new ``health based'' requirements if the cancer risks are at a certain level to people living near a plant. _Require a broad range of industry to curb smog-causing pollutants. However, environmentalists complained that the compromise weakened major portions of the original Senate bill. ``The back-room dealing has generated bad deals for the American people,'' complained Richard Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition, which is lobbying on clean air issues for various environmental organizations. Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund, added, ``Powerful special interests have succeeded in rigging the game in their favor.'' The agreement eliminated an automatic second round of tailpipe emission controls for cars, although such controls still could be used under some circumstances. It exempted thousands of small businesses from tougher smog-control requirements in the original bill, and it removed a provision in current law requiring the federal government to impose an air pollution reduction plan if local officials fail to do so. There was criticism from the Senate as well. ``The agreement fails to require the controls we need to provide clean air in the nation and in New Jersey,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J. Midwest senators were concerned about the high cost of acid rain controls, although some new provisions were aimed at holding down those costs. ``It's a better bill, but we'll have to continue the fight for fairness on the Senate floor,'' said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., said the compromise still threatens thousands of his state's coal miners. He promised to seek additional changes but added, ``I'm not going to engage in any filibuster.'' Speaking of the difficulties Midwest senators face on the acid rain provision, Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., told reporters: ``We did not have a choice between the good, the bad and the ugly. We had a choice between ugly, uglier and ugliest.'' The Edison Electric Institute called the accord ``unnecessarily costly'' for utilities, while the Chemical Manufacturers' Association contended the tougher toxic chemical controls were the product of politics and not science. The agreement is ``far from what business and industry would consider acceptable,'' said William Fay, administrator of the Clean Air Working Group, industry's lobbying organization on clean air issues.

DOC.HEAD: Alderman to Train Black Militia to Promote Minority Causes
DOC.TEXT: An alderman was accused of pushing the ``politics of violence'' after announcing he would revive the Black Panther Party and train an armed cadre of street gang members to advance minority causes. Alderman Michael McGee made his announcement at a City Hall news conference he described as a ``State of the Inner-City Address.'' McGee, 40, was an active member of the militant Black Panthers in the 1970s and has been an outspoken inner-city representative since his election to the Common Council in 1984. ``We want complete liberation and control of our communities and our destiny,'' McGee said in an interview Thursday, a day after announcing his plans. He added he would begin assembling the militant activists by the end of the year. Common Council President Thomas P. Donegan, who is white, said he was neither frightened nor shocked by McGee's speech, which he said ``enunciates the anger and frustration of the most estranged class of people'' in Milwaukee. But Donegan said: ``I personally don't believe in the politics of intimidation or the politics of violence. If he actually means it .. it'll be a totally useless effort and it will set progress back for the poor community.'' McGee said he would call the group the Black Panther community militia and those recruited would undergo weapons training, education and ``survival programs.'' He said he would begin his recruitment among the city's many street gangs and the group would formally take up arms in 1995 if conditions for the city's minorities aren't improved by then. He gave no details of operations the force might undertake. ``They're just shooting each other and dying for no reason at all,'' he said. ``I'm giving them a reason to die. ... I'm going to show them who the enemy is: the government, the big private interests, the multi-millionaires.'' He called for creation of an emergency $100 million job training program for blacks and equal representation of minorities in all bodies of city government. McGee in the past has staged numerous peaceful protests, including whistle-blowing demonstrations aimed at white politicians, but said the lack of response to those protests convinced him of the need for violence. He said he, his three teen-age sons and others would be unafraid to die fighting for ``liberation and freedom for our community.'' State Rep. Gwendolynne Moore, a black Democrat representing the inner city, said McGee's threat was an attempt to highlight the serious problems of poverty, unemployment, teen-age pregnancy, school dropouts and crime in the black community. She stopped short of endorsing the call to arms. ``When you reduce people to nothing, they'll want to survive by any means necessary,'' she said. ``I have sons 10 and 12 years old and I am not eager to see them go into the streets to die. ``I am not interested in burying my black sons. But I think what Michael is saying is a barometer of the degree of frustration.'' Mayor John Norquist was out of town, but his chief of staff, H. Carl Mueller, issued a brief statement that ``violence or the threat of violence are not the answer.'' McGee's previous protests included hanging a black baby doll on a tree, saying it symbolized racism in Milwaukee, and wearing a paper bag over his head during a photo session of the city council to protest lack of funding for minority programs.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Officials Say Computer Drought List Contained Errors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note in 12th graf that official says that no corrected list is available.
DOC.TEXT: A computer list of 80 drought payments to farmers in excess of the $100,000 limit contained a number of errors that were subsequently corrected, according to Agriculture Department officials. The department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service said such errors and corrections were not unusual. Officials denied the mistakes were the result of sloppy bookwork in county offices. ``No, no evidence (of sloppiness) that I'm aware of,'' said William E. Penn, assistant deputy administrator of the USDA agency. ``Anytime you've got an organization as large as ours, with 3,000 field offices, there's going to be some problems.'' The 80 names headed a list of more than 600 compiled by the department's National Computer Center at Kansas City, Mo., on Jan. 4, officials said. The payments were made under the Disaster Assistance Act of 1988. As of Dec. 31, payments of more than $3.88 billion had been made to 805,152 recipients. The 80 payments listed Jan. 4 as exceeding the $100,000 limit _ about half were over by less than $100 each, and many of those by only a dollar _ comprised only 0.01 percent of the total recipients. According to the agency, the Office of Management and Budget had requested information on the ``top 50'' payments under the 1988 drought law. The computer search resulting in the Jan. 4 listing disclosed hundreds of ties among the top 50 dollar rankings, which ranged from $380,092 to $99,990. For example, the top 43 payments were made to the 80 farms listed as having received more than the $100,000 limit. There were more than 600 recipients tied for 44th place at exactly $100,000. Finally, there were 24 farms listed as sharing the remaining six, with the 50th payment totaling $99,990. A copy of the payment list was made available upon request to The Associated Press, which ran the names and amounts of the top 80 on Feb. 20. Almost immediately, there were complaints that some errors were made. Some within ASCS were irked that the AP ran the list in the first place, although the agency has a history of being comparatively open about subsidy payments to farmers. One ASCS official, who demanded anonymity, said the list should not have been given out without a formal Freedom of Information request, which would have resulted in checking to see if all the names and amounts were correct. ``We ought to clean up our list before we give it to you, that's all,'' the official said, adding that he knew of no ``clean'' list that would be available now. ``We would have to go to the county offices.'' Penn, who helps directly supervise the agency's field operations, said he did not have the full details about the Jan. 4 computer report. ``Anytime data is found to be in error, that data is corrected,'' he said. ``So, if you had January numbers they're probably not accurate, compared to what they are today. There are going to be errors that take place.'' But Penn, who was head of the ASCS state office in Michigan before coming here, said he felt ``very comfortable in saying that in general, no, there's no evidence that there's widespread sloppy work'' at the county level. ``We've got nothing to hide,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Once-Banished Indians Seek Comeback with Iowa Casino
DOC.TEXT: Banished to a remote prairie 130 years ago, the Santee-Sioux Indians are rising again, this time with playing cards in their hands. The tribe plans to build a $67 million hotel-casino in Council Bluffs that would dwarf all other gaming operations between Nevada and New Jersey. ``I'm tired of government handouts and dependency,'' said Don LaPoint, the tribal council's chairman. ``One of the things we do have going for us is gaming. I'm very optimistic this is going to succeed.'' The tribe has hired Harveys Resort and Casino near Lake Tahoe, Nev., to run the casino, which with a convention center and 450-bed hotel would employ up to 1,000 people. Gov. Terry Branstad opposes the casino, and much legal wrangling lies ahead. But local officials said the 1988 Indian Gaming Act, a federal law providing preferential treatment for Indians, could help the casino become a reality. ``The governor feels there is sentiment among Iowans that we've gone far enough in gambling,'' said Dick Vohs, a Branstad spokesman. Chuck Shearer, vice president of finance for Harveys, said the casino would push ahead with its plans ``until we have exhausted all the legal opportunities available or until the city of Council Bluffs asks us to get out of town.'' The Santee-Sioux have an option to buy a 50-acre tract for the casino in Council Bluffs, across the Missouri River from Omaha, Neb. Proponents expect the casino also would lure customers from Des Moines, 120 miles to the east, and Kansas City, 200 miles to the south. Few employees are likely to be Indians, but the tribe's share of the income would go back to the reservation, some 200 miles to the northwest in Nebraska, where about 60 percent of the 2,300 tribe members live. The Sioux-Santee were banished to the 12-by-17-mile reserve by President Lincoln after the bloody Minnesota Uprising of 1862. ``We're isolated here,'' LaPoint said in a telephone interview from the reservation. ``Nobody comes here. There are no airports, no industries. We need to come back with pride, dignity.'' The Council Bluffs City Council and business community have not taken a formal position on the casino, but the general sentiment is favorable, said city attorney Richard B. Wade. ``People fear that if we don't do everything to get it, next year it will either be in Des Moines or Chicago or Kansas City,'' Wade said. That the casino is possible at all stems from the Iowa Legislature's decision last year to allow low-stakes casinos aboard riverboats beginning in the summer 1991. The riverboat casino law opened the door to other gambling. The Mesquakie Indians, who already hold high-stakes bingo games on their settlement near Tama, are nearing agreement with the state on adding video lottery games and slot machines. Indian tribes nationwide, faced with cutbacks in federal money and a limited tax base, have instituted gambling to raise revenue. The 1988 act helps them set up operations off their reservations, in more easily visited areas. The act states that such gaming is permitted if officials agree it is in the best interests of both the community and the Indians. But Vohs said his reading of the law is that the governor has final say on the establishment of any high-stakes casino. ``Obviously, that's not how we see it,'' said Shearer. Joel Starr, a U.S. Interior Department gaming expert, said casino advocates would have little room to maneuver if the governor turned them down. Seven Midwest bishops have issued a statement criticizing the casino, saying gambling can shred families and hurt communities. But Wade said: ``We've already devised several ways you can lose your paycheck. A lot of people feel the moral issue has already been decided.''

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Companies Say Legislation Too Extreme
DOC.TEXT: Chemical companies say proposed legislation outlawing the export of pesticides banned in the United States goes too far in trying to control other nations. ``I don't think U.S. regulators should make decisions for other countries about what they do and do not need,'' said Donna Jennings, spokeswoman for Velsicol Chemical Corp. Her company, the only manufacturer of chlordane and heptachlor, was criticized Thursday by Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., who referred to the products as ``deadly poison.'' The products are not registered for use in the United States. Gore's comments came as he and four other lawmakers announced legislation that would prevent U.S. chemical manufacturers from selling products abroad that can't be used in the United States. ``If the EPA says it is too hazardous to be used on U.S. grown foods, then it is too hazardous to be used on foreign grown foods,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. He said the legislation he and Gore are sponsoring in the Senate would close a legal loophole that allows U.S. chemical companies to manufacture here and sell abroad pesticides that are probable carcinogens. Reps. Mike Synar, D-Okla., Leon Panetta, D-Calif., and Dan Glickman, D-Kan., are the House sponsors of the same bill, known as the Pesticides Export Reform Act. The lawmakers said that banned and unregistered pesticides made in the United States are showing up on foreign food imported to the United States. ``These chemicals are killers. We know that,'' Gore said. ``Velsicol has the same responsibility of every manufacturer to act in a responsible way and to protect public health.'' But Jennings said chlordane and heptachlor are only temporarily off the U.S. market during a review by the Environmental Protection Agency. She said the products are used to kill termites and protect germinating seeds from other pests. While alternative chemicals exist for use in the United States, there are some regions of the world, such as the tropics, where weather and pest conditions prevent other products from being effective, she said. Those same conditions, she said, also cause the chemicals to break down faster than in the United States, creating less danger to human health. Synar, who chairs the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources, said that information from the United Nations showed many countries, especially in the Third World, lack the ability to assure safe pesticide practices. Business in the chemical industry in this country could take a downturn if the legislation is passed, said National Agricultural Chemicals Association president Jay Vroom. ``A unilateral approach to a global issue does no good and only puts U.S. manufacturers at a disadvantage, and may drive importing countries to suppliers that may supply far less environmental stewardship with their products,'' he said. Other key provisions in the bill include: _A ban on imports that have been treated with outlawed chemicals. _Listing by importers of chemicals used to grow foods shipped from abroad. _Labeling of exported U.S.-made chemicals in the language of the receiving country.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Irish Prime Minister Leading Drive
DOC.TEXT: It is falling to the Prime Minister of Ireland, in this season of rapid change, to see what can be done to anchor the emerging new and more powerful Germany in a democratic European Community. Ireland is the only neutralist country in the 12-nation community. But Charles J. Haughey, the prime minister, is not neutral about the task at hand. Like most Europeans, he considers unification of East Germany and West Germany inevitable _ and a good thing. But he knows a lot of people are anxious, and Haughey feels the best way to allay those concerns _ especially economic ones _ is to wrap Germany into the European Community, which is on a fast track to economic union. He also favors stronger U.S. ties to Europe. As the president of the European Council, a job that rotates every six months, Haughey called on President Bush this week and held other meetings around town that, for a change, were not focused on the trouble in Northern Ireland. To begin with, West Germany is an economic colossus, accounting for 25 percent of the gross national product of the 12 Community countries. East Germany will integrate its currency with its wealthy cousins in West Germany and thereby unleash a wave of purchasing power that could touch off inflation as East Germans reach into their savings to acquire long-denied consumer goods. The fact that Germany will be even stronger militarily is another source of worry to its neighbors, although Haughey said any European concerns ``would be directed most at German economic might and possible domination.'' Haughey, who has served three unconnected terms as Irish prime minister, is pleased that Germany would remain in the European Community after unification, participating in the transition to a Europe of shared interests and cooperation. ``A Germany remaining a full and committed member of the European Community is a great reassurance,'' he said. Still, Haughey admits the turn of events is unprecedented. ``There are no rules or texts that can guide us on how to handle it,'' he said. Haughey is counting heavily on the good sense of West German officials and a European determination to pull together. While West Germany will bear most of the burden of rehabilitating East Germany, the 11 other European Community members intend to provide assistance with trade and investment programs. ``In short,'' he said, ``there will be very big costs to bring East Germany in, and to bring it up to West European standards.'' A European Community development bank will be ready to make loans to all the East European countries as they switch to non-Marxist systems, and to the Soviet Union as well. ``Fortunately,'' Haughey said, ``Germany is the member ablest most easily to bear this burden. It can handle it with the greatest skill and determination.'' Moreover, Germany is anchored by the 35-nation European Security Conference. This is the grouping of the Soviet Union and its allies, West Europeans, neutralists and the United States and Canada with a common commitment to human rights. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for a summit later this year to promote a common European home has U.S. support provided human rights are enshrined at the summit as a fundamental principle. The summit was to have been held in 1992. ``Moving it up reflects everyone's anxiety to deal with the German issue,'' Haughey said. ``There are anxieties _ concerns may be a better word. I think, on the whole, people will be relieved by these factors.'' A strong nationalist who has worked as a barrister and an accountant, Haughey is considered a canny analyst. His analysis of European integration is that it is unstoppable, despite British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's reservations. In seeking stronger U.S. ties to the Community, Haughey worked out with Bush a plan for semiannual meetings of the presidents of the United States and the European Council, as well as meetings twice a year between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and the 12 Community foreign ministers. All this is fine with the Bush administration. The ``new architecture'' Baker has proposed for Europe includes closer U.S. ties. But that doesn't mean Haughey favors U.S. membership in the Community. ``There cannot be a 13th seat at the table,'' he said. The Europeans intend to make integration decisions themselves.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid covers diplomacy for The Associated Press from the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Low Speed Bumper Crashes Bring Big Repair Bills
DOC.TEXT: Small cars that should be protected from damage by their bumpers at low speeds cost between $769 and $3,838 to repair after four test bumps, an auto safety institute reports. The most damaged among 16 new cars tested at 5 mph by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety was the 1990 Daihatsu Charade SE and the least damaged was the Honda Civic DX, said institute president Brian O'Neill. ``Every bumper we tested this year did a poor job of preventing damage, and some were downright lousy,'' O'Neill said in releasing the results of the annual testing Thursday. The institute, funded by the insurance industry, buys the cars, runs each one into flat barriers, front and back, into a front angle barrier and then backward into a pole _ all at 5 mph. He said bumper performance has deteriorated since 1982, when the Transportation Department rolled back federal requirements that car bumpers be able to sustain 5 mph crashes without damage to the vehicle. Manufacturers have weakened bumpers without the federal rules and consumers need to know which cars will require the biggest repair bills, O'Neill said. A 1981 Ford Escort sustained no damage in any of the institute's four tests, O'Neill said, while damage to a 1990 Escort totaled $1,718. Hyundai Excel bumpers were weakened during the 1990 model year, he said. An Excel tested before the change sustained $561 damage in the rear-into-pole test, while the same model with the weaker bumpers cost $721 to repair. Eight cars that sustained no damage when run forward into a flat barrier, were badly damaged costing between $200 (for the Honda Civic) and $718 (for the Mazda 323 Protege SE) when run into an angled barrier, the institute said. Among seven cars with no damage in rear barrier tests, damage in the rear-into-pole test ranged from $479 for the Dodge Shadow to $1,404 for the Ford Escort, the report said. The institute said it found that Toyota Corollas manufactured in Japan and exported to the United States have more protective bumpers than Corollas built in California or a nearly identical Geo Prizms built in the same California plant. The Prizm had $267 worth of damage in the front barrier test, while the Japan-built Corolla, whose bumper assembly weighs two pounds less, had none, the institute said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Son On Trial For Grenade Attack, Army Destroys Family's House
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in her life, Arab-Israeli strife has driven Fatima Sufarin from her home. ``This is the price we have to pay for our homeland,'' the 70-year-old Palestinian said Thursday. She said she was first displaced when she fled from her home in the village of Lifta near Jerusalem during the 1948 Arab-Israeli war. On Wednesday, Israeli troops blew up her two-story house, and Mrs. Sufarin's 12-member family carried what was left of their possessions to a nearby shack. The six-room house was demolished to punish the family for the alleged crimes of Mrs. Sufarin's 25-year-old son Imad, who is accused of throwing a firebomb that wounded an Israeli soldier. Family members say Imad, who is awaiting trial, is innocent. According to the army, more than 450 houses have been destroyed or sealed in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip since the beginning of the Palestinian uprising in December 1987. On Thursday, troops sealed three houses in the village of Tamoun in the northern West Bank, the army said. Palestinian reporters said the sealings made 16 people homeless. The houses belonged to the families of three Palestinian men who allegedly carried out acts of sabotage in nearby Jewish settlements and threw firebombs on homes of several Tamoun residents suspected of cooperating with Israeli authorities. The United States and other Western nations have criticized house demolitions and sealings, saying the practice was a form of collective punishment and violated the right to due process. In nearly all cases, houses are destroyed or sealed before a suspect has been tried. Israeli military officials say the practice is an effective deterrent and is legal under emergency regulations dating to the pre-state British mandate period. The demolition of Mrs. Sufarin's house left 12 people homeless, including herself, her daughters, Jamile and Wedad, and their teen-age children. Wedad, 42, suffers from schizophrenia and has been kept in a locked room for the past 15 years because family members said otherwise she might harm herself and others. Wedad found refuge in the Bethlehem Mental Hospital, which earlier had refused to take her in because of her violent outbursts. But hospital officials said she would have to leave soon because she was too much of a burden. On Thursday, Mrs. Sufarin's family gathered around the rubble of the house, at the foot of the Judean Hills and near the site where the Bible says Jesus was tempted by the devil. Mrs. Sufarin, her white headscarf soaked by driving rain, wept as she found chickens buried under the rubble and looked for anything to salvage. The Sufarins spent the night in a nearby shack into which they had piled all their possessions, including blankets, carpets, wicker chairs, a grandfather clock and a refrigerator. Mrs. Sufarin said Thursday she was waiting for U.N. officials to deliver an emergency tent that would be her new home. Since the beginning of the uprising, 659 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Study of Twins Links Stress Disorder to Combat
DOC.TEXT: A study of twins who served in the military during the Vietnam era offers new evidence that post-traumatic stress disorder is more a product of combat than of any inborn susceptibility to stress. The findings indicate the disorder _ marked by painful memories, flashbacks and nightmares _ is three times more common among veterans who served in Southeast Asia than among their identical twins who served elsewhere. The twins who saw heavy combat in Vietnam _ 179 servicemen _ were found to suffer nine times as often from the problem as their identical twins who served in the armed forces in other parts of the world. ``Identical twins are more similar than any two individuals,'' said lead researcher Jack Goldberg, an assistant professor of epidemiology at the University of Illinois at Chicago. ``And so you have two guys with 100 percent of the same genes, who grew up together, and one guy goes to war and one doesn't. And 15 years later, one has post-traumatic stress disorder and one doesn't. That sort of debunks the idea of predisposition.'' A popular myth holds that ``just the bad eggs were sent to Vietnam,'' Goldberg said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``That's not the story. ... The average Joes went to Vietnam.'' The study, published in today's Journal of the American Medical Associaiton, was developed from a specially designed registry of 2,092 male twins in military service during the Vietnam War era, from 1965 to 1975. The registry was established to further scientists' understanding of health problems believed to be partly due to genetic traits and partly to environment, including alcoholism, drug abuse and heart disease, he said. When the survey was conducted in 1987, 16.8 percent of the twins who served in Southeast Asia during the Vietnam era had symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder. Just 5 percent of their identical twin brothers who didn't serve in Southeast Asia had the symptoms. Terence M. Keane, chief of psychology at the Boston Veterans Administration Medical Center, said the study ``represents a major advance in our understanding of post-traumatic stress disorder.'' The findings closely match those of a congressional study estimating 15 percent of Vietnam veterans suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder, Goldberg said. That means 450,000 veterans are afflicted with it, he said. ``These guys are hurting,'' he said. ``They're not psychotic. They're not crazy. They have nightmares. They have problems. But our sense is that a lot of these guys function very well.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pentagon Must Provide Realistic 5-Year Spending Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon must provide a realistic five-year spending plan because the current budget indicates that $138 billion in spending cuts are needed to meet President Bush's defense goal, a congressional report says. ``The Congress is faced with budget decisions that will have long-term implications, but without an updated five-year defense plan, it does not have the information necessary to fully assess alternatives,'' Comptroller General Charles Bowsher told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday. Bowsher presented the General Accounting Office's assessment of defense spending. The investigative arm of Congress found that Bush's budget for fiscal 1991 includes a five-year program that projects spending of $1.5 trillion. That total is $212 billion less than the recent five-year plan that the administration prepared in fiscal 1989. However, the Pentagon has come up with only $74 billion in reductions from the 1989 projections. ``The Defense Department is still faced with decisions on how and where to make reductions of another $138 billion between fiscal 1992 and fiscal 1994,'' Bowsher said. The Pentagon, he said, has said the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe and the lessening Soviet threat to the West has made it difficult to decide where and how the reductions will be made. The comptroller general said the GAO does not expect the Pentagon to act hastily, but the decisions must be made soon. Bowsher suggested that the administration ``rethink our entire weapon system acquisition strategy,'' starting with the B-2 stealth bomber and the multiple-warhead MX nuclear missile. Repeating testimony he gave last week to the House Armed Services Committee, Bowsher suggested slowing down production of the costly stealth bomber until critical tests have been completed on the radar-evading aircraft. According to the GAO, the current schedule calls for spending more than $48 billion and ordering 31 bombers before critical performance tests have been conducted. The GAO also found that the Air Force plans to make an initial production decision on moving the MX missile from fixed silos to railroad cars before operational tests and evaluations have been done on the completed system. Shortly after the production decision, the Air Force plans to buy about 73 percent of the launch cars for the MX. Bowsher said that during the 1980s, the strategy of concurrent production and testing ``was designed to get systems in the field more quickly, but it often resulted in making extensive _ and expensive _ changes after the systems were fielded.'' The B-2 bomber and the MX rail-garrison program are following the same path, he said. Overall, the comptroller general painted a dire financial picture as he accused the Bush administration of spending projections that are ``the result of creative bookkeeping; they do not portray the real situation.'' According to Bowsher, the government is using surpluses in the federal trust funds for Social Security, highways and other divisions to cover up the real budget deficit. ``If we continue along this same path, we can expect the national debt to increase to $4.5 trillion by fiscal year 1995,'' Bowsher said. ``A debt of this magnitude would require annual interest payments of over $335 billion and would represent the largest single item in the federal budget.''

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Foes Target Environmental Groups
DOC.TEXT: The National Right to Life Committee says abortion opponents should withhold contributions or drop their memberships in three environmental organizations because the groups support abortions. The anti-abortion group says the National Wildlife Federation, the National Audubon Society and the Sierra Club support abortions by backing legislation that would allow broader use of federal money for birth control in Third World countries. Wildlife Federation and Audubon Society officials say their organizations have no position on abortion. Nancy Walker, director of the Sierra Club's population program, said her group supports a woman's right to an abortion and has been targeted by the right-to-life group before. ``We believe the true pro-life position supports population stabilization,'' she said. The National Abortion Rights Action League called the controversy bewildering. ``It's this kind of activity that shows how extreme they are,'' Loretta Ucelli, spokeswoman for the abortion-rights group, said about the National Right to Life Committee. The anti-abortion group issued a call in the March edition of its magazine, National Right to Life News, for its members to drop out or withhold donations to the three groups. Doug Johnson, the group's legislative director, said the step was taken because all three groups have endorsed a bill that would reverse Bush administration policy denying aid to family planning organizations that provide abortion information or services in less-developed countries. ``It is wrong to solicit people's contributions to protect wildlife and then use the money to lobby for pro-abortion policies,'' Johnson said.
