Officials of the three groups said they support global birth control efforts because overpopulation threatens the environment. ``Singling out environmental groups is taking it to an extreme,'' said Stephanie Sklar of the National Wildlife Federation. ``It's trying to make an issue out of something that's not an issue for these groups.'' She said the dispute was touched off last year when environmental groups jointly issued a report that urged a modification of the administration policy, which was left over from the Reagan administration and embraced by the Bush White House. Hope Babcock, counsel for the Audubon Society, said her group opposed the administration policy. But, she said, ``we have absolutely no position'' on abortion. ``We are about educating the world about the relationship between population and the environment, and the stress put on the environment through population growth,'' she said. None of the targeted groups said they expected to lose much money or many members as a result of the action.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Speeds Up Elections For Fear of Stronger Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanians scrambled to move up elections to allow their parliament to vote on independence before Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev gains new power they fear could thwart their drive. Activists in the Baltic republic were making the moves while Soviet authorities also came under pressure Thursday in neighboring Latvia and in Moldavia. In the neighboring Baltic republic of Latvia, the parliament gave some youths the right to refuse conscription in the Soviet army. In the southwestern republic of Moldavia, Communist leaders admitted their party's past mistakes and agreed to talks with popular political movements, the official news agency Tass said. Already, 22 local election boards in Lithuania have moved up their runoff elections from March 10 to Sunday, Tass reported Thursday. Others are expected to follow, said Vitoris Radjavichus, a spokesman for the Lithuanian people's front, Sajudis. That will allow the new Lithuanian parliament to meet _ and possibly vote on independence _ before March 12, Radjavichus said. That is the opening day of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, which is scheduled to vote on creating a more powerful presidency, expected to be occupied by Gorbachev. The bill would give Gorbachev the power to declare a state of emergency and suspend a republic's parliament. He could also send troops into a locality and even declare war without asking the Soviet parliament. Radjavichus described the powers as ``dictatorial.'' Candidates backed by Sajudis, which favors independence, won 70 of 90 seats filled in the first round of the election Saturday. But 94 of the parliament's 140 seats, or a two-thirds majority, must be filled before the body can begin to act, Sajudis secretary Andryus Kubilyus told the Radio Moscow news service Interfax. Kazimieras Motieka, a Sajudis leader and member of the national parliament, appealed on Lithuanian television for the republic's new legislature to take office by March 11, Tass said. In the December session of Congress, Motieka asked Kremlin leaders to begin negotiations on the Lithuanian demand for independence from the Soviet Union, which forcibly annexed Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in 1940. In its decision Thursday, the Latvian parliament said local youths will be allowed to choose three years of alternative public service work to the military, if they have pacifist or religious convictions, Tass said. The decision contradicts Soviet law, which requires all 18-year-olds to serve two years in the army. All three Baltic republics adopted constitutional amendments in the past 16 months giving their parliaments the right to overturn Soviet laws. The Kremlin has denounced these actions as violating the Constitution, but so far there has been no direct confrontation. In Moldavia, the Communist Party Central Committee agreed to talks with mass movements in hopes of calming tensions between Russians and Moldavians, who are ethnically related to Romanians. The party leaders, apparently in a debate over some activists' calls for independence or reunification with Romania, voted to support ``independence within the framework of a renewed Soviet federation.'' ``Leaders of the Moldavian Communist Party intend to start a democratic and open dialogue with rank-and-file Communists and the broad public,'' Tass quoted Moldavian party chief Pyotr Luchinsky as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Feld Ballet `Mother Nature' Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: ``Mother Nature,'' an amusing ballet which mixes the Garden of Eden and Greek mythology _ mainly as an excuse for dancing about in light-hearted fashion _ received its premiere Thursday night by Feld Ballets NY. Eliot Feld choreographed ``Mother Nature'' and the other three ballets on the program at the Joyce Theater. Jeffrey Neeck and Buffy Miller were the man and woman in brief, flower-bedecked costumes. At first he was asleep inside a cosy fenced enclosure; she was piled up with four furry female sheep. Darren A. Gibson as Cupid shot arrows at the two and Amoretto _ Joan Tsao, dancing as Cupid's partner _ dropped an apple into the hands of Neeck. When he tossed aside the core, the ballerina sheep scampered for it. James Sewell as a satyr entered and pursued Neeck, not Miss Miller. The sun, moon and clouds were carried across the stage, depicting days passing. Scott Rink did one-hand cartwheels across the stage, while carrying the sun in his other hand. Everybody gamboled about and did amazing controlled things with their bodies while balancing on their shoulders or their lower arms. The couple married and had a wedding night, behind a big leaf. The music was several pieces by Monteverdi, including ``Madrigali Erotici.'' It was all jolly and our only complaint is that nearly every section went on until the audience's delight was diminishing. The evening was all on the light-hearted side. It began with the smile-producing ``Excursions'' from 1975, to music by Samuel Barber, continued with ``Asia'' from 1989, in which Lynn Aaron does many slinky Orientalisms to Ravel's ``Sheherazade.'' Willa Kim's chiffon trousers for the five women were graceful and sexy. Then James Sewell performed ``Medium:Rare,'' using eight slant boards and a small trampoline. Sewell needed to be an athlete and an actor to vary moods and he was both. The music was minimalist, by Steve Reich. All evening, dancers looked in top form. Eliot Feld has choreographed 63 ballets since 1967, giving Feld Ballets NY a big repertoire. It really is a brilliant company.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 34,057.56, up 227.98 points, or 0.67 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Kaifu Seek Progress in US-Japan Trade Dispute
DOC.NOTE: EDS: May stand
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators face a series of deadlines on contentious trade issues, and the rhetoric is heating up on both sides of the Pacific as President Bush meets with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Japanese officials are complaining of high-handed U.S. demands, while American officials are warning of retaliatory measures if the Japanese do not grant concessions to reduce the huge trade imbalance between the two nations. The trade dispute was expected to be at center stage when Bush welcomed Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., this afternoon for two days of talks. While no significant breakthrough was considered likely, U.S. officials hoped the Bush-Kaifu discussions would at least lay the groundwork for progress as the negotiations proceed at a lower level in coming months. There is a growing U.S. impatience with Japan, especially among Democrats in Congress who point to new government figures showing that Japan accounted for almost half of America's $108.6 billion trade deficit last year. The deficit with Japan remained stuck at $49 billion, little changed from a $51.8 billion imbalance the year before. ``Congress is getting tired of the games they play. We can't crack their markets,'' Rep. Marty Russo, D-Ill., told U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills at a hearing this week. ``I remain optimistic that Japan will see the need to open up the second largest market in the world,'' Hills told reporters on Thursday. The Japanese are upset about being singled out for America's trade problems, many of which they believe are a product of U.S. inability to compete on international markets. On the campaign trail, Kaifu blasted Congress for ``raising a sword'' against the Japanese on trade issues. Hills conceded that the U.S.-Japanese relationship was ``at a difficult point and needs to have the highest level of attention.'' Speaking to a gathering of economists on Thursday, Hills suggested that ``it would be extremely helpful politically'' for Japan to make some trade concessions so she could point to progress in a report she must send Congress by March 30. The Bush administration is facing a series of deadlines to resolve disputes over a variety of products, ranging from lumber to super computers. Among the issues in contention: _The United States last May put Japan on a trade ``hit list'' for its alleged unfair barriers against the sale of American wood products, satellites and super computers. The administration, which acted under a section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301, has until June 16 to negotiate a removal of the barriers. If the negotiations fail, the administration can impose retaliatory tariffs against Japanese products. _The United States and Japan are engaged in an ambitious effort aimed at tackling the underlying causes of the trade deficit such as Japanese exclusionary business practices and also the low U.S. savings rate. American negotiators have expressed disappointment that three rounds of discussions in the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative have produced little progress. An interim report is expected this spring and the final report is due this summer. _Japanese barriers to the sale of American telecommunications products, a primary source of tension between the two countries in recent years, also are being discussed. Negotiators met last month in Tokyo with the American side demanding more freedom for Japanese companies to decide which telephone products to buy. _Negotiations are going forward on other issues from construction to shipbuilding to protection on U.S. patents and copyrights. Even as the talks continue, some in Congress are laying the groundwork to force the administration to take a tougher line unless the Japanese grant concessions. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., has introduced legislation that would require retaliation if Japan does not liberalize its markets for super computers, satellites and wood products by June 16. Referring to that legislation, Hills said there was an urgency in Japanese officials moving quickly ``before Congress takes an action that would limit our discretion.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Spends $100 Million to Honor Former Members
DOC.TEXT: What do Hubert H. Humphrey, Everett McKinley Dirksen, Mike Mansfield, John Stennis, Barry Goldwater, Claude Pepper, Henry M. Jackson, Margaret Chase Smith, Sam Rayburn, John W. McCormack and Joe Martin have in common? The answer is not the simple one that all are retired or deceased members of Congress. It is, rather, that all are political eminences whom Congress has chosen to honor by paying out millions of federal dollars to establish foundations bearing their names. Total price tag over the last 15 years: more than $100 million. The practice, according to an article by Julie Kosterlitz in this week's issue of the National Journal, goes far beyond merely naming a building for a distinguished congressional statesman. The name of Sam Rayburn, the late speaker of the House, already was carved in marble on the walls of the Rayburn House Office Building when, in 1974, Rep. Wright Patman, D-Texas, an old friend, got a bright idea. Patman noted that Congress was about to give $10 million in proceeds from the sale of the Eisenhower commemorative dollar coin to help out financially ailing Eisenhower College, named for the late president. Patman attached an amendment requiring the college to transfer $1 million of the Eisenhower money to the Sam Rayburn Library in Bonham, Texas. It was opened with private money in 1957 to house the papers of the speaker who died in 1961. The bright idea soon became an established idea. The most recent example: $10 million added to a defense appropriations bill to endow a foundation to be named for the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla. and his wife, Mildred, to carry on his work on behalf of the elderly. Other examples: _The 1986 Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship and Excellence in Education Foundation set up to honor the retired GOP senator from Arizona by providing a record-breaking $40 million to aid college students studying mathematics and the natural sciences. _The 1986 Henry M. Jackson Foundation in Seattle got $10 million to honor the Democratic senator from Washington who died in 1983. Additionally, the Henry M. Jackson Foundation for the Advancement of Military Medicine in Rockville, Md., got $1 million to endow a chair in dermatology. _The Hubert H. Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Minnesota received $5 million in the late 1970s to honor the late Democratic senator and vice president. At the same time, an institute named for the late Sen. Everett McKinley Dirksen, R-Ill., received $2.5 million. _Former Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield, D-Mont., who also served for nearly a decade as U.S. ambassador to Japan, was honored in 1983 by the creation of a $5 million foundation at the University of Montana in Missoula to study the nations of the Pacific Rim. _A $3 million federal grant was approved in 1982 to create a John W. McCormack Institute of Public Affairs at the Boston campus of the University of Massachusetts. McCormack retired as speaker of the House in 1971. _A grant of $4 million in the late 1980's created the Joseph Martin Institute for Law and Society at Stonehill College in Northeastern Massachusetts to honor the late GOP speaker of the House. _The John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Development was opened in Starkville, Miss., in honor of the recently retired Democratic chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. It received $7.5 million. _In 1989 Congress approved $2.5 million for the Margaret Chase Smith Foundation which operates a library attached to the Skowhegan, Maine, home of the 92-year-old former Republican senator. Sometimes Congress is asked to honor a former member _ and says no. For various reasons, it turned down requests to finance institutes and foundations to honor the late Senate Republican leader Robert Taft of Ohio, former House Speaker Thomas P. ``Tip'' O'Neill Jr., D-Mass., and the late Sen. Warren G. Magnuson, D-Wash. Still pending is a $5 million request by Maine's Bates College to house the archives of Democrat Edmund S. Muskie, a former Maine governor, U.S. senator and secretary of state.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Returns Andy Rooney to `60 Minutes'
DOC.TEXT: Andy Rooney is bringing his weekly gripe session back to ``60 Minutes'' on Sunday after CBS lifted his suspension early with the blessing of the NAACP. ``I'm very pleased,'' Rooney said Thursday after CBS News president David Burke reinstated the 71-year-old humorist, whose curmudgeonly commentary has been a show-ending ``60 Minutes'' feature since 1978. Burke on Feb. 8 had suspended Rooney for three months without pay after The Advocate, a gay magazine, quoted him as saying that blacks had ``watered down their genes'' _ a remark Rooney denied making. On Thursday, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said it believed Rooney was misquoted, didn't object to his return to work and considered the matter closed, spokesman James Williams said. Rooney also had drawn fire from homosexuals for a Dec. 28 CBS special in which he cited ``homosexual unions'' as among things that cause ``self-induced'' death, and for a letter to The Advocate in which he said he found male homosexual acts ``repugnant.'' Burke said of the suspension, ``Painful though these events have been, we have all learned a great deal about how sensitive and fragile our society is _ how thoughts and words can be misunderstood.'' He said Rooney ``has consistently stated publicly that he is not a man who holds prejudice in his heart and mind towards any group in our society. Those of us who know him and work with him know two things _ first, that is true, and second, it is time that Andy returned to his proper place on `60 Minutes.''' Rooney, who said he would address the uproar Sunday on ``60 Minutes,'' said it had sensitized him to some of the problems faced by homosexuals. ``I think they have really made their point,'' he said. ``I believe they are in a more difficult position than I understood.'' In a statement, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation complained that Rooney ``has yet to make amends with the gay and lesbian community regarding the series of homophobic comments he made in the last few months.'' During his three weeks away from ``60 Minutes,'' the program, while still top-rated, has slipped in the ratings, dropping to 18th last Sunday, when it was beaten by a special rerun of ABC's hit ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' Some CBS executives and researchers at the networks said entertainmnent programs at other networks had more to do with the ratings drop than did Rooney's absence. CBS has received more than 5,000 viewer calls for Rooney's return. ``We all get the bittersweet in our lives,'' Rooney said of the matter, adding that he likes a quotation attributed to ABC newsman Sam Donaldson: ``Only the amateurs stay mad.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Awaits Israel Response on Talks With Palestinians
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is looking for a response this weekend from Israel on whether it will accept his proposal for talks with a Palestinian delegation about elections in the occupied territories. ``We've really done pretty much all we can do, we think, from our end, and we are waiting for a response from the Israeli government,'' Baker said Thursday at a hearing before the House Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee. ``We're coming very close to the time when we will know one way or the other'' whether Israel will accept a proposal for talks concerning elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories, Baker said. Baker has been expressing growing impatience with Israel's failure to respond to his proposals, aired during his meetings with the foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel. Two issues he raised at the hearing seemed certain to add pressure on Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The secretary said the Bush administration could endorse a move to give Israel $400 million in loan guarantees to build housing for an influx of Soviet Jewish refugees, but only if Israel promises not to put any new settlers in the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza strip. There might be support ``if there were some assurance from the government of Israel that it would not be engaging in any new, additional settlement activity in the territories,'' Baker said. The money is expected to be added to an upcoming supplemental appropriations bill and is likely to win congressional approval because of Israel's strong support on Capitol Hill. Israel has declined to provide such assurances about future settlement, but has contended in the past that about 1 percent of refugees have settled in the territories. ``Settlements are not conducive to the peace process'' because they aggravate tensions with Palestinian residents, Baker said. ``It is not unreasonable to ask some assurances these funds will not be used to create new settlements or expand old settlements in the occupied territories.'' Baker also said the Bush administration may support cutting U.S. aid to Israel and Egypt if similar cuts were applied to other nations to free money for emerging democracies. ``We're willing to stand up and be counted'' on such a plan because it would allow foreign aid money to be distributed where it is most needed, Baker said. He said administration support for the cuts would ``depend on whether we do it in a non-discriminatory manner.'' Baker said he has not found any significant reduction in tensions in the Middle East. But he added: ``At the same time, we must find a way to respond to changes in Eastern Europe, in Panama and in Nicaragua.'' ``If these leaders are not able to produce for their people, we will rue the day'' that the United States fell short in providing aid, he said. ``We are talking about supporting an extraordinary outbreak of freedom and democracy.'' Baker also said he did not want to see a repetition of the current year's budget crunch, in which some friendly countries that expected U.S. aid got little or nothing because 90 percent of the aid budget was already earmarked by Congress for other recipients. Economic aid to all of Africa totaled just $14 million this year ``because there's no one up here lobbying for them,'' he said. His comments were the clearest indication yet that the administration would accept cuts to Israel and Egypt, which get the largest slice of U.S. aid as a result of their participation in the Camp David Middle East peace accord a decade ago. Israel is receiving $3 billion this year and Egypt $2.1 billion from an overall aid budget of roughly $10 billion. The administration has asked Congress for the same amounts for both countries next year.

DOC.HEAD: Juvenile Justice Nominee Coming Under Renewed Fire
DOC.TEXT: The administration's choice of education aide Robert Sweet to head $70 million in juvenile justice programs is coming under renewed fire from Democrats as Republicans try to ease him into the post. ``You're in a tough spot,'' Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said Thursday after Sweet answered questions from the panel for more than two hours at his confirmation hearing. Biden said the administration probably would not have tapped Sweet for the post if he had refused to support a 90 percent cut in the program from $70 million to $7.5 million proposed by President Bush this year. Sweet is a firm supporter of the cut. Biden added, however, that support for the proposed slash in the budget might just sink Sweet's chances of winning Senate approval because the program is popular with lawmakers. The comment came on top of numerous complaints from Democrats that the 52-year-old former White House adviser lacked the experience to be administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention in the Justice Department. The office distributes millions of dollars in federal grants to state and local agencies to combat juvenile delinquency. ``I am troubled that an individual apparently without the requisite credentials would be nominated for this important position,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Sweet, one-time head of the New Hampshire Moral Majority, has drawn critics ranging from the National Parent-Teacher Association to People for the American Way, a liberal Washington group. At least some opposition appears to stem from fierce political infighting at the Department of Education while Sweet was an aide there in the early 1980s. Former Education Secretary Terrel Bell was highly critical of Sweet in his memoirs, ``The Thirteenth Man.'' Those urging confirmation of Sweet range from the Boys Clubs of America to Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., who has been pointing out that many opponents are financial beneficiaries of the government's juvenile justice programs. ``It's understandable, may I observe, that the grantees would like one of their own to be head of this office, but that may not be such a good idea from the standpoint of prudence,'' Humphrey told the committee. Sweet, a former high school teacher and textbook salesman, told the panel that he had devoted his life to young people. He said his background in education should meet a federal law requiring a juvenile justice administrator with experience in the juvenile justice field. ``I want to be an advocate of helping young people have a better shot at life than they otherwise would have,'' Sweet said, adding that he has been studying juvenile justice issues and would be ``a quick study'' once he was in the post. ``I believe that Bob Sweet is fully qualified for this position,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. ``I know him personally and I support him.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., however, asked for written answers to a number of questions about juvenile justice issues. He said the replies should be more complete than the ones Sweet gave verbally.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge End to Baseball Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Senate thinks it's time to play ball. Expressing dismay at baseball's lockout, the Senate voted 82-15 Thursday to urge an end to the dispute. But one senator called the action a waste of time. ``Quite frankly, we are wasting everybody's time and we just look like fools,'' said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., describing it as one of an ever-expanding number of ``irrelevant'' resolutions. Owners and players, he said, don't care what the Senate thought of the problem. His colleagues applauded him warmly but went ahead to adopt the resolution sponsored by Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., and seven others. As the lockout reached its 15th day, Sen. Steve Symms, R-Idaho, said the dispute showed baseball had forgotten ``those of us who buy tickets and make billionaires out of owners and millionaires out of players.'' Negotiations between the owners and the players union have stalemated over when the players become eligible for salary arbitration. The union wants the time reduced to two years while management is trying to keep it at three. The resolution called on ``baseball owners, players and their negotiators to settle their differences promptly and begin a complete spring training and regular season as soon as possible.'' ``The negotiators in this dispute have an obligation to baseball fans,'' the resolution said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves $125 Million Plan to Spur Volunteerism
DOC.TEXT: A $125 million bill to kindle the spirit of volunteerism will get Americans away from ``the values of Wall Street and go back to the values of Main Street,'' a lawmaker says. The measure is aimed at encouraging activities ranging from teaching reading to cleanup drives in the nation's forests and parks. It goes to the House after being approved Thursday in the Senate after four days of intense bickering and maneuvering. It would authorize $125 million for volunteer programs through the end of the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. ``What we do in this bill is begin to get away from the values of Wall Street and go back to the values of Main Street, of neighbor helping neighbor,'' Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., said after the 78-19 Senate vote. The bill would earmark $25 million for school-based programs, involving teachers' aides, tutoring and teaching reading. It also would provide $35 million for a youth service corps, involving park and forest cleanup programs for volunteers 16 to 25 years old. Included would be a full- and part-time national service program for individuals 17 and older that would focus on service in education, human services, environment and public safety. It would be authorized at $25 million. Also included would be a $25 million Points of Light Foundation sought by Republicans in keeping with President Bush's campaign remark that the needy in America would be helped through volunteer efforts from ``a thousand points of light.'' The foundation would encourage volunteerism. Under the plan, states would bid for grants and the money would be distributed by a $4 million Commission on National and Community Service established by the bill. Some of the volunteers would receive living allowances and other stipends as well as education and housing benefits under the bill. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., the bill's floor manager, needed four days to shoehorn it through a balky Senate as lawmakers kept attempting to pile on amendments, some unrelated to volunteerism. The Senate fought for two days over an amendment sponsored by Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., to allow Big Brothers and other volunteer groups in the District of Columbia to bar homosexuals from activities involving minors. The lawmakers finally adopted a Kennedy substitute version that would allow the volunteer groups to bar homosexuals from such activities if they had been convicted of a crime or were currently faces charges. The amendment applied only to the nation's capital. ``It's just plain wrong for any arm of government to force private volunteer groups to unite adult homosexuals with minors as companions and role models,'' Armstrong said. Even after that issue was resolved, the debate dragged on for hours as lawmakers sought to attach provisions concerning the Nicaraguan elections and the repression of dissent in China. As the final vote neared, however, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., took the floor to condemn the notion of paying volunteers. He said benefits paid to some volunteers under the program, including living allowances and health insurance, were ``not in keeping with the spirit of volunteerism.'' Sponsors replied that poor people needed stipends because they felt the spirit of volunteerism as much as the wealthy.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Mexico Funded Sandinistas Covertly
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials say Mexico offered upward of $11 million in covert assistance to Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega's campaign, far above the acknowledged U.S. donations to the victorious opposition coalition. Mexican officials acknowledged that donations had been made but said the U.S. figure was highly exaggerated, sources said Thursday. Under the laws governing Sunday's Nicaraguan election, foreign contributions were required to have been reported to the Supreme Electoral Council. Half of the cash contributions were to have been shared with the council. The U.S. contribution to the campaign of President-elect Violeta Chamorro was about $3.3. million. More than $5 million in additional funds were provided for non-partisan activities, such as registration and poll watching. Efforts to reach the Mexican Embassy on Thursday for comment were unsuccessful but Nicaraguan Vice President Sergio Ramirez denied the U.S. allegation when asked about it by the Los Angeles Times. Ramirez said the Sandinistas reported all donations. The State Department said media accounts indicated that foreign contributions acknowledged by the Sandinistas totaled $300,000. According to Ramirez, no funds were received from the Mexican government or the ruling PRI party. The information obtained by U.S. officials indicated the contributions came from the PRI. The initial report of the donation appeared in Newsday. While expressing irritation over the Mexican contribution, the officials said it was not clear whether President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was aware of it. The purported donation, which included cash, T-shirts, posters and other items, was consistent with the support Mexico historically has provided to the Sandinista government.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Lower on Tokyo Market
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed at 149.75 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Friday, down 0.03 yen from Thursday's close.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rise, Dollar Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose moderately Friday, while the U.S. dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 762.41 points Thursday, recouped 227.98 points, or 0.67 percent to close at 34,057.56. The dollar closed the week at 149.75 yen, down 0.03 yen from Thursday's close of 149.78 yen. After opening at 150.35 yen, the currency ranged between 149.50 yen and 150.50 yen. In the bonds market, the yield on the No. 119 benchmark 10-year bond closed at 7.125 percent, up from Thursday's close at 7.090 percent. A stock dealer for Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., who spoke on condition of anonymity, said buying picked up in midmorning, centering on blue-chip stocks such as high-tech issues. A stock trader at Nomura Securities, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Tokyo exchange has not yet recovered from its continuing weakness during the last two weeks, but he said there was no reason to fear a big collapse in the near future. ``Stock dealers have begun to understand the techniques of arbitrage'' and other sophisticated trading techniques used by foreign securities companies, which some have blamed for pulling stock prices down during recent weeks. In arbitrage trading, traders aided by computers spot price gaps between the stocks and stock-index futures and seek to profit from them. On the foreign exchange market, Sumitomo Bank's Sumio Fukushima said the dollar opened strong following its gains overnight in New York. Buyers pushed the U.S. currency even higher to the mid-150 yen range, he said, but intervention by the Bank of Japan stopped the rise. Foreign exchange dealers said Japan's central bank engaged in strong dollar-selling to bolster the yen. The bank does not confirm or deny its market activities. But despite the government's efforts, there was still a tremendous demand for dollars, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst at New Japan Securities Co. The increased demand reflected the rapid increase of Japanese firms investing abroad in real estate and securities, he said. ``Also the (West German) mark weakened yesterday, which strengthened the dollar and, in turn, weakened the yen,'' Kanai said. ``The question is how far will the dollar be bought,'' given the Bank of Japan's determined dollar-selling, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Service Fires on Man After He Parachutes Near President's Hotel
DOC.TEXT: A Secret Service agent Thursday fired on a skydiver who parachuted into a parking lot behind a hotel where President Bush was staying. The man, who was not hurt, was later arrested near his home, police said. Charles Sweeney, 47, of Newhall, hopped from a 36-story building under construction, sailed across the street under his canopy and landed behind the Century Plaze Hotel around 6 a.m. while the president was inside, said Lt. Al Moen. A police officer on security detail for the president's arrival saw the man land and alerted other officers and Secret Service agents over the radio, Moen said. ``The parachutist then scooped up his parachute and ran to a waiting car, which he drove in circles at a high rate of speed,'' said Moen. He said Sweeney drove near a Secret Service officer, who fired a couple of rounds at the car. A police cruiser tried to seal off the parking lot, but Sweeney's car bore down on the police car, and the officer got out of the way, said Moen. Sweeney was later arrested near his home, booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon on an officer and freed on $3,000 bail, Moen said. Sweeney did not immediately return a telephone call late Thursday. Secret Service agents in Los Angeles declined to comment, referring calls to the Washington office, which was closed.

DOC.HEAD: Strike for Multiparty Democracy Shuts Shops, Halts Traffic
DOC.TEXT: Shops closed, traffic halted and students stayed at home today to support a nationwide strike called by two outlawed parties to push a movement for multiparty democracy in the Himalayan kingdom. The strike was the second called by the Nepali Congress Party and the Communist Party of Nepal since they launched the campaign Feb. 18 for restoration of the multiparty system in the national assembly, called the Rashtriya Panchayat. A Feb. 19 strike sparked widespread violence throughout Nepal, leaving at least three people dead by police gunfire, according to the government. Activists claimed five people were killed and 12 were injured. The government says at least nine more people died since then in sporadic violence but the activists claim at least twice as many died. Ganesh Man Singh, a top leader of the Nepali Congress, said the government ``is bent upon unleashing widespread violence to provoke the peaceful agitators like they did on Feb. 19.'' No violence was reported today as police patrolled Katmandu's nearly deserted streets. A few private vehicles and motor rickshaws were seen on the roads. Buses leaving Katmandu, the capital, were escorted by armed police in jeeps, but few passengers traveled. Buses coming into Katmandu were half empty. ``Nobody wants to travel because of the strike,'' said a passenger who arrived from Dani, 115 miles northwest of the capital. He did not wish to identified. The Communist Party and the Nepali Congress Party demand an end to a 29-year-old royal decree that banned all political parties in the kingdom, one of the world's oldest monarchies. A Home Ministry statement said, ``It is common knowledge that extremist communists ... have been active in disruptive force since Feb. 18.'' The ``government would never lag behind legal action against those who attempt to disrupt public life,'' the statement said. Power in Nepal is shared between the king and the Rashtriya Panchayat. One-fifth of the assembly's 140 members are nominated by the king. The rest are elected. The government of King Birendra says the campaign to lift the ban on political parties runs counter to a 1980 referendum which narrowly voted for retaining the Panchayat's system of nonpartisan membership. Former Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa, one of the earliest advocates of the non-partisan system, said today: ``Nepal's current problem should be solved with mutual understanding. ``The government has, however, decided to end political crisis with the use of force and repression. Such an animal instinct will not do,'' said Thapa, an assembly member. Nepal's two-year experiment with Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when King Mahendra, father of the present monarch, dissolved the government of the Nepali Congress Party, accusing it of corruption and poor administration.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Inaction Prompts Turkey to Lift Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Turkey lifted restrictions on U.S. military personnel there after the U.S. Senate refused to pass a resolution commemorating the alleged genocide of Armenians seven decades ago. The Turkish government notified the U.S. ambassador of the move, saying senators had acted ``in a statesmanlike manner'' to quash the resolution, which the government considered ``a distortion of the historical facts.'' The restrictions, imposed after the Senate Judiciary Committee approved the resolution last Oct. 18, barred certain kinds of meetings on defense cooperation and U.S. activities at the Konya bombing range, suspended visits by U.S. ships and denied permission for new construction at four major U.S. military facilities in Turkey. The resolution, sponsored by Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., would have marked April 24 as a day to remember the Armenian genocide in 1915-1923. Dole shelved the measure late Tuesday after the Senate refused to break a filibuster against it. Armenians claim the alleged massacre killed 1.5 million people during the Ottoman empire, but Turkish officials dispute that assertion. They say some 600,000 people died during the period, including Muslims and Christians, as a result of civil strife and marauding bands.
DOC.HEAD: Food-Garbage Hauls By Trucks Continue, Lawmakers Say
DOC.TEXT: Despite concern by food companies, truckers continue to alternate garbage hauls with shipments of beef and other edible products, according to lawmakers. Truckers, senators and the Bush administration could not agree at a hearing Thursday on how best to stop the practice, which is known as ``backhauling.'' It has been 10 months since a central Pennsylvania newspaper reported that refrigerated food-hauling trucks known as ``reefers'' were being loaded with municipal solid waste at a transfer station. In October, truckers told a House panel about the related practice of hauling chemicals and juice back to back. ``While there has been almost universal agreement on the need to end these most egregious practices, unfortunately, garbage backhauling is still legal and is still occurring every day,'' Rep. Chris Smith, R-N.J., told a Senate Commerce subcommittee Thursday. The House Public Works and Transportation Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee are trying to reconcile differences between bills they have approved to end backhauling.
DOC.HEAD: First Woman Confirmed as Surgeon General
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Antonia Coello Novello has been confirmed as surgeon general by the Senate, becoming the first woman and first Hispanic to hold the post. The action came Thursday night on a voice vote without debate. She succeeds C. Everett Koop, who stepped down in December. A 45-year-old pediatrician and expert on AIDS in children, Dr. Novello has been deputy director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health.
DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Soviets Announce Joint Stamp Issue
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union will jointly issue four new postage stamps this fall. The U.S. Postal Service announced Thursday that the stamps, two designed by an American government artist and two by a Soviet counterpart, will feature creatures of the sea. First-issue ceremonies will be Oct. 3 in Baltimore, Md., and Moscow. Peter Cocci of the U.S. Bureau of Engraving and Printing is designing dolphin and killer-whale stamps. The other two, showing northern sea lions and a sea otter, are being crafted by Vladimir Beilin of the Soviet Ministry of Communications. The American stamps will have a 25-cent value, while the Soviet versions will be priced at 25 kopecks. The United States has also jointly issued stamps in recent years with Australia, France and Sweden.

DOC.HEAD: Israel And Bulgaria To Renew Diplomatic Ties
DOC.TEXT: Israel announced today that it will renew diplomatic relations with Bulgaria after a 23-year hiatus, when Foreign Minister Moshe Arens visits Sofia in the near future. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yosef Amihud said the date of Arens' visit has not been determined yet, but Israel radio said relations would be renewed within a month. ``The initiative came from the government of Bulgaria, and we praise it,'' Amihud said. Bulgaria would become the fourth East European country to renew diplomatic relations with Israel. The Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries, except for Romania, severed relations with Israel in 1967 to protest its occupation of land belonging to Moscow's Arab allies in the Middle East war of that year. Hungary was the first to re-establish relations in September, followed by Czechoslovakia Feb. 9 and Poland on Tuesday. The Soviet Union and Israel have exchanged consular offices but the Kremlin says renewal of full diplomatic relations is conditional on progress in the Middle East peace process. Israel has been also negotiating the establishment of ties with East Germany following its acceptance of some responsibility for the genocide of Jews during the years of the Nazi rule. East Germany's previous stand of denying any responsibility for Nazi deeds has prevented the two countries from having any relations.

DOC.HEAD: West German Politicians Dominate East German Campaign
DOC.TEXT: West German politicians are enjoying celebrity status in East Germany's first free election campaign in 40 years. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and former Chancellor Willy Brandt have been among the visiting campaigners who have drawn crowds of up to 100,000 at election rallies. Some Communists and members of other leftist groups say the Bonn leaders should stay out of the campaign being waged by their sister parties for the March 18 parliamentary elections. But most East Germans seem to welcome the support, saying Kohl, Genscher and Brandt are providing their nation with a crucial lesson in democracy. ``The questions being addressed here concern the people in West Germany too,'' said Karl-Heinz Gandre of Erfurt. ``We are one people, and we belong together,'' Gandre said. Gandre was in a crowd of 60,000 people waving West German flags and chanting ``Germany, united fatherland'' as they greeted Genscher at a rally for the centrist Association of Free Democrats in Erfurt. Politicians in East Germany's new pro-democracy movements are relatively unknown and inexperienced. They benefit from the reflected fame of the visiting West German politicians, who are well-known from West German television broadcasts that blanketed the country even before the frontiers were opened last fall following a popular movement for democratic reforms. For the West German leaders, the campaign is an opportunity to shape the future of a new Germany and perhaps establish a power base in this nation of 16 million now that uniting the two countries appears inevitable. Open politicking is new in East Germany, and some campaign posters have been torn down and defaced. Under the old Communist regime, political signs were virtually sacrosanct. ``Partly, this is still a very undisciplined campaign,'' said Ulli Mueller, another Erfurt resident who came to hear Genscher. ``There's no experience in making democracy work here, because we've been ruled by one man for so many years.'' He referred to former Communist leader Erich Honecker, who was ousted in October after 18 years of hard-line rule. Communist Premier Hans Modrow remains the most popular politician in East Germany, despite the party's fall from power, according to West German media polls. Despite his personal prestige, Modrow's party is expected to finish no better than a distant third in the March vote, trailing the Social Democrats and the conservative Alliance for Germany. Brandt, the architect of the 1970s period of detente between the two German states, kicked off the East German Social Democrats' campaign in Leipzig. Kohl chose Erfurt to make his debut on East Germany's campaign circuit, addressing a cheering crowd of 100,000. The rally was organized by a three-party coalition, including the East German version of Kohl's Christian Democrats. Some people in the audience chanted ``Helmut! Helmut!'' There were also a few hecklers, and fliers reading ``Kohl, do your campaigning at home'' were pasted over campaign posters throughout the city. ``What Mr. Kohl is doing is just party politics,'' said Hannelore Tauer, an East Berlin supermarket clerk. ``It's not doing the West or East German people any good.'' But that seemed to be a minority view. ``The politicians in West Germany ... have done a lot for East Germany before, so I think it's right they come to the election campaign here,'' Gandre said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Deserting; Army Reportedly Hiding Weapons
DOC.TEXT: Draftees in the Sandinista-controlled army are deserting their ranks and the military is reportedly hiding arms ahead of next month's swearing in of an opposition government. Sandinista officials on Thursday acknowledged the desertions but denied weapons and ammunition were being squirreled away. Also Thursday, President Daniel Ortega called on the United States to resume aid on the day he steps down to the opposition coalition that upset his leftist party in Sunday's election. ``The best that could happen would be for the Contras (rebel guerrillas) to be demobilized by April 25 and for the United States to lift the embargo and send the aid it has promised starting that day,'' Ortega told Nicaraguan journalists. Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who is due to succeed Ortega as president on April 25, has echoed Ortega's call for the Contras to lay down their weapons. Her United National Opposition (UNO) and Ortega's Sandinistas are beginning to discuss the process of transition. The Sandinistas staked out a tough set of positions Tuesday, including the dismantling of the U.S.-supported Contra rebels from their Honduran jungle camps. Honduran officials today were expected to join Sandinista and UNO officials on shutting down the Honduran rebels camps. The Sandinistas, who receive Soviet and Cuban aid, have also demanded the army and the Interior Ministry security forces remain intact, at least until the U.S.-backed rebels disband. The close link between the Sandinista party and army and security forces has been a source of strength for the Sandinistas, but the army's integrity was questioned as reports of desertions circulated. The deserters _ draftees doing two years of compulsory military service _ apparently have decided not to wait for the inauguration of Mrs. Chamorro, who is committed to banning the draft. ``They took our weapons away on Monday and didn't give them back,'' Juan Carlos Medina, 18, told The Associated Press. ``Maybe they didn't trust us.'' Medina said 40 out of 60 young draftees in his unit, stationed at the main air force base in Managua, deserted this week. He said the officers seem to want to ignore the problem. The desertions are ``normal under the current situation,'' said Lt. Col. Rosa Pasos, Defense Ministry spokeswoman. ``We definitely don't want to have people who don't want to be with us,'' Ms. Pasos said. ``And anyway, we're going to reduce the army.'' The deserters also reported weapons stored by the military. One deserter told of tunnels being dug in an army post in San Nicolas, near the northern town of Esteli, in which to hide weapons. A government official said 600 weapons, including Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, were taken from the regional military headquarters in Juigalpa to the remote town of El Rama, in central Nicaragua near the Atlantic Coast, on Monday. On Wednesday, a witness saw trucks from the Ministry of Construction taking about 600 boxes of ammunition out of an army depot. An army source said the ammunition was going to be hidden at Construction Ministry facilities. UNO leaders have expressed concern to international observers about weapons being taken by boat across Lake Nicaragua into the southern province of Rio San Juan. But Capt. Nelba Blandon, spokeswoman for the Interior Ministry, denied the reports. ``Those are just rumors to try to affect the dignified image of the Sandinista Front,'' Ms. Blandon said. ``Just the fact that for us it (losing the elections) was an enormous surprise means we could not have set up a plan to transport weapons,'' she added. The Episcopal Conference of Nicaragua, the top Roman Catholic religious leaders, called for a peaceful transition and said the Sandinistas must give up all power. ``The current government must give up each and every one of the powers that correspond to the new democratically elected government,'' said the bishops' statement, released Thursday. Juan Cueva, special representative of Honduran President Rafael Callejas, was in Managua on Thursday to meet with Mrs. Chamorro, Ortega and Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Miguel D'Escoto. Cueva said the meetings were scheduled to start today and that his job was to help hasten the rebels' demobilization from Honduran jungle camps. Israel Galeano, the Contras chief of staff, has said his forces will not disperse until the Sandinistas are out of power.

DOC.HEAD: Former Official Wanted In Camarena Case Arrested, But No Plans To Extradite
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested a former Mexican Interpol chief on drug and weapons charges, but they said there were no plans to extradite him to California for trial in the slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. Federal agents arrested Miguel Aldana Ibarra at a restaurant in Mexico City on Wednesday, the attorney general's office said Thursday. Aldana, 44, and four others were indicted Feb. 1 by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles on charges of participating in the 1985 murder of Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and a Mexican pilot. When asked whether the Mexican government planned to extradite Aldana, a spokesman at the Mexican attorney general's office said, ``No.'' There was no immediate word from U.S. officials regarding Aldana, who until four years ago headed Mexico's Interpol, the international law enforcement agency. Camarena's slaying strained U.S.-Mexican relations amid allegations of corruption among Mexican police officials. The Mexican attorney general's spokesman, Arturo Antelmo, said Aldana was arrested in connection with a huge operation to smuggle marijuana to the United States five years ago. The 9,000 tons of marijuana seized at the Buffalo Ranch, in the northern state of Chihuahua near the Texas border, was the biggest drug bust in Mexican history. ``He was picked up on a warrant for involvement in the 1985 case at the Buffalo Ranch, and also for the cocaine and six AR-15 automatic rifles found at his Cuernavaca home,'' Antelmo said in a telephone interview. Agents raided Aldana's house in Cuernavaca, 50 miles southeast of Mexico City, after the Wednesday arrest, the attorney general's office said in a statement. The government confiscated 2.3 pounds of cocaine, six automatic rifles, two pistols and ammunition, the statement said. Seven other people are being held for questioning in the case, it said. Aldana told reporters in January that Camarena had been in league with drug smugglers and was never killed. He alleged the slain drug agent had plastic surgery and was living off drug profits in California. The statements were made after the January broadcast of the NBC mini-series ``The Drug Wars'' about the Camarena killing. Government officials were outraged by the program, saying that it painted a distorted picture of Mexican law enforcement efforts against drug smuggling. Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were killed after the agent led a series of raids on marijuana plantations allegedly operated by Rafael Caro Quintero, who ran the drug ring. The bodies, showing signs of torture, were found March 5, 1985, on a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara, 360 miles northwest of Mexico City. The indictment in Los Angeles charged Aldana along with Manuel Ibarra Herrera, the former head of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police, and three others participated in the killing to protect the operations of a Guadalajara drug cartel, according to the U.S. Department of Justice. Aldana resigned from his Interpol post on Jan. 2, 1986, after serving 24 years as a law enforcement officer. He quit after the weekly magazine Proceso said a drug defendant had testified that a shipment of Colombian cocaine seized at the Mexico City airport was for Aldana. The defendant later recanted, claiming his testimony was made under duress. Since then, Aldana has been a working as a lawyer.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Drivers Strike Greyhound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs urgent series; ADDS quotes from company, drivers, no talks scheduled. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound's 6,300 drivers went on strike early Friday against America's only nationwide bus company. The union said its drivers would take passengers to their next scheduled stop before joining the 50-state walkout. ``We went on strike because the company has refused to bargain in good faith, and we have struck because the company insisted on imposing'' its original offer, said union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson said in Scottsdale, Ariz. The strike began at 12:05 MST after talks broke off in Scottsdale despite the arrival late Thursday of a federal mediator. No new talks were scheduled. Also on strike were 3,075 of the company's office and maintenance workers in the union, the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Locals, whose old, three-year contract with Greyhound Lines Inc. expired at midnight Thursday. ``This is a damn pure shame to have to do business like this. All we want is some of what we've given up over the last few years,'' said a driver early Friday at a Greyhound terminal in Phoenix. He would not give his name. In Dallas, pickets forced two Greyhound buses to stop just outside the downtown terminal, about two blocks from the skyscraper where the company's corporate offices are located. The pickets cheered as the drivers left their buses, which were then taken over by company officials. In one instance, passengers got off a bus and helped guide it past pickets into the terminal. Greyhound, which says it serves 9,500 U.S. communities and is the only public intercity transportation in about 9,000, had arranged schedules so that no new runs would begin after the strike deadline, and Nelson said working drivers would continue to their next stop at that time, then join picket lines. ``While we regret the decision of the (union) to strike, we will be in operation to serve our passengers,'' said Greyhound vice president P. Anthony Lannie, chief negotiator. Lannie said Greyhound would operate with replacements and any employees who come to work. He said the company would give preference to routes connecting major urban centers and plans to be at full service by the end of the month. Greyhound has ``declared a war on the members of this union,'' said Harold Mendlowitz, president of Local 1202 in New York City, which also covers Albany, N.Y.; Hartford, Conn., and Montreal. ``If it's a fight that they want it's a fight they are going to get,'' said Mendlowitz. ``They want to force us out. They want to bust this union.'' Elizabeth Hale said the company advised passengers this week of the possibility of a strike and worked to reduce the number of buses on the road at midnight. About 22 million people rode Greyhound last year, the company said. ``We'll do our best to get that person to their final destination and take care of his or her needs in the interim,'' Ms. Hale said. The company has been advertising for drivers, and as of last week had 600 in training. Ms. Hale did not have an updated number of new hires. Amtrak, meanwhile, told ticket agents to honor Greyhound tickets when buses are not available, railroad spokeswoman Sue Martin said in Washington, D.C. She said no additional fare would be charged, but added that some trains require reservations and that bus passengers may find no space on crowded routes. The 3-year-old company earned its first profit last year after being created in a buyout of Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp.'s bus operations. Drivers' wages were the main unresolved issue, with the company offering a 6.9 percent first-year raise and 13.5 percent during the three-year contract. Drivers earned an average of $24,743 last year, according to the company. The company says the union wants a 33 percent first-year raise, a figure Nelson called ``false and ... misleading.'' Dallas-based Greyhound Lines Inc. was formed when an investment group led by Fred G. Currey paid $270 million to buy the Greyhound bus system from Greyhound Corp. Four months later, the group paid $80 million for Trailways Lines Inc., the country's largest operator of Trailways buses. As part of the deal, the union agreed to a 22 percent wage cut, and Greyhound said the drivers were trying to win back the entire amount at one time. The company expects to earn a profit of about $730,000 on $1 billion in revenue. In the previous two years, the company lost $20 million.

DOC.HEAD: Forces That Affected Eastern Europe At Work In Nicaragua
An AP Extra
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When Violeta Barrios de Chamorro told an audience of peasants last year that she was going to Europe to ``bring you back a piece of the Berlin Wall,'' she drew disbelieving laughter. Few in the rural town of Nandaime had ever heard of the Berlin Wall. Why would someone bring them a piece of a wall? Although in recent months Mrs. Chamorro and other United National Opposition (UNO) politicians frequently portrayed themselves as riding the tide of democracy that swept Eastern Europe last year, that theme had little resonance inside Nicaragua. ``Eastern Europe? You mean, the people who gave us aid?'' said Mario Ramirez, a Sandinista party activist, when asked if he thought Eastern Europe had affected the voting. ``I think when people went to the polls, they voted with their stomachs. And I think they thought about the empty stomachs of their children,'' said Paul Reichler, a Washington lawyer who advises President Daniel Ortega. Sunday's vote for change from a fractured economy and the strain of civil war against the U.S.-supported Contras swept Ortega's leftist Sandinistas from power in favor of Mrs. Chamorro, who takes office April 25. It marks the end of Sandinista government, which began with the ouster of dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979. But while the example of Eastern Europe did not reach the average voter, the forces that caused change there affected the atmosphere and structure of the campaign, as well as the Sandinistas' decision to hold and accept the consequences of a free vote. ``They had to change because the world was changing,'' said Mauricio Diaz, secretary-general of the Social Christian Party. The Bush administration credits the Soviet Union and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with encouraging Nicaragua's move to democracy. Additionally, reductions in East bloc aid and the visible failures of socialism affected the Sandinistas' own economic and political policies. ``The Sandinistas started out trying to build a nation on the Cuban model, but they really gave up on that by 1984,'' Diaz said. He and other analysts say the Sandinistas were driven to democracy and a mixed-economy theory by the hostility of the United States and the horrible state of their own economy. The process was gradual, both impeded and propelled by the war against U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas _ impeded by the need to maintain wartime political discipline, propelled by the damage the war did to the economy. Real change did not take place until the United States halted lethal aid to the Contras in early 1988. Shortly after the U.S. Congress voted to cut off aid, the Sandinistas put in place an economic austerity plan, ``An IMF (International Monetary Fund) plan without the IMF,'' as Ortega put it. While some of the plan's more Draconian proposals for firing public employees were not carried out, enough was done to hurt poor people badly, according to Patricia O'Kane, a researcher at the Regional Coordinator for Economic and Social Research in Managua. The Sandinistas began wooing the private sector and acknowledged errors in some of their confiscation and expropriation policies. ``It was tropical perestroika. They tried to reform the revolution, but it was too late,'' Diaz said. Still, there were noticeable changes in the last year. Private advertising in newspapers and on radio and television picked up. New cars began to appear on the streets; also new streetlights, and some street repairs were made. In a strange conjunction that also occurred in Poland under Wojciech Jaruzelski's government, the country held its first beauty pageant in years. ``They're very pragmatic. I think they began those moves as pure tactics _ the opening towards democracy, a mixed economy, non-alignment. But somehow it became more than tactics,'' said Diaz. ``They took a big gamble and they really thought they were going to win. They totally underestimated the effects of the economic crisis,'' O'Kane said. Ortega and other Sandinistas insist their party is not anything like the communist parties of Eastern Europe. Ortega has said the comparison is invalid because he won 40 percent of the vote _ much more than any communist party in Eastern Europe is likely to gain. Diaz noted that Nicaragua was never ruled by an all-encompassing single party. ``There were always independent unions, though weak, there was always a private sector, there was always a political opposition,'' he said. He believes the influence of a nearby and very interested United States was a factor. ``People were tired of always fighting the United States,'' he said. ``Now, everyone's waiting for the first McDonald's to open.'' The Sandinistas are not complete democrats, however, said Diaz. ``They linked the party, the army and security forces and the government in a kind of triangle,'' he said. They've lost the government, but they are currently fighting in negotations with the opposition to hold on to the party-army link, their last hold on power. Diaz said he thought there was real irony in the Sandinista evolution. ``Just as they were becoming democratic, they lost an election,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Army Seeks Repayment of Scholarship That Went to Homosexual
DOC.TEXT: The ROTC is seeking to recover a $25,000 scholarship it gave to a star recruit who lost his commission after disclosing he's gay. James Holobaugh, 24, was to have been commissioned by the Army in May, when he disclosed his homosexuality. The military withdrew the commission and moved to make Holobaugh reimburse the Reserve Officers' Training Corps for the scholarship at Washington University. The Pentagon regards homosexuals as unsuitable for military service and does not knowingly permit them to serve. Its policy, stating that the presence of homosexuals ``would seriously impair discipline, good order, morale and security,'' was upheld by the Supreme Court in two decisions Monday. It is not unusual for homosexual cadets to be removed from ROTC, but this is apparently the first case in which the Army had asked for its scholarship money back, said William B. Rubenstein, Holobaugh's attorney. Holobaugh was rated one of the top performers in his ROTC class and was selected by the Army to be in a nationwide advertising campaign to attract students. Holobaugh, who expects to graduate in the spring, said that he was dating women when he began college in 1984. It wasn't until late 1988 or early 1989 that he realized he was homosexual, Holobaugh said. Holobaugh said he was ``appalled at the prejudice'' in the military against homosexuals. ``It's kind of blowing my mind,'' he said. ``I will without a doubt fight to not have to pay back my scholarship,'' he said. His case is being reviewed by the commander of the Army Second Region at Fort Knox, Ky. At an informal hearing in December, the Army questioned whether Holobaugh was masquerading as a homosexual to evade his service obligation, but later ruled that no such evidence existed, said Rubenstein, who is also staff counsel for the Lesbian and Gay Rights project of the American Civil Liberties Union. After completing the ROTC program, students commissioned as officers must serve in the military for four years of active duty or eight years in reserves. Washington University supports Holobaugh. Its provost of the university, Edward S. Macias, wrote to Lt. Col. Robert L. Bates, the ROTC commander, saying the ban on homosexuals was ``inconsistent with the nondiscriminatory values of this _ and I should think virtually all _ universities.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Stocks Rise Moderately in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed slightly lower against the yen today, pushed back by rumors that Japan's central bank will raise its official discount rate. Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange gained moderately. The dollar closed the week at 149.75 yen, down 0.03 yen from Thursday's close of 149.78 yen. After opening at 150.35 yen, the currency ranged between 149.50 yen and 150.50 yen. It was the first time that the dollar's trading range rose to the 150-yen level since June. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, commenting on the dollar's rise, told reporters that Japan's economic fundamentals remain solid and that the ``situation is not such that we are coming to a crisis,'' Kyodo News Service reported. But Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told a regular news conference that he was ``extremely worried'' about the yen's continued decline against the dollar, though there has been no adverse effect on the country's economy and prices. Both Kaifu and Hashimoto said the situation must be watched carefully. Currency dealers said the dollar continued to rise in the morning session, despite the reported dollar-selling intervention by the Bank of Japan, but the dollar was sold because of the interest rate rumors. The rumor was found later to be groundless. ``Many market players consider the dollar's underlying sentiment basically remains bullish because of the currency's actual demand,'' said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, who spoke anonymously. There has been speculation for weeks that the central bank will raise its official discount rate, the rate charged on its loans to commercial banks, in a range of 0.5-1.0 percent. The rate is currently 4.25 percent. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 762.41 points Thursday, recouped 227.98 points, or 0.67 percent, to close at 34,057.56. A total of 570 million shares changed hands, down from 620 million shares traded on Thursday. Securities dealers said the Tokyo market is showing a gradual recovery, despite rising interest rates on Japanese bonds and the yen's relative weakness. Declining bond prices were partly responsible for the sagging stock market over the last two weeks. ``Today, the market proved its strength in spite of such negative factors,'' said Masahiro Umemori, an equity analyst with Nomura Securities. In the bonds market, the yield on the No. 119 benchmark 10-year bond closed at 7.125 percent, up from Thursday's close at 7.090 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica Asks For Extradition Of American Linked To Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Costa Rica will ask the United States to extradite an Indiana man for the 1984 bombing of a news conference in which four people were killed, a Foreign Ministry source said. The source, who did not want to be identified by name, said the Costa Rican Embassy in Washington will present the extradition request Monday for John Hull, who skipped bond and fled to the United States last July after living 20 years in Costa Rica. In an interview Thursday from his home in Patoka, Ind., Hull said the charge of planning the bombing is ``completely false and it's completely politically motivated.'' He said the Costa Rican government objects to his ties to an American religious organization. Hull, who owned a ranch near the Nicaraguan border, was accused of supplying weapons to the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. The May 31, 1984, explosion in a house in Penca, Nicaragua, killed three reporters _ American reporter Linda Frazier, two Costa Rican journalists and a Nicaraguan rebel. They were attending a news conference by Eden Pastora, a Contra rebel commander at the time who had defected from the Sandinista government. Pastora, who was believed to be the target of the bombing, and about a dozen other people were injured. Prosecutor Jorge Chavarria said Hull and Felipe Vidal, a Cuban, planned the bombing to avenge Pastora's statements linking Hull to the CIA. The whereabouts of Vidal and the man who placed the bomb have not been determined. Hull said he had not heard from either U.S. or Costa Rican officials by Thursday night. ``As I understand it, before they can extradite a U.S. citizen, they have to prove the charges in a U.S. court,'' he said. ``They could have proved the charges in a court down there because you can manipulate judges and everyone else in the judicial system, but you can't do that here in the United States.'' Maximo Esquivel, a judge in northern Costa Rica, was quoted in Thursday's editions of The New York Times as saying he signed the extradition order last month. Esquivel's office said the judge would not make any statement about the matter when The Associated Press contacted his office by telephone Thursday in Quesada, about 100 miles north of San Jose. The status of Hull's nationality is unclear. While the Costa Rican government claims he has acquired Costa Rica citizenship, Hull referred to himself as an American on Thursday. Hull was released from a hospital Thursday in Evansville, Ind., where he had been treated for heart problems. He said recently returned from a trip to El Salvador for the Toledo-based Americans Helping America organization, providing Bibles and securing chaplins for the military there. Hull was jailed last year in Costa Rica, accused of drug trafficking to help the rebels and of violating Costa Rica's neutrality. He fled to Indiana after his release on $37,000 bond.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Grants Seabrook License; No White Flag For Plant Foes
LaserPhotos CR1, CR2
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook nuclear plant overcame two decades of protests, legal challenges, ballooning costs and the financial ruin of its chief investor to capture the ultimate prize: a license to operate. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3-0 Thursday to grant the $6.5 billion reactor a full-power license. But the appeal process will hold up the license for at least two weeks, and Seabrook opponents pressed on. About 125 anti-Seabrook demonstrators waved signs, chanted and blocked plant gates after the decision. More than 70 were arrested. At the NRC meeting in Rockville, Md., utility executives hugged each other after the ruling, and maintenance workers at the 1,200-plus employee plant hoisted a sign reading, ``Startup '90: We Have the Power.'' ``It's a milestone in the lives of our employees, more than just mortar and bricks,'' said Edward Brown, president of Seabrook operator New Hampshire Yankee. Seabrook, perhaps the nation's most hotly contested nuclear plant, became a symbol of the anti-nuclear movement, and its foes claimed a broader victory, contending that as a result of the long fight against Seabrook, no utility would risk the costs of trying to build and open another nuclear plant. Conceived in 1968, it was proposed in 1972 as a twin-reactor plant costing less than $1 billion. Construction delays and cost increases forced the cancellation of one reactor in the mid-1980s and plunged lead owner Public Service Co. of New Hampshire into bankruptcy reorganization in 1988. The plant was held up largely by concerns over whether the area could be evacuated in an emergency. The NRC ruling ratified recommendations by its staff and several lower-level boards that the plant is safe and that evacuation plans would work. ``I would be happy to live within two miles of this plant and I wouldn't worry about it at all,'' said NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr. Weeks before Thursday's licensing, plant operators raised temperatures and pressure in the 1,150-megawatt reactor to ready it for nuclear fission. ``We're going to stay at temperature and pressure and as soon as we get the license in hand, we're ready to go,'' said Brown. The decision gives opponents seven days to file an appeal; seven days after the filing the license becomes effective unless a judge issues a stay. If the appeal fails, ascension to full power could take two to three months. Seabrook opponents remained undaunted, saying the final battles now move into an arena more likely to rule in their favor. Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon and two environmental groups planned to ask for a stay of the license next week in the federal appeals court in Washington. ``It's correct to say there has never been a case where the court has overturned an NRC license, but it's also correct to say that there has never been a license issued which has been so legally vulnerable,'' Shannon said. Those vulnerabilities include what opponents consider the NRC's violation of its own procedures in rulings on emergency evacuation plans for the densely populated New Hampshire and Massachusetts communities near the plant. One of Seabrook's most prominent opponents, Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, refused to summit emergency plans in 1986 after declaring that safe evacuation was impossible. The NRC then accepted utility-drafted plans for Massachusetts. In Boston on Thursday, Dukakis held George Bush, who defeated him in the 1988 presidential election, partially responsible for the NRC action. Bush's support of the plant ``has made a significant difference here,'' he said. Bush supported Seabrook while campaigning for New Hampshire's 1988 presidential primary, with John Sununu, then New Hampshire's governor and now White House chief of staff, leading his campaign. Sununu is a staunch Seabrook supporter. Overall, there have been more than 3,200 arrests in anti-Seabrook protests, which peaked in the mid-1970s during construction and picked up again last summer as the plant drew closer to a full-power license. Carr on Thursday defended the commission's handling of the Seabrook license. ``We see nothing at present that persuades us that Seabrook cannot be operated safely,'' the NRC chairman said. ``This is one of the most closely scrutinized and safely built plants in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Weather May Make This Year's Iditarod a Slow Run to Nome
DOC.TEXT: The 70 mushers in this year's Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race will face some of the worst weather in the race's 18-year history. ``Conditions are as bad as they possibly can be,'' said race manager Jack Niggemyer. ``Nature is throwing everything at us it can. It might slow things down a bit.'' The race begins Saturday. Wind chill readings to 60 degrees below zero, the deepest snow in a quarter-century, ash from Redogale-force winds are combining to make things extremely difficult for trailbreakers who on snowmachines are trying to groom the 1,100-mile Anchorage-to-Nome run. At leaubt Volcano and st 30 inches of new snow on the south side of the Alaska Range has virtually smothered hundreds of miles of trail, and winds in the desolate Farewell Burn have shaped 8-foot drifts that threaten to turn another 100 or so miles into a frozen pattern of furrows. ``Your nightmare has come true,'' Niggemyer said. ``Shades of '85,'' said Iditarod veteran Dee Dee Jonrowe of Willow, referring to the year in which deep snow stalled the race. ``I think this should be our goal: The Idit-a-made-it.'' Among the mushers entered this year are four-time winner Rick Swenson, of Two Rivers; three-time winner Susan Butcher, of Manley; defending champion Joe Runyan, of Nenana, and 84-year-old Norman Vaughn, of Trapper Creebaum, the spiritual leader of the Satmar sect, was a weekly target of the paper, whose circulation was estimated at from 500 to 2,000 copies. ``This was worse than yellow journalism,'' Rabbi Chaim Stauber, an associate of Teitelbaum, told The New York Times. ``He stopped short of nothing. There was absolutely no moral code, no bounds.'' Officials said that Teitelbaum's secretary, Rabbi Moses Friedman, told the district attorney about the extortion threat and offered to cooperate. Yiddish-speaking investigators eavesdropped Wednesday when Shaulson visited Friedman's house in Brooklyn, officials said. Police said Friedman gave Shaulson $1,000, then signed a contract with Shaulson that the negative attacks would cease. Shaulson was arrested minutes later.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Obtains Rights to Emmy Broadcast for Three Years
DOC.TEXT: The Fox network will broadcast the Emmy Awards for the next three years, the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences announced. Published reports have indicated that Fox Broadcasting Co. will pay the Academy around $9 million for the rights to the show, which will be seen on 129 Fox affiliates. Fox has broadcast the Emmy show for the last three years. The contract requires Fox to broadcast the previously non-televised presentation of Emmy awards for creative arts categories from 1990 to 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Dealer Convicted of Murder in Student's Cocaine Overdose
DOC.TEXT: A drug dealer was convicted of murder for supplying the cocaine that caused a college student's death. ``We like to think this would put people on notice that there are other consequences to selling drugs besides distribution charges,'' said Dan Connally, assistant district attorney.
