A jury Wednesday convicted Brad Noble Palmer, 34, in the 1984 overdose death of Ryan Richardson, an 18-year-old freshman at Panhandle State University. Connally said prosecutors charged Palmer with murder because he knew an earlier dose taken by Richardson had made him so ill that he was hospitalized. Jurors recommended a 25-year prison term. Sentencing was set for March 19.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Admits Conspiracy with Ex-Ashland Chairman
DOC.TEXT: A businessman who played a role in the Iran-Contra scandal admitted taking part in a scheme to sell confidential Ashland Oil Co. documents to an Iranian company involved in a dispute with Ashland. Roy M. Furmark, 58, an oil broker, pleaded guilty Thursday in federal court to conspiring with former Ashland chairman Orin Atkins to provide secret information to the National Iranian Oil Co. about Ashland's decision not to pay NIOC for $283 million worth of crude oil purchased in 1979. Furmark, a friend of the late CIA director William Casey, testified before Congress during the investigation of the Iran-Contra scandal that he was involved in the sale of arms to Iran. Atkins, who resigned as Ashland chairman in 1981 but remained a consultant until 1988, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and wire fraud in September. He faces up 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine at sentencing June 7. Furmark faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine at sentencing June 15. He told U.S. District Judge Miriam Cedarbaum at that he, Atkins and a lawyer, Charles Barnett, conspired to sell 259 documents Atkins had obtained from a source at Ashland in 1982. The conspirators reached an agreement with NIOC in 1984 that they would receive 25 percent of any damages the company might receive in a lawsuit against Ashland for the unpaid oil shipment, prosecutors charged. ``Though I tried to deceive myself as to the propriety of my actions, I knew in my heart it was wrong,'' Furmark said. The Iranian company never completed the deal to buy the documents, prosecutors said. The legal dispute were settled in September with Ashland agreeing to pay $325 million. Barnett, of Palm Beach, Fla., whose law firm once worked for Ashland, goes on trial in April.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced for Bilking Banks of More Than $1 Million
DOC.TEXT: A man who used fake tax returns, a fictitious herd of cattle and a non-existent salary from a bull sperm bank to obtain more than $1 million in loans was sentenced to 12 years in prison. U.S. District Judge George S. White on Thursday also ordered Lowell Abbe, 47, to repay $413,000 to seven Ohio lenders. Abbe had pleaded guilty to 22 counts of fraud. Prosecutors said Abbe used fake tax returns, property, farm equipment, automobiles and Black Angus cattle he didn't own in obtaining the bank loans. Court documents said he also buried an expensive sports car and a horse trailer on his family farm in an attempt to hide assets. FBI agents dug up the car. ``He did things a banker would never dream a borrower would do,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Ann Rowland. ``I've never had a bankruptcy trial where assets were buried.'' Abbe changed attorneys six times since his indictment four years ago, tried to withdraw his guilty plea and fainted in court at his sentencing Monday, forcing a postponement. Carolyn J. Strouse, whom Abbe married in December, was sentenced to four years in prison Monday on 14 counts related to the fraud.

DOC.HEAD: Tomato Seeds Sent into Space for Six Years Withstand Test of Time
DOC.TEXT: Tomato seeds exposed to the rigors of space travel for six years seem to be germinating normally, scientists say. The first small batch of seeds recently returned from a NASA satellite were displayed Thursday _ apparently sprouting normally in a germination test that began Saturday, said Dr. Jim Alston of Park Seed Co. ``Everything looked fine. No little green critters came flying out,'' joked Alston, whose company provided the 12.5 million seeds for the experiment aboard the space agency's Long Duration Exposure Facility. At a news conference called to display the germinating seeds, officials also cracked open one of eight unopened canisters of seeds launched into space in April 1984. The satellite was supposed to be picked up by space shuttle astronauts and returned to Earth 10 months after it was launched, but scheduling difficulties and the 1986 Challenger disaster delayed its retrieval. They were retrieved in December by the shuttle Columbia. The seeds _ most of them in sealed, insulated canisters _ appeared to have survived their long space journey, said officials working on the project with NASA. In addition to the 12.5 million tomato seeds _ of the Rutgers California Supreme variety _ there were 120 types of seeds including corn, onion, cucumber and sunflower. Scientists will look for mutations caused by the heavy radiation they were exposed to in space. Plants grown from the seeds will be examined for differences in color _ indicating a loss of chlorophyll _ and for differences in leaves, stems, flowers and fruit. The results may be significant in determining whether food can be grown in outer space. Opening the canister is something less than high-tech. After undoing its 36 screws, Alston first tried to pop the top off with a chunk of wood and a hammer, but he ended up prying it off with a rusty butcher knife, a pocketknife and a putty knife. Some of the samples will be analyzed at the seed company, but most will be shipped to colleges and elementary and high schools across the country for experiments. The results of those experiments will be sent to Oklahoma State University, which is scheduled to publish a report this fall on the findings.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Wanted: Salesclerk for tobacco shop _ no smokers need apply. One might think a tobacco shop would be safe haven for those puffing pariahs already persona non grata in restaurants, elevators, trains, planes and automobiles. But Tobacco Emporium owner Lindsay Heine, who advertised for the non-smoking clerk this week, believes even smoke shop customers have the right to be exposed to smoke on their own terms. ``I can see how that that might be a little contradictory,'' she said. Of the shop's six employees, only one smokes, and she smokes only at home, Ms. Heine said. A smoker would disrupt the smoke-free working environmment. ``I wear contacts,'' she said, ``and you know how smoking is on those.''

DOC.HEAD: Studies: Cholesterol Screenings by Portable Machines Often Inaccurate
DOC.TEXT: The accuracy of cholesterol screening tests varies widely, with portable testing machines used by poorly trained operators giving highly inaccurate results up to one-fourth of the time, researchers said. Poorly set instruments and inadequate training were mainly to blame for misleading readings, which can cause people to seek unneeded medical treatment or falsely reassure them they don't need it, researchers said in a study today. Even under the best of circumstances, ``cholesterol is a lot like blood pressure,'' said one of the researchers, Michelle J. Naughton, a sociologist at the University of Minnesota School of Public Health in Minneapolis. ``It will vary by the time of day you take it, and it will vary from day to day.'' Excess cholesterol in the blood is one of the three main modifiable traits linked with increased likelihood of developing heart disease, the nation's No. 1 killer. The two others are high blood pressure and smoking. In the Journal of the American Medical Association study, Ms. Naughton's group said cholesterol screening results were within an acceptable range of accuracy in only one of four public screenings they analyzed. In the three other screenings, readings often strayed from true values by more than 14.2 percent, the largest range of error allowed under guidelines of the National Cholesterol Education Program, researchers said. True values were established on samples from the same subjects measured in a nationally standardized laboratory, the researchers said. The highest rate of unacceptable results was 23.5 percent, among tests done by a cholesterol-screening company at an unidentified worksite, the researchers said. Other testing groups had rates of unacceptable error ranging from 6.9 percent, at a retail store; to 3.6 percent, at a grocery store; to zero percent, at the Minnesota State Fair, the researchers found. At the unidentified worksite, where accuracy was worst, testers had received only one day of training and no apprenticeship or refresher courses. At the retail store and the grocery store, testers had undergone two days of training and an apprenticeship, the researchers found. At the Minnesota State Fair, testers had undergone four days of training, an apprenticeship and three-hour refresher courses every three months, the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Co-Defendant Wants Trial Moved From Anti-Castro Miami
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for a co-defendant of Manuel Noriega said his client cannot get a fair trial in South Florida because the drug-trafficking case against the deposed dictator is linked to Cuban leader Fidel Castro. South Florida is ``dominated'' by people who fled their homelands to escape communist dictatorships, especially Cuba and Nicaragua, said Samuel Burstyn, the attorney for former Noriega aide Luis del Cid. Calling Castro an unindicted co-conspirator in the drug-trafficking indictment, Burstyn said the trial should be moved to San Francisco, New York or Puerto Rico. He asked for a change of venue Thursday in federal court. The February 1988 indictment alleges that Castro mediated a dispute between Noriega and Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. The indictment alleges that del Cid handled a drug payoff for Noriega. In his motion, Burstyn noted that during del Cid's unsuccessful attempt to get bail, prosecutors released a photo of del Cid, Noriega and Castro meeting in Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Exclusion of Women From Jobs Involving Lead
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court has struck down a company policy prohibiting women capable of bearing children from working around lead. The court ruled that the ``fetal protection program'' by Johnson Controls Inc., which owned a battery manufacuter in Fullerton, assumed that all fertile women would become pregnant and was nothing more than sex discrimination. ``We are in an era of choice. A woman is not required to become a Victorian brood mare,''the court said in the ruling, released Thursday. Catherine Ruckelshaus of San Francisco Legal Aid's Employment Law Center, which represented the woman in the case, Queen Foster, said it was the first appellate decision in the country to overturn a fetal protection policy. The ruling was based on California civil rights law and lacks direct effect outside the state but could be a model for courts elsewhere, Ms. Ruckelshaus said. ``We're ecstatic,'' she said. ``Employers can no longer discriminate on the basis of one's ability to have children.'' Gerald Griffin, a lawyer for Johnson Controls, referred questions to corporate officials, who did not return a call Thursday. The company makes batteries for some of the nation's biggest retailers under their house brands. Ms. Foster had been denied a battery assembly job in 1983 at a Johnson plant under a nationwide policy the company had started three months earlier. High concentrations of lead, which is used in automobile batteries, have been found to affect adult and child health and have been linked by some researchers to birth defects. In 1987, the state Fair Employment and Housing Commission ordered Globe Battery to hire her, give her back pay and additional amounts to be determined later, and rescind its policy. The company appealed and won in 1988 in Superior Court. The appeals court ruling rejected the reasoning of the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which upheld the company's policy in a Minnesota case last year. The United Auto Workers has appealed the Minnesota ruling to the U.S. Supreme Court. The policy apparently presumes that ``the employer is better suited to safeguard the interests of a woman's future offspring, should there be an unexpected pregnancy, than is the woman herself,'' said the California court in the 3-0 decision.

DOC.HEAD: Northern Plains Bask in Warmth; Sierra Nevada Awaits Heavy Snow
DOC.TEXT: A warm front that set record highs in the upper Plains lingered across the region today, while heavy snows were expected this weekend in the Sierra Nevada. Thunderstorms extended from the Texas Gulf Coast on Thursday in a swath that cut across Louisiana, Mississippi, northern Alabama, Georgia, the western portions of the Carolinas, Kentucky and central Tennessee. Almost an inch of rain soaked Lafayette, La., and two-thirds of an inch fell at Houston and Palacious, Texas. As much as 1{ feet of snow is expected from the winter storm returning to the Sierra Nevada. Winter storm watches for tonight have been posted in the higher elevations of the range, from north of Yosemite, Calif., to the California-Nevada border along the Lake Tahoe-Truckee area. Another storm is likely to sweep across the area on Sunday, bringing with it much colder temperatures. The northern Plains basked in unseasonably warm weather Thursday, with temperatures as much as 30 degrees warmer than usual. In South Dakota, Aberdeen registered 64 degrees, breaking by 3 degrees the record set in 1901 for March 1. Bismarck, N.D., hit 62, breaking the record of 1905 by 1, and Fargo, N.D., tied the 1918 temperature of 58. Minneapolis-St. Paul set a new high of 59, topping the high of 45 registered in 1964 and again in 1985. Also in Minnesota, Cloud had 58 degrees, bettering the 1918 mark of 55, and Duluth was 48, topping the 1956 record by 5 degrees. In Michigan, Marquette was 52, bettering the 1964 mark of 45, and Alpena tied the 1923 high of 48. And in Washington state, Olympia bettered the 1986 mark of 61 by 1, and Tacoma tied the 1968 record of 62. A winter storm warning was posted beginning tonight for the upper Kobuk and Yukon valleys of Alaska. As much as a foot of snow was expected by Saturday. The high for the nation Thursday was 89 degrees at Yuma, Ariz. _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 29 fair; Atlanta 51 cloudy; Boston 34 windy; Buffalo 34; Charleston, S.C., 49 foggy; Chattanooga 46 foggy; Cincinnati 38 cloudy; Cleveland 31 fair; Detroit 31 fair; Hatteras 41 cloudy; Jacksonville 53 foggy; Key West 68 fair; Knoxville 43 rain; Macon 53 cloudy; Miami 70 fair; New York 31 fair; Philadelphia 31 fair; Pittsburgh 25 fair; Portland, Maine, 31 fair; Richmond 38 cloudy; Tampa 59 fair; Washington, D.C., 35 partly cloudy. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 51 rain; Bismarck 29 fair; Chicago 32 fair; Denver 27 fair; Des Moines 31 fair; Fort Worth 44; Indianapolis 28 fair; Kansas City 25 fair; Little Rock 40 cloudy; Louisville 41 rain; Memphis 41 rain; Nashville 41 rain; New Orleans 65 rain; North Platte 25 fair; Oklahoma City 32 fair; Omaha 29 fair; Rapid City 34 fair; St. Louis 34 fair; Minneapolis-St. Paul 37 cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 36 fair; San Antonio 37 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 36 fair; Anchorage 37 showery; Boise 37 cloudy; Casper 25 fair; Fairbanks 20 cloudy; Great Falls 25 fair; Honolulu 64 showery; Las Vegas 62 cloudy; Los Angeles 55 cloudy; Medford 48 showery; Pendleton 34 fair; Phoenix 63 fair; Portland, Ore., 46 fair; Reno 39 cloudy; Salt Lake City 42 partly cloudy; San Diego 57 cloudy; San Francisco 51 partly cloudy; Seattle 39 fair; Spokane 27 fair. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 23 fair; Montreal 34 windy; Ottawa 30 fair; Regina 23 fair; Toronto 32 fair; Winnipeg 16 fair; San Juan 74.

DOC.HEAD: Court Reverses Award in Family's Challenge to MIA's ID
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court reversed a $632,814 award to a serviceman's family who challenged the military's finding their loved one was killed in action during the Vietnam war. The ruling Thursday by the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals went against the first American family to refuse to accept the remains of a casualty of war. The court reversed the decision of a U.S. District judge in Florida, who in 1988 ordered the government to pay $632,814 to the family of an Air Force officer whose gunship was shot down in Laos in 1972. The judge ruled that the Air Force recklessly caused the family emotional distress by declaring Lt. Col. Thomas Trammell Hart III dead. The appeals court found the government acted within its authority and ruled that the lower court both lacked jurisdiction and decided wrongly on the merits of the case. Hart, 32, was one of 16 crewmen aboard the gunship. Two crew members parachuted to safety; the others, initially listed as missing in action, eventually were determined by military experts to have been killed. Hart's wife, mother and daughter challenged the techniques used to identify the remains, and charged that the methods violated military policy. Anne Hart also wanted her husband returned to the ``unaccounted for'' list. She said the decision to label him killed in action without positive identification could doom him if he were still alive and being held as a prisoner of war. The appeals court noted that searchers reconstructed the downing of the plane and dug around the accident site to a depth of 14 feet, unearthing 50,000 bone fragments, identification tags and personal effects. In reviewing the government's handling of the case, the appeals court said, ``Clearly in cases where the total evidence indicates the persons involved in the incident were in fact killed, and where recovery efforts were thorough and complete, we must conculed that the individuals have been accounted for.'' The government, according to the court, ``made its identification as best it could, and when that proved to be insufficient, it complied with every request made by the Harts except their request that Lt. Col. Hart be returned to unaccounted-for status.'' The appeals court said the family could pursue its case through other channels, such as the Armed Forces Board, but added that the courts shouldn't second-guess discretionary policies.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Move Toward Privatizing Industry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs, `In Poland...' to CORRECT that rallies were Thursday; picks up 5th pvs, `Details are...'
DOC.TEXT: East German authorities have taken another step toward the introduction of capitalism by announcing the nation's state-owned industries will be sold off to private investors starting March 15. However, land and fixed assets will not be on sale to foreigners in what is seen as a move to prevent a huge sellout to West Germany. Also Thursday, the East German Foreign Ministry proposed that experts from both Germanys meet soon to work out a common position on German unification for presentation to the World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. In Poland, demonstrators rallied Thursday in three cities to support their government's demand that it also be included in the talks. Poland says it needs access to the talks to win assurances a united Germany would not claim prewar territory that is now part of present-day Poland. Details are sketchy on the economic measures by the interim government of Premier Hans Modrow, which were announced by economic reform commissioner Wolfgang Krause. The program to sell off East Germany's huge industrial combines mainly to East German nationals begins three days before parliamentary elections scheduled March 18, the first free vote this Communist-led nation has seen in 40 years. The new parliament would supervise the program and could even make substantial changes. It could exempt some foreign investors from the purchasing ban if that is deemed in line with the public benefit, Krause said. The privatization plan is a compromise between the concerns of West German investors, who want full integration of the two nations' economies, and worries in East Germany of a complete takeover by the West. Government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer said the interim step toward privatization would give industry managers more autonomy while hindering ``arbitrary sale of assets and property.'' The lack of specifics apparently reflected the Modrow government's reluctance to go ahead with major reforms without a parliamentary mandate. Modrow, however, also faces immense pressures to quickly restore confidence in his nation's ailing economy as up to 3,000 people a day continue to leave for West Germany. That haste was also reflected by East Germany's proposal to form a joint committee of experts to work out a German line in the reunification talks with the allies who defeated the Nazis in 1945. Under the plan announced last month in Ottawa, the two Germanys will first discuss their common approach to unification and submit that to the four World War II allies. According to the official news agency ADN, a Foreign Ministry memorandum said Germany's neighbors should play some role in the unification process where their security interests were at stake. This was an apparent reference to Poland. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who faces pressure from a conservative constituency in December elections, has continued to hedge on Polish demands for guarantees that Germany won't reclaim territories it lost to Poland. East German parliamentary secretariat chief Herbert Krause meanwhile told the Communist Party newspaper Neues Deutschland on Thursday that 35 parties have so far registered for the March 18 vote, although no candidate lists are available yet. Despite Modrow's great personal prestige, recent opinion polls predict East Germany's Social Democratic Party will finish first, followed by the conservative Alliance for Germany, a three-party coalition including the Christian Democratic Union as well as the Democratic Awakening group.

DOC.HEAD: First Day on Job, TA Chief Gets Lost On Subway
DOC.TEXT: Alan Kiepper wanted to start off his first day as president of the Transit Authority on the right foot. Instead, he started it on the wrong train. The new subway chief got lost on the F line and ended up in Queens Thursday morning instead of the TA's headquarters in Brooklyn. But Kiepper, 10 minutes late for a staff meeting, showed his managerial sense of direction by launching a review of train and station cleaning standards and asking his staff to brainstorm on how to speed up a station restoration program. Still, Subway Map Reading 101 might be useful. Before boarding the wrong train in Manhattan, Kiepper took time to stop and give directions to a man looking for the No. 6 train. ``I found out later I gave him the wrong directions,'' Kiepper said.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Service Fires on Man After He Parachutes Near President's Hotel
DOC.TEXT: A Secret Service agent opened fire on a sky diver who parachuted into the parking lot of President George Bush's hotel and sped away in a car, police said. Bush was staying at the Century Plaza Hotel during the Thursday morning episode that ended with the arrest of Charles Sweeney, 47, of Santa Clarita. Sweeney, arrested at his home hours after the incident, was booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon on a law officer and freed on $3,000 bail, said police Lt. Al Moen. Police and the Secret Service wouldn't comment on what motivated the sky diver. Sweeney did not immediately return a telephone call. The sky diver hopped from a 36-story building under construction near the hotel about 6 a.m., sailed across the street and landed in the hotel parking lot, Moen said. A police officer on security detail for the president's stay saw Sweeney land and alerted other officers and Secret Service agents, he said. ``The parachutist then scooped up his parachute and ran to a waiting car, which he drove in circles at a high rate of speed,'' Moen said. The driver passed near a Secret Service officer who opened fire, the lieutenant said. ``I don't know whether the car was hit or not,'' Moen said. The driver was not wounded. A police cruiser tried to seal off the lot, Moen said, but ``it soon became apparent that he was closing in on the officer at a high rate so the officer accelerated out of the way and the suspect was able to get away.'' Detectives tracked Sweeney to Santa Clarita, about 30 miles from downtown Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Clinton Seeking Fifth Term as Arkansas Governor
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clinton announced he will seek a fifth term. If successful he could become the longest-serving governor in Arkansas history. Clinton, 43, made the announcement Thursday before about 500 supporters at the Capitol rotunda. Clinton was first elected governor in 1978, lost a re-election bid to Republican Frank White in 1980 and beat White in a 1982 rematch. He was re-elected in 1984 and won a four-year term in 1986 after the gubernatorial term was changed. Education has been the cornerstone of Clinton's administrations. He has been mentioned as a possible presidential candidate. The longest serving Arkansas governor, Orval Faubus, held office for 12 years, from 1955 through 1966. Congressman Tommy Robinson and Sheffield Nelson, a lawyer and businessman, are seeking the GOP nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Execution Date For `Thin Blue Line' Witness
DOC.TEXT: The man whose recanted testimony led to the release of ``The Thin Blue Line'' defendant Randall Dale Adams has been sentenced to die by injection for an unrelated slaying. District Judge Larry Gist on Thursday set an April 3 execution date for David Ray Harris of Vidor, who first implicated then cleared Adams in the slaying of a Dallas police officer. Harris killed Mark Mays, 30, of Beaumont during a 1985 shootout after Harris allegedly attempted to kidnap a woman from the man's apartment. Harris testified he shot Mays in self-defense. The Adams case became the subject of Errol Morris' 1988 documentary ``The Thin Blue Line,'' which suggested Adams had been wrongly convicted. Adams spent 12 years in prison for the 1976 shooting death of Robert Wood before being freed last March.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies today in quiet European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the dollar is strong, largely ignoring any bad economic news and taking favorable reports as an excuse to advance further. The currency was boosted by continued weakness in the yen and the West German mark, traders said. A senior dealer at the Bank of Montreal said the dollar could weaken on expectations that the West German central bank, the Bundesbank, will intervene to keep the mark from falling too low. ``We have to be careful about the Bundesbank. It has made a policy decision that it wants a strong Deutsche mark,'' the Bank of Montreal's Mark Sexton said. Other dealers disagreed and predicted the Bundesbank would not intervene until after the East German elections March 18. ``Intervention wouldn't make any sense at this point,'' said Manfred Totzauer, a vice president at Citibank AG in Frankfurt. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.03 yen to a closing 149.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 149.90 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.7172 West German marks, up from 1.7145 _1.5067 Swiss francs, up from 1.5060 _5.8017 French francs, up from 5.7935 _1.9342 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9307 _1,266.50 Italian lire, up from 1,266 _1.1915 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1899 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6629, compared with $1.6655 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $406.50 a troy ounce, down from $407.75 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of 406.40 dollars. In Zurich, the bid price was $406.25, down from $407.75 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.02 to close at a bid $406.61. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $5.16.

DOC.HEAD: Western Ideas Banned From Chinese Journalism
DOC.TEXT: Chinese reporters will never again be allowed to disseminate Western ideas and those who try to change the socialist system will be punished, Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin said in a speech published today. Editorials, commentaries and speeches on the correct role of journalism in China have appeared regularly since the leadership cracked down on last year's massive pro-democracy movement. The full text of Jiang's speech, made Nov. 28 at a seminar organized by the party's propaganda department, took up nearly a full page in the official party newspaper, the People's Daily. The speech was the lead item in all major newspapers. There was no explanation for the delayed release of Jiang's speech, but it is not unusual for leaders' talks to be published months or even years after they were given. In the speech, Jiang reminded reporters they should serve as the ``mouthpieces'' of the party to ``give publicity ... to the party's basic line.'' From April to June, all major newspapers ran detailed, lively and accurate reports of the student-led movement for political reforms, displaying an autonomy rarely seen in Chinese journalism. The military later crushed the pro-democracy movement. Jiang accused those newspapers of being controlled by advocates of bourgeois liberalism, or Western ideas, saying they ``became tools for arousing sentiments against the party and the socialist system.'' He singled out for criticism Shanghai's World Economic Herald, China's most liberal newspaper. The paper has not been allowed to publish since May, and sources say it is being disbanded. Before the protests last spring, the paper often printed thoughtful essays on the need for political and economic reforms. Jiang warned ``from now on, newspapers, magazines, radio and television stations will never be allowed to disseminate bourgeois liberalization.'' Instead, the mass media ``must fight firmly and persistently against bourgeois liberalization.'' Journalistic activity ``aimed at altering the socialist system'' would be punished, Jiang said without elaboration. Jiang claimed there is ``no absolute and unlimited press freedom in any country,'' and argued the work environment for reporters in other countries was not much better than China. He added that Western countries have always punished journalistic activity aimed at changing the capitalist system, but did not give any examples. Jiang also called for greater party control over reporters. ``Leadership of the press should be firmly held by Marxists,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``It would be neat to be in the highest court. Even though she's a girl, I would still want to be Sandra Day O'Connor.'' _ Sixth-grader Scott Green of Blytheville, Ark., one of hundreds of students who wrote the Supreme Court to congratulate it on its 200th anniversary.

``Seabrook is the last hurrah for a crippled industry. The nuclear power industry has failed to rally support on Wall Street or Main Street.'' _ Scott Denman of the Safe Energy Communication Council, a Washington-based group, speaking about the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's licensing of the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

``Quite frankly, we are wasting everybody's time and we just look like fools,'' said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., urging the Senate to resist voting on a resolution on the baseball lockout. The senate voted 82-15 urging the lockout be resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Toothpaste Brand Switches Name To Appease Critics
DOC.TEXT: ``Darkie,'' a popular brand of toothpaste in Hong Kong, has been changed to ``Darlie'' in response to accusations the old name was racist, a company spokeswoman said today. However, the new brand, which first appeared on local counters Thursday, still has Chinese print that reads ``Black Man Toothpaste.'' Hawley and Hazel Chemical Co. Ltd. renamed the brand ``Darlie'' after the U.S.-based Colgate-Palmolive Co., which bought a 50 percent share in the company in 1985, faced pressure at home to make the change. In addition to keeping the old Chinese name, the company also continued using the brand logo of a grinning black minstrel with sparkling white teeth. Mary Kwan, spokeswoman for Hawley and Hazel, said the entire label will eventually be replaced in a further bid to improve the product's image. To many Chinese, ``the name does not carry any racist connotations,'' she said. ``We believe local customers prefer the original name as concluded from our previous intensive market research.'' A representative of the African National Congress visiting Hong Kong to discuss trade matters still expressed outrage over the product. ``If this company found itself in South Africa it would not be used,'' Eric Molobi was quoted by the English-language South China Morning Post as saying. ``There would be a permanent boycott.'' Miss Kwan predicted that the change of names would have minimal effect on sales. The brand now has a market share of more than 30 percent. The toothpaste is distributed only in Asia and already has been renamed in Taiwan, Malaysia and Singapore, she said. In 1987, the Taiwan government warned the public not to carry ``Darkie'' toothpaste abroad to avoid trouble or misunderstanding.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Okay after Getting Run Over Two Times
DOC.TEXT: Rosalie Searles may be the luckiest woman ever to have been run over by two cars in one day. Searles escaped without broken bones or other serious injuries early Thursday when she was accidentally run over, first by her husband, then by a fireman responding to the accident, state police said. Both drivers were charged with driving while intoxicated. Searles' misfortune began around 2:30 a.m. Thursday when she and her husband, Gary Searles, 37, were arguing in their car in this central New York town, according to a state police arrest report. Mrs. Searles, 30, had her passenger-side door open and somehow fell out onto the road, police said. Searles accidentally hit the gas pedal and ran over his wife's right leg. Mrs. Searles lay in the road waiting for an ambulance with police when the fireman, Eric J. Barnes, 22, drove around the police cars and ran over both of her feet. She was taken to a hospital in nearby Sidney, treated for bruises and scrapes and released, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Smokers Lose Ability To Smell With Every Passing Puff
DOC.TEXT: A smoker's sense of smell recedes with every passing puff, according to researchers at the University of Pennsylvania who conducted scratch and sniff tests. ``The majority still have a sense of smell, but not as acute as if they weren't smoking,'' said Richard Doty, director of the university's Smell and Taste Center. Both current and former smokers lose their ability to smell all kinds of odors in proportion to the amount of cigarettes and length of time they had smoked, the researchers reported today in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The researchers used the scratch and sniff tests to evaluate the ability of 638 volunteers to smell 40 different odors. Of the subjects, 262 had never smoked, 197 were ex-smokers and 179 were current smokers. In addition, 14 people said they also smoked cigars or pipes. ``A person who smoked two packs of cigarettes a day for 10 years has less of an ability to smell, on average, than someone who had smoked two packs of cigarettes for five years,'' said the report's lead author, former research associate Richard Frye. Frye is now a graduate student at Drexel University. Current smokers are nearly twice as likely to show a loss of smell than those who never smoked, according to the researchers. A medical psychologist studying the effects of smoking and nicotine called the study's results ``very intriguing.'' ``It could help explain why a lot of the old studies connected a loss in the sense of taste to smoking,'' said Neil Grunberg of the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, in Bethesda, Md. Grunberg pointed out that the sense of taste is linked to the sense of smell, and the study could shed light on what component of cigarettes affects both senses. The loss appears to be reversible, Doty said, but two-pack-a-day smokers would have to quit for as many years as they smoked to regain the essential sense, he said. ``Smell is our primary sense for detecting such environmental dangers as leaking natural gas, spoiled food and smoke,'' Doty said. ``In addition, it may be of diagnostic value for the early detection of a number of neurological disorders, including Alzheimers' disease and Parkinsonism,'' in which the diseases' victims lose some of their sense of smell. Doty said that the cause of the smell loss was not known, but he believed that a chemical in the tobacco smoke may kill nasal cells. ``The loss of the sense of smell is yet another good reason to quit smoking,'' Doty said. ``Smoking creates the possibility of losing, at least in part, the ability to appreciate flowers, good food and good wine. So, if one likes those things, one should think twice about smoking.''

DOC.HEAD: Donetsk Miners Walk Out to Press Political Demands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with strikes today, background; ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Miners in the Ukrainian coal capital of Donetsk walked off the job today to press demands that the local Communist Party leadership resign, a city official said. About 1,500 miners waving banners calling for the resignations gathered in front of party headquarters, and 24 miners announced a hunger strike until the party leaders quit, said Nikolai Ponomarenko, a regional strike committee member. The walkout followed a six-hour ``warning strike'' Thursday. Strike leaders in the city 500 miles south of Moscow said they believe the party leadership will interfere in the campaigning in the Ukraine for Sunday's multiparty elections, which also will take place in Russia and Byelorussia. They also said there is dissatisfaction that promises made after coal strikes in the region last summer are not being implemented quickly enough. Miners had demanded better living and working conditions as well as local autonomy. Yuri Smirnov, the chairman of the Donetsk city council, said on local radio that the walkout shut down two shafts and partially idled a third, an action he described as a ``political strike.'' The warning strike affected the Thursday afternoon shift at a number of mines in Donetsk, according to the TV news show ``Vremya.'' But the official news agency Tass said many miners at a strike committee meeting were reluctant to go along, saying the walkout would aggravate the grave economic situation. Ponomarenko said that at the rally outside party headquarters, city officials refused to allow the use of loudspeakers because the gathering was not approved and speeches could spark disorder. ``This is a provocation,'' Ponomarenko said in a telephone interview. ``There have never been any disorders during strikes, because miners themselves keep the discipline,'' he said. Radio Moscow said the local party committee put off consideration of the miners' demand that they resign at least until a regional party conference, scheduled April 6-7. ``The party committee spoke in favor of holding a conference next month which would be authorized the give a vote of confidence or elect new party leaders,'' the radio said. On Feb. 7, a mass rally held in Donetsk forced the resignation of the local party chief, A. Vinnik. The miners held another rally a week later to demand that the entire party leadership of Dontesk resign.

DOC.HEAD: Trials Open for Securitate Officers Accused of Shootings
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one officials of toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's hated security police faced a military court today on charges related to the deaths of as many as 1,000 people in December's uprising. The defendants are accused of either complicity in genocide or facilitating genocide _ charges arising from the shooting of unarmed demonstrators in mid-December opposed to Stalinist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. National outrage over the shooting helped spark the bloody revolution that subsequently swept Ceausescu and his followers from power and resulted in the execution of the dictator and his wife, Elena, on Dec. 25. The proceedings are the first in Timisoara, about 180 miles west of Bucharest, and the first against those suspected of trying to throttle the uprising before it spread. It follows similar trials in January in Sibiu of several police officers accused of firing on demonstrators in that city, about 120 miles northwest of the Romanian capital. Fighting was particularly fierce in Sibiu, stronghold of Ceausescu's son Nicu, who is awaiting trial on various charges. Sentences of up to 19 years were meted out there. In Bucharest, four Politburo members were convicted in January of complicity in genocide and sentenced to life in prison after they testified that they went along with the dictator's orders to fire on demonstrators. Initially, as many as 4,000 people were reported killed by Ceausescu loyalists in Timisoara, but no authoritative final count has been published. The actual figure is more likely in the hundreds, and expectations are that a final toll will be disclosed at the trial.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Leaves for Summit With Bush, Says He'll Strive To Trade Friction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Kaifu departing for U.S.; picks up 6th pvs, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu left for California today for talks with President Bush after telling Parliament he will strive to overcome Japan's chronic trade problems with the United States. In his first speech to Parliament since his re-election as prime minister, Kaifu said Japanese efforts to create a new international ``age of hope'' will be based on ``firm relations of cooperation'' between Tokyo and Washington. ``The solution of the trade and economic issues between Japan and the United States is one of the main policy issues facing Japan today,'' Kaifu said. He said talks between the two nations on causes of their trade imbalance were ``an urgent and important issue.'' The talks ``are intended to improve the Japanese standard of living and to strengthen America's competitiveness,'' he said. ``I intend to make every possible effort for progress in these talks.'' Hours after delivering the speech, Kaifu left Tokyo on a special flight for Los Angeles. Although Kaifu and Bush have agreed not to set a specific agenda for their talks later today and Saturday in Palm Springs, the trade issue is expected to be a major topic. The United States is pressing Japan to restructure fundamentals of its economy, including its convoluted distribution system, high savings and investment rate, and land use policies, which Washington claims are protectionist. Two days of talks last week ended with negotiators doing little more than agreeing to disagree, and on Thursday Democrats in the U.S. Congress urged Bush to take a hard line against Japanese trade barriers. The $49 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan last year was little changed from $51.8 billion in 1988. Kaifu indicated a willingness to compromise. ``I intend to work for streamlined distribution, strict enforcement of the anti-monopoly law, import promotion ... and other improvements,'' he said. Kaifu said Wednesday that he also hoped to discuss with Bush issues such as the environment, the drug and international debt problems, and technology transfer to the Third World. He was to leave Japan by special jet this evening. In elections Feb. 18 for the powerful House of Representatives, or lower house, Kaifu led the governing Liberal Democratic Party to a majority. Governing party politicians said the victory, following the Liberal Democrats' disastrous showing in upper house elections last year in the wake of a series of bribery scandals, was a public vindication of the party. Kaifu, who was vaulted from obscurity to the premiership six months ago to lead the party out of its scandals, pledged to continue reforming politics.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Hears Arguments on Tobacco Ads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Fishel's first name to Dave sted Dan in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A legislator contends that R.J. Reynolds is using a T-shirt promotion to hook youngsters on cigarettes, a charge the tobacco company denies. ``I'm 41 and I wear T-shirts,'' R.J. Reynolds spokesman Dave Fishel said in a telephone interview from Winston-Salem, N.C. Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., attacked the company's T-shirt promotion Thursday at an Energy and Commerce subcommittee on transportation and hazardous materials hearing on a bill to restrict tobacco advertising. ``I contend that when you give away T-shirts you are targeting children, not targeting adults,'' Slattery said, adding that to deny that youngsters are being targeted ``is an insult to people's intelligence.'' Slattery was referring to an R.J. Reynolds campaign that offers free T-shirts with a cartoon version of the longtime Camel cigarette mascot, ``Old Joe.'' Opponents of the bill to restrict advertising argue that the campaign against so-called ``targeted advertising'' is an elitist and patronizing affront to the judgment of those being targeted, including blacks, Hispanics and women. Recent marketing documents surrounding a new R.J. Reynolds brand talked about targeting the ``Dakota'' cigarette to so-called ``virile females,'' young white women who watch television sitcoms and go to tractor pulls. Rep. Alex McMillan, R-N.C., criticized anti-smoking advocates who say target groups ``are victims and that these people do not have the intelligence or wisdom to make their own decision whether or not to smoke.'' ``You don't hear cries of outrage over housewives being targeted by detergent makers or yuppies being exploited by exposure to American Express commercials,'' said Tino Duran, president of the National Association of Hispanic Publications. ``Why is that? Because, unlike Hispanics, nobody would dare suggest that those people need to be `protected' from advertising.'' Duran said many Hispanic publications would collapse if the government bans tobacco and alcohol advertising. Anti-smoking advocates say the tobacco industry is preying on Hispanics, blacks, women and youngsters to make up for the lost market from people who quit smoking. Under the Reynolds promotions, people may call a toll-free number for the ``Old Joe'' T-shirt. Those who call later receive a brochure in the mail offering them free cigarettes. Fishel denied that minors were taking advantage of the promotion and said that parents must bear some responsibility in keeping their children from doing so. Slattery displayed a brochure that was sent to a 14-year-old boy who had ordered the T-shirt. The boy's mother, contacted by The Associated Press, said she found the offer when she sorted the mail. The brochure offered free packs of cigarettes, but required signature on a card stating that the person placing the order smokes and is over 21. ``My son knows of at least four kids who received the coupons other than him,'' said the woman, who spoke on the condition she not be identified by name. She said she was particularly upset because her father recently died from emphysema, blamed on years of smoking. Fishel said company records indicated that the boy had given his age as 24 and said he smoked Marlboro Lights. ``We don't want kids on our mailing list,'' Fishel said. ``Anytime anybody has complained about something like this, the name automatically comes off the mailing list.'' The legislation sponsored by Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio, would limit tobacco print advertising to text, ban advertising directed at minors and restrict tobacco advertising on billboards.

DOC.HEAD: Man Under Investigation in Judge Bombing Files Contempt Motion Against Media
DOC.TEXT: A man under investigation for two mail bomb deaths in December is asking the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to find news organizations in contempt of a court-imposed gag order. Details of the request were unclear because the attorneys representing the man, Walter Leroy Moody Jr., of Clayton County, refused to give lawyers for the news organizations copies of the contempt motion. Moody's attorneys, who obtained the gag order last month, also refuse to comment on any aspect of the case. Terry Adamson, attorney for The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and WSB-TV, said he received a letter Thursday notifying him that a contempt motion had been filed, but it did not give any details. ``Any suggestion that we or our clients have violated any court order is sadly ludicrous and patently frivolous,'' said Adamson, who has appealed the order sealing records and barring official comment on the Moody case. Meanwhile, the White House confirmed that Moody has written to President Bush about the investigation. Cheryl Kienel of the White House media relations office said a letter from Moody was received Feb. 23. ``We had received guidance from the FBI if we received any correspondence from Mr. Moody we should forward it to them, which we did,'' Ms. Kienel said. Bruce Harvey, one of Moody's attorneys, declined to discuss the letter beyond saying, ``It involves the investigation.'' Moody is one of three men in Georgia and Alabama whose properties have been searched in the bomb investigation. Federal agents have been working since mid-December to solve a series of bombings, two of which claimed the lives of 11th Circuit Judge Robert Vance and Savannah lawyer Robert Robinson. The judges of the 11th Circuit have removed themselves from hearing matters related to the Moody case and the bombing investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasting Gauge Flat in January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files
DOC.TEXT: The government's chief economic forecasting gauge was flat in January, the Commerce Department said today in a further indication that the economy's current sluggishness will extend into midyear. The lack of change in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, followed a revised 0.6 percent gain in December and a 0.1 percent advance in November. The index fell 0.4 percent in October. Many economists had expected a slight increase in the January index. Three of the 11 forward-looking statistics contributed to the gain, led by a sharp increase in building permits during the warmest January on record. Others showing strength were slower business delivery times and an increase in the backlog of manufacturers' unfilled orders. The biggest drag on the index in January was a decline in orders for consumer goods. Other negatives were a drop in the money supply, a decline in plant and equipment orders, lower stock prices, a decrease in the price of raw materials, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence and an increase in weekly unemployment claims. One indicator, the length of the average work week, was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 145.3 percent of its 1982 base of 100. The index rose 0.8 percent from August through January after falling 0.7 percent the previous six months. The December index orginally was reported to have risen 0.8 percent, but was revised downward to 0.6 percent, largely because of lower orders for consumer goods. Despite the sluggishness, recent surveys indicate that business executives and economists generally believe the Federal Reserve is driving the economy down the right road, steering it away from a recession while braking the growth of inflation. Seventy-two percent of the professional forecasters responding to a poll by the National Association of Business Economists said the central bank was on the right track. And 56 percent of the business leaders participating in a survey by the National Association of Manufacturers said Fed policies are ``just about right.'' But most of the business leaders and economists surveyed project continued sluggish growth in 1990 as the Fed keeps interest rates relatively high to slow the economy and keep prices under control. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan told Congress this week that the economy would avoid a recession, although it would grow only at a modest annual rate of 1.75 percent to 2 percent this year. But he added: ``Whenever you have economic growth as low as this, you are vulnerable.'' Greenspan was referring to the latest report on the gross national product, released Wednesday, that showed the economy slowing in the fourth quarter of 1989 to a 0.9 percent growth rate, down from 3 percent in the third quarter. In the opposite lane is a minority of economists who believe the economy is about to cross into negative growth _ if it isn't already there. Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Association in West Chester, Pa., said the economic slowdown has not passed and ``we may be just in the middle of it. ... The question is whether the weakness in manufacturing will spread to other sectors of the economy.'' Nevertheless, the two surveys completed last month showed guarded optimism. The business economists poll found that 60.6 percent of the forecasters thought the economy, while in a ``danger zone,'' would avoid a recession during the next three years. The manufacturers' survey found that 82 percent of the executives questioned saw sluggish growth but no recession in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Offices, Ministries Close as Police Fire Tear Gas at Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: President's name is pronounced Hoof-WAY Bwa-NEE
DOC.TEXT: Police today fired tear gas and turned fire engine hoses on hundreds of young student protesters who demanded that President Felix Houphouet-Boigny resign. Businesses closed and government employees stopped work. Streams of workers left government ministries, although some said they were merely leaving to collect their children from schools closed by demonstrators. Protesters are angered by harsh austerity measures proposed to rescue this once-prosperous West African nation from the worst economic crisis in its 30 years of independence. Armed soldiers and paramilitary police patrolled the city and suburbs. In some areas of the city center, business continued as usual, and sidewalks were filled with vendors. In downtown Abidjan, police hurled and fired tear gas grenades at more than 100 protesters who shouted: ``Houphouet, we are fed up _ resign!'' They chased fleeing protesters and beat them with batons. Reporters watched half a dozen paramilitary forces fire tear gas at hundreds of uniformed high school pupils protesting outside the offices of Fraternite Matin, the state-controlled newspaper that has not reported on the protests that began Feb. 19. The pupils fled in the direction of Adjame, the capital's most-populous district. Troops and police sealed off the district of middle-class and working-class neighborhoods that houses the capital's biggest outdoor market, and turned away all traffic. At the campus of the National University of Ivory Coast, in the luxury Cocody suburb, a dozen paramilitary forces periodically fired tear gas at about 500 unarmed students. Each time the students regrouped, the helmeted troops opened fire, preventing them from marching into downtown Abidjan. Trucks of armed troops and police guarded the presidential palace and the state television station, both near the Cocody campus. More paramilitary forces were posted around the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Paul's, which 200 students occupied for 10 hours Feb. 23-24 in the most dramatic of the protests. They were beaten and detained for two days when they peacefully ended their protest. Police also beat and briefly detained a priest who accompanied the students to guarantee their safety. Their action angered Catholic Church officials who negotiated the detainees' release. Amnesty International, the London-based human rights group, today denounced the police action and said students were beaten for merely pressing political demands. Militant students said they were not satisfied by a government response to their lesser demands this week. The government halved costs of university board and lodging and named a new education minister. But Houphouet-Boigny has rejected demands for a multiparty democracy, which he argues would endanger national unity in a country still wrought by tribal rivalries. The president also is fighting unexpected opposition from trade union leaders angered by plans to cut government employees' salaries, frozen for eight years, by between 15 percent and 40 percent as well as impose a 10 percent solidarity tax on all wage earners. Houphouet-Boigny has postponed a meeting to discuss the proposals from today until Monday. The Ivory Coast economy is suffering the cumulative effects of a 10-year recession caused by slumping cocoa and coffee prices, its main exports. Salary cuts, unemployment and inflation have brougth mounting discontent among the nation's 11 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Havana Considering Reforms, But Won't End One-Party Rule, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES references to exporting revolution from overline and lede. Pickup 2nd pvs, ``Rolando Rodriguez...''
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban Foreign Ministry adviser says Fidel Castro's Communist government is considering political and economic reforms but will not veer away from one-party rule. Rolando Rodriguez Garcia also said Thursday that the electoral defeat four days earlier of the leftist Sandinistas in Nicaragua _ a longtime ally _ does not mean the end of the revolution there. ``It is not a bankruptcy,'' the official told a news conference at the Cuban Embassy. ``It is only a bitter blow, a transitory setback.'' Rodriguez said Cuba is ``in solidarity with all the revolutions of the world. Cuba is not alone. We continue to have many friends at our side.'' He said the Caribbean island nation, led by Castro since a revolution in 1959, began to undergo changes before Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for perestroika ignited changes in other socialist countries. ``We undertook transformation before perestroika,'' he said. He said restructuring began in the 1960s after Cuba found social systems it copied did not work. At the Cuban Communist Party's third congress in 1985, the country's system underwent ``an exhaustive analysis,'' and a fourth congress planned for next year will continue to review Cuba's socialist trajectory, he said. ``We are not perfect. We have various problems. We are the first to say we have defects,'' he said. Recent installation of young leaders in high government posts is ``a guarantee that they will continue transforming,'' he said without elaboration. Still, he maintained that Cuba is not contemplating doing away with its one-party system. ``We are are going to maintain our unity through one single party,'' Rodriguez said.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Region Leader Reports `Hot Spots' in China
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party secretary in a sensitive minority region said there are many ``hot spots'' of unrest in the area that could blow up if not resolved quickly, according to a report seen in Beijing today. Song Hanliang, the top party official in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region in China's far northwest, made his remarks after touring portions of Xinjiang near the border with Soviet Kazakhstan and Kirgizia. ``Every place and every work unit now has some problems with hot spots,'' Saturday's Xinjiang Daily quoted Song as saying in his report Feb. 23. The newspaper arrives in Beijing one week late. ``Although they are only `contradictions among the people,' if they are not paid attention to and resolved ... They can become the fuse of an outburst,'' he said. In Marxist ideology, a contradiction among the people is less serious than one between the people and an enemy class, such as landlords or the bourgeoisie. ``We must ... Handle the problem while it is still in the embryonic stage,'' he said. The newspaper did not explain what ``hot spots'' or problems Song was referring to. His statement was the clearest indication yet that longstanding ethnic tensions in Xinjiang have resurfaced recently in unrest. Xinjiang is home to several Central Asian ethnic minorities, including the Uygurs and Kirgiz, many of whom are devout Moslems. They are closely related to groups living across the border in the Soviet Union, which has seen several bloody outbursts of ethnic rivalry in recent months. Soviet Kazakhstan and Kirgizia, just west of Xinjiang, have been quiet. Chinese authorities have refused to comment on the possible impact of the Soviet unrest on China's minorities but have markedly stepped up public calls for ethnic unity. Xinjiang officials also have held special meetings to discuss the problem, and ordered police to improve their anti-riot training and intelligence work among minority groups. Earlier this week, police in Xinjiang expelled a French television reporter and her French translator for allegedly conducting interviews without permission, reflecting the sensitivity of officials in the region to visits by outsiders. ``In regard to the possible appearance of disturbances this year, it is better to over-estimate a little and absolutely not relax vigilance or be off our guard,'' Song said in his Feb. 23 remarks to top party and government officials in Xinjiang. He also called for tighter supervision of religion, to ``stop up loopholes, remove hidden perils and not allow religious activities or religious places to be used ... For separatist activities.'' Religion is a key element of the traditional cultures of many minority groups, including the Uygurs, and nationalist protests in the past often have taken on a religious tinge. During the last confirmed unrest in Xinjiang in May, young Moslems stormed government offices to protest a book they said slandered Islam. An alleged leader of the protest was sentenced to life in prison, and nine other participants to lesser terms.

DOC.HEAD: Moslems Protest Shooting of Separatist Demonstrators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 3rd, `Witnesses contacted...' to ADD description of the death shrouds. Pickup 4th, `The police...'
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 Moslems wearing death shrouds tried to march to Srinagar today, one day after troops opened fire on pro-independence rallies in Kashmir and killed at least 49 Moslems, police said. A senior police official said that police deployed to enforce a curfew blocked the march in Sumbal, 15 miles north of Srinagar. ``They were forced to return back,'' said the officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Witnesses contacted by telephone said the demonstrators wore the shrouds to symbolize their willingness to sacrifice their lives for the movement demanding independence for Kashmir, a Moslem-dominated region of India. The shrouds are the large swatches of material in which the corpses of Moslems traditionally are draped before burial. Only the protesters' heads were visible through holes cut in the fabric that flowed down to their ankles. The police officer said at least 49 people were killed and between 45 and 100 were injured Thursday when Indian forces fired on two separate processions marching toward Srinagar, demanding secession from predominantly Hindu India. In both cases, some marchers tried to seize guns from soldiers and paramilitary police and the troops opened fire, according to witnesses who spoke on condition of anonymity. An estimated 1 million people participated in Thursday's demonstrations in Srinagar. A curfew confining people to their homes was imposed at 4 a.m. today in Srinagar and other towns in the northern Kashmir Valley. The government in neighboring Pakistan, which is mainly Moslem and has fought two wars with India over Kashmir, today condemned the killings as ``wanton shooting by Indian security forces.'' Pakistan's official news agency said the shootings were a ``brutal Indian response ... to the people of Kashmir, who were asking only for their right of self-determination, a right assured them by the Untied Nations.'' By this morning, the streets of Srinagar, a city of nearly 1 million people, were deserted except for heavily armed army and paramilitary police, other witnesses said, also speaking on condition of anonymity. The loudspeakers on mosques, which often blare Islamic and pro-independence slogans, were quiet at midmorning today, the Moslem weekly holy day, which is often a flashpoint for trouble. Thursday's shootings brought to at least 162 the number of people killed in Kashmir's latest bout of secessionist violence that began Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on the militants. One person died when he fell to his death in a cold lake while troops chased protesters, the officer said. Also Thursday, Pushker Nath Handoo, an assistant director of the Jammu-Kashmir state information department, was assassinated in Srinagar. Handoo, a Hindu, in 1986 was the private secretary to Jammu-Kashmir Gov. Jagmohan during Jagmohan's first term as governor of the northwestern state. Jagmohan, who uses only one name, was reappointed governor in January. Big pro-independence processions have been staged around Srinagar for the past week, with crowd estimates ranging from 20,000 to 400,000. But those processions were generally orderly, and witnesses said the leaders seemed to be trying to keep their followers from provoking government troops. The Kashmir issue has been simmering for more than four decades, following Britain's 1947 partition of its former colony into India and Pakistan. The division left the former princely state of Kashmir in dispute. Srinagar and the surrounding Kashmir Valley became part of the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir. The western slice of Kashmir came under Pakistan's control. The two nations have gone to war three times since partition, twice over Kashmir. Pakistan has denied Indian charges that it is inciting the unrest. The Kashmir portion of Jammu-Kashmir state is mostly Moslem, while the southern Jammu segment is heavily Hindu. About 65 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslems, who nationwide make up only 12 percent of India's population. Hindus account for 82 percent of the 880 milion Indian citizens.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Chairman Says Drexel Situation Does Not Indicate Unsound Markets
DOC.TEXT: The slide of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. into bankruptcy court is not an indication that U.S. securities markets are unsound, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. ``Drexel was uniquely concentrated among large securities firms in high-yield securities and that concentration proved to be fatal when these securities became unmarketable and unpledgeable,'' Chairman Richard C. Breeden told a Senate hearing. Drexel's insolvency ``should not be taken as an indication that U.S. securities markets, or other major participants in those markets are financially unsound,'' he testified before the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee. Breedon noted that Drexel's $28 billion business has been reduced by about 75 percent since its parent company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, filed for bankruptcy protection, ``and the public was not called upon to pay the creditors of Drexel's unregulated operations.'' He called for passage of a market-reform act which would give federal regulators information on the holding companies of securities firms such as Drexel which are not now subject to government oversight. Such legislation, he said, would go a long way toward preventing situations similar to Drexel's. Sen. Donald W. Riegle, Jr., chairman of the Senate committee, has said he wants to know what lessons can be learned from Drexel's situation and whether it calls for regulation of the funds flowing between a broker-dealer and its parent company. On Thursday, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told another congressional committee that Wall Street's ho-hum reaction to Drexel's collapse showed regulators were right to let the securities firm fail. ``Our concern was not with the fortunes of a particular firm'' but with ``the orderly operation of the financial markets,'' Greenspan said. Drexel, once the fifth-largest securities company in the nation, sought bankruptcy protection in the wake of a sharp drop in the value of its high-yield, high-risk junk bond portfolio and its admission of securities law violations in a plea bargain with federal prosecutors. Its parent company sought court protection from creditors under the federal bankruptcy law on Feb. 13 after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt. It has listed more than 2,000 creditors and nearly $3 billion in liabilities. Despite Drexel's once towering position on Wall Street, the stock market took its troubles in stride. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell 29.06 points to 2624.10 on Feb. 12, the day Drexel announced its distress. It rose 4.96 points the following day, when Drexel's parent filed for bankruptcy. ``This market reaction tends to validate the judgment that the failure of Drexel, while a tragedy for the many involved, did not present undue risks to the orderly functioning of the financial system or the economy,'' said Greenspan in testimony before the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on economic and commercial law.

DOC.HEAD: Israel to Censor Soviet Immigration Figures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th pvs, `An announcement...' to UPDATE with reaction from Foreign Press Association. Pickup 5th, `Maariv said...'
DOC.TEXT: In a change of policy, the government says monthly Soviet immigration figures must now be submitted to Israel's military censor prior to publication in the media. The release of such figures in the past has led to mounting Arab protests over the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel. The Associated Press was not allowed to report the new restriction when it was imposed Thursday, but that order was lifted today after the daily Maariv carried a story on the new censorship procedure on its front page. An announcement from the censor's office said today that ``all material pertaining to immigration of Soviet Jews must be submitted to the censor prior to publication.'' The censors are not expected to release the data, so the screening process is expected to amount to a ban. Previously, the media reported the figures without checking with the censor first. Robert Slater, the head of the Foreign Press Association in Israel, said the new procedure was pointless because the immigration story has already been reported in great detail. ``We are extremely disappointed at the use of military censorship for political purposes,'' Slater said. Maariv said the move was recommended by senior government officials and approved by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. A Shamir aide, however, said it had ``nothing to do with the prime minister.'' The newspaper said the government acted after a government official estimated this week that up to 230,000 Soviet Jews are expected to immigrate this year, as opposed to previous estimates of 80,000 to 100,000. The new estimate was made by Yasha Kazakov, deputy head of the Liaison Bureau, a once-secret government unit that deals with Soviet immigration, Israeli media reports said. Maariv said the figure ``created panic in the Arab countries, and the protests coming from these countries endanger immigration.'' Shamir's top aide Yossi Ben-Aharon agreed, saying: ``There is so much talk of numbers and forecasts that it caused damage. Why say 230,000 or whatever?'' Ben-Aharon, interviewed Thursday night, said he was not aware of any order to the censor but added: ``I know there is a campaign by all the Arab world against the immigration, so what's the wonder.'' The latest immigration surge began last year, when 12,000 Soviet Jews came to Israel. In January 1990, 4,700 Soviet Jews immigrated. Israeli leaders have said they expect up to 750,000 this decade. The Hebrew-language daily Davar reported today that 5,500 Soviet Jews arrived in Israel during February. Concern in the Arab world arose after Shamir suggested that Israel needed to retain the occupied lands to settle the immigrants. Israel has denied that it would direct the flow of immigrants to the occupied lands, where some 200 Soviet Jews settled in 1989, but Arab leaders view even mass immigration to Israel proper as a grave threat. Western nations and the United States have strongly opposed any plan to settle the Soviet immigrants in the occupied lands. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said on Thursday that Israel's request for U.S. aid for Soviet immigrants should be linked to a pledge to suspend all Jewish settlements in the occupied territories. Bassam Abu-Sharif, a top adviser to PLO chief Yasser Arafat, told reporters Feb. 21 in Tunis that the movement of immigrants to disputed lands was ``an act of war against the Palestinian people and the Arab nation.'' ``Such an act can only cause similar action on our part, that is to say acts of war,'' Abu-Sharif said. On Feb. 23, Israeli newspapers warned of a possibility that Arab guerrillas could target immigrants for a retaliatory attack. The Jerusalem Post daily quoted a ``reliable'' source as saying Israel had stepped up security for immigrants because of these fears.

DOC.HEAD: Anderson's Sister Returns to United States Buoyed But Weary
DOC.TEXT: The sister of hostage Terry Anderson says a 2{-week trip on behalf of her brother has left her cautiously optimistic _ something three previous journeys failed to do. ``That isn't to say my optimism means there's going to be a release today or next week or next month,'' an exhausted Peggy Say said Thursday shortly after stepping off a plane from Zurich at John F. Kennedy International Airport. ``I think we all hope this will be resolved soon for all of them,'' Mrs. Say said. She was referring to 18 Western hostages missing in Lebanon _ eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held of the hostages. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Since then, Mrs. Say has traveled four times to the Middle East and worked relentlessly on behalf of the hostages. But she said this trip, which included meetings with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Pope John Paul II and Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat, was the first to leave her hopeful. She traveled with a delegation from the AP to the Middle East, Europe and Africa. She has said her optimism stems partly from reassurances by U.S. officials that they are doing all they can, and partly from statements from Iran, recent changes in nations around the globe and pledges that the Syrians want to help. ``The Syrian commitment is 100 percent,'' she said. NBC News on Thursday quoted a senior administration official it did not identify saying that Syria's foreign minister will travel to Iran in a few days to press for the hostages' release. Say's comments and the NBC report came even as President Bush called ``ridiculous'' news reports saying there was movement in the hostage situation. ``I hope the hostages will be released. If I see an opportunity for talks in private or in public about this to get them released, I'll do it,'' he said as he left his hotel to visit a new Los Angeles County jail. As to how she believed U.S. officials were working toward a solution, Mrs. Say said, ``I assume they're talking as they always have done through third parties.'' She added: ``I was reassured that my government is doing what it should be doing in a positive way to bring this to an end.'' She said she was confident that when the hostages are released it will be ``without conditions. There will be no ransom.'' Mrs. Say was accompanied on her trip by Larry Heinzerling, deputy director of World Services for the AP, which supports her efforts financially and logistically while pressing its own efforts for Anderson's freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes Mourned at Park Avenue Service
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Scottish bagpipes, English horns and ``The Battle Hymn of the Republic'' set an appropriately unconventional tone as relatives, celebrities and Hell's Angels bid farewell to millionaire publisher Malcolm Forbes. ``He was so many things to so many of us,'' said Forbes's son, Robert. ``Boss, bon vivant, raconteur, balloonist, columnist, happiest millionaire, leader of the pack ... source, mentor, friend, super this, mega that, father, grandfather, father-in-law, uncle, cousin and sparkling, naughty boy.'' Former President Nixon, actress Elizabeth Taylor and motorcyclists were among 1,700 mourners who gathered at Thursday's memorial service. Forbes, 70, who died of a heart attack Saturday at his 40-acre estate in Far Hills, N.J., also was eulogized by his other children: Timothy, Christopher, Malcolm Jr. and Moira Forbes Mumma. Nixon sat in a front pew next to Miss Taylor, who was a frequent companion of Forbes; next to them were Nixon's daughter, Tricia Cox, and former Mayor Edward I. Koch. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca, entrepreneur-daredevil Rocky Aoki, Barbara Walters, Joan Rivers, David Rockefeller, Ann Landers and Mrs. Douglas MacArthur also were present. Amid tears, the mourners smiled at their memories. ``He loved to laugh and to make people laugh _ a gift that is one of life's most magic spices,'' said Robert Forbes. Forbes, whose worth was estimated at $400 million to $1 billion, enjoyed his fortune by owning 68 motorcycles and globe-trotting with royalty and celebrities aboard his gold-fixtured, helicopter-equipped yacht. He celebrated his birthday last September with a celebrity-studded, $2 million party in Morocco. He made the first free flight in a hot air balloon over Beijing _ after the Chinese government denied permission, Timothy Forbes recalled. ``It landed about 20 minutes later _ smack in the middle of a Red Army base.'' ``A balloon is not meant to be tied down. It's meant to be free, to float with the wind,'' his father explained later. ``You see, for Pop, a balloon was _ and is _ an apt symbol of the human spirit,'' Timothy said. At the landmark, Byzantine-style St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue, worshipers sang ``The Battle Hymn of the Republic,'' the words copied from Julia Ward Howe's original manuscript in the Forbes collection. The Scottish bagpipes and English horns _ the latter played by eight French musicians in red and black hunter's costumes _ were mixed with traditional songs from a white-robed choir. ``If you and your siblings had had to go to church every Sunday dressed in kilts, with your friends snickering ... you could begin to understand why all of us are so close,'' Christopher said. Forbes had directed that his body be cremated and the ashes interred on Lauthala, his South Pacific island. He asked for this inscription on his tombstone: ``While alive, he lived.'' ``It's been a hell of a party, Pop, my special friend, and such fun,'' said Robert. ``Thanks for the trip.''

DOC.HEAD: Christians Object to Restaurant's Buddha Statue as `False God'
DOC.TEXT: An 8-foot, gold-colored statue of Buddha outside a Chinese restaurant represents a ``false god'' and should be removed, says a woman who complained to town officials and drafted a petition. Eleven Harford County residents signed the demand for the statue's removal, but San Lin Garden restaurant owner Yu-Pin Cass says Buddha is staying. ``I'm really disappointed,'' she said. ``This has nothing to do with religion. I wanted something to stand out for my business.'' Nancy J. Collins of nearby Aberdeen, who describes herself as a ``Bible-believer,'' wrote town officials last week to complain about the statue. ``A false god should not be thrust upon the public on the edge of a national highway,'' Collins said.
