The smiling Buddha figure, with its robes open to display a round belly, overlooks U.S. 40 in this city about 30 miles northeast of Baltimore. ``All of my customers love it. I've got all these compliments. People love the Buddha,'' Cass said. ``That's what's so great about America. It doesn't matter if you're a Catholic, a Buddhist or what. I will not move it.'' Havre de Grace code inspector Clovis R. Bolen said the presence of the 1,000-pound fiberglass Buddha does not violate any city regulation. ``We have no law against it,'' Bolen said. ``I'm a Christian, too. But it's an ornament she put in her yard for business purposes.'' Cass, who was born in Taiwan into the Buddhist faith, said the flap reminded her of what she learned when studying the Bill of Rights for her U.S. citizenship test. ``It says freedom of religion and freedom of speech,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Reported Case Number Approaching Quarter Million Mark Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization said today that 7,596 new cases of AIDS were reported last month, raising the total by 3.5 percent to 222,740 cases listed worldwide since registration began in 1979. The United States continued to account for more than half of the global figure, with the number of cases up 3.3 percent in one month from 117,781 to 121,645. Zimbabwe, updating a 3-month-old report, listed one of the sharpest upward trends, with a new total of 1,632, a 42 percent increase. Australia reported its number went up 7.3 percent in one month to 1,707, while Canada listed a 6.9 percent increase to 3,509. Updates were lacking from most African countries with some, including Zaire, Congo, and the Central African Republic, not having filed new reports for more than a year. In Europe, France reported a total of 8,883 cases, 10 percent more since the end of September. During the same period, the number of Spanish cases went up by 16.8 percent to 4,633. Spain thus replaced West Germany as the European country with the third-largest total, trailing Italy which has not yet updated its latest list of 5,307 cases. West Germany, with a case number up 2.8 percent in one month to 4,433, and Britain, up 1.8 percent to 2,830, were among European countries reporting below-average increases. The situation in Asia, the region with the lowest reported incidence rate, remained largely unchanged. Japan was the lone exception, reporting 182 cases by Dec. 31, 1989, a 68.5 percent increase in three months. The World Health Organization estimates that the actual accumulated total of AIDS cases may be as high as 600,000, including about 300,000 fatalities. The director of the WHO's AIDS program, Dr. Jonathan Mann, has predicted that the case total may reach 6 million by the year 2000 and has warned that even this estimate may be too low if infection with the AIDS virus accelerates.

DOC.HEAD: Research Council Gives Qualified OK to NASA Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS year in 6th graf, Putting a, to 1995 sted 1955
DOC.TEXT: NASA's plan to establish a base on the moon and launch expeditions to Mars appears reasonable, but other strategies should also be studied, the National Research Council said today. President Bush endorsed the basic elements of the plan in a speech last July 20, marking the 20th anniversary of the landing on the moon of American astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin. The proposal called for a base, to be established early in the next century, that would have a full-time, long-term staff. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's strategy calls for frequent flights to the moon and construction there of living quarters, laboratories and power stations. The lunar soil would be mined to extract oxygen, which then could be turned into rocket fuel. Bush outlined no details in his proposal and said he was leaving it up to NASA and to Vice President Dan Quayle, as head of the National Space Council, to come up with timetables. Putting a space station in orbit has already been scheduled for after 1995. NASA scientists say a moon base would be a laboratory for a voyage to Mars. Bu others have questioned this, saying the moon is not sufficiently like Mars and that establishing the moon base would delay the Mars exploration. The National Research Council, an arm of the congressional chartered National Academy of Sciences, was asked by Quayle to evaluate NASA's strategy for the Mars exploration. David Beckwith, the vice president's press secretary, said, ``It's a very interesting report, and we are pleased and grateful.'' ``The NASA report addresses a reasonable set of technological and strategic approaches, but not all of the technically credible approaches have been analyzed,'' the council said. It said any program for exploring the moon and Mars ``must incorporate ideas from a variety of concepts, some that now exist and others that will arise in the future.'' ``Certainly more intense scrutiny and evaluation of the options must take place before decisions are made regarding mission architecture,'' said H. Guyford Stever, who chaired a 14-member committee named by the council to perform the study. ``This is an initial discussion to offer direction for helping the program get under way,'' said Stever, a former presidential science adviser. The committee said that, although NASA does not discuss eventual phaseout of the space shuttle in its report on its 90-day study of moon-Mars exploration, the shuttle fleet will have to be replaced. ``Continued access of humans to space will require that planning begin soon for a new transportation system that will first supplement and then assume the shuttle's role ... sometime between 2000 and 2010,'' the committee said. The panel disagreed with the contention of scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory that humans could be placed on Mars by the year 2000. It said that ``underestimates the many practical and difficult engineering and operational challenges involved.'' The NASA plan calls for placing humans on the moon in 2001 and on Mars by 2011 at the earliest. The Research Council study said even those dates depend on accelerating completion of the planned space station, which could result in higher risks and costs. In addition to replacing the space shuttle, a new generation of launch vehicles will be needed to lift massive equipment into lower-Earth orbit, the committee said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lifts Ban on Visitors for Detained Vermont Woman
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today ruled that an American held in solitary confinement in a hospital room for the past five weeks should be allowed to meet friends and attorneys of her choice, news reports said. Patricia Munday, 39, is being treated under police guard at a Calcutta hospital for injuries sustained when she was attacked by villagers in Purulia, near Calcutta. Ms. Munday, who was part of a United Nations team that won the 1981 Nobel Peace Prize, is being held for links with a mysterious Hindu cult called the Ananda Marg, or the Path of Bliss, which is based in the Purulia district. Membership in the cult is not a criminal offense, but police are deeply suspicious of the order, claiming it practices black magic. Ms. Munday has not been charged. The Supreme Court order said Ms. Munday, who is from Waitsfield, Vt., could see friends and attorneys, but a policeman would be present during the meetings, according to the Press Trust of India. Arguments on the legality of her detention have been set for March 16. In Calcutta, a prominent politican who unsuccessfully attempted to visit Ms. Munday on Thursday called her detention ``inhuman and uncivilized.'' Mamta Banerjee, a member of the opposition Congress Party, said West Bengal state officials ``cried themselves hoarse for Nelson Mandela. But what are they doing to this helpless foreign lady? She will go mad in this condition.'' Miss Banerjee, who said she visited the Belle Vue Nursing Home in an attempt to meet Ms. Munday, said she saw the American woman briefly before police pushed Miss Banerjee away from the door of the hospital room. ``I raised my voice and told her that I would like to offer any help that she might need,'' Miss Banerjee said. ``She thanked me.'' West Bengal state, of which Calcutta is the capital, is ruled by the Communist Party of India-Marxist, which in the past has often clashed with followers of Ananda Marg. Ms. Munday, who was a member of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees team that won the Nobel Peace Prize for its work in Somalia, arrived in India from Nepal on a private visit. Villagers attacked her and a female companion when they were traveling in the Purulia district on Jan. 26. Ms. Munday suffered a gash on her forehead and was arrested when she tried to lodge a complaint about the attack. Ananda Marg is a secretive cult which claims to have branches around the world. Little information about the group's activities is available because members are bound by an oath of secrecy. Indian newspapers have said the group uses skulls and daggers in its ritualistic dances. The group says it wants to create a social, economic and spiritual order that will replace both capitalism and communism and rid society of sectarianism and parochialism.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Late, Man Shoots at Postman, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: A man who waited five hours on his front porch for his Social Security check opened fire on the postman with a shotgun when the mail finally arrived, authorities say. Gerald Pawloski, 42, wounded a substitute mail carrier and at least three other people in the assault Thursday, police said. He was scheduled for arraignment late today in Grand Rapids District Court on four counts of assault with intent to murder, Police Chief William Hegarty said. ``I would not think of those shots as being random,'' Hegarty said. Mail carrier Kenneth Peek was listed in fair condition today at Butterworth Hospital, hospital spokesman Tim Bulson said. At least one pedestrian and two passing motorists were hit by pellets but not seriously injured, police said. Pawloski, forced out of his house by tear gas, surrendered to police about 8:30 p.m. after a five-hour siege. Hegarty had made a television appeal to Pawloski, saying police would solve problems he had with his Social Security check. Rose Sheck, who managed the apartment building where Pawloski lived for six years, said he had been awaiting his Social Security check. ``On check day he'd always be out on the front porch waiting for it,'' she said. Neighbor Alan Peckham said he was walking down the street when he heard shots. ``He was shooting like crazy at the mailman and at the car in front of him, filling the car full of holes,'' Peckham said. ``I walked up to about 15 or 20 feet away from him and asked him what he was doing. He said he was shooting at the postman. ``He kept shooting at that car and at any car that came past. The mailman was hiding behind the car. Jerry was mumbling to himself. It was just like it was his job or something. He wasn't sweating, shaking or nothing. It was like he was skeet shooting.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 17; Three Americans Reported Among Dead
DOC.TEXT: Another body was found today in the burned rubble of a luxury hotel, bringing the death toll in the fast-moving fire to 17. At least three of the victims were Americans, police said. One of the dead U.S. citizens was identified by a relative as 67-year-old Robert D. Cresap of Houston. His sister-in-law, Mrs. Alfred Cresap of Sioux City, Iowa, said Cresap and his wife had been in Egypt one day when the blaze broke out Thursday at the Heliopolis Sheraton near Cairo's international airport. The identities of the other Americans were not known. Meanwhile, questions continued to be raised about the tent in which the fire began. The government newspaper Al-Akhbar reported today that preliminary inquiries show that Cairo officials ``sent several warnings to the hotel management to remove the tent because it was a fire hazard.'' The newspaper said the tent, which housed a restaurant and was attached to the hotel, was erected in violation of rules requiring that the Ministry of Tourism be informed of such construction. The head of Cairo's fire brigade, Maj. Gen. Adel Nigm, said Thursday such canvas tents are fire hazards and the Sheraton put it up without consulting the fire department. A man at Sheraton's national headquarters, who refused to give his name, denied the hotel chain had been warned about the tent. ``If that's true, then why didn't the authorities come and remove it?'' he said. Asked if there was fire-safety equipment in the tent, he said yes but could provide no details. Fire spread quickly through the T-shaped, 630-room room hotel early Thursday after sparks from an oven caught the canvas on fire, and strong winds fed the flames. The six-story hotel had neither fire alarms nor sprinklers _ they are not mandatory in Egypt _ and guests tied sheets together or jumped from windows to escape. Many of the injured suffered broken bones. At least eight people remained hospitalized. Harb said the dead victims identified so far were three Finns, three French, three Americans and a Greek. Seven people were not identified, he said. The director of Cairo's central morque, Dr. Kamal el-Saadani, said the victims also included one Briton and one Chilean. Most died of burns, he said. A U.S. Embassy spokeswoman would only confirm one American dead, and she said three were unaccounted for. There was no explanation for the discrepancy. The injured included Cresap's wife, Helen, who was reported in good condition at Heliopolis Hospital. The Heliopolis Sheraton, about two miles from Cairo International Airport, was a favorite of airline crews, and airline workers were among the victims. Several flights were reported delayed on Thursday, some for hours, because of disruptions involving the crews.

DOC.HEAD: Weicker Enters Connecticut Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Sen. Lowell P. Weicker, a crusading liberal Republican who said he was out of politics for good when he lost his 1988 bid for a fourth term, announced today he will run for governor as an independent. Weicker announced his plans to reporters at a packed news conference at the state Capitol, ending months of speculation about a political comeback. ``Both political parties, in Washington and in Connecticut, don't want to handle the tough answers and the tough problems because they are afraid of the heat. ... I'm willing to go ahead and take that kind of heat,'' Weicker said. Sixteen months ago, when he conceded defeat to state Attorney General Joseph Lieberman, Weicker appeared to rule out any return to politics. The narrow loss to Lieberman was Weicker's only electoral defeat in a 26-year career during which he constantly flirted with disaster by antagonizing Republican leaders. ``In 1988, you all took me down a peg or two. And probably deservedly so,'' Weicker said today. His decision to seek the governor's job had been a well-kept secret; only his family and a handful of friends were told. Weicker apparently made no courtesy calls to top Republicans, including Connecticut's three GOP congressmen, to tell them of his plans. One of those congressmen is John G. Rowland, the perceived front-runner for the GOP gubernatorial nomination. Republican leaders had said it would be a mistake for Weicker to jump in, either as a Republican or an independent, because Weicker has no clear base of support since he lost in 1988. He always enjoyed strong support from Democrats and unaffiliated voters and was the only Republican to win statewide office since 1970. Democrats had been hoping Weicker would run, since he could split the GOP and threaten what many view as the Republicans' best shot in 20 years at winning the governor's chair. During his 18 years in the Senate, Weicker was constantly at odds with his party, starting with his opposition to President Nixon during the Watergate scandal. Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, who plans to seek a third term, said Thursday that a Weicker candidacy would make it ``a very spirited contest.'' Since his 1988 defeat, Weicker has headed a group promoting medical research called Research! America, based outside Washington. Besides Rowland, three Republicans are seeking the GOP nomination: state Senate Minority Leader Reginald Smith of New Hartford, New Haven developer Joel Schiavone and Fairfield banker Joseph McGee.

DOC.HEAD: First Exiled Members Of African National Congress Return
With PM-Mandela
DOC.TEXT: An elderly white couple received a rousing welcome today when they became the first exiled members of the African National Congress to return to South Africa. ``Down with white supremacy, up with people's power,'' shouted Jack Simon, 83, upon his arrival at Jans Smuts Airport in Johannesburg. Simon, a university professor, and his 76-year-old wife Rachel Alexander, a trade union organizer, previously were banned in South Africa and fled the country in 1965 for the ANC's exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. Several hundred activists, black and white, cheered the couple at the airport and sang ``God Bless Africa,'' the anthem of the anti-apartheid movement. ``This is a great and joyous occasion after 25 years of exile,'' Mrs. Alexander said. ``We must see to it the breakthrough in South Africa is widened and our people take over power in a peaceful and orderly manner.'' President F.W. de Klerk last month legalized the ANC and more than 60 other opposition groups. The ANC, the largest group fighting the white-led government, had been banned since 1960. The ANC has an estimated 15,000 members in exile, and they are expected to begin returning in large numbers shortly. The ANC also announced today that it will move its headquarters to Johannesburg. The government has said that ordinary members of previously outlawed groups are free to return. However, the government has not clarified the position of exiles suspected of involvement in guerrilla attacks. Some members of the other recently legalized groups, such as the Pan Africanist Congress, already have begun to return to South Africa. ``We decided in 1965 to ... emigrate to Lusaka, the closest independent base from which to work for the liberation of South Africa,'' Simon and Mrs. Alexander said in a joint statement. ``We return home to continue the struggle for liberation.'' In another development, about 1,000 people peacefully marched on Parliament in Cape Town today to express support for some 350 prisoners on a 5-day-old hunger strike. Friends and family members of the hunger strikers have marched in Cape Town every day this week, and dozens have been arrested, although there were no incidents today. The inmates at the Robben Island Prison off Cape Town stopped eating Monday, saying they consider themselves political prisoners and should be released under reforms initiated last month by de Klerk. De Klerk said people imprisoned simply for belonging to those organizations that he legalized would be freed. Several have been released, and dozens more are expected to be let go. However, the government so far has refused to free people convicted of violent acts.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Leaders Hail Verdict in `Skinheads' Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf, `During the ...' to UPDATE with police saying today a prosecution witness has been arrested for allegedly harassing a black woman. Picks up 5th graf, `The New ...'
DOC.TEXT: Minority groups hailed the conviction of five white supremacist ``skinheads'' for racially motivated crimes against Jews, blacks and Hispanics. An all-white jury found all five men guilty Thursday of two counts of conspiring to violate the civil rights of minorities. The defendants, members of the Confederate Hammerskins, were accused of defacing a synagogue and Jewish community center in 1988 and roughing up and chasing blacks and Hispanics from Robert E. Lee Park that same year. During the trial, former ``skinheads'' testified that the Confederate Hammerskins planned to pump cyanide gas into the air conditioning system at Temple Shalom in a reminder of the Holocaust, in which millions of Jews perished. A 21-year-old skinhead who was a prosecution witness in the trial was arrested, along with six others, following a confrontation with a black woman, police said today. The woman complained skinheads yelled racial slurs at her after breaking her car's windshield. Michael Thornton, 21, of Center Hill, Fla., was jailed in Richardson, a north Dallas suburb, on several charges, including disorderly conduct, criminal mischief and public intoxication, said police Sgt. Ray Pennington. Thornton is a former member of the Confederate Hammerskins. The New York-based Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith called the verdict ``a major victory in the continuing battle against hate-inspired violence by skinheads around the country.'' ``This should send a warning across the nation that young racists cannot commit crimes of hate,'' said Barry Kowalski, a prosecutor with the U.S. Justice Department's civil rights division. ``They can believe what they want and say what they want, but they better not vandalize or commit acts of violence.'' Each of the charges carries up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Sentencing was set for April 19. Defense attorneys contended that the men, known as skinheads because of their close-cropped hair, were being tried for their beliefs. They said their clients merely were exercising free speech. ``It is very unpopular, the things they believe,'' said Leon Carter, a Dallas lawyer who defended Jordan. ``But they have the right to believe it.'' The defendants are Jon Lance Jordan, 19, of Garland; Sean Christian Tarrant, 20, and Daniel Alvis Wood, 20, of Dallas; Christopher Barry Greer, 25, of Irving, and Michael Lewis Lawrence, 22, of Tulsa, Okla., Rabbi Kenneth Roseman of Temple Shalom praised the verdict but added, ``Just because five people have been convicted, doesn't mean there aren't more radicals and bigots around.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Who Sentenced Ceausescus to Death Kills Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD Justice Ministry announcing death, confirming details, adding that Popa left suicide note. CORRECTS Popa's rank to Maj. Gen., sted Lt. Gen. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The head of the military tribunal that condemned Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife to death has committed suicide, officials said today. Maj. Gen. Gica Popa shot himself in the head Thursday at his office in the Ministry of Justice, Justice Minister Teofil Pop told a news conference. Popa was rushed to the Bucharest military hospital, where he died two hours later with his wife and daughter by his side, Pop said. The military officer left a suicide note that asked for forgiveness, but did not explain the motive for his act. Pop said the suicide was the result of a ``very grave depression'' and said ``it is possible'' that it was related to the Ceausescu trial. A source close to the family, however, said that Popa had been troubled by anonymous death threats, apparently from Ceausescu loyalists, for the past two months. Pop said that he had recently asked Popa if he had been threatened after the trial, and the major-general said no. The justice minister also confirmed that Popa's voice was the one heard on the video-recording of the Dec. 25 trial of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, which was broadcast repeatedly on Romanian and international television. The angry voice was heard interrogating the pair and then announcing that they had been sentenced to death for crimes against the Romanian people. The couple was then executed. The identity of the person was not made public earlier ``to protect the judges while there were still terrorists around,'' Pop said. He used the word ``terrorists'' to refer to members of Ceausescu's secret police force, who fought revolutionary forces for about a week after the dictator was toppled Dec. 22. Pop said Popa, who was the head of the Military Territorial Tribunal, ``had extraordinary prestige and was one of our best judges.'' The prosecutor-general's office and police were investigating Popa's death, officials said. News of the suicide coincided with the start of a trial in Timisoara of 21 former secret police officers charged in connection with scores of deaths in that city, where the revolution began. It was the first trial of ex-officials accused of trying to crush the revolution before it spread across the country.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Named ANC's Deputy President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts inserts 4 grafs after 10th, `Mandela will...' to ADD further detail on Mandela's health. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Mandela told...'
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress today named Nelson Mandela as its deputy president and welcomed him and two others to leadership positions they held when they were arrested in South Africa in the 1960s. Mandela, released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, becomes the No. 2 official in the ANC, behind president Oliver Tambo, who is recuperating from a stroke in a Swedish clinic. The post of deputy president is a new position. Mandela effectively becomes the ANC's top leader, because the ailing Tambo is widely believed to be unable to resume an active political life as the ANC sets about establishing a political framework in South Africa. The ANC, the main black group fighting South Africa's white-led government, also reaffirmed its intention to meet soon with South African President F.W. de Klerk and said it would soon open headquarters offices in Johannesburg. While the ANC was outlawed in South Africa, its political and guerrilla leaders operated their headquarters from Zambia. De Klerk lifted the 30-year ban on the ANC on Feb. 2. Mandela and fellow longtime political detainees Walter Sisulu and Govan Mbeki resumed seats they held on the National Executive Committee when they were arrested more than two decades ago, said an ANC statement read at a news conference by acting president and meeting chairman Alfred Nzo. Sisulu, 77, and Mbeki, 79, were sentenced to life in prison along with Mandela in 1964. Mbeki was released in 1987 and Sisulu was freed in October. The committee is the ANC's main policy-making group. Mandela gave few details on his new role in the ANC. ``I am prepared to serve in any role the national executive instructs me to fill,'' he said. Mandela will visit neighboring Zimbabwe on Sunday and then ``move swiftly'' to see Tambo in Sweden, Nzo said. Mandela is known to have invitations to visit several other countries, but ANC officials indicated the organization will be selective about accepting foreign trips and future engagements for him out of concerns for his health. The 71-year-old black nationalist, treated in prison for tuberculosis two years ago, receives a daily checkup from a physician, said a senior ANC official, who asked not to be identified. ``For someone who has been isolated in prison for so long, it's incredible. He hasn't stopped. We all want to be sure he isn't overworking,'' the official said. ``We have just got him back (from prison). The last thing he should see now is hospital walls,'' the official added. Mandela told reporters he was optimistic about a political settlement but said he was unwilling to predict any time frame for negotiations or the return of exiles. ``We are already making progress. There is no reason why we should not be able to make further progress,'' he said. ``I am optimistic that the process of removing all obstacles (to negotiations) is on. I will be surprised if we don't succeed in removing the obostacles.''' The ANC reiterated that it will not enter formal negotiations with the South African government until it lifts the state of emergency and releases all political prisoners. De Klerk has said he plans to lift the 3{-year-old state of emergency and will free prisoners convicted of belonging to previously outlawed organizations that he legalized last month. However, the government has said it will not free people convicted of violent acts.

DOC.HEAD: Independence Group Stages Series of Demonstrations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 6th, ``Personally, I...' to UPDATE with Mazowiecki to visit Washington and Paris; SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Krzystztof Krol...' to conform. Pickup 8th pvs, `The confederation...
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people demonstrated in six cities to support Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's demand that Poland be allowed to take part in international talks on a reunited Germany, organizers said. The demonstrations Thursday in Krakow, Katowice, Poznan, Lublin, Rzeszow and Belchatow were organized by an anti-Communist group, Confederation for an Independent Poland. The state-run PAP news agency said some protesters carried banners reading ``Nothing About Central Europe Without Poland'' and ``Yalta Never Again,'' a reference to the 1945 conference at which the leaders of the four Allies reworked Poland's borders. The confederation's leader, Leszek Moczulski, told a news conference that Poland deserves access to the ``two-plus-four'' talks on German reunification that would involveg West and East Germany as well as the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. Poland wants to be a part of the talks to guarantee that former German land it received after World War II remains in Polish hands. ``Personally, I see no real threat to our western border,'' said Moczulski. ``But such a situation cannot be ruled out.'' Mazowiecki will visit Paris and Washington this month in his effort to win international support for a treaty confirming the present Polish border. The Paris trip will take place March 9, while Mazowiecki will fly to the United States in the last 10 days of March, government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska told reporters today. In Washington, he will meet with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, she said. Mazowiecki also will visit Canada. Krzysztof Krol, another leader of the confederation, said more than 2,000 people participated in the demonstrations Thursday. He said the largest one was in Krakow, where about 1,500 people gathered. The confederation is a nationalistic party that often stages demonstrations along with extreme anti-Communist groups. It has been active for more than a decade, founded with the aim to seek total freedom for Poland from Moscow. The precise extent of its support is not known, but it failed to win any elections to parliament last year.

DOC.HEAD: New Detention Center to be Built
DOC.TEXT: The government Finance Committee approved $14.8 million in funding for a new detention center to house 10,000 more Vietnamese to relieve overcrowding at existing camps. The panel voted 26-11 to build the camp on outlying Tai A Chau Island. Public anger over spending more money had delayed approval by a month. About 55,000 Vietnamese live in this British colony's squalid camps, which are filled to near capacity. Hong Kong considers most of the Vietnamese illegal immigrants subject to deportation, but Hanoi so far has accepted the forced repatriation of only 51 people. More than 25,000 Vietnamese sailed into Hong Kong between last March and July, the season when winds over the South China Sea blow toward the colony. Officials say the new camp will enable temporary and unsatisfactory camps to be closed and will ease overcrowding at remaining centers. They said other measures will be needed if a new influx of Vietnamese arrive. Construction of the Tai A Chau camp is expected to begin soon and take six months, with Britain matching the Hong Kong expenditure. During debate Friday, some Finance Committee members suggested the United States and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which oppose forced repatriation, pay for the facility.

DOC.HEAD: Planned Nude Cruise Canceled
DOC.TEXT: A cruise line abruptly canceled a planned excursion for nudists because of slow bookings and the threat of negative publicity. ``I just feel personally that it doesn't fit our corporate image and the kind of attraction we try to be,'' Fred Battaglia, general manager for Europa Cruise Line, said Thursday. He added the company didn't want to deal with publicity that another company had faced for its planned nude ``dance party'' cruises out of nearby Clearwater. The scheduled March 14 Europa cruise, which was limited to 150 couples, was about half booked, said Ben Simmers, president of Caribbean Travel Naturally. The clothing-optional cruise was to have included dinner, dancing, two bands and a casino.

DOC.HEAD: New York Times Big Winner at Polk Awards
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times dominated the annual George Polk Awards in Journalism, winning three citations for its coverage of education, the turmoil in China and chemical weapons. The Casper, Wyo., Star-Tribune was among the other 1990 winners. It was the fifth time in the 41-year history of the awards that a single news organization received three awards in a single year. The Polk awards are named for a CBS correspondent killed in 1948 while covering the Greek civil war. A committee of Long Island University faculty and alumni select the winners; the awards will be presented at a luncheon on April 4. The categories and the winners: _Career award: Fred M. Hechinger, now the president of The New York Times Company Foundation, for 45 years of reporting and commenting on education for the Times. _Foreign Reporting: Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl Wu-Dunn, Beijing correspondents for The New York Times, for their coverage of the Chinese student uprising. _International Reporting: Stephen Engelberg and Michael R. Gordon, Washington bureau reporters for The New York Times, for stories on chemical weapons-producing technology in the third world. _National Reporting: Rick Atkinson of The Washington Post for a three-part series on the Stealth bomber. _Political Reporting: Andrew Melnykovych of the Casper Star-Tribune for exposing collusion between the federal government and 12 oil companies to cut back on royalty payments to Wyoming. _Local Reporting: The Hartford (Conn.) Courant for its articles on the civil rights effects of recording suspects' conversations with their lawyers. _Regional Reporting: Miranda Ewell and David Schrieberg of the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News for a three-part series on the effect of the inadequacies of California court interpreters. _Medical Reporting: John M. Crewdson of the Chicago Tribune for his story on the response of the scientific and political communities to the AIDS crisis. _Network Television Reporting: CBS News for coverage of the Chinese student uprising. _Local Television Reporting: WCSC-TV in Charleston, S.C, for Hurricane Hugo coverage. _Television Investigative Reporting: Jonathan Kwitny for ``The Kwitny Report'' on WNYC-TV, a series of analyses of international and domestic events. _Radio Reporting: Robert Knight, senior producer of ``Undercurrents,'' a nationally syndicated investigative news program, for coverage of the U.S. invasion of Panama. The program originates at WBAI-FM in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Draft Plan Seeks $65 Billion in New Health Benefits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs, Several sources, to update with meeting still going at noon.
DOC.TEXT: A draft proposal to spend $65 billion on two of the nation's biggest health care problems is running into behind-the-scenes White House opposition even before it comes up for a vote. The U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care planned to vote today on a proposal to provide health insurance to more than 31 million uninsured Americans and help 9 million Americans pay the high cost of long-term care. The commission's closed meeting stretched past three hours this morning and continued into early afternoon. Several sources said Thursday that approval was not guaranteed, noting that the White House had been pressuring Republicans on the 15-member commission to withhold their support. Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, a California Democrat who is a member of the commission, predicted its recommendations to Congress would be a ``dead letter'' because of opposition from the White House. ``The postmaster in this case is President Bush and ... they don't want a plan which would embarrass them in the next election,'' Stark said. The commission's draft plan would require all businesses with more than 100 employees to provide private health insurance to their workers, or to contribute to a public plan for employees and non-working dependents. When fully implemented, all Americans would be provided health insurance through their employer or the public plan. It also would offer all Americans coverage for long-term care in their homes and for the first three months in a nursing home. Federal benefits for additional time spent in a nursing home would be greatly improved. The draft plan did not recommend how to pay for the benefits, saying ``the commission is committed to raising whatever additional revenues are necessary.'' The commission _ including 12 members of Congress and three White House appointees _ was created by Congress in 1988 to tackle the thorny questions of how to ensure quality, affordable care for the uninsured and for those devastated by the high costs of long-term care. The panel is commonly known as the Pepper Commission in honor of its first chairman, the late Rep. Claude Pepper, D-Fla., an outspoken advocate for the elderly and disadvantaged. Stark criticized the draft plan, saying it would not guarantee health coverage for all Americans, particularly those employed by small businesses. He noted it provided extended nursing home protection only to those of limited income and assets, and complained that it failed to recommend how to pay for the $65 billion program. But two advocacy groups for the elderly said the proposed plan recommended important improvements in the nation's health care system. John Rother, legislative director for the American Association of Retired Persons, called it ``a promising start.'' ``We're pleased to see that the plan is for all Americans, regardless of age, and that it addresses both the needs of those without health insurance coverage at the same time it addresses the long-term care problem,'' Rother said. Ronald Pollack, executive director of the Families USA Foundation, a non-profit advocacy group for the elderly, said the plan ``meets the crucial goals of health-care reform _ protection from the devastation of long-term care costs at home or in a nursing home as well as affordable health care for all Americans, regardless of income or job status.'' Stark proposed an alternative plan that would require more comprehensive insurance coverage and nursing home benefits, to be paid for by broad new taxes on personal and corporate income. He conceded that with a $120 billion-a-year price tag, his plan ``is apt not to be very popular.'' However, he said an agreement on how to meet the nation's health care needs will come only after people recognize the extent of the problem and the costs for a complete solution.

DOC.HEAD: Nude Statue Makes Splash at Condo Complex
DOC.TEXT: Neptune, the Roman god that stirred up storms to sink mariners who ventured to sea, has caused a storm of another sort at a condominium complex. Three weeks ago, the Island Club condo association spent $1,300 for a 1,400-pound, 6-foot-10 concrete statue of Neptune for the entrance of the building. Neptune is nude, except for a strategically located fish tail. Trouble is, some residents are complaining that even the fish tail is too graphic. The condo board decided to let residents vote on the issue, but for now a mesh fishnet covers the problematic parts. Linley Ray, owner of Paramount Concrete, the Pompano Beach company that sold Neptune to the condo, is aware of the controversy. Ms. Ray said one woman who lives at the complex swore at her as she was painting the cream-colored Neptune. ``There's nothing obscene about it,'' Ms. Ray said. ``It's a classic standard Neptune statue. His behind is semi-exposed, but on the front it's really a fish tail and it's very obvious it was put there to hide everything.'' Gary Berletic, president of one of the condo's association, said he doesn't find Neptune offensive because the fish tail hides all. ``It's not really lewd,'' he said. ``I think it looks nice.''

DOC.HEAD: Seoul's Top Diplomatic Goal: Improving Ties With Moscow
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's foreign minister said Friday his top diplomatic priority for 1990 will be establishing formal ties with the Soviet Union. Speaking to South Korean diplomats, Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong also said Seoul will try to join the United Nations as a full member in two or three years. South Korea, which is staunchly anti-Communist, has recently established formal ties with Hungary and several other socialist nations but it has yet to normalize relations wnion and China, close allies of North Korea. The Soviet Unith the Soviet Uion and China basically limited their contact with South Korea to non-political areas but the communist nations also have shown interest in expanding their links further with Seoul. Because of its rivalry with North Korea, South Korea's past bids to enter the United Nations have been blocked by the Soviet Union and China. North Korea opposes a separate entry into the United Nations by the two Koreas, contending that would perpetuate the division of the peninsula. After some years of improved relations with the Soviet Union and China, Seoul is increasingly confident they would not oppose Seoul's separate U.N. membership in two or three years. The foreign minister reported to President Roh Tae-woo lastnt or wholly owned ventures in computer manufacturing and coal and natural gas development. Hyundai earlier signed a formal contract to build a soap plant and develop forest in the Soviet Far East. Two-way trade between the Soviet Union and South Korea reached $700 million last year and is expected to reach $1 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: Courter Will Not Seek Re-Election to Congress
DOC.TEXT: Rep. James Courter, a six-term Republican who lost a bid for governor of New Jersey in a bruising battle last year, will not seek re-election to a seventh House term, sources said today. Courter, 48, scheduled an afternoon announcement at his Morristown, N.J., headquarters to dicuss his plans. The decision by the northern New Jersey congressman, ranking Republican on the House Armed Services subcommittee on procurement and military nuclear systems, comes three weeks after he changed his position on abortion and announced he would support a woman's right to choose whether to have an abortion. Courter's anti-abortion position during the gubernatorial campaign drew national attention, with pro-choice women's organizations targeting him for defeat and supporting his opponent, former Rep. Jim Florio. After Courter announced the switch, anti-abortion colleagues criticized him for changing sides and Democrats accused him of waffling on the issue for political purposes. Courter built his reputation in Washington on defense issues such as the Strategic Defense Initiative and was a defender of Oliver North during the Iran-Contra hearings. Democrats have pinned their hopes for winning back the House seat on Marguerite Chandler, a wealthy businesswoman and philanthropist from Somerset County, N.J. She has amassed more than $200,000 for a Democratic bid and is expected to announce her candidacy this month.

DOC.HEAD: Six Language Services Saved at Voice of America
DOC.TEXT: The Voice of America, responding to pressure from its managers and listeners, has decided to save six language services slated for elimination by budget cuts. VOA Director Richard Carlson informed employees on Friday that the Lao, Greek, Turkish, Swahili, Slovene and Uzbek language programs would remain on the air and their 57 broadcasters and producers would keep their jobs. The announcement came just one month after Carlson informed employees the services would go off the air April 1 to save the government's radio network $3 million. ``We will be given the money to keep the services on the air,'' Carlson said. But it was unclear where the money would come from. Bruce Gelb, the director of the U.S. Information Agency, which oversees VOA, wants the money taken out of the construction account used to build transmitters and upgrade technical services. But Congress, which must approve such a transfer of money, is opposed, Carlson said. He said Gelb had assured him that if Congress rejects the move, money would be found elsewhere in USIA's budget. Carlson's announcement that the six services would be eliminated triggered a clash with Gelb, who reportedly claimed he knew nothing about the plan even though he had signed the cuts proposal. The controversy resulted in both men, who are presidential appointees, holding talks with White House officials and being urged to bury their differences. Greek-Americans and other supporters of VOA have been lobbying Congress to prevent the cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Seek Major Role In South Africa's Future
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Despite the failure of communist regimes around the world, the South African Communist Party remains an influential and popular force that has not given up its goal of a socialist state. While its actual membership is tiny, many blacks respect the South African Communist Party because of its prominent role in opposing the country's white-minority government. Red communist flags and slogans are common in black townships and at anti-government demonstrations. Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, hailed the party in his first speech on the day he left prison. ``I salute the South African Communist Party for its sterling contribution to the struggle for democracy. ... We are heartened by the fact that the alliance between ourselves and the party remains as strong as it always was,'' he said. The party's call for a socialist state and a redistribution of wealth also appeals to many poor blacks who see the white-dominated capitalist economy as a pillar of apartheid. Communists claim that whites, who make up less than 15 percent of the population, control 98 percent of South African's wealth. Joe Slovo, the white secretary-general of the party, says the biggest question facing South Africa beyond ending white-minority rule is how to handle the economy. ``The fundamental aim of economic policy must be the redistribution of wealth,'' he said in a recent statement. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the Communist Party and other anti-government groups Feb. 2 to help start talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing political power with the black majority. The party, founded in 1921, was banned in 1950, but operates underground in South Africa with headquarters in Zambia. For years the South African government vehemently denounced the party, portraying its members as Soviet agents plotting to build a Marxist slave state. Government officials routinely claimed that black nationalist groups were communist fronts. Little is known about the highly secretive party. Estimates of its strength range from a few hundred members to a few thousand members with the Communists refusing to give any detailed information on the party. The secrecy makes it difficult to assess the party's strength or evaluate what role it may play in South Africa's future. It appears to have considerable influence within some black political and labor groups. The main source of strength is its close ties to the African National Congress, the main anti-apartheid black force, and the group most likely to form a future government after the end of white rule. Senior Communist Party officials also hold important ANC posts and play key roles in its affairs. While the Communists have few members in South Africa, the party reportedly has been able to recruit many black political leaders and intellectuals. At least half the members on the ANC's ruling National Executive Council are party members or sympathizers, according to independent South African press reports. The Communist Party's ``strategic position within the ANC, its commitment to socialism and the tendency of township radicals to link capitalism with racism, means it will not necessarily be confined to a minor role in the dramatic years ahead,'' The Star newspaper of Johannesburg said recently. The party also served as the link between the ANC and the Soviet Union and as a conduit for Soviet aid. But that role has diminished following a decline in Soviet aid because of Moscow's internal political problems. The ANC denies it is Marxist, saying it works with any group that fights apartheid. But ANC economic programs lean toward socialism and it favors some degree of economic nationalization to redistribute wealth. Critics contend Slovo and the Communists remain hard-line Marxists who have simply adopted new language to conceal their true intentions. White right-wing groups contend any black government will be taken over by Communists. Slovo, a former head of the ANC's military wing, says the Communists will launch a recruiting drive in South Africa to build up their strength. He says the party also will send a delegation for independent talks with the government on the future of South Africa. Slovo has tried to moderate the party's position following the collapse of Eastern Europe's Communist regimes. He has stressed the need for democracy and pledged to seek a socialist state through peaceful means. ``We also believe that if there is real democracy in the post-apartheid state, the way would be open for a peaceful progression towards our party's ultimate objective _ a socialist South Africa. This approach is consistent with the Marxist view ... that the working class must win the majority to its side,'' he said recently. But Slovo still talks in traditional Marxist terms of the state serving the working class, and people abandoning the pursuit of personal gain and working for the common good. ``For our part we firmly believe in the future of socialism; nor do we dismiss its whole past as an unmitigated failure,'' he said. Communists and other activists shrug off questions about the failure of communism elsewhere, saying they won't repeat the mistakes of others. ``The socialist countries have only been in existence for less than a century. They have overcome serious problems and will do so in the future,'' said Ahmed Kathrada, an ANC leader.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Federal Judge to Investigate Pierce Allegations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 5, We're glad, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: Former federal judge Arlin M. Adams was appointed today to investigate allegations that former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. and top aides illegally steered government rent subsidies to politically connected developers. Adams was appointed an independent counsel by a special court to investigate allegations that Pierce and top aides at the Department of Housing and Urban Development conspired to defraud the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. Adams, who served 17 years as a member of the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, is now a private lawyer in that city and chairman of the board of directors of the University of Pennsylvania Law School. The appointment had been sought by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh following a 90-day preliminary inquiry into the allegations by the Justice Department's public integrity section. ``We're glad that an independent counsel has been finally appointed and the investigation can proceed,'' said Robert Plotkin, a lawyer for Pierce. ``We have every reason to expect that Judge Adams will conduct the investigation in a fair and impartial manner.'' Adams, 68, has been affiliated with the Philadelphia law firm of Schnader, Harrison, Segal and Lewis since retiring from the court in 1986. A former state secretary of public welfare, he also chaired the Pennsylvania Trade Association Commission from 1967 to 1971. In 1988, Adams was approached by Justice Department officials about the possibility of becoming deputy attorney general in the waning days of the tenure of Attorney General Edwin Meese III. Adams said he had other professional commitments and was could not consider taking the post. Asked about what preparation he has had for his new appointment, Adams recalled in an interview today that as state welfare secretary in the 1960s ``I got involved'' in looking into alleged misuse of various government programs. In a statement, the Special Division of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here said that Adams ``brings to this investigation the judgment, experience and ability acquired by many years of service as a federal circuit judge, as a private practitioner and as a recognized leader of the courts and the bar of the nation.'' Under the jurisdiction set by the court, Adams is empowered to determine whether Pierce ``and other department officials may have committed the crime of conspiracy to defraud the United States or any other federal crimes ... relating to the administration of the selection process of the department's Moderate Rehabilitation Program from 1984 through 1988.'' The special court's order also empowers Adams to investigate any allegations of ``perjury, obstruction of justice and destruction of evidence and intimidation of witnesses'' during the course of the investigation. Under the Moderate Rehabilitation Program, developers receive tax credits and rent subsidies for performing a moderate amount of rehabilitation on housing for low-income citizens. In his Feb. 1 application to the court for appointment of an independent counsel, Thornburgh cited reports of a ``widespread perception among developers'' and municipal officials that ``funds were being disbursed in disproportionate amounts to projects backed by prominent Republicans acting as consultants or by former HUD officials.'' The Justice Department's preliminary inquiry included a review of voluminous reports compiled by HUD's inspector general as well as testimony before a House Government Operations subcommittee that held hearings on the agency last year. The original request for an independent counsel was made by Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee. They cited allegations of political favoritism as well as charges that Pierce had lied under oath during congressional testimony last spring. Thornburgh found there was no basis for further allegations that Pierce lied under oath. Pierce refused to answer further questions when called back twice to give additional testiony before the subcommittee. He invoked his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. Under the special prosecutor law, the three-judge panel, chaired by Senior Circuit Judge George MacKinnon, is required to appoint an independent counsel after receiving a request to do so from the attorney general.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicatators Unchanged _ Economy Still Slow But Stable
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge was unchanged in January, the Commerce Department said Friday in a report that analysts said points to an aimless economy with little growth but little chance of a recession either. Economist Kevin Logan of the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York said the Index of Leading Economic Indicators means the economy ``is moving sideways ... There is not a lot of strength but neither is there pervasive weakness.'' ``January's report ... shows that the economy has no clear direction,'' said William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``I would regard the leading indicators for January as suggesting that we continue to be in a period where we're not likely to tip into recession, but where growth will continue at a sluggish pace,'' added Richard Peach, an economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. The index, designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, followed two months of increases. However, the December figure paled somewhat in the latest report, being revised downward from an 0.8 percent gain to 0.6 percent because of lower orders for consumer goods. The index rose a weak 0.1 percent in November after falling 0.4 percent in October. The flat January report means the index remained at 145.3 percent of its 1982 base of 100. Economists had been expecting a moderate increase. In another bit of bad news, the Commerce Department also reported Friday that sales of new homes plummeted 7.1 percent in January to the lowest level in nearly a year. Both the housing and the manufacturing industries have borne the brunt of Federal Reserve efforts to contain inflation by keeping interest rates high and thereby slowing the economy. The leading indicators index is heavily weighted toward measuring manufacturing health. The service economy, such as health care and education, generally are regarded as healthy. Three of the 11 forward-looking statistics provided positive contributions to the index, including a big increase in building permits. But Peach, the Mortgage Bankers' economist, said the ``transitory'' gain in permits was concentrated in the multifamily sector. It was expected, he explained, because of extremely mild weather and because of the rush by many builders to beat a deadline for expensive new building standards. The standards, required by 1989 fair housing legislation, are designed to make apartment buildings more accessible to the handicapped. Also showing strength were slower business delivery times, since that indicates strong demand for products, and an increase in the backlog of manufacturers' unfilled orders. However, a decline in orders for consumer goods led the statistics, providing a drag on the index. Other negatives were a drop in the money supply, a decline in plant and equipment orders, lower stock prices, a decrease in the price of raw materials, a drop in an index measuring consumer confidence and an increase in weekly unemployment claims. One indicator, the length of the average work week, was unchanged.

DOC.TEXT: A hotel owner and his wife who were charged with rebellion and murder in connection with a coup attempt that nearly toppled President Corazon Aquino surrendered today, authorities said. Rebecco Panlilio...Pickup 2nd graf.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Aid Coordinator Appeals for More Funds
DOC.TEXT: A senior U.N. official Friday appealed for more relief funds for war-torn Afghanistan, and urged Communist authorities and Moslem rebels to set up non-combat zones to encourage refugees to return home. Sadruddin Aga Khan, coordinator of the U.N. economic and humanitarian assistance program for Afghanistan, said $88 million in cash contributions was still needed to meet this year's planned aid target of $650 million. He said that without additional cash contributions the United Nations would find it difficult to make effective use of the material and food aid donated to Afghanistan. He said the funds were also needed to continue a program that already has trained 20,000 Afghans to detect and remove the vast number of unexploded anti-personnel mines that were planted during the country's long conflict. Non-cash assistance accounts for about 70 percent of the international contributions to the U.N. program known as Operation Salam, he said. Sadruddin said Operation Salam's 1990 program would concentrate on agriculture, food and health assistance, as well as mine clearance. He appealed to Kabul's ruling Communist government and the Moslem rebels to reach agreement on the formal establishment of non-combat zones which could absorb some of the estimated 5 million Afghan refugees who fled their country after the Soviet invasion in 1979. Sadruddin said he would discuss U.N. plans to designate a number of areas as so-called ``zones of tranquility'' when he visits Afghanistan this month. In order to qualify as such a zone, an area must be peaceful and local authorities must accept a U.N. presence, he said. The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Thorvald Stoltenberg, is also due to travel to Kabul with Sadruddin. Despite last year's Soviet military withdrawal from Afghanistan and the subsequent reduction in hostilities, only about 100,000 refugees are believed to have returned home, Sadruddin said. Some 3 million Afghans are estimated to remain in refugee camps in Pakistan and another 2 million in Iran. They account for about 40 percent of the worldwide total of refugees, according to U.N. figures. ``The refugees have spent their 11th winter in exile. We don't want to see them spending another year away from their country,'' Sadruddin said. ``I am reasonably confident that with the necessary contribution from the international community ... the number of returnees this year could be quite substantial,'' he added. But he warned of a continuing exodus of Afghans into Iran to escape chronic food shortages in northern provinces where last year's harvest was ravaged by insects and disease. He said that despite efforts to assist the stricken areas, the situation in the north could worsen without extra international funds.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Converts to Judaism Celebrate First Sabbath
DOC.TEXT: About 50 South American Indians who converted to Judaism celebrated their first Sabbath in this West Bank settlement Friday after immigrating from Peru. The tribe's move to the occupied lands comes at a time of growing U.S. pressure on Israel to stop building or expanding Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and demands that Israel not settle Soviet Jews in those areas. The Indians who call themselves the ``Sons of Moses'' became interested in Judaism 40 years ago while living near the town of Cajamarca in northern Peru, said Israeli Rabbi Eliahu Aviahil. Two tribal elders began studying the Old Testament at the time, and about 20 years later the whole tribe abandoned Christianity and began living a Jewish lifestyle, the rabbi said on Israel radio. Aviahil said he learned of the Indians three years ago and initiated their formal conversion and immigration. The tribe's men underwent ritual circumcision before everyone in the group was converted six months ago by a special rabbinical court according to Orthodox Jewish law. Aviahil heads Amishav, a society that researches Judaism's 10 lost tribes which according to legend disappeared after the exile of the Jews to Babylonia in 722 B.C. The Israeli newspaper Hadashot quoted the rabbi as saying the Peruvians were descendants of one of the lost tribes, but did not elaborate. The Indians arrived in Israel late Wednesday night and were greeted by Elon Moreh settlers who drove them in a convoy of trucks Thursday to their new home, the daily Maariv reported. Elon Moreh, home to some 500 observant Jewish settlers, is located on a windswept and rocky mountaintop four miles from Nablus, the West Bank's largest city and a hotbed of anti-Israeli violence. Elon Moreh is reputed to be the site where the biblical patriarch Abraham first entered Canaan. Aviahil said the new immigrants asked to settle in Elon Moreh because if its religious atmosphere. ``They asked and they are happy to live in a religious settlement like Elon Moreh,'' the rabbi said. The settlers turned away journalists Friday, saying they wanted to give the new immigrants some privacy before allowing interviews. Elon Moreh settlers, meanwhile, were preparing for the Jewish Sabbath which begins at sundown Friday with the lighting of candles and a special blessing said before the evening meal. Settler Shoshi Ilan, who is in charge of the new immigrants, told The Associated Press the tribe consisted of about 15 families and they would live in houses that have been vacant for some time. ``We worked very hard to get them here and don't want anyone to bother them,'' Mrs. Ilan said. She said some of the Indians spoke Hebrew and that all would take language classes in the settlement. Another settler, who would not give his name, said the new arrivals ``are not Indians, but Jews in every way.'' Aviahil said the Peruvians were aware of the Palestinian uprising that has been raging in the occupied lands since December 1987. ``They are ready for it,'' he said. ``They want to fulfill the commandment of living in the Land of Israel (Eretz Israel),'' the rabbi said. The Hebrew phrase ``Eretz Israel'' is a reference to the biblical land of Israel that also includes the West Bank. Two Elon Moreh children have been killed since 1987, including 15-year-old Tirza Porat who was inadvertently shot by a Jewish settler guard firing wildly during a confrontation with Palestinian villagers. In the second case, 8-year-old Rami Chaban was found slain near Elon Moreh, and settlers blamed Palestinians. Aviahil, meanwhile, said the Peruvian Indians were not a unique case, and that other communities around the world were adopting a Jewish way of life. ``There is an interesting phenomena today in Latin America where many Christians leave their religion and turn to the Old Testament, and some of them become Jews,'' he said. ``Judaism today is a magnet for people seeking the truth.''

DOC.HEAD: House Report Faults Finding That Hartwig Probably Caused Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, The panel, to CORRECT year of explosion to 1989 sted of 1988.
DOC.TEXT: The Navy's inquiry into the USS Iowa disaster failed to prove its contention that Gunner's Mate Clayton Hartwig probably set off the explosion that killed himself and 46 other crewmen, a congressional panel said today. ``By the standards of this subcommittee _ and the standards that we think should have been applied in the Navy's investigation _ there is only a hypothesis, and a tenuous one at that,'' said the report by the House Armed Services investigations subcommittee. The Navy, in its report on the blast, concluded that Hartwig ``most likely'' caused the explosion by inserting some type of detonator between bags of gunpowder in one of the ship's 16-inch guns. Navy officials did acknowledge that their evidence was circumstantial in light of the fact that all the witnesses, including Hartwig, were killed in the blast in the battleship's gun turret No. 2. Navy spokesman Cmdr. Mark Baker, asked about the panel's criticism, responded, ``We stand by our original report.'' The panel found fault with four aspects of the Navy's investigation into the April 19, 1989, explosion as the battleship sailed near Puerto Rico. Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass., the subcommittee chairman, said the flaws were the structure of the probe, the technical tests, police work and psychological analysis. ``First, the Navy convened a one-man investigation without the use of formal hearings,'' Mavroules said in a statement accompanying the report. ``If the Navy had convened a board of several members operating through formal hearings, the theories and hypotheses that evolved would have faced more rigorous questioning. ``Instead, there was an excess of certitude,'' he said. On the technical inquiry, Mavroules said that when Navy investigators were told that Hartwig owned a timing device, the tests ``proved'' that a timer was used to trigger the blast. Later, he said, when the timer information proved to be false, the technical tests ``suddenly found a chemical detonator to be the logical igniter.'' Mavroules also criticized FBI psychologists who took part in the investigation, calling their analysis the ``real villain of this case.'' Last December, three FBI psychologists testified that Hartwig _ based on his letters, interviews with the seaman's family and friends and his personal history _ was ``egocentric, shy ... not sufficiently aggressive, had a low self-esteem.'' The psychologists cited various bits of information that when pieced together, according to their assessment, form a picture of an individual bent on self-destruction. Mavroules said the FBI analysis was used as a substitute for a thorough investigation. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the full Armed Services Committee, said the Navy probe ``leaves us with something of a bad taste in our mouths.'' ``We are concluding that the Navy hasn't definitely found the culprit. But we haven't found the culprit ourselves,'' Aspin said. ``Yet, I don't think reopening the original investigation will get us anywhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Non-Official Exchanges Surge While War of Words Continues
DOC.TEXT: Official efforts to mend U.S.-China relations appear to have stalled, but recent days have seen a surge in people-to-people exchanges despite the still-intense political war of words. The same week that saw daily Chinese expressions of outrage over a critical U.S. State Department human rights report also saw the arrival of more unofficial American delegations at one time than any other week since June. That was when the Chinese army opened fire on crowds protesting in Beijing for democratic reform, killing hundreds and possibly thousands. Hundreds of bilateral programs for exchanging students, scholars, artists and scientists ground to a halt. This week it was almost like old times. First, a team of 17 Americans arrived to climb Mount Everest, the world's highest peak, together with Chinese and Soviet mountaineers. Then, a dozen delegates from five states arrived to explore trade and investment opportunities. A dozen more came with the National Committee for U.S.-China Relations for three days of talks with Chinese scholars and policy-makers on topics from the global environment to bilateral ties to the problem of Chinese students staying in the United States. The biggest group of all, nearly two dozen people from Washington state, reached agreement to hold a huge economic and trade seminar in Seattle in October, complete with a Chinese food fair, a business exhibit and Chinese acrobats. The organizer, Norman Swanson of People to People's Citizen Ambassador Program, said as many as 500 Chinese might attend, making it their largest delegation ever to the United States in the 11 years since relations were normalized. The week ended with U.S. Industrialist Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum, appearing on Chinese TV with President Yang Shangkun to express his willingness to invest more money in China. Occidental already has invested $200 million in a Chinese coal mine. David Lampton, president of the National Committee on U.S.-Chinese Relations, said individual U.S. Scholars also are coming back for short periods to renew contacts and research projects. ``There are whole areas of exchange that we probably won't engage in at the moment,'' Lampton said. ``I don't want this to be construed as business as usual.'' But he said groups such as the committee, which sponsors a range of scholarly and other non-official exchanges, oppose shutting down contacts during times of political strife. He said the committee's symposium with the Chinese People's Institute of Foreign Affairs was the fourth in a periodic series of such meetings planned ``to build close personal relations so that when times get bad there will be a fabric of relations.'' Although the U.S. report critical of human rights abuses in China prompted an angry Chinese response, China made no move to halt any of these or other planned unofficial exchanges, as it did several times in the early 1980s when governmental relations deteriorated. Nor, by week's end, had China tightened surveillance around U.S. Embassy compounds or otherwise put pressure on American diplomats, as it did in the months after June. The downward spiral in government relations may coast to a halt, Lampton said _ but there are no prospects for improvement, either. ``Both sets of leaders think that any further compromise is going to be very costly in terms of their domestic position,'' he said, stressing that he did not speak for the committee. The United States sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, resumed government trade credits and approved airplane and satellite sales. China lifted martial law, released a small portion of arrested protesters and agreed to resume Fulbright scholarly exchanges. ``Each believes that the other must take the next step,'' Lampton said. But he said he found no evidence that any significant faction of Chinese leaders want to reduce or cut bilateral ties. ``I see a deadlock of indefinite length,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Witness, Lawyer Spar Over Hazelwood's Actions Before Flu Delays Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Hazelwood illness delaying trial. Picks up 3rd graf, `But the...'
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood got the flu today, stopping his trial at a point where the defense was trying to puncture an expert witness' claim the Exxon Valdez skipper recklessly tried to refloat his grounded tanker. ``It seems we're missing the star player _ Captain Hazelwood has the flu,'' attorney Dick Madson told Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone. The judge canceled today's session and ordered jurors to be especially careful about avoiding publicity about the case during their long weekend recess. Lawyers said Hazelwood should be ready to resume Monday. William Milwee Jr., a marine salvage consultant, remained adamant Thursday as attorney Michael Chalos challenged his assertions that Hazelwood risked losing his tanker and the lives of his crew when he ordered the ship forward after it hit a reef. But the witness also agreed that in a grounding, the captain's first instinct would be to get his ship afloat. Chalos suggested the ship's engines did not have enough horsepower to extricate the massive tanker from the reef. ``There is absolutely no question this ship would not have moved using its engines alone,'' said Milwee. ``No matter what Captain Hazelwood did?'' asked Chalos. ``No matter what Captain Hazelwood did,'' responded the witness. ``But Captain Hazelwood did nothing to try and determine that.'' Repeatedly, Milwee insisted that Hazelwood should have had more information before he attempted any maneuver in the wake of the grounding. The retired Navy salvage expert said a captain should take soundings, by dropping a piece of lead with a line attached to it over the side, to ascertain how deep the water is and how the vessel is grounded. But he acknowledged that soundings might have been inaccurate in water thick with oozing oil. The 987-foot tanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude in little more than an hour after it ran aground in Prince William Sound on March 24. It was the nation's worst oil spill, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. The prosecution claims that Hazelwood's actions after the ship hit jagged Bligh Reef worsened the problem and risked more damage to the tanker. The 43-year-old skipper from Huntington, N.Y., is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could receive 7\ years in prison and fines of $61,000. Milwee, the third expert witness for the prosecution this week, said he has a $25,000 contract with the state for his work on the case. Chalos confronted Milwee with a book on seamanship containing 14 points of advice for the skipper of a grounded vessel. As Chalos read off the points, Milwee acknowledged that Hazelwood followed almost all the recommended procedures, including alerting the engine room, lowering lifeboats, sending a distress message and remaining calm. On each of those points, Chalos asked him: ``Was that a correct action?'' ``Correct action,'' answered the witness. ``A good action?'' asked the attorney. ``Good action,'' said the witness. But Milwee faulted Hazelwood on two points: failing to sound a general alarm to wake the crew and not taking soundings before activating the engines. ``You shouldn't attempt to move a ship in any way until you have knowledge of the water that lies around it,'' he said. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole asked how certain a captain should be of a situation before he attempts refloating. ``Dead certain,'' said the witness. As far as Hazelwood's failure to sound a general alarm, other officers have said the skipper didn't want to incite panic among the crew members, most of whom were asleep. Milwee ridiculed that reasoning. ``I can't imagine a crew that sounding the general alarm is going to panic,'' the witness said. ``If it does, they're not much of a crew.''

DOC.HEAD: Daytona Prepares for Influx of Spring Break Hordes
DOC.TEXT: Battle plans were drawn Friday as this spring break mecca prepared for the annual invasion of 400,000 college students that's worth perhaps $1 billion to the region. ``Party Smart'' is the theme this year as community leaders attempt to try to tone down the free-for-all party that has accompanied the annual rites of spring here in recent years. ``Be smart, be legal or be caught,'' said Ty Wilson, vice chairman of the Spring Break Festival Task Force, a committee formed after severe problems developed last year, when police made 1,200 alcohol-related arrests. ``It's going to be a great spring break,'' chairman Ray Eddy said as last-minute preparations were discussed. ``The message is that the students are welcome.'' Concerts, sports events, beauty pageants are among the planned promotions. The task force has created 1,000 new parking spaces near the beach, will install more than 100 portable toilets and has more carefully scheduled events to lessen the impact of the crowds. Laws also will be more strictly enforced. Many residents complained last year that traffic was at a virtual standstill and students were urinating in public and passing out drunk. The task force was created to solve some of those problems and to make students welcome because of the tremendous economic impact. Chamber of Commerce officials estimate students will spend $120 million from early March through mid-April. The first group of 20,000 students arrived this week just as 240,000 ``bikers'' arrived for motorcycle races at Daytona International Speedway. By using a multiplier, officials estimate spring break has almost a $1 billion impact on the area's economy. Daytona Beach became the nation's spring break capital about three years ago after Fort Lauderdale tightened law enforcement, signaling that students weren't welcome. Gulf Coast beaches are expecting some of the overflow from Daytona Beach. The Daytona Beach police department and the Volusia County Beach Patrol are pledging more stringent enforcement of drinking laws. ``We're proud of spring break, but it has to be managed better,'' said Police Chief Paul Crow. ``It will be a much more organized event.'' Contrary to percepitions, Crow said, ``Our problems haven't been with the college kids.'' About two-thirds of last year's arrests were Florida youngsters, many of them underage high school students. ``We have to deal with the day trippers,'' he said. This year, Crow said exits to Daytona Beach off Interstate 95 will be closed when the beach is full to prevent gridlock. ``We are going to close the gate,'' Crow said. Volusia County Beach Patrol chief John Kirvan, whose agency is responsible for law enforcement on the beach, said his officers will take ``a no-nonsense approach to drinking and rowdyism.'' ``We hope they have a good time, but we are going to enforce the laws,'' Kirvan said.

DOC.HEAD: All But Captain Found After South Korean Fishing Boat Sinks
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one crewmembers of a South Korean fishing were rescued Friday after their boat sank in the South China Sea, but their captain still was missing, Japan's Maritime Safety Agency said. Another South Korean vessel found the crew floating in a life raft, agency officials said. The officials believe that the captain, taking responsibility for the accident, decided to go down with his ship.
