The 100-ton fishing boat Hanaho sank Thursday afternoon about 300 miles west-northwest of Naha in Japan's southernmost prefecture of Okinawa. Japanese officials said the cause of the accident was unknown but said it was believed the Hanaho was hit by large waves.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Seize Drug-Infested Bronx Apartment Buildings
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities have taken over two Bronx apartment buildings described as ``veritable `Macy's' of crack sales.'' An affidavit supporting Thursday's seizures said drug dealers who worked out of the buildings terrorized the neighborhood, including a nearby drug rehabilitation center. The affidavit said numerous gunshots were fired at the center and that on one occasion, a resident barely missed being hit by a bullet. It also alleged that dealers frequently surrounded the rehab center and taunted the recovering addicts by dangling vials of crack through the fence. The seizures were announced by U.S. Attorney Otto G. Obermaier, whose office brought the action, and Bronx District Attorney Robert T. Johnson, who investigated the drug activity. They said more than 150 drug arrests had been made in the past 14 months at the two six-story, 53-unit apartment buildings, where police officers had observed up to 100 people lining up outside to buy drugs. The seizures were made under a provision of the federal narcotics law that allows the government to take over property known to be the site of drug activity. The buildings' owner was identified as John Dino and his Phelan Corp. in Queens. Authorities charged that Dino had not taken reasonable action to rid the buildings of drug traffickers and to make the building safe for legitimate tenants who occupied a small percentage of the apartments. Efforts to get comment from Dino were unsuccessful because there were no telephone listings for him or his company. The affidavit said as many as 10 different drug organizations used the buildings as ``veritable `Macy's' of crack sales, with selling occurring on the street, in the lobby, in the stairwells and in apartment doorways.'' Authorities said 19 people were arrested on drug charges during the seizures Thursday. The other tenants _ no exact number was available _ were allowed to stay in their apartments, said Deborah Corley, a spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Puts ``Twin Peaks'' and Three Other New Shows
DOC.TEXT: ABC said Friday it is putting four new series on its spring schedule and taking two others off temporarily. Those two, ``China Beach'' and ``Anything But Love,'' will go on a production hiatus. Three of the new series, including ``Twin Peaks,'' are one-hour shows. Each will have a two-hour premiere before the start of its regular weekly run. ``Twin Peaks,'' a dark-humor series set in a small town in the Northwest, will begin in its regular Thursday time period on April 12, with ``The Young Riders'' shifted to make room for it. ``Riders'' will move to Monday on April 16, joined then by the new ``Capitol News,'' a one-hour series set in a newspaper in Washington, D.C. The mid-season switch will end ABC's usual Monday movie fare this season. ``Equal Justice,'' the third new one-hour series, is a drama set in the office of a big-city district attorney. It will debut in its regular Wednesday time period on March 28, displacing ``China Beach.'' ABC's fourth new show, a situation comedy called ``The Marshall Chronicles,'' is about teen-age life. It will premiere in its regular Wednesday time period on April 4, displacing ``Anything But Love.''

DOC.HEAD: New Home Sales at Lowest Level in Nearly a Year
DOC.TEXT: Sales of new homes fell 7.1 percent in January to their lowest level in nearly a year, the government said Friday, surprising analysts who had expected a rebound from a steep plunge in December. The Commerce Department said new, single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 589,000 units in January, the worst performance since sales had fallen to 556,000 homes on an annual basis last March. ``Frankly, it's a bit of a surprise,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. ``I thought the weather would give us at least as good a month as December.'' Sales in December totaled 634,000 units, down 8.4 percent from November. January sales also were down from the 704,000 units purchased in January 1989, and marked an ominous start for the new year. Despite the healthy pace at the beginning of 1989, the year itself ended on a slack note, with sales down 3.8 percent from 1988 to the lowest level since 1984. John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, attributed the January decline to a rise in mortgage rates, which he expects to taper off in the spring. Tuccillo also blamed rates, as well as a usual January buying lull, for a 2.2 percent drop in existing home sales in January. Interest rates rose, on average, from 9.83 percent to 10.05 percent in January, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Rates continued to rise last month, reaching 10.31 percent by Feb. 23 before dropping to 10.23 percent Friday. But Richard Peach, deputy chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said rising rates often boost sales because buyers want to lock in on loans before mortgage costs go up even more. The housing industry slowed dramatically early in 1989 as the Federal Reserve sought to contain inflation by keeping interest rates high and thereby slowing the economy. Mortgage rates fell during the summer, spurring sales, but moved back into the double-digit range in January. Seiders said a recent survey by the Home Builders found 50 percent of its members offering incentives to offset the industry weakness. They include optional equipment at no extra cost and builder payment of closing costs. ``It doesn't seem to have worked,'' he admitted. In its report, the Commerce Department said the median price of a new home continued to climb in January, rising 1.4 percent to $127,000. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less. On the other hand, the average price of a new home in January fell 2.9 percent to $152,600. The South suffered the largest sales drop, down 18.9 percent to 202,000 units at an annual rate. Sales in the West were off 5.9 percent to 190,000 units. But sales in the Northeast, where housing activity had been slow, rose 13.5 percent to 109,000 units. Sales also rose in the Midwest, up 1.1 percent to 88,000 homes at an annual rate.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Lawmakers Meet De Klerk, Anti-Apartheid Leaders
DOC.TEXT: A 10-member U.S. congressional delegation met President F.W. de Klerk and anti-apartheid leaders Friday to assess the rapidly changing political climate in South Africa. The delegation, led by Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., described the talks with de Klerk and other government leaders as ``candid'' but made no substantive statements. The lawmakers met Friday night with members of anti-apartheid United Democratic Front. More meetings were planned for the weekend. The bipartisan group arrived Friday in South Africa after talks in Zambia with the African National Congress, the main black group fighting the white-run government. The ANC urged the congressmen to keep in place the limited U.S. sanctions against South Africa as a means of putting pressure on the government. President Bush has said he would consider lifting the sanctions if de Klerk continues with reforms aimed at negotiating a new constitution that would include the 28 million-member black majority. Last month de Klerk legalized more than 60 opposition groups, including the ANC, and freed ANC leader Nelson Mandela. The U.S. delegation includes: Howard Wolpe, D-Mich.; Dean Gallo, R-N.J.; Steny Hoyer, D-Md.; Ron Dellums, D-Calif.; Steven Solarz, D-N.Y.; Mike Andrews, D-Texas; Beverly Byron, D-Md.; Victor Fazio, D-Calif.; and Jim McCrery, R-La.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Glamorization of Drugs `Fading Fast'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 10-12, Bush said people, with remarks at drug rally, embargoed for 3:40 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today the glamorization of drug use in popular culture is ``fading fast'' and urged television producers to show how illegal drugs destroy lives. Bush's anti-drug speech was interrupted when a man in the ballroom audience of TV industry members leaped up and shouted, ``Why don't you ever talk about AIDS? Why don't you lead the country on AIDS?'' Bush, smiling slightly, stopped speaking and looked at the man as he continued shouting from his table and was joined by a second protester. Some in the audience shouted for them to sit down, and the two submitted to hotel security people who briskly led them from the room. As they left, Bush said his administration has increased federal funds ``to an all time high,'' for AIDS programs ``to try to help people who are concerned, and we will continue.'' He then said, ``I've come a long way in my own political maturity. This guy's intervention doesn't bother me one little bit and I'm glad we live in a country where we can all speak up even if it takes advantage of the hospitality of you all.'' Bush's speech to the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences came a day after he urged business people to screen job applicants for drug use. He called on the academy to make TV ``a force for positive change'' through anti-drug education. The president praised an upcoming cartoon program called ``Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue,'' in which several cartoon producers collaborated on a story about a boy who says no to drugs. ``Never before in cartoon history have Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck worked with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, the Muppets, the Smurfs and all the other stars of the cartoon world,'' Bush told a breakfast meeting of the academy before heading to Santa Ana for an anti-drug rally.
DOC.HEAD: Following 3 grafs embargoed for 3:40 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Bush said people around the country ``in thousands of towns are standing up to make the same courageous choice: drug-free neighborhoods, drug-free schools, drug-free kids.'' ``We have seen some scattered but hopeful new signs of progress against the horror of drugs,'' Bush said in remarks for the Santa Ana rally, recounting examples of communities that banded together to drive out drug pushers. ``The days of the drug lords may not be over yet but their days are numbered,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: End Embargoed Material
DOC.TEXT: Bush later today was flying to Palm Springs to conclude his West Coast visit in talks with Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, scheduled to begin late this afternoon. ``Thank goodness the days when popular culture glorified and glamorized drug use are fading fast,'' Bush said. ``I'm not asking you to compromise your art'' by portraying ``a fantasy world where drugs don't exist,'' he told the elevision academy members. Rather, he said, he was entreating them ``to show in the real world how drugs destroy.'' On Thursday night, Bush called on business leaders at a California Chamber of Commerce dinner to ``help us turn the tables against the dealers, turn them forever.'' ``So-called casual users and their money keep these merchants of death in business,'' he said. ``America now condemns what has too long been condoned. The country has had enough,'' he declared. Noting that many businesses already conduct pre-employment drug screening, Bush told the group: ``We need to make it very clear, to every American, that if you do drugs, you don't get hired.'' He said every city should have a safe house on each block where youths can go for help, information about drugs and ``refuge from dealers.'' Bush later was flying to Palm Springs where he invited Kaifu for a round of talks focusing mainly on trade issues that have left the United States with a $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Bush told former President Reagan about his upcoming meeting when he paid a courtesy call Thursday in Los Angeles. ``It's going to be an interesting meeting. I've mentioned we've got to move forward on some of the tough problems we have,'' Bush said. The president told the Chamber of Commerce gala on Thursday night his meeting with Kaifu would entail ``very important business.'' He said it was fitting that he will see the prime minister in California, a reference to the state's interest in U.S.-Japan relations because of the many areas of industrial competition, including autos, agriculture and electronics. Kaifu said on the eve of his visit that he hoped to convince Bush that Japan is making progress in opening its markets and cutting its trade surplus with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Christians Fight Room to Room For Control of Enclave
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled room to room in a high-rise building Friday as Gen. Michel Aoun's troops surged toward the waterfront for control of Lebanon's crumbling Christian enclave. Outside, as the city shook from artillery exchanges, Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Butros Sfeir threatened to excommunicate Aoun and Samir Geagea of the Lebanese Forces militia if they continued fighting. Sfeir urged both commanders to ``have mercy on the population and observe a cease-fire immediately.'' ``Whoever gives the order to shoot and whoever obeys such orders will be excommunicated,'' Sfeir warned, including their troops in the threat. Geagea's militia has 6,000 members; Aoun commands 19,000 men. Shortly after Sfeir's appeal, Aoun said he ordered his forces to observe a cease-fire. Fighting continued all day, although the intensity of the artillery duels decreased noticeably, police said. Smoke billowed from the contested neighborhoods in the 310-square-mile enclave. A casualty figure was not available from the fierce clashes in the low-income residential districts of Nabaa and Sin el-Fil, strongholds for Geagea's militia. At least 46 people were killed and 77 wounded overnight. Aoun appeared to be trying to take the neighborhoods in a drive toward Beirut port to cut off Geagea's headquarters from a key stronghold. Aoun's U.S.-made tanks fired at close range at apartments, cars and ``anything that faces them,'' the police spokesman said. ``They are applying scorched earth combat tactics. The whole district is on fire,'' the spokesman said. Police said Aoun's troops fought the militiamen from room to room for control of the 12-story Shalouhi building that commands the street linking the embattled districts with the seaside boulevard. A spokesman said the strategic building repeatedly changed hands throughout the day. It was occupied by Aoun's commandos in a swift attack at first light, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with regulations. Geagea's men, he said, launched a counteroffensive about 10 a.m. and regained control of the building. The army attacked again at noon ``and the battles have been going on inside the building. Both forces are there,'' the spokesman said. The building housed the offices of a number of foreign corporations and prominent Lebanese firms. These included The American Express bank, the Dutch airline KLM and the Reuters news agency. Reuters has another office in west Beirut. Lebanese couturier Choueiter, who has a shop in Paris, had his east Beirut offices in the building. Most clients evacuated in the early days of the battle when the neighborhood was first shelled, starting a fire on the building's ninth floor. Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi said his government, based in Moslem west Beirut, ``would intervene in the proper time'' to end the bloodshed, which has killed 754 people and wounded 2,061 since it broke out Jan. 30. Hrawi, addressing a news conference at his temporary residence, said he soon will tour Arab nations to enlist support for plans to halt the Christian battle. He urged Aoun's men to join Gen. Emile Lahoud, appointed by Hrawi to replace Aoun as commander of the armed forces a few hours after he was elected president Nov. 24. Aoun, Geagea, Hrawi and Lahoud are Maronites, the Catholic community that has dominated Lebanon since independence from France in 1943. Hrawi also sharply attacked a mediation effort by the Palestine Liberation Organization, saying, ``They have come to rescue us after they caused our war. They started Lebanon's tragedy. ... We don't need their advice.'' He was referring to the nearly 15-year-old civil war which started as a clash between Arafat's guerrillas and the Christians in April 1975. Aoun has rejected parliament's election last fall of Hrawi, who has pledged to enact a peace pact. Aoun says he opposes the peace plan because it does not require the pullout of 40,000 Syrian troops, deployed under a 1976 Arab League mandate to keep the peace in the civil war. Hrawi fired Aoun as army commander, but Aoun refused to step down.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Senator Says He Wants to Run for President
LaserPhotos MLA5,7
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile announced from jail Friday that he intends to run for president in 1992 if he is cleared of criminal charges related to the December coup attempt against Corazon Aquino. Enrile has been in custody since Tuesday, when he was charged with ``rebellion with murder'' in connection with the sixth and most serious attempt to overthrow President Aquino. He said he will accept the presidential challenge if the opposition Nationalista Party, of which he is the secretary-general, nominates him, and if he is acquitted of the charges. Mrs. Aquino's popularity remains high among many Filipinos, but the constitution bars the president from seeking a second term. Also Friday, hotel owner Rebecco Panlilio and his wife Erlinda, who were charged Tuesday with Enrile, surrendered to the National Bureau of Investigation, officials said. Enrile and the Panlilio couple were among seven people so far indicted in the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. One of the seven, who remains at large, is cashiered Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, Enrile's former chief security aide who led an August 1987 mutiny against Mrs. Aquino. The Panlilios were allegedly at Enrile's home on Dec. 1, when witnesses claimed they saw Honasan and about 100 rebel soldiers also at the senator's residence. Enrile claims he has not seen Honasan since 1987. Enrile was defense minister under President Ferdinand Marcos but turned against the autocratic ruler in February 1986 in the military mutiny that swept Mrs. Aquino to power. He was fired as defense minister in November 1986, after his followers tried to oust Mrs. Aquino. The Supreme Court has set a hearing Tuesday on a petition by Enrile's lawyers questioning the legality of the charges. Enrile says they were filed to punish him for opposing Mrs. Aquino. The high tribunal also ordered government lawyers to answer within 10 days the Panlilio couple's petition challenging the validity of the charges against them. Meanwhile, about 300 supporters of Mrs. Aquino picketed the Senate on Friday protesting ``special treatment'' they say is being considered for Enrile. Senators have been debating since Wednesday a proposal to ask the court to put Enrile under the custody of the Senate's sergeant-at-arms so he could attend sessions. Enrile's lawyers said they will ask the court handling the charges to delay a scheduled arraignment Monday pending a decision on the petition for freedom. Under the law, rebellion is punishable by up to 12 years imprisonment, and murder carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. About 3,000 mutinous troops, many of them from the army's elite Scout Ranger Regiment, launched the December coup attempt in which at least 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Pleads No Contest in Toddler's Potty-Training Death
DOC.TEXT: The mother of a toddler who died after repeatedly being dunked headfirst into a toilet struck a deal with prosecutors today, pleading no contest to a second-degree murder charge. Under the plea accepted by Circuit Judge Dale Durrance, Sheryl McGee Coe, 21, will face no more than 30 years in prison for her role in the July 28 death of 2-year-old Bradley McGee. The Lakeland woman had been charged with first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse charges, which could have brought a life prison term. Her husband Thomas Edward Coe, 22, faces trial on the same charges this summer in Fort Lauderdale, and prosecutors have said they intend to seek the death penalty. Bradley died July 28 after he was dunked head first into a toilet for soiling his pants, authorities charge. The toddler had spent most of his life in foster care after he was abandoned at a Lakeland mall. The boy's death prompted an indictment against four state social workers and a special legislative session to boost state spending for child protective services. Charges have been dismissed against one social worker, and a second won an acquittal Tuesday when a Polk County judge threw out a misdemeanor charge. Kenneth Houk, the acquitted 18-year veteran of the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services, called the whole experience a nightmare. ``I kept thinking I was going to wake up and never did,'' Houk said Thursday. ``Children are sacred to me. ... They have always been and they will continue to be _ Bradley McGee or any child.'' The pain of the boy's death and the criminal charge haunted Houk. He said he lost 23 pounds and was bothered by nausea and bad dreams. Houk was an administrator in the division supervising Bradley when the toddler died. Houk voluntarily took a demotion and now finds jobs for single mothers.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leader Excludes Return to One-Party Rule
DOC.TEXT: A Communist Party leader declared Friday that his party now supported democracy and opposed any attempts to restore its former monopoly on power. Communist Party First Secretary Vasil Mohorita said the party was willing to play the role of a constructive opposition if, as expected, it loses in free elections scheduled for June 8. ``Our main priority is to convince the people that we do not wish a return to the old days, not to win the elections,'' said Mohorita, who became first secretary after the party's hard-line leadership was ousted during last year's democratic revolution. ``A return to the thesis of one-party rule must not be allowed, this monopoly on power must be prevented,'' he added. After 41 years of orthodox, one-party Communist rule, Czechoslovakia underwent a peaceful revolution last November and December that introduced political pluralism. Mohorita said the communists should not be concerned about winning the elections, but rather must convince Czechoslovaks that they now support democracy. ``We have to show the people that we have been participating in these (democratization) processes from the beginning, and if we have to be in opposition, it will be a constructive one,'' he said. Despite losing its hold on power, the Communist Party still has some 1 million members ``or maybe a little less,'' Mohorita said. The party claimed 1.7 million members before the start of last year's revolution. Some 1.3 million of those people joined the party after the purge of half a million members that followed the 1968 Soviet-led invasion that crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reform movement. Mohorita indicated that party members who do not support the new pro-democracy policy would be dropped from the ranks. He admitted that an unspecified number of party members still favor orthodox one-party rule, but stressed that ``we have to part with these people.'' Mohorita said there was a need for ``deep, critical but very serious analysis'' of the past four decades of communist rule, but he complained of what he called increasingly sharp attacks against the party in the media it once controlled. A career Communist official, Mohorita led the state-controlled Socialist Youth Union until tumultuous changes in the party propelled him into the position of first secretary in December. At the same time, Ladislav Adamec was named chairman of the party.

DOC.HEAD: More Study, Fewer Risks Necessary for Mars Mission, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 14th graf, NASA Administrator ... with NASA reaction; picks up 14th graf pvs, David Beckwith ...
DOC.TEXT: Before carrying out President Bush's proposal for a base on the Moon and a manned mission to Mars, the space agency needs to study new technologies and eliminate ``unacceptable risks to the crew,'' the National Research Council said Friday. In a report requested by Vice President Dan Quayle, the council said the exploration plan by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration ``addresses a reasonable set of technological and strategic approaches, but not all of the technically credible approaches have been analyzed.'' The council, an arm of the congressionally chartered National Academy of Sciences, also said: _Operation of a U.S. space station by the late 1990's as scheduled is a ``reasonable assumption,'' but present plans for the station are not adequate for a Moon-Mars mission. The station ``may not be the most appropriate staging base for the Moon and Mars,'' or, two stations may be needed. _Nuclear power ``eventually will be essential'' for the Moon and Mars bases. Also, nuclear propulsion of spacecraft, included by NASA as an option, should be tested. ``The use of nuclear technology in space faces formidable barriers of public acceptance, however, especially if employed in Earth orbit. Therefore, issues of safety are paramount in research and development.'' _Although the NASA proposals envision bases on Mars ``it appears that a station in Mars orbit requires a less demanding infrastructure than a surface base and might serve a useful purpose in the early stages of human space exploration.'' _Possiblities for international cooperation should be explored because breakthroughs have been made in Europe, Japan and elsewhere and ``most importantly, the USSR has substantial relevant capability, demonstrated continued inerest in Mars, and an apparent strong desire for cooperation with the U.S. in Mars exploration.'' The council's study, made by a 14-member committee named in January, said it was vital to the Moon-Mars mission that the United States have ``the capability to send humans into space, maintain them in a physical condition that permits them to work productively, and return them to Earth in good health.'' However, it added, ``it has not been demonstrated after long-duration spaceflight individuals can readjust rapidly to gravity without serious physiological consequences.'' It said research into this problem was ``critical'' to the design of the bases and vehicles. It said this should include study of artificial gravity, not included by NASA in its list of critical technologies for the mission. ``With the current state of knowledge, a multiyear exposure to weightlessness, even with on-board exercise and countermeasures and an intermediate stay on the surface of Mars, presents unacceptable risks to the crew,'' the committee said. Bush announced a U.S. commitment for humans to return to the Moon and journey to Mars in a speech last July 20, the 20th anniversary of the 1969 moon landing. He asked Quayle, chairman of the National Space Council to come up with recommendations for carrying out the initiative. NASA made a 90-day study, and Quayle asked the National Research Council to evaluate it. NASA Administrator Richard Truly said in a written statement issued by the space agency's public affairs office, ``NASA is pleased that, after careful consideration, the NRC panel found the material developed in NASA's 90-day study accurate and appropriate to the human exploration initiative at this stage in its development.'' David Beckwith, the vice president's press secretary, said, ``It's a very interesting report, and we are pleased and grateful.'' The council said costs of the program ``are uncertain _ and likely to remain so for some time.'' It said it appeared unlikely ``for technical and cost reasons'' that the space station could be built in time so that Americans could reach Mars by 2011, as envisioned in the most ambitious NASA plan. The other NASA option calls for exploration in 2018. The panel disagreed with the contention of scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory that humans could be placed on Mars by the year 2000. It said that ``underestimates the many practical and difficult engineering and operational challenges involved.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhotos NY44
DOC.TEXT: Waylon Jennings is confident his 10-city concert tour with Johnny Cash, Kris Kristofferson and Willie Nelson will ``breathe new life into us.'' The country music stars, who have recorded two albums as the ``Highwaymen,'' open their first joint tour this month in Houston. ``I think we're going to find when we get through doing this, that it's going to breathe new life into us,'' Jennings told reporters Thursday. Kristofferson said he hopes the tour can eventually go overseas. ``We want to take this all over the world _ play Moscow, Berlin, Sydney ... Tokyo,'' he said. Their first album, ``Highwayman,'' released in 1985, has sold more than 1 million copies, and ``Highwayman 2'' was released this week.

Four-time Grammy Award winner Bonnie Raitt, Don Henley and Richard Marx head the lineup at the Farm Aid IV concert in the Hoosier Dome on April 7. Tickets go on sale for $30 each Saturday at all Ticketmaster locations. Singers Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp and Neil Young are organizing the fourth concert to benefit the nation's farmers. Dick Clark, Michelle Greene and Sarah Purcell will be host of the marathon show that tentatively features 60 acts. Others expected to perform include Guns 'n Roses, John Denver, LL Cool J, Carl Perkins, John Prine, Was Not Was, Forrester Sisters, Gorky Park, Arlo Guthrie, Kris Kristofferson, K.T. Oslin, Poco, Jackson Browne, Iggy Pop, Lou Reed, Ricky Van Shelton and Dwight Yoakum.

Billy Joel says he didn't start the fire, but he certainly helped fan one under Cloquet High School freshman Kevin Shutes. Shutes correctly identified and described 116 of the 119 people, places and events in Joel's hit song, ``We Didn't Light the Fire,'' in a trivia contest sponsored by the Carlton County Historical Society. His reward included the $25 top prize, a year's membership in the society, free pizzas, car washes and movie passes. ``I thought all the entrants really did a great job,'' said the society's director Ellen Quinn, who organized the contest to help broaden the students' knowledge of history. ``I was surprised by the amount of time they put in and how complete their answers were,'' she said Thursday. Shutes ``had very complete answers and even went into a little commentary.'' Shutes described ``Woodstock,'' a word in the song, as ``a massive rock 'n' roll orgy that involved 500,000 young people out for a good time. They completely took over the area and indulged in sex and drugs freely. The sanitary conditions were said to have been disgusting.'' He identified ``Studebaker'' as ``a short-lived product of the car industry. A free pony was offered to consumers who purchased the car.'' For extra credit, Shutes noted singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, who gets a mention in the song, was born Duluth and reared in Hibbing. The three references he stumbled on were: ``Sugar Ray,'' ``Pope Paul,'' and ``Santayana.'' He incorrectly identified boxing champion Sugar Ray Robinson as a baseball player; he confused Pope Paul VI of Italy with John Paul II, as the first Polish pope, and misidentified philospher George Santayana as the 1960s rock band Santana.

A woman who alleges she was sexually assaulted by author Hunter S. Thompson admits she produced X-rated movies in the 1970s. But she claims not to know where the ``gonzo'' journalist got the idea that she's now in the sex-aids trade. Gail M. Palmer-Slater of St. Clair, Mich., alleged she went to Thompson's Woody Creek home on Feb. 21 to conduct a ``professional interview'' because she idolized him, she said in an interview Thursday with the Aspen Times Daily. She said when she refused to join him in his hot tub, he allegedly punched her and grabbed her breast. Thompson, the author of ``Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail,'' told the newspaper that Palmer-Slater ``was real drunk, sloppy drunk'' and pressured him to have sex with her. ``I pushed her away from me,'' he said. ``She went backward and one hand brushed her breast.'' Thompson, who lives near Aspen, was arrested Monday on sex assault and simple assault charges, and later freed on $2,000 bond. He is expected to enter a plea at a March 13 hearing. He said Palmer-Slater came to his house to talk about a new business venture. ``She wanted me to help her get publicity for her business, which is women's lingerie and dildos,'' Thompson said. Thompson said he had seen porno videotapes of Slater made in the mid-1970s, when she was in her 20s. Slater said she was a video and film producer in the 1970s and that she sometimes appeared in the productions. Jim Holliday, author of ``Only the Best,'' a history of the porn film industry, said a woman named Gail Palmer produced and directed porn films in the 1970s, including ``The Erotic Adventures of Candy'' and ``Candy Goes to Hollywood'' in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leaders Meet March 11; May Drop Party Control of Institutions
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party Central Committee will meet March 11 to consider new party rules that drop the requirement for party officials to monitor administrators of virtually every factory and institution, it was reported Friday. Communist Party leaders in February agreed to give up their monopoly on power, and compete in a multiparty system. But reformers say the change will be ineffective unless the party also abolishes its committees in virtually every factory and institution in the country. In a related decision, the ruling bureau of the Communist Party of Lithuania decided to suspend the activities of party members in the affairs of the Interior Ministry, KGB, customs, Ministry of Justice, prosecutor's office, courts, and the economic inspection department, the Interfax service of Radio Moscow reported. The Lithuanian Communists broke off from the national party in December. They have led the way on a number of key reforms. The national party leaders also will prepare for the March 12 opening of the Congress of People's Deputies, which is expected to approve the party's proposal for a more powerful presidency. Interfax said the Central Committee will return to its session to nominate its candidate for president after the Congress passes the appropriate constitutional amendments. Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev is expected to be elected to the post, probably by the Congress during that same week.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Actor William Shatner, who commanded the starship Enterprise on the television show ``Star Trek'' to boldly go where no man has gone before, took a stroll recently _ and got lost. Jennifer Watson, an advertising copywriter for radio station WSM, said Friday she gave Shatner a ride two months ago when he showed up at the station, lost on foot after leaving his nearby hotel for an appointment. She recalled driving the actor a mile from the station to the studios of The Nashville Network cable station. She said Friday she was embarrassed because her old car had a banana peel in it. She has since traded her old car in for a newer model. Last week, she received an envelope with a letter inside on Shatner's stationery. The letter said, ``For your new car...'' and had a banana peel wrapped in plastic. Watson said the appreciative actor had apparently been alerted about her new car by some of her friends at the station. ``I just kind of yelled,'' she said about her reaction to his note. ``I ran up and down the hall yelling, `Look what I got.'''

The city has a message for the mascot of a restaurant called Lotta-Bull: it's no bull _ no bull. City officials say the restaurant that uses a strolling bull to promote its carnivore-friendly menu is ranging beyond the limits of the law. When the Lotta-Bull mascot _ actually a man in a $300 bull suit _ roams through parking lots and waves to passing cars, code enforcement officers say he violates Rockville's ban on outdoor signs. Paul Tibolla, owner of Lotta-Bull, who often is the man inside the suit, was unrepentant. ``When I send the bull out, business goes up,'' he said. Tibolla received warnings from the city before being fined $75 last week. The city's 1984 sign ordinance, designed to curb the number of signs on an already cluttered retail landscape, strictly forbids ``freestanding signs which have the shape in the form of any person, animal, vegetable, product or animation of any of the foregoing.'' Lawyer Stanton Gildenhorn decided to take the bull by the horns and advised Tibolla not to pay the fine and take the matter to court. ``I couldn't conceive how any jurisdiction could bust this bull,'' Gildenhorn said. The lawyer said he would argue in court that Tibolla's use of the bull costume is an exercise of his First Amendment rights.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Politicians Line Up To Confess Former Pot Use
DOC.TEXT: In a remarkable mass mea culpa, Massachusetts politicians are lining up to confess their past dalliance with marijuana, an urge to repent that began when the attorney general fessed up to using the demon weed. State Attorney General James Shannon, 37, went to the ``confessional'' first during a mid-week television interview, where he was being queried about his tough stance on casual drug users. Within 24 hours, more politicians lined up at the booth. Allegations of drug use may have locked federal appeals Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg out of a U.S. Supreme Court seat, but in Massachusetts the new political wisdom seems to dictate that there is safety in numbers. On Friday, the Boston Herald, under the Page One headline ``Pols who have gone to pot,'' lined up thumbnail photos of some who acknowledged dabbling in marijuana use. The politicians made their admissions when asked by the newspaper. The growing list includes six Democrats _ U.S. Sen. John Kerry, U.S. Reps. Joseph Kennedy and Richard Neal; Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, who is a candidate for governor; state Auditor Joseph DeNucci; and state Sen. William Golden, who is running for lieutenant governor. There are two Republicans, both running for lieutenant governor _ Paul Cellucci and state Rep. Peter Torkildsen. The admissions all sound a similar theme. They contain references to youthful indiscretion, lessons learned and reason that comes with age. Most of those coming forward point out that they grew up in an era when drug experimentation was as common as doing the twist and wearing Beatle haircuts. Kennedy, 37, said in a statement: ``Like many people my age, I tried it when I was younger, but I certainly believe that there is no benefit to drug use and there can be terrible consequences.'' And Ms. Murphy, 49, who acknowledged using marijuana once or twice, said the public will have to judge the conduct of those now admitting prior drug use. ``I think we're much wiser about the damage drugs have done,'' she said. There are, of course, staunch holdouts who say they never smoked marijuana. A former U.S. attorney accused his predecessor, William Weld, of smoking pot at a party. Weld, now a GOP gubernatorial candidate, was exonerated of that charge. His spokesman, Ray Howell, reiterated Friday that the 44-year-old Weld has never tried drugs. At a shopping center near the Statehouse, several people seemed positively underwhelmed by the news that their elected officials had smoked pot in college. ``I really think it shouldn't be a big deal,'' said Bruce Hall, a 39-year-old construction worker. His buddy, Jim Mooreside, 41, agreed: ``I think it might hurt their image, but I don't see why.'' And one 40-year-old woman, Sherry Flashman, who works in planning, chastised the politicians for decrying their past drug use. ``I really think it's a problem with this society that there can't be an acknowledgment that a lot of people did it and it wasn't a terrible thing,'' said Flashman. ``I think that's the real shame.''

DOC.HEAD: Reform Hurts Readiness of Once-Feared Warsaw Pact Frontline Force
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's army has suffered a loss of morale, readiness and nearly a quarter of its troops since the borders were opened and the perception of a threat from the West began to diminish. East German troops have deserted, sold their uniforms in the West and some even refused to take part in a military exercise last month with Soviet troops. Defense Minister Theodor Hoffmann has conceded that reform has inflicted ``many difficulties'' on the once-feared frontline force of the Warsaw Pact. ``We are practically without subordinates,'' a senior army officer said. ``The officers themselves have to walk patrols and service tanks.'' The officer, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said the army has been hit hard by the departure of thousands of soldiers through the open borders with the West. Col. Gerd Aperz of the Defense Ministry information office said reports of the East German army's diminished defense capability have been exaggerated in the West, but confirmed the emigration to West Germany has taken its toll on the force. He also noted that more than 10 percent of the National People's Army troops are deployed in factories, municipal maintenance crews and in other public works to keep crucial industries and services operating despite the daily departure of thousands of workers. More than 40,000 soldiers have left army service since Jan. 26, when a military reform was announced to cut what was then a 200,000-troop force to 110,000 by the end of the year, Aperz said. But other Defense Ministry sources said only about half of the departures were due to the planned reduction that was to be phased in over the year. Increasing numbers have deserted to seek their fortunes in the West, or failed to report back from furloughs amid a noticeable decline in discipline and readiness, the sources said. Capt. Olaf Marks said nearly half of the 2,000 soldiers stationed at his 23rd Rifle Regiment based in Bad Salzungen had left in recent weeks. They join more than 400,000 East Germans who have fled to West Germany since last summer, having abandoned hope that their living standards will improve. Reform is being blamed for much of the decline in what was once viewed as the strongest fighting force in Eastern Europe and the most strategically located, due to its border with NATO member West Germany. Improved relations between the two Germanys, as well as between the two military alliances to which they belong, have changed perceptions of Westerners from enemies to friends and greatly reduced East German fears of a military threat emanating from across the border. A young officer at this week's session of political talks between Communists and opposition parties said many East German soldiers can no longer conceive of circumstances that would prompt them to take up arms against their West German brothers. Hoffmann, the defense minister, also addressed the session, appealing to politicians not to make the army a campaign instrument in the March 18 balloting, East Germany's first free elections. Expectations of imminent unification of the two Germanys has encouraged the East German force to seek means of cooperating with the West German Bundeswehr, rather than planning for counterattacks that seem increasingly unlikely to be needed. Military strategists from East Germany and West Germany have been discussing ways of sharing defense burdens in the event the nations are unified. A joint East German-Soviet exercise near Berlin in early February had to be scaled back after some East German troops refused to take part. Aperz confirmed some soldiers objected because they ``considered the exercise to be in conflict with the new reform character'' of the army, but denied reports the soldiers refused to work with the Soviet troops. East Germany is host for the bulk of the Soviet Union's 565,000 troops deployed in Eastern Europe, which has long been a matter of resentment among residents of the regions where the Soviets are stationed. The Kremlin has not yet faced significant pressure from East Germans to pull out its troops, but a large withdrawal is expected to be negotiated soon at the Vienna-based negotiations on conventional armed forces. In the meantime, signs abound that the army has been taking its responsibilities less seriously. In search of hard currency to buy consumer goods during Western visits, some soldiers sell their uniform jackets, hats and ensignia at the thriving West Berlin flea market near the Checkpoint Charlie border crossing. On a recent afternoon, one brown-clad soldier approaching a ditch-digging brigade drew a crowd of impressed fellow soldiers around him when he displayed what two passing American reporters mistook for a grenade launcher. ``It's a muffler,'' the soldier corrected the foreigners as his fellow troops broke into howls of laughter. ``I just bought it over in West Berlin.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Model in Washington Mayor Arrest Sentenced in DUI Case
DOC.TEXT: The ex-model who helped the FBI arrest Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry on a drug charge pleaded no contest to drunken driving Friday and was sentenced to three years' probation and fined $927. Hazel Diane Moore, 38, of Burbank, known while modeling as Rasheeda Moore, was not at the Van Nuys court. Defense attorney Ron Lewis entered the plea for her, said Ted Goldstein, a city attorney's office spokesman. Court Commissioner Mitchell Block assessed a fine of $390 and penalties that boosted the total to $927. Ms. Moore also was ordered to attend a 90-day alcohol education school. A 90-day restriction was placed on her driver's license allowing her only to drive to and from work, and to and from the school. She was stopped by north Hollywood police on Jan. 1 at 11:40 p.m. because she was driving with her headlights off. Ms. Moore, a friend of Barry, worked as an undercover informant for the FBI, calling the mayor to a Washington hotel room where he was arrested Jan. 18 for investigation of possessing cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Transit Chief Takes Wrong Subway Train on First Day on Job
DOC.TEXT: The president of the city's Transit Authority had a rough first day on the job: He took the wrong train. Alan Kiepper also said he gave another subway rider the wrong directions. ``Needless to say, I was somewhat embarrassed,'' Kiepper said. ``I got off to a rocky start.'' Kiepper, who started his job Thursday after heading transit systems in Houston and Atlanta, began his day with a subway map in hand at a station near his midtown Manhattan home. ``I always have a subway map, but I was distracted by the gentleman asking about the (other) train,'' Kiepper said. He then saw what he thought was his train and got aboard to go to the Transit Authority headquarters in Brooklyn. ``As I hopped on the train, I noticed it was not full,'' he said. ``I got on a train going to Queens.'' He said the mix up made him 10 minutes late for a staff meeting.

DOC.HEAD: BBC to Expand in US, Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The British Broadcasting Corp. announced plans Friday to expand its news programs in the United States and Eastern Europe. ``One of the main principles behind the success of our international broadcasting is that we broadcast to our friends as well as those who _ until recently _ were enemies,'' said John Tusa, managing director of the BBC World Service. ``We talk to open as well as to closed societies,'' he said. Tusa said that later this month, Americans will be able to dial up the latest BBC news program by telephone at any time ``for less than a dollar a minute.'' One cable television service, C-Span, is devoting an audio channel to a 24-hour relay of BBC news and Tusa expects it to grow from its present 1 million subscribers. He said he also hopes for growth in an arrangement with American Public Radio that permits any of its stations to relay all BBC world service material from midnight to six in the morning. Tusa, who was born in Czechoslovakia, said Eastern European countries still need to hear controversy, comment and news from a broad international viewpoint. He said non-Communist leaders in Eastern Europe have asked the BBC to continue its programing and are giving it facilities for local rebroadcast. To show the influence BBC broadcasts have had, Tusa held up a photograph taken last June in Tiananmen Square before Chinese tanks put down the pro-democracy movement. Students were carrying the Chinese flag and a sign in both English and Chinese. In English it said, ``Thank you BBC.'' Tusa added that BBC officials are asking Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government for more money but declined to say how much. He insisted that government financing does not lessen BBC independence. ``The Foreign Office does not even attempt to tell us what to say,'' Tusa told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershock Jolts Southern Californians Amid Quake Cleanup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with landslide, new quote, editing to conform; picks up 9th graf pvs, `The quake, felt ...'
DOC.TEXT: A wide area of Southern California rolled today with another aftershock of Wednesday's big earthquake, triggering a rockslide on a mountain road but no reports of significant damage or injuries. The quake shook Los Angeles, Riverside, San Bernardino and San Diego counties. It also hit Orange County, where President Bush was addressing a noon anti-drug rally. The aftershock measured 4.7 on the Richter scale at 9:26 a.m., said Robert Finn, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. It was preceded today by a 2.5 quake at 2:52 a.m. and followed within two hours by about 10 quakes under magnitude 2.5, including a 2.4 at 10:41 a.m., according to Caltech. A rockslide closed Mount Baldy Road in the mountains north of Upland and only residents were allowed through, Caltrans spokesman Anthony Hughes said. ``It was scary and I'm shaking. But nothing fell or flew this time,'' said Melina Manning of Ontario, two miles south of the epicenter. ``All the pans and the lights swayed back and forth. It was mild compared to the other day but very scary especially because your nerves are shot from the other day.'' ``I was under the desk again. It was very strong here,'' said state Office of Emergency Services spokesman Michael Guerin in Ontario. The aftershocks came as Southern Californians bounced by the largest quake to hit the region in more than two years were sweeping up after millions of dollars in damage. City council members in Pomona _ hardest hit of several areas struck by Wednesday's earthquake _ said they would meet today to request that Gov. George Deukmejian assist them in obtaining federal or state funds to repair an estimated $10 million in damage in their city. The state Office of Emergency Services said Thursday the quake, measuring 5.5 on the Richter scale, caused at least $12.7 million damage in the cities of Claremont, Pomona, La Verne, Chino, Ontario, Rancho Cucamonga, Montclair and Upland and the counties of Los Angeles, Riverside and San Bernardino. The figure ``is very preliminary, based on information provided by cities and counties,'' said Guerin. The quake, felt along the coast from San Diego to Santa Barbara and as far east as Las Vegas, was centered on an unnamed fault three miles northwest of this city 40 miles east of Los Angeles. It toppled scores of chimneys, shattered hundreds of windows and collapsed one building's wall, but remarkably, caused no major injuries or deaths. Dozens of smaller aftershocks have rattled the area since. There was no official estimate of the number of injured other than ``several dozen'' from the OES. The most serious injuries, officials said, were a few broken bones. Only one person, a Pomona man, was known to have been left homeless by the quake. But the temblor spurred renewed calls for Southern Californians to prepare for the so-called ``Big One,'' a catastrophic earthquake measuring between 7.5 and 8 on the Richter scale of ground motion. A 1988 U.S. Geological Survey report said that a quake that size is at least 60 percent likely by the year 2018 on the southern San Andreas Fault. ``This is the handwriting on the wall and we better start looking at the design of some of our buildings,'' Pomona Vice Mayor Clay Bryant said Thursday. ``We've already been put on notice by a 5.5.'' Pomona Mayor Donna Smith said city inspectors were compiling a list of how many unreinforced masonry buildings remain in the city, which has several landmark structures more than 100 years old. She said 301 buildings in Pomona were damaged and 17 were declared uninhabitable. Pomona, Claremont and La Verne all declared local states of emergency Wednesday, but the La Verne City Council withdrew its declaration Thursday after determining damage was not as bad as first believed. The destruction was widely scattered throughout the region. In Pomona, for example, part of the south face of the 58-year-old brick-and-concrete Trinity United Methodist Church collapsed while the brick Pilgram Congregational Church a block away withstood the quake. At the city's historic Phillips Mansion, built in 1875, a chimney toppled onto a roof, causing an estimated $500,000 damage, but surrounding buildings were unscathed. Despite the damage, the quake was far less serious than the one that struck the Whittier area on Oct. 1, 1987. That one measured 5.9 and, together with a 5.3-magnitude aftershock on Oct. 4, killed eight people, injured more than 200 and caused $358 million in damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 5 can cause considerable damage and 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Block Moslem March to Srinagar
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Moslem separatists dressed in death shrouds tried to march to Srinagar on Friday, a day after government troops shot to death 49 Moslems, but soldiers blocked the rally, police said. The march was to have begun in Sumbal, 15 miles north of Srinagar, said a senior police official who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said at least 1,000 Moslems gathered in the town but were stopped by soldiers before they could leave for Srinagar. Witnesses contacted by telephone said the demonstrators had draped themselves in white burial shrouds to show they were willing to die in the fight for secession. A police officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said at least 49 people died and between 45 and 100 were injured Thursday in two incidents related to the Moslems' campaign. The government said the officers fired in self-defense. The militants want independence for the Moslem-dominated Kashmir region, a part of India's Jammu-Kashmir state. It is the only Moslem-dominated state in India, where the majority of the population is Hindu. The latest shootings prompted authorities to impose an indefinite curfew at 4 a.m. Friday on Sringar, which is the capital, and six other towns. It prevented Moslems from attending the weekly Friday prayers, which in the past have been flashpoints for trouble. Police said one group of separatists defied the curfew and gathered along Dal Lake, but they were chased away by paramilitary troops. An officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said one of the protesters fell to his death in the cold lake. The victim was not identified. The death brought to 162 the number of people killed in Kashmir since the current round of secession-related violence flared Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on Moslem militants. The violence brought criticism from neighboring Pakistan, a Moslem nation that disputes India's right to govern Kashmir. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's government said it condemned the ``brutal Indian response ... to the people of Kashmir, who were asking only for their right of self-determination.'' The Kashmir issue has been a point of contention between Pakistan and India since 1947, following the partition of the old British colonial Asian Subcontinent into two independent nations: mostly Hindu India and overwhelmingly Moslem Pakistan. Kashmir became a subject of dispute because its population was mostly Moslem but its ruler was a Hindu who wanted to join India. A brief war between the two countries left a slice of the valley under Pakistani control and the rest of Kashmir as part of the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir. A second war in 1965 did not change the situation.

DOC.HEAD: US Calls For Contra Demobilization, With Assurances
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Friday that immediate steps should be taken to encourage the demobilization of the Nicaraguan Contras but that the rebels must have ``full assurances'' beforehand for their personal and economic security. ``It is important that their legitimate needs be met,'' said department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler, noting that Central American presidents have signed agreements stating that the Contra concerns must not be ignored. The bulk of the Contra forces have spent most of the last two years at camps in Honduras. Ms. Tutwiler said the admnistration has dispatched veteran envoy Harry Shlaudeman to Honduras to confer with the Contras about their concerns. Shlaudeman served as ambassador to four South American countries and was called out of retirement last year to deal with the Nicaraguan issue. Ms. Tutwiler said that equally important to the Contra demobilization is the ``full and unequivocal transfer'' of civil and military power to the new Nicaraguan government. Both President Daniel Ortega and the victorious opposition candidate in Sunday's election, Violeta Chamorro, have said the Contras should be disbanded. Ortega has indicated that demobilization is necessary if a peaceful transition is to be carried out on April 25, inauguration day. But State Department officials said that a former Contra regional commander who went back to Nicaragua to join the election process several weeks ago accused the Sandinistas of mistreating returning Contras. The Contra officer, known as Comandante Johnson, said that of 41 rebels who had returned in peace, 27 were in prison, 12 were dead and only two were free. State Department officials, insisting on anonymity, said they believe Johnson's figures are essentially correct. About 10,000 rebels are at camps in southern Honduras, surviving on food and other necessities provided by the United States. The total number being cared for in the camps, including family members, is 60,000. The demobilization of the Contras and civilian control over the military, now under Sandinista party control, have dominated the political debate in Nicaragua since Mrs. Chamorro's election victory.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Fuel Prices Rise 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday ordered a 25 percent increase in fuel prices, which have nearly tripled since the first of the year. The price of gasoline rose from $2.15 a gallon to $2.93 a gallon. The prices for diesel fuel, kerosene, alcohol fuel and cooking gas also rose one-fourth. The government subsidizes alcohol to make it 25 percent cheaper than gasoline, although it costs twice as much as gasoline to produce. About one-third of Brazil's 13.5 million vehicles run on alcohol made from domestically grown sugar cane. The increase was the sixth since January, and 15 days after a 48 percent price hike. Fuel prices have risen 281 percent this year. The government adjusts fuel prices for inflation, which hit a record 73 percent for February. It raised prices 17 times in 1989, when inflation was 1,765 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Loyalists Stage Rally To Counter Anti-Government Protests
DOC.TEXT: Disabled Iranian war veterans staged a pro-government rally in Tehran on Friday in an apparent attempt to counter protests of the administration reported in the capital and other cities. Tehran radio said ``a large group'' of disabled veterans marched about 1{ miles through the capital from the former U.S. Embassy to the Tehran University campus. Residents of the capital have reported a number of angry or violent protests last week sparked by popular resentment over continued economic hardships faced by most Iranians. Friday's marchers, chanting pro-government slogans, joined the weekly prayers at the university campus. They called on judicial officials to crack down on opposition group members, profiteering shopkeepers and drug smugglers, the radio said. Although Iranian officials have kept reports of any unrest under wraps, a senior Iranian cleric Friday hinted at the trouble. Hojatoleslam Emami Kashani, addressing the weekly university prayer session, admitted that ``of course we have many economic problems, which the government is trying to solve.'' But he added, ``Some people ... say things out of ignorance such as `This (government) program cannot be pursued,' or `This program cannot solve the economic hardships.''' The state-run radio, television and the Islamic Republic News Agency, all monitored in Nicosia, have not reported any unrest in Iranian cities, apart from an IRNA report that 30 people were arrested Feb. 16 when soccer fans protested the cancellation of two matches. An Iranian newspaper, the Farsi-language Resalat, reported that some of the sports fans had ``taken advantage'' of the cancellations to voice other concerns. The country is plagued by soaring inflation, shortages of most commodities and high unemployment despite President Hashemi Rafsanjani's attempts to revitalize the economy. An Iranian opposition group, the Iraq-based Mujahedeen Khalq, has reported that security forces killed several hundred people while putting down recent anti-government protests in Tehran and the provincial centers of Isfahan, Shiraz, Tabriz and Mashad. The reports could not be independently confirmed. Iranian travelers to Cyprus have reported demonstrations in Tehran calling for stricter control of the Islamic dress code and expressing dissatisfaction with Rafsanjani's attempts to liberalize the tightly controlled society. A leading Iranian cleric, Ayatollah Ahmad Azari Qomi, said in a sermon last Friday that some agitators were stirring up relatives of those killed in the Islamic revolution, to convince them the state-run radio and television were airing un-Islamic programming. Such rhetoric about anti-Islamic moves has been voiced by radicals in the Tehran hierarchy who are locked in an intensifying power struggle with Rafsanjani's so-called pragmatic camp. The radicals, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, believe Rafsanjani's economic policies calling for foreign investment and ties with the West, plus his attempts to ease the government controls on the society, will dilute the fervor of the Islamic revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Cruises Quietly Through Last Full Day of Space Experiments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with inspection of solid rocket boosters; CLARIFY in 1st graf that Friday was last day of work on classified projects sted last day in orbit. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `As long as...
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' astronauts, silent to the world because of their military mission, put in a final day of work in orbit Friday on their hush-hush assignments before preparing for a Sunday landing. NASA said Atlantis is scheduled to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, and a spokesman said this means the five-member, all-military crew probably will spend most of Saturday packing up for the return to Earth. No information was released about the crew's activites in orbit, but Jeff Carr, a spokesman at the Johnson Space Center, said that if the Atlantis crew follows shuttle mission routine, then Friday was the final full day to complete the secret objectives. Typically, the day before landing ``is a day to clean up and start cabin stowage,'' Carr said. He said astronauts usually must spend their pre-return day in orbit dismantling and putting away equipment used during the mission. Carr said the astronauts on Saturday also must test fire the reaction control jets and check other critical systems that Atlantis will need during its fiery plunge through Earth's atmosphere. Workers, meanwhile, started inspections of the solid rocket boosters that were used to put Atlantis in orbit. The spent boosters were recovered from the sea, where they fell after the launch and towed to the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The boosters will be disassembled and refurbished for later use. NASA spokesperson Lisa Malone said a general inspection of the rockets didn't reveal any abnormalities, but noted, ``we really won't know until they're taken apart.'' It was a failed solid rocket booster that caused the 1986 Challenger accident that killed seven astronauts. The silence from Atlantis on Friday was good news, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. As long as there is no announcement from Mission Control, said Buckingham, ``we can safely assume there are no problems.'' A Pentagon-imposed blackout on mission details is to be broken sometime Saturday for an official NASA announcement of the precise landing time. This announcement usually comes 24 hours before landing. Sources at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the astronauts accomplished the major objective of their mission Thursday. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the astronauts successfully cast into orbit a $500 million spy satellite that will take detailed pictures of the Soviet Union, including areas not seen by previous shuttle-launch satellites. The spy craft also is able to tune into electronic communications all over the world, the sources said. Atlantis' mission began early Wednesday with a spectacular launch in darkness from the Kennedy Space Center. The liftoff came on the sixth attempt. Five earlier countdowns were halted due to weather, the illness of an astronaut and a failed computer. The mission is commanded by Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. Others in the crew are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Atlantis' flight is 34th shuttle mission and the sixth dedicated solely to the military.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Recovering from Successful Hand Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis rested at home Friday after undergoing surgery for a broken hand he suffered while helping push his father-in-law's car from a snowdrift, his press office said. Dukakis fractured the fourth and fifth metacarpals, the bones between the fingers and the wrist. During a two-hour operation at Brigham and Women's Hospital, done under local anesthesia, doctors used a plate and screws to set the bones in his left hand. The unsuccessful presidential candidate also tore the ligament on the inside of his right thumb during the Feb. 24 accident, and was expected to undergo minor surgery on that hand later. The governor was wearing a plaster splint, which will be replaced next week with a removable one. Healing will take up to six weeks, his doctors said.

DOC.HEAD: Fear of Arab Backlash Over Soviet Immigration Leads to Censorship
DOC.TEXT: Israel on Friday ordered journalists to submit all stories containing monthly Soviet immigration figures to the military censor, apparently because of fears the numbers will increase Arab opposition to the influx. In its announcement, the military censor said ``all material pertaining to immigration of Soviet Jews must be submitted to the censor prior to publication.'' The censor is not expected to release the data, so the screening process could amount to a ban. Previously, the media reported the figures without checking with the censor. The new restrictions were imposed after it was estimated this week that up to 230,000 Soviet Jews may immigrate this year, as opposed to earlier estimates of 80,000 to 100,000, the Maariv newspaper reported. Maariv said the higher figure was predicted by Yasha Kazakov, deputy head of the Liaison Bureau, a government unit that deals with Soviet immigration. The estimate ``created panic in the Arab countries, and the protests coming from these countries endanger immigration,'' the daily said. Yossi Ben-Aharon, Prime Minister Yizhak Shamir's top aide, agreed, saying that ``there is so much talk of numbers and forecasts that it caused damage. Why say 230,000 or whatever?'' Robert Slater, the head of the Foreign Press Association in Israel, said the restrictions are pointless because there already have been many detailed reports on Soviet immigration. ``We are extremely disappointed at the use of military censorship for political purposes,'' Slater added. Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office, called the restrictions ``very limited'' and denied they were imposed for political reasons, such as to silence debate on whether Soviet Jews can settle in the occupied territories. Israel denies it directs the flow of immigrants to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians are fighting for their own state. The United States and Soviet Union oppose new settlements in the occupied lands, saying they are an obstacle to making peace with the Palestinians. Arab leaders view even mass immigration to Israel proper as a grave threat. The latest immigration surge began last year, when 12,000 Soviet Jews came to Israel, in part because of relaxed emigration rules in the Soviet Union. In January 1990, 4,700 Soviet Jews immigrated. Israeli leaders have said they expect up to 750,000 this decade. Israel is hoping for $400 million in loan guarantees from the United States to help house the immigrants, and Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday the Bush administration may link that aid to assurances that no new Jewish settlements would be put in the occupied territories. The proposal brought angry responses from Israeli leaders Friday and concerns the disagreement could further delay Middle East peace talks. Shamir of the right-wing Likud bloc called the Baker proposal ``completely unneccesary'' and urged Washington to reconsider what he called the ``maddening idea.'' Shamir also criticized the timing of the remarks, noting that Baker is trying to persuade him to accept compromises to get U.S.-mediated peace talks started. ``No pressure, whether internal or external, will be able to influence me when it comes to vital national issues,'' Shamir told Israel television. In a rare show of unity, his rival, Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, joined in the criticism of Baker's proposal. Diplomatic sources in Washington said Friday the dispute over the U.S. aid, combined with other comments Baker made Thursday about the PLO, could set back the peace process even more. The sources, who refused to be identified, said Shamir had been prepared to recommend the Israeli government approve in principle a three-way meeting of Baker and the Egyptian and Israeli foreign ministers. But now, the sources said, that would be ``almost impossible.'' In addition to the aid proposal, Baker said Thursday in Washington he was satisfied that PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat was adhering to his December 1988 renunciation of terrorism against Israel. Baker said there was no evidence of Arafat's complicity in terrorism since then. Shamir is under pressure from Washington and from legislators at home to accept compromises so that preliminary peace talks with a Palestinian delegation can be held. Labor politicians want him to compromise, but hard-liners in Likud oppose any concessions. The country's top leaders are to meet Sunday on the issue. Baker said Thursday he expects a decision soon from the Shamir government on the peace process. ``We have done pretty much all we can do, we think, from our end, and we are waiting for a response from the Israeli government,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Earthquake Shakes Southern Illinois
With AM-SoCal Quake
DOC.TEXT: A mild earthquake shook people awake early Friday, generating dozens of calls to authorities but no reports of damage or serious injuries. The tremor, centered about 10 miles south of Vandalia, struck at 1:02 a.m. and registered 3.4 on the Richter scale, said Waverly Person, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. A quake of magnitude 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage. Person said small earthquakes occur frequently in the area. He said aftershocks were unlikely and the quake was too mild to extend outside Illinois. Southern Illinois rests on several fault lines, including the New Madrid Fault, which generated one of the most powerful earthquakes in U.S. history _ measuring an estimated 8.3 on the Richter scale _ near New Madrid, Mo., in the early 1800s. That fault, which extends from Cairo to Marked Tree, Ark., was not a factor in Friday's tremor, authorities said. The Marion and Clinton County sheriff's departments received about a dozen calls. ``One lady that lived in a government housing unit said the whole building shook,'' said Pauline Bliss, a Marion County corrections officer. ``One called us and thought they'd had a prowler in the house ... and another wanted to know if the (grain) elevator had collapsed or something.'' ``I was asleep and it kind of woke me up and I thought it was a big truck. We live right beside the interstate,'' said Martha Wilkes, a convenience-store employee in Sandoval. ``My husband told me, ``Something _ I don't know what it was _ but the whole house shook,''' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gandhi's Party Loses Heavily in State Elections
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's battered Congress Party was voted out of power in five of eight state legislatures this week, election results showed Friday. But it retained control in the western state of Maharashtra and awaited election results from the crucial state of Bihar, where it faced stiff competition from the Janata Dal party of Prime Minister V.P. Singh, Gandhi's arch political foe and successor. Elections, marked by widespread violence and allegations of vote fraud, were conducted Tuesday for 1,610 seats in the eight states and the federally administered Pondicherry region in the south. The Congress Party had controlled all nine legislatures. The defeats came three months after Gandhi's party lost power in national parliamentary elections. Political analysts and newspapers have attributed the defeats to alleged corruption and incompetence in the party's federal and state governments. At least 80 people were killed in Bihar, India's poorest state, in bomb blasts, police shootings and clashes since voting began this week. Nationwide, 98 people died in election-related violence. Results of Tuesday's elections showed the Congress Party had lost Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Orissa and Rajasthan to the Janata Dal and the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, or the Indian People's Party. Few results from the eighth state, Arunachal Pradesh, had come in. The Congress also lost the Pondicherry assembly. ``It would clearly take a superhuman effort by the party to recover the lost ground in the coming days,'' said The Statesman, a Calcutta-based independent daily. ``The results from Maharashtra came as a morale booster to the Congress, which had been stunned by its second debacle in three months,'' said another newspaper, Patriot. The Congress Party won 142 seats in the 288-member Maharashtra assembly. The Bharatiya Janata Party won 39, Janata Dal took 25 and the rest were splintered among smaller parties and independents. But overall, the Congress Party has only 343 of the 1,367 seats declared so far in the eight states and Pondicherry. In the eastern state of Bihar, which has the largest assembly among the nine territories, results of 136 constituencies had been announced, with the Congress getting 23 seats, the Janata Dal 52 and the Bharatiya Janata Party 15. The rest went to smaller parties and independent candidates. The Election Commission ordered repolling in 1,000 voting centers in Bihar after complaints of ballot stuffing, voter intimidation and widespread violence. On Friday, soldiers patrolled the streets of Meham town in Haryana state, where at least 13 people were killed during a by-election for the state legislature. The violence was blamed on supporters of Om Prakash Chauthala, the Janata Dal candidate in Meham and the chief minister of Haryana. Newspapers said violence erupted when supporters of Chauthala tried to stuff ballot boxes and scare voters in areas where he was not expected to get many votes. Chauthala, who was appointed to the chief minister's elected post, was required under Indian laws to seek voters' mandate to ratify his position. Janata Dal spokesman Jaipal Reddy said the party will take disciplinary action against Chauthala if he was found guilty of violence. ``Nobody will be above this process,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Deputy Premier Resigns from Socialist Party
DOC.TEXT: A former deputy prime minister accused of receiving a $2 million bribe resigned from the Socialist party on Friday, three days after Swiss authorities sent his bank records to Greek investigators. Agamemnon Koutsogiorgas, 68, said he was resigning temporarily until he cleared his name. He was indicted by Parliament in September on charges of accepting a bribe from banker George Koskotas. A former aide, Yannis Mantzouranis, told a parliamentary inquiry that Koutsogiorgas received a $2 million bribe in 1988 after passing legislation allegedly hindering Central Bank audits of Koskotas' privately owned Bank of Crete. Koskotas has been charged with embezzling $210 million from the bank. He fled to the United States in November 1988 where he is imprisoned in a Boston area jail fighting extradition to Greece. Papandreou and three other senior Socialist officials have also been indicted in connection with Koskotas' allegations that they authorized and took part in the embezzlement scheme. They face possible prison sentences of 10 years to life if convicted. No trial dates have been set. The contents of Koutsogiorgas' Swiss bank account, held jointly with his wife, have not been made public. Koutsogiorgas served in Andreas Papandreou's 1981-89 government in several posts. In 1974, he was one of the founders of the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or PASOK, and was Papandreou's personal lawyer and closest aide. The Socialists lost inconclusive elections in June and November, and participated in an all-party coalition from November to February. Koutsogiorgas and former Transport Minister George Petsos were barred by PASOK from running for Parliament in 1989. Petsos resigned from the party last year.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troops to Withdraw From Mongolia by 1992
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will withdraw all of its troops from Mongolia by 1992, Tass said Friday. Previously, the Soviets had said they would remove about three-quarters of their troops and all of their aircraft in the sparsely populated republic on the Chinese border. It was part of a move to normalize strained relations with China. The London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies yearbook for 1989-90 estimated the Soviets had 60,000 troops in Mongolia, including one army headquarters unit, two tank divisions and two motor rifles divisions. Tass said the main combat units would be withdrawn in 1991 and equipment support units would be removed in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Begins Review of Timetable for Opening Repository
DOC.TEXT: Eds: CORRECTS byline

Senators told Energy Secretary James D.
