Watkins on Friday to speed up opening the Yucca Mountain underground storage site for nuclear power plant waste but said his new timetable may be too optimistic. ``We can't continue simply to speculate on what we might or might not find there,'' Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., told Watkins, in urging that underground exploration begin. ``It is time to start making some of those controversial decisions.'' Johnston presided over a hearing of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee in its first review of Watkins' plan, which was released in November 1989. The timetable calls for above-ground studies to begin next January at the Nevada site, which was selected by Congress to hold the spent fuel from the nation's 100 nuclear power plants. The spent rdioactive fuel is currently being stored on site, but that capacity is limited and 27 sites will run out of storage, according to the Energy Department. Congress enacted the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in 1982 and amended it in 1987 to deal with that problem. In the meantime, according to testimony, utility customers are paying extra for on-site storage and the federally mandated plan. Johnston also noted that the longer the delays, the less money the plan will receive from Congress and the more difficult it will be to ``scale up'' spending later. The original date for the first testing had been in May 1989, but that schedule has been delayed because of objections in Nevada to the state's being the repository for radioactive waste from power plants nationwide. Watkins' timetable called for the underground repository to begin accepting spent fuel in 2010, at least seven years behind schedule. The first step in that process is the above-ground tests that would begin in early 1991. The above-ground tests are needed to make a preliminary determination of whether underground storage is even feasible. But the big ``if'' in the schedule is the outcome of two lawsuits filed this January: one by the state of Nevada against the Energy Department; and one by the department against Nevada. Both cases deal with the refusal of Nevada to grant the necessary permits to begin exploration of the site, which was chosen by Congress as a solution to the spent fuel storage problem. Sen. James A. McClure, R-Idaho, said now that the issue is in the legal system there is little control over it. ``I do know enough about that profession to be pessimistic,'' said McClure, a lawyer.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Elizabeth Morgan Can Have Passport Returned
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, involved in an international custody battle over her daughter, can have her passport back so she can go to New Zealand to fight a lawsuit filed by her former husband, an appeals court panel ruled Friday. A three-judge District of Columbia Court of Appeals panel freed her to travel to New Zealand and visit her daughter, Hilary. Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon had seized the passport in August 1987 when he jailed Morgan for failing to reveal the whereabouts of Hilary, whom Morgan said had been a victim of sexual abuse by the girl's father. He has denied the charges and claimed Morgan was mentally ill. Morgan and Foretich separated before Hilary was born. On Thursday, Dixon said he was satisfied that the return of the passport was ``in the best interests'' of Morgan's daughter, who is now 7. However, he was unable to return it because it was in the possession of the appeals court. The girl, who has been living with her maternal grandparents in Christchurch, New Zealand, was the subject of a 2{-year search by her father. Her whereabouts became known Feb. 23. Dixon had ordered Morgan to jail for contempt of court in August 1986 for refusing to allow Foretich to visit the girl. Morgan was released three days later by the appeals court, which required her to surrender the deed to her house as bond and turn over her passport. In February 1987, Dixon sent her to jail again, but she was released three days later after agreeing to allow Foretich's visits. In August 1987, Dixon jailed Morgan for a third time. She remained imprisoned until September 1989. In his order of Thursday, Dixon noted that Morgan remained in contempt of court. Elaine Mittleman, Foretich's attorney, has not ruled out the possibility of taking further legal action against Morgan.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Who Plays the King Getting Elvis-ed Out
DOC.TEXT: Portraying Elvis Presley is a lot of fun, says actor Michael St. Gerard, it's hearing all those stories about the King of rock 'n' roll that wears him out. ``There are times where if one more person tells me one more thing about Elvis, I'd like to punch him out,'' said St. Gerard, who portrays a young Presley in the ABC series ``Elvis.'' While the Presley persona is well known, St. Gerard says he doesn't feel bound to simply imitate Elvis when doing the show. ``There are times when I throw it all out the window and I just go for the truth of the scene. Here's a 19-year-old guy. What would he do? What would I do?'' said St. Gerard in US magazine's March 19 issue. ``I can't always be bogged down with mannerisms, because I would fall into the danger of playing a caricature of him.'' St. Gerard's taste in women is a bit different from the King's as well. Asked about a woman he admires, St. Gerard replied, ``Margaret Thatcher. I love Margaret Thatcher.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Announces Soybean Planting Procedures
DOC.TEXT: Farmers who signed up in a new ``0-25'' program for 1990-crop soybeans will be allowed to plant all of their requested acreage, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Keith Bjerke, executive vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp., said that under 0-25 provisions producers could request permission to plant soybeans on as much as 25 percent of their 1990 permitted acreages of wheat, feed grains, cotton and rice. The signup was held Jan. 16 through Feb. 16. Sunflowers and safflowers also were permitted but did not require a formal signup. Farmers participating in the program will not have the oilseed acreage charged against farm acreage bases or individual crop bases. Instead, the land planted to soybeans, sunflowers and safflowers will be considered as planted to the program crop for crop history purposes. However, Bjerke said no program benefits other than soybean price support loans and purchases will be available on the production from the acreage planted under the 0-25 option. When the program was announced on Dec. 29, it was specified that USDA would estimate how 1990 soybean prices may respond. If prices were indicated at less than $4.98 per bushel _ 110 percent of the price support loan rate of $4.53 _ the department would reduce or eliminate the acreage to be allowed for soybeans. Bjerke said a review of anticipated additional soybean plantings showed the 0-25 program will not result in 1990 prices dropping below the specified level. In all, about 1.92 million acres of additional soybeans were enrolled in the program, along with 10,161 acres of sunflowers and 87.1 acres of safflowers. Some of the biggest soybean enrollments included: Illinois, 293,155 acres; Indiana, 121,722; Iowa, 261,617; Kansas, 229,028; Minnesota, 169,576; Nebraska, 255,178; and South Dakota, 116,123.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss to Receive $3.9 Million for Soviet Assets Nationalized in War
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has agreed to pay Switzerland $3.9 million to compensate for assets nationalized by Moscow in World War II, officials said Friday. The compensation agreement relates to property owned by about 900 Swiss companies and individuals in areas of the Soviet Union that were formerly part of East Poland, East Prussia, the Baltics and Bessarabia, a foreign ministry statement said. The deal however does not include Swiss assets seized after the Communists came to power in 1917. Switzerland has already signed similar accords with Poland and Hungary. The Swiss government will decide how to distribute the funds after ratification of the agreement, the date of which was not divulged following a meeting in the Swiss capital. Switzerland has pressed for compensation ever since it resumed diplomatic relations with Moscow in 1946. Bilateral talks started in 1972. The two countries also concluded an investment guarantee accord to encourage the establishment of joint ventures and improve the investment climate by strengthening legal protection. Igor Feodorovich Koslovski, a vice-minister in the Soviet finance ministry, attended the meeting in Bern.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Shot Postman Said to be Angry His Check was Late
DOC.TEXT: A man angry that his Social Security check was late wounded a postman and three passers-by in a 25-round barrage of shotgun fire, authorities said Friday. One neighbor likened the violence to a bizarre skeet-shooting session. Gerard Pawloski was arraigned in Friday in Grand Rapids District Court on eight counts of assault with intent to murder for the shooting spree that erupted Thursday when he spotted a substitute mailman, who was running about five hours behind schedule. ``He was shooting like crazy at the mailman and at the car in front of him, filling the car full of holes,'' said neighbor Alan Peckham, who recalled that despite the violence, Pawloski appeared strangely calm. ``I walked up to about 15 or 20 feet away from him and asked him what he was doing,'' Peckham said. ``He said he was shooting at the postman. ``Jerry was mumbling to himself,'' Peckham said. ``It was just like it was his job or something. He wasn't sweating, shaking or nothing. It was like he was skeet shooting.'' Mailman Kenneth Peek, hit three times, was in fair condition Friday. A pedestrian and two passing motorists sustained minor wounds; the remaining charges covered people who were in the area but who weren't hit. ``We've substantiated from witnesses who he talked to at the time of the shooting or afterward that he indicated his displeasure over the absence or tardiness of the check,'' said police Lt. Victor Gillis. Pawloski, 42, who neighbors said often waited on the front porch for his government disability check, fired 25 rounds from a 12-gauge, double-barrel shotgun when he spotted Peek across the street, according to Gillis. The officer didn't know the nature of the disability for which Pawlski got payments from the Social Security Administration. After the shooting spree, which Gillis said lasted three or four minutes, Pawloski holed up inside his home, keeping police at bay for five hours. He surrendered about 8:30 p.m. after being forced out by tear gas. Pawloski, who has a history of mental illness and spent time in psychiatric institutions, doesn't have criminal record, police said. Pawloski also was charged with felony use of a firearm. He was ordered held at the Kent County Jail on $250,000 bond and a preliminary examination was set for March 12. If convicted he could be sentenced to life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Asks Bush to Cut Troops in Europe Before Treaty Signed
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee called on the Bush administration Friday to consider reducing the number of troops in Europe and not wait until a U.S.-Soviet conventional arms treaty. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., cited the testimony of CIA Director William Webster, who told the panel Thursday that reversing the radical changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet threat to the West is highly unlikely. ``What Judge Webster was saying is we've seen a lot and regardless of whether we get a conventional forces agreement or not there has been a fundamental shift in the threat to Europe,'' the chairman said Friday at an Armed Services hearing. But Gen. John R. Galvin, the commander of U.S. forces in Europe, said he opposed any cuts in American troop levels until a U.S.-Soviet pact is reached to reduce conventional forces. ``Let's keep our chips on the table here until we get the agreement,'' said Galvin. He said the administration's plan to reduce forces in the Central Front of Europe to 195,000 will take about three years. Aspin questioned why cuts couldn't be part of the president's budget for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. ``If you believe clearly what Judge Webster was saying, we shouldn't have to wait and put the whole 1991 budget on hold in Europe. We ought to be making some changes starting next fall,'' he said. ``I see this 1991 budget as essentially a hold budget in Europe.'' Although Webster said a resurgence in the Soviet threat is unlikely, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney warns that a hardline government could present problems to the United States. In testimony Thursday, Cheney stood by the administration's plan to cut troop levels in Europe, allowing 195,000 in the central zone and 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Cautions West German Chancellor on Unified Germany
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, in a letter to the dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center for Holocaust Studies, said anti-Semitism will not be tolerated in a reunited Germany. Rabbi Marvin Hier said Friday that he's not ``applauding the rush toward German reunification'' despite Kohl's assurances, which came in a reply to a letter Hier wrote Feb. 9. In it, the rabbi urged that a united Germany ban anti-Semitic organizations and take pains to remember its Nazi past. Kohl, in a response dated Feb. 28, said hate crimes are not tolerated in West Germany and do not go unpunished. He acknowledged ``the untold suffering inflicted on those people in the name of Germany and by Germans,'' and added, ``I understand the anxiety expressed by some victims ... in view of the prospect of German unity.'' However, he told Hier, ``It needs to be asked whether such anxiety is essentially justified, whether its roots lie not only in the past but also in the present. In this respect, our views evidently differ.'' On Thursday, the East German Foreign Ministry proposed that experts from both Germanys meet soon to work out a common position on German unification for presentation to the World War II Allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. In his letter, Hier outlined a 10-point plan that he said would ``reassure those who bear the scars of Nazism that a united Germany will never again heed the call of a dictator.'' The rabbi said a unified Germany should establish a federal agency to monitor hate groups and prosecute violators, and a national education task force that would emphasize teaching of the Holocaust. Concentration campsites should be turned into museums ``that would depict the horrors of Nazism,'' Hier said. He called for a ban of anti-Semitic organizations and pushed for restitution payments and a government commitment to rebuild synagogues and Jewish learning centers in East Germany. Kohl has said West Germans are taught about Nazi oppression through schools, church groups and the media. ``To my mind, there is no doubt that these provisions will also apply in a united Germany,'' Kohl wrote. ``This certainly does not require any special demand!'' Hier said Friday that the victims of Nazi Germany should have a say in planning of a new Germany. ``Those who suffered have paid dearly for the right to voice their concerns,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``They deserve as much attention as issues being raised by world leaders.'' ``It's kind of naive for Kohl to suggest, `Trust me on this,''' Hier said. ``There's no reason to accept that trust.''

DOC.HEAD: Contras Refuse To Lay Down Arms Immediately
DOC.TEXT: Contra commanders on Friday again spurned a plea by Nicaragua's President-elect Violeta Chamorro to lay down their arms immediately, and instead proposed negotiations with the new government. The Sandinistas, defeated in Sunday's elections in Nicaragua, have threatened to keep control of the country's military and secret police as long as an estimated 10,000 Contras remain armed and mobilized. Mrs. Chamorro and, more recently, President Bush have called on the rebels to surrender their arms to achieve a national reconciliation and end a decade of civil war, but at a news conference here they again refused. ``We demand the total demilitarization of the Sandinista Front, and the disappearance of the state-party-army that support it,'' said spokesman Juan Fernando Ramirez. ``There can be no disarming of the resistance without a transfer of command to the new government.'' He also said Contra leaders want an explanation of comments by Sandinista party officials that they will ``govern from below'' even after the U.S.-backed government assumes power on April 25. ``That could mean terrorism, extortion and assassination,'' he said. Fernando released a letter written to Mrs. Chamorro by top Contra leader and commander Israel Galeano, proposing negotiations with the new government. He said she has not formally replied, but has indicated willingness to take part in talks with the Contras. Commander Jose Rivas, representing the Contra's largest force, the northern front operating from Honduras, said his troops wanted peace, but not at the price of immediate surrender of their arms. ``Our position is that when the Sandinista front surrenders its arms, we will surrender ours,'' Rivas said. Maritza Herrera said many of her 2,500 Costa Rica-based rebels on Nicaragua's southern front felt they were betrayed by the leftist government during the amnesty. She said 50 of the rebels who turned themselves in were arrested and 28 were killed. ``There is no international organization, there is no government, that can guarantee our safety,'' she said. ``This process will take time.'' Asked if the Contras were providing a pretext to the Sandinistas to stay in power, Rivas said the rebels had learned ``through blood and tears'' not to trust their enemy's promises. Following the election, Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega ordered his troops to cease attacks on the Contras, and there have been no major reported military confrontations since then.

DOC.HEAD: American Bankers Association Endorses Deposit Insurance Reform
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest banking trade group on Friday endorsed a plan to reform deposit insurance and force uninsured depositors to accept some losses in bank failures. The American Bankers Association's plan would continue $100,000 per account coverage, but it would eliminate the current de facto practice of treating some banks as ``too big to fail.'' Accounts over the $100,000 limit would be subject to an immediate ``haircut'' based on the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.'s experience with past bank failures. The haircut would change, probably once a year. But if the plan were in effect now, uninsured depositors would probably lose 12 cents on every dollar, the trade group estimates. Currently, depositors are guaranteed nothing beyond $100,000. But, in practice, regulators have guaranteed all deposits at large institutions because they're afraid a collapse of a major bank would ripple through the financial system, causing runs on banks generally. As a matter of fairness, regulators also usually protect all deposits when a small institution fails. The American Bankers' proposal is similar to one advanced last summer by former Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman William Issac, now a private banking consultant. The idea is to encourage safe banking by giving large depositors an incentive to put their money only into sound institutions. Reform proponents attribute at least part of the savings and loan crisis to the fact that depositors had little reason to care whether they're institution was well or poorly run. Robert Dugger, chief economist of the banking group, argued that the reform proposal would prevent banks and S&Ls from embarking on fast-growth, risky investment strategies. The deposits wouldn't be available to do that. Also, regulators, because of the threat of deposit withdrawals, would be forced to step in immediately when a bank fails, minimizing the losses, he said. However, others warn that tinkering with deposit insurance coverage could destabilize the financial system, leaving it vulnerable to lightning-quick runs. ``The signal would pass that funds over $100,000 are at risk. I think that signal is potentially dangerous, not only for little banks, but for big banks,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of a rival trade group representing smaller banks, the Independent Bankers Association of America. The American Bankers' proposal, approved by the group's board of directors and a 400-member leadership conference, is being forwarded to the Treasury Department, which is studying deposit insurance. Treasury's recommendations, due next February, are expected to form the basis of major banking legislation in 1991. Deposit insurance was enacted in 1934 as part of the financial reforms put in place after the 1929 stock market crash and the wave of bank failures in the early 1930s.

DOC.HEAD: Second W.Va. Teacher Walkout Brings Thousands to Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of teachers chanting, ``Pay raise or strike!'' skipped school Friday for the second time in two weeks for a protest at the Capitol over pay and benefits. About 5,000 teachers, their ranks swelled by members of the United Mine Workers and other unions, rallied in a steady drizzle on the Capitol steps, then moved inside to attend Senate and House of Delegates floor sessions and lobby individual legislators. At one point, about 100 teachers surrounded Education and Arts Secretary Steve Haid in a hallway outside the governor's office, peppering him with questions and complaints. Unlike a Feb. 15 rally, in which state police were called after teachers pounded on the House of Delegates doors and demanded to be let in, there were no reports of trouble Friday. Several teachers said they are willing to strike if the Legislature does not approve a pay raise this session, which ends March 10. ``We have been ignored for many years, and we're not going to be ignored any more,'' said Gwen Taylor, a teacher at Hurricane High School in Putnam County. The West Virginia Education Association says the average West Virginia teacher is paid $21,904, ranking the state 49th in the nation. Teachers received a 5 percent pay raise effective last month. Other concerns include pensions and health insurance. The association said 21 counties canceled Friday classes because of the rally. Pickets in Mingo County turned away buses at three schools, forcing officials to cancel classes. Two county schools closed for the same reason on Thursday. Association President Kayetta Meadows complained that the state this week granted 5 percent to 25 percent pay raises to Division of Highways engineers, and the Legislature is considering a plan to give state troopers raises up to $7,000 a year. At the same time, she said, Gov. Gaston Caperton says there's no money for higher teacher pay. ``Do they think we're so dumb that we can't read the paper, that we can't tell what's going on?'' Meadows asked.

DOC.HEAD: Army Seeks Repayment of Scholarship That Went to Homosexual
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army is seeking repayment of a $25,000 scholarship from a student who says he is homosexual. James Holobaugh, 24, won a full four-year ROTC scholarship to attend Washington University in St. Louis and was featured in a nationwide recruiting campaign. He was scheduled to be commissioned an Army officer last May through the Reserve Officer Training Corps, but after his acknowledgement, the military moved to refuse his commission. Under a Department of Defense policy, homosexuals are considered unsuitable for military service and are not permitted to serve. The policy says their presence in the military ``would seriously impair discipline, good order, morale and security.'' William B. Rubenstein, a staff counsel for the Lesbian and Gay Rights project of the American Civil Liberties Union and Holobaugh's attorney, said Thursday it was not unusual for homosexual cadets to be removed from the ROTC. But he said this was the first case the ACLU knew of where the Army had asked for its scholarship money back. At an informal hearing in December, the Army questioned whether Holobaugh was masquerading as a homosexual to evade his service obligation, Rubenstein said. After completing the ROTC program, students commissioned as officers must serve in the military for four years of active duty or eight years in reserves. In January, the Army ruled that no evidence existed that Holobaugh was trying to evade service, Rubenstein said. Nonetheless, the Army recommended against commissioning Holobaugh and in favor of forcing him to reimburse the military for his scholarship. The case is being reviewed by the commander of the U.S. Army Second Region at Fort Knox, Ky. Holobaugh was rated one of the top performers in his ROTC class at Washington University and was selected by the Army to be in a nationwide advertising campaign to attract students. It wasn't until late 1988 or early 1989 that he realized he was homosexual, Holobaugh said. Last April, he sought the advice of a ROTC captain, who told him to tell the Army he was homosexual then, rather than wait until after his commission. Holobaugh said he was ``appalled at the prejudice'' in the military against homosexuals. ``It's kind of blowing my mind,'' he said. He said he wanted to be an Army officer. If he cannot be commissioned in the Army, he said, ``I will without a doubt fight to not have to pay back my scholarship.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Plead Guilty in Smuggling Case That Left Aliens Dead in Boxcar
DOC.TEXT: Four people pleaded guilty in the smuggling of five illegal aliens who died of exposure to poisonous chemicals while they were locked inside a truck trailer on a train. The aliens, from Mexico, Honduras and El Salvador, died Oct. 9 from inhaling Phostoxin, which had been applid to the tortilla flour in the trailer before they boarded it, authorities said. They were locked inside the trailer on a flatbed rail car on a train bound from the Lower Rio Grande Valley to Victoria, officials said. The four Victoria residents pleaded guilty Thursday in U.S. District Court in Brownsville. In exchange for the guilty pleas, other charges in the 13-count indictment were dropped, said U.S. Attorney John Crews. ``They weren't river bandits,'' Crews said. ``They were callous, but they didn't intend to kill the aliens.'' Eleutorio Amaya-Torres, 35, and Magdaleno Arcos-Soriano, 34, each pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to transport illegal aliens. The charge carries a maximum punishment of five years in prison and $250,000 in fines. Jane Amaya, 39, pleaded guilty to one count of tampering with a witness, which carries the same penalties. The charges stems from allegations the smugglers returned money to relatives of the dead in exchange for silence. Mary Ann Martinez, 24, pleaded guilty to a charge of failing to report a felony to authorities. The charge carries a maximum penalty of three years in prison and a $250,000 fine. U.S. District Judge Filemon Vela set sentencing for May 15. A fifth person accused in the case, Renato Avila Botello, remains at large on charges of conspiracy to transport illegal aliens and witness tampering.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Romanian Tribunal That Doomed Ceausescu Commits Suicide
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the military tribunal that condemned Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife to death has committed suicide, Justice Minister Teofil Pop announced Friday. He told a news conference Maj. Gen. Gica Popa, 57, shot himself in the head with his standard-issue Makharov pistol at 1:15 p.m. Thursday in his Justice Ministry office. The announcement coincided with the opening of the trial of 21 former secret police officers charged in connection with scores of deaths in the December revolution that overthrew Ceausescu. The trial is being held in downtown Timisoara, the western city where the revolution originated. Pop said that Gen. Popa was rushed to the Bucharest military hospital, where he died two hours later with his wife and daughter by his side. The general left a suicide note that asked forgiveness, but did not explain the motive for his act, he reported. Pop called the suicide the result of a ``very grave depression.'' But Popa's wife, Eleonora, told The Associated Press her husband had been receiving anonymous threats ``beginning with the 25th of December,'' the date of the Ceausescu trial. ``For two months, he didn't sleep in his own house,'' she said. She said Popa tried to discuss the threats Thursday morning with the justice minister, but ``was turned away.'' ``They didn't support him in any way,'' she said. She also said her husband wrote he was ``frustrated and scared'' in his suicide letter, which was ``taken away by the justice minister.'' Pop told reporters Popa had suffered serious depression related to family problems 10 years ago. He said he recently asked Popa if he was threatened after the trial, and the general said no. The justice minister said Popa, chief of the Military Territorial Tribunal in Bucharest, ``had extraordinary prestige and was one of our best judges.'' He confirmed that Popa's voice was the one heard on the video-recording of the trial of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, which was broadcast repeatedly on Romanian and international television. The angry voice was heard interrogating the pair and then announcing they had been sentenced to death for genocide and other crimes against the Romanian people. The couple were subsequently executed by firing squad. None of the military judges was shown on the tape. The identity of the person speaking at the trial had not been made public ``to protect the judges while there were still terrorists around,'' Pop said, referring to members of Ceausescu's secret police who fought revolutionary forces for about a week after the dictator was toppled Dec. 22. The other judge at Ceausescu's trial was his deputy, Maj. Gen. Ioan Nistor. Both Popa and Nistor were colonels at the time of the trial, officials said. Three other career officers completed the five-man tribunal: Capt. Corneliu Sorescu, Lt. Maj. Daniel Condrea, and Lt. Ion Zamfir. The trial was held in Tirgoviste, 45 miles northwest of Bucharest. The prosecutor-general's office and police were investigating Popa's death, officials said, without divulging more details on its circumstances. In Timisoara, 180 miles west of Bucharest, armored personnel carriers and soldiers surrounded Casa Tineretului theater, now converted into a courtroom. The proceedings are the first against those suspected of trying to crush the uprising before it spread across the country. The defendants, headed by Maj. Gen. Emil Macri, sat glumly in their striped brown prison suits as the indictment was read. Macri and six others are charged with genocide and face life in prison if convicted. The 14 others face up to 20 years in prison if convicted on lesser charges stemming from the shootings of unarmed civilians who took to the streets of Timisoara in December to demonstrate against Ceausescu. In opening statements, the chief prosecutor, Col. Vasile Kozma, said 94 people died in the Timisoara violence, 300 were injured and 20 were missing. Early in the revolution, reports in Timisoara spoke of up to 4,000 people dying there. On Friday, the ruling Provisional Council of National Unity decided to remove the 15-foot-high bronze statue of Lenin from northern Bucharest. The council, which acts like a miniparliament until May 20 elections, also expanded its membership to 259. It will absorb three members each from the Federation of Jewish Communities in Romania and the Democratic Romani (Gypsy) Union. About 2 million Gypsies and 20,000 Jews live in Romania, according to official figures.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Judge Will Investigate Charges Against Pierce
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs first 3 grafs to reflect appointment was announced, sted made, Friday; inserts 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, The program, with background on Congress cutting program's funds.
DOC.TEXT: A retired federal judge was appointed independent counsel to investigate allegations that former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. illegally showed political favoritism to developers, a special court said Friday. Arlin M. Adams, 68, a Philadelphia lawyer who served for 17 years on the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, was sworn in Thursday as independent counsel to investigate the allegations against Pierce and former aides at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The appointment, made by the special three-judge panel, was announced Friday. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had requested the appointment last month. Adams was given jurisdiction to investigate whether Pierce or other HUD employees had ``committed the crime of conspiracy to defraud the United States or any other federal crimes'' in the administration of the department's Moderate Rehabilitation Program from 1984 through 1988. The program qualified developers for lucrative rent subsidies and tax breaks for performing a moderate amount of repairs on low-income housing units. As a result of the HUD scandals, Congress voted not to appropriate money for the program this year. In 1989, Congress had appropriated $225 million, but HUD Secretary Jack Kemp suspended the disbursement of $167 million pending a review of the grant awards. Thornburgh's request to the special court said that the Justice Department's preliminary inquiry had found reports of a ``widespread perception'' by developers and local officials that money was awarded ``in disproportionate amounts to projects backed by prominent Republicans acting as consultants or by former HUD officials.'' Adams said in an interview Friday that he was already at work on the case. ``In these assignments, you start promptly and work very hard,'' he said. ``I've called on the FBI for assistance and I have begun to make arrangements for facilities in Washington, which will be my base, and for staff,'' Adams said. He declined to estimate how long the investigation will take, saying ``there is no deadline.'' Robert Plotkin, one of Pierce's defense lawyers, lauded the appointment, saying, ``We have every reason to expect that Judge Adams will conduct the investigation in a fair and impartial manner.'' ``We're glad that an independent counsel has been finally appointed and the investigation can proceed,'' Plotkin said. Pierce was HUD secretary throughout the eight years of the Reagan administration, the only member of Reagan's Cabinet to stay in office through both terms. The attorney general's request for an independent counsel followed a preliminary inquiry by the Justice Department's public integrity section into allegations of favoritism that were presented by Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee. The allegations were based on hearings conducted by the House Government Operations education and housing subcommittee into mismanagement at HUD during Pierce's tenure. Thornburgh rejected the lawmakers' request for an independent counsel to investigate allegations that Pierce had lied under oath when he denied having ``hands on'' involvement in running the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. Pierce was called back to testify on two other occasions, but refused to answer questions, invoking his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., who chaired last year's congressional hearings on HUD, welcomed the appointment, saying he will meet with Adams next Wednesday in Washington to discuss the probe. As Pennsylvania secretary of public welfare from 1963 to 1966, Adams said, he examined alleged misuse of government programs. In a statement, the Special Division of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here said that Adams ``brings to this investigation the judgment, experience and ability acquired by many years of service as a federal circuit judge, as a private practitioner and as a recognized leader of the courts and the bar of the nation.'' Frank Keating, general counsel at HUD, also praised the appointment and pledged that the department would cooperate with the investigation. A Republican, Adams chaired Richard Nixon's Pennsylvania presidential campaign in 1968. A year later, as president, Nixon apponted Adams to the 3rd Circuit, where he sat until 1986. Adams was also considered for Supreme Court appointments by both Nixon and President Ford. In 1988, Adams rejected overtures to be deputy attorney general in the last days of the tenure of then-Attorney General Edwin Meese III.

DOC.HEAD: Romania to Build Cathedral in Memory of Victims of Revolution
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: The government will build a cathedral in the capital to honor those who died in December's democratic revolution, Bucharest Radio reported Friday. The state radio said the cathedral would be called All Saints-St. Anastasia. The feast of St. Anastasia is celebrated in the Romanian Orthodox church on Dec. 22, which also is the date when longtime Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled in a popular revolution. The Ministry of Religious Affairs intends to build the church near Liberty Park in southern Bucharest, a ministry official said. The church would be the first built in Bucharest in years. Religious activity was suppressed under Ceausescu and 22 Romanian Orthodox churches were pulled down in Bucharest the past six years to make way for a huge project that included a tree-lined boulevard and a government palace. In the revolution, there were reports of up to 4,000 dead in the western city of Timisoara alone, where the uprising began.

DOC.HEAD: High School Students Clash With Officials Over Anti-Gang Dress Code
DOC.TEXT: High school students enraged by a new anti-gang dress code boycotted classes, staged noisy demonstrations and pelted rocks at a a sheriff's patrol car. Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies in this Mojave Desert community north of Los Angeles said they arrested two students during protests at three high schools, and were seeking two others. At Palmdale High, about 200 pupils staged a noisy walkout as a ban took effect Thursday on all but official school baseball caps. The new policy authorizes school officials to prohibit any clothing they consider gang-oriented. But most students returned to classes after three hours when police threatened arrests for disturbing the peace. At Antelope Valley High, hundreds of students rushed a sheriff's sergeant who had detained four men off campus, hurled rocks and debris at his car and chanted, ``Let Them Go,'' sheriff's Sgt. Ron Shreves said. The four were not linked with the demonstrations, and were apparently mistaken by the crowd for fellow students, Shreves said. The board of trustees of the Antelope Valley Union High School District adopted the dress code last month. Students who violate the code will be warned for a first offense, then suspended and possibly expelled for subsequent offenses, the board said. ``People should be able to dress the way they want at a public high school,'' said Scott Welcome, a 16-year-old junior at Palmdale High. ``They're just trying to turn this school into a prison,'' said Jason Oster, a 15-year-old sophomore. ``Why should we suffer for what the gang-bangers do?''

DOC.HEAD: Police Called to Investigate Paranormal Activity
DOC.TEXT: Police who inspected a house for a possible burglary this week say they saw objects fly around inexplicably. They had a priest bless the house but filed no official report on the strange occurrences. Patrolman Stan Anderson and Sgt. William Clark were called to the home after Virginia John returned from work Sunday night to find everything in disarray. ``Dishes were smashed, several windows were broken, a lamp exploded in the living room, and eggs lined up in the refrigerator all had exploded,'' Anderson said Thursday. ``A vase flew across the room and two objects flew right by my head,'' said Anderson, a 13-year veteran of the Indianapolis Police Department. Residents of the house couldn't have thrown the things, he said. Clark said he saw a large radio leap from a desk and slide under a bed. ``The house was completely destroyed,'' Anderson said. ``She said objects had been moving around all day and strange things had been happening.'' The police officers called the police department chaplain, the Rev. Wilbert A. Cunningham, and a Catholic priest who asked that his name not be made public. The priest blessed the home and its occupants, which included Ms. John's father, brother and 3-year-old son. ``He sprinkled holy water throughout the house while performing the standard blessing,'' said Charles Schisla, director of the Catholic Communications Center. Police said a 14-year-old relative from Puerto Rico who had been living at the home was believed to have been involved in devil worship. He had been sent back to Puerto Rico, said Sgt. Gregory P. Bieberich. Police did not file an official report on the investigation. ``How would we classify this case?'' Anderson asked. ``It wasn't a burglary, but it was close to a vandalism. Even if we could classify it, who would we consider as a suspect _ a spirit?'' The family could not be reached for comment Friday. Their number is not available through directory assistance and Ms. John was not at her job at Wishard Memorial Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Move To Block Secord's Appeal Of His Guilty Plea
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutors moved Friday to stop a court appeal by Richard Secord until a lower court judge decides whether to reinstate 11 other criminal charges against him. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, pleaded guilty Nov. 8 to making a false statement when he told congressional investigators he was unaware of any money that went to benefit Oliver North. But Secord announced his intention to appeal after his sentencing Jan. 24 and the government says he is trying to circumvent his plea agreement with the government. Under that plea agreement, the government agreed not to pursue 11 other criminal charges against Secord. The appeal is based on a contention by Secord's lawyers that independent counsel Lawrence Walsh lacks jurisdiction to prosecute for an offense arising out of Secord's testimony to Congress. Iran-Contra prosecutors Feb. 5 asked U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson to reconsider his decision dismissing the 11 other charges. ``While the District Court has before it important questions relating to the effectiveness of the plea agreement in this case,'' the appeals court proceedings should be stopped, prosecutors said in a court filing. Secord agrees the appeal should be suspended until the lower court rules, said the court filing. The government has said it is ``an act of bad faith'' to plead guilty with the undisclosed intent of challenging the validity of the plea. Secord, who was placed on two years' probation, paid for a $13,800 security system at North's home out of proceeds from the Enterprise. The Enterprise was the network of offshore companies and secret accounts which Secord and business partner Albert Hakim used to move money in the Iran-Contra affair. The 11 other charges against Secord included obstruction and perjury counts based on his testimony to Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Law Crackdown Will be Mounted in 8 Cities
DOC.TEXT: Federal task forces to crack down on people who violate federal gun laws calling for mandatory prison sentences will be launched in eight cities later this month, officials said Friday. The Project Achilles task forces will be in place by March 26 in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami, Detroit, Washington and Phoenix, said Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms spokeswoman Dot Koester. The ATF conducted a similar, four-month Armed Career Criminal operation in Washington last year as a prelude to the upcoming project, and ``made quite an impact,'' she said. In addition to making numerous arrests, ``because they kept hitting certain areas again and again, the neighborhood people started coming out and cheering the agents on,'' Koester said. ``Out of that developed a hotline which the neighbors then used to call us when something was going on,'' she said. ``It created a whole new interest in the neighborhoods where we went.'' The neighbors, she said, ``would invite (the agents) in for coffee after they made their raids.'' Congress last year included $4.5 million in the ATF's budget for 1990 specifically as salaries for 75 full-time workers in the Achilles task forces in five cities, but the ATF expanded that number to eight, said a spokesman for Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., who chairs the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Treasury, Postal Service and General Government. The agents will work with state and local law enforcement officials. The task forces, working for the Armed Career Criminal Program, will be targeting people under two sections of federal law that call for mandatory sentencing. One says anyone convicted of a felony crime of violence or drug charge who is carrying a gun automatically is sentenced for at least five years on the weapon-possession charge. The other section says that a person who has three previous felony convictions for a violent crime or drug offense will be sentenced to at least 15 years on the firearm charge. The task forces are being launched at the same time that ATF faces cutbacks under the Bush administration's proposed 1991 budget of 185 positions created by the 1990 Anti-Crime Initiative. The cutbacks will be required because of the need to offset administratively uncontrolled overtime pay and inflation, according to DeConcini's spokesman, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. To cope with the additional expenses, the ATF is proposing to reduce firearms-law enforcement personnel not specifically connected to drug cases by 122 people next year, according to congressional documents.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Nationalists Mount Demonstrations
With AM-Germany-Poland
DOC.TEXT: About 200 members of a nationalist group marched through the capital Friday to support Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's demand that Poland take part in international talks on a reunified Germany. It was the second day of such marches organized around Poland by the Confederation for an Independent Poland. The group often holds demonstrations with extreme anti-communist groups. It has been active for more than a decade, founded with the aim to seek freedom for Poland from Moscow. Marchers demonstrated Thursday in Krakow and five other cities, said leaders of the group. Friday's protesters in Warsaw marched to the embassies of the four powers that occupied Germany at the end of World War II: the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. They are to hold talks with the two German states leading to reunification. At each embassy, marchers carried banners saying ``We Were Cheated Once'' and ``We Don't Want a Second Yalta and Potsdam,'' referring to the 1945 conferences where the victorious Allies agreed to change Polish borders without Poland's participation. Poland says it should take part in reunification talks to win a treaty guaranteeing its present border with East Germany. Polish officials fear a reunited Germany might press claims to Polish lands that were transferred from Germany at the end of the war. On Friday, the West German government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl offered an eventual treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border, but it said Poland must abandon any claims to war reparations. The Polish government reacted sharply to the offer, saying the two issues should not be linked.

DOC.HEAD: 15,000 Bulgarian Students Demand an End to Communist Rule
DOC.TEXT: About 15,000 students defied rain, cold and a ban on city marches on Friday to denounce the ruling Communists as a ``mafia'' and demand that they step down. The students gathered near Vasil Levski Stadium, site of a rally by 70,000 Communists Thursday, and then paraded 2{ miles downtown to a square in central Sofia, shouting their support for the democratic opposition. Thousands of Bulgarians along the route cheered as the students marched past, chanting ``Down with the BKP!'' _ the initials of the Bulgarian Communist Party _ and ``Then and now _ the Communist Party a mafia!'' People waved and clapped from windows and balconies. Hospital nurses left their ward to watch the procession, punctuated by rhythmic jumping and chanting of ``SDS!'' _ the Bulgarian abbreviation of the opposition. The activists carried placards reading, ``Freedom or Socialism,'' ``Communism is a Drug for People'' and ``The Communist Party must go to the Belene jail'' _ an infamous prison for political prisoners. Miners in 26 pits meanwhile went on strike Friday to press for a cut in working hours and that demands made in a miners' strike in January be fulfilled. The independent Podkrepa trade union organized the job action. Strikers interviewed on state television said they wanted a 36-hour work week, and a 30-hour week for those mining for minerals causing silicosis, a chronic lung disease caused by continued inhalation of silica dust. Also Friday, Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the Union of Democratic Forces, called on all non-Communist groups to join a UDF conference in Plovdiv to work out opposition strategy for the first multiparty elections, likely by June. Bulgaria was known for years as one of the Kremlin's most loyal allies, but was caught up in the reform changes sweeping Eastern Europe and last November replaced its Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, after 35 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Links War Reparations to Polish Border Guarantees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Polish premier's reax, U.S. letter to NATO members, details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government on Friday offered an eventual treaty guaranteeing Poland's western border after German reunification but said Poland must abandon any claims to war reparations. Such a pact also would be linked to Poland's pledge to protect the rights of its German minority, according to West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel. Polish Premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki said he was ``especially astonished that the question of the German minority has been brought up. We have settled this matter, and we keep our word.'' In his his remarks on West German television, the premier added, ``There are mutual obligations here, which also concern the Polish minority in Germany.'' Earlier, Polish government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska told Polish television news, ``Poland did not wish to link the problem of treaty regulation of the border on the Oder and the Neisse with any other problems.'' ``But if the West German side wishes to broaden these subjects, we will raise the problem of compensations for over a million Polish citizens who were forced to work in the Third Reich during World War II,'' she said. Kohl has come under intense criticism abroad and at home for his stance on lands east of the Oder and Neisse rivers ceded to Poland after Nazi Germany's 1945 defeat. Poland wants reassurance that a reunited Germany will not seek to reclaim those lands, which make up one-third of present-day Poland. Kohl repeatedly has said Germans have no designs on that property, but has insisted that, legally speaking, final say can only come from a future united German government. Kohl has been reluctant to run the risk of angering arch-conservative voters needed to help his Christian Democrats win re-election in federal elections this December. But at the same time, his statements have drawn negative responses in Poland and a number of other countries, including the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain. Kohl for the first time on Friday openly said a treaty would be possible recognizing Poland's western border after a united Germany government comes into being. But at the same time he demanded that Poland's 1953 decision on war reparations be an element of such agreement, as well as Poland's assurance last year that the ethnic rights of its German minority would be guaranteed. In the statement delivered by Vogel, Kohl again carefully avoided stating outright that a united Germany would never lay claim to land ceded to Poland. According to Vogel, Kohl reiterated his support for both German parliaments passing an identical declaration pledging to respect the current borders after East Germany elects its first freely chosen parliament on March 18. Vogel said ``such a declaration must at the same time make clear that the Aug. 23, 1953, declaration of the Polish government, in which reparations against Germany are renounced, continues unchanged.'' The Western powers ended reparation collections from West Germany in 1952. The Soviet Union did the same for fellow Communist state East Germany a year later, while Poland said it, too, would not seek reparations. Vogel said that on the basis of such a border resolution by the German parliaments, ``a treaty between an overall German government with the Polish government should be concluded and be ratified by a united German parliament.'' In Poland, meanwhile, hundreds of people demonstrated in several cities Thursday and Friday to support Mazowiecki's demand that Poland be allowed to take part in international talks on a reunited Germany. Poland says in order to win an ironclad guarantee of its western border, it needs access to the so-called ``two-plus-four'' talks involving West Germany and East Germany as well as the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. In Madrid, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher reiterated that the borders of a reunified Germany would be those fixed at the end of World War II. ``We have no claims as far as Poland is concerned, not now or in the future,'' Genscher said. Genscher, in Madrid to allay Spanish concerns about plans for German unification, also said he and Kohl were in ``total accord'' on the issue. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Secretary of State James A. Baker III sent a letter to all NATO foreign ministers inviting their views on German reunification. ``As you know, all of us have agreed that Germany's continued membership in NATO, including participation in NATO's integrated military structure, and the continued commitment of NATO forces to the security of Germany is of enduring importance to stability and security throughout Europe,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Tries to Prevent Disclosure of Ad, Circulation Data
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of a Las Vegas newspaper seeking to form a joint operating agreeement with its competitor sought Friday to prevent the disclosure of its advertising and circulation revenues by the Justice Department. Donrey of Nevada Inc., publisher of the Las Vegas Review-Journal, asked Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to reconsider his Feb. 16 order requiring the newspaper to publicly disclose its advertising and circulation revenues. Donrey, owned by the closely held Donrey Media Group, submitted the figures ordered by Thornburgh but they were placed under seal pending a ruling on the company's request they be kept private. Thornburgh, who rules on requests for joint operating agreements, had given the company until Friday to submit the data. Donrey is seeking a partial merger of the Review-Journal with the Las Vegas Sun under the anti-trust exemptions provided in the Newspaper Preservation Act. Both newspapers say that the Sun, owned by the Sun Co., is in ``probable danger of financial failure'' and therefore should be allowed to merge its production and commercial departments with the Review-Journal. Donrey argued there is much financial information already on the public record to document the Sun's claim of impending financial trouble without disclosing ``statistical detail about the inner workings of the Review-Journal.'' ``Access to the aggregate revenue data, coupled with the data in the record and the information available generally about the economics of the newspaper business would enable a competitor or potential competitor to make a close approximation of the single most sensitive piece of intelligence about a closely held company: its profits,'' the company's lawyers said in a legal brief. An affidavit signed by Fred W. Smith, president of Donrey Media Group, said ``public disclosure of such information would be detrimental and damaging to Donrey in its relationships with customers, suppliers and labor unions and would provide an unfair advantage to its competitors, not only in the Las Vegas market but in the other 73 markets in 21 states in which Donrey operates.''

DOC.HEAD: Highland Peasants Send the Heads of 13 Guerrillas to Army Commander
DOC.TEXT: Outraged Highland peasants armed with sickles and homemade shotguns captured 13 Shining Path guerrillas, killed them and sent their heads to the local army commander, police said Friday. Police said 200 peasants who organized into a village defense group because of their fears of reprisals by the Maoist-inspired insurgents ambushed 20 Shining Path rebels Thursday near Cochas, a town 30 miles northeast of Huancayo. Using machetes, sickles, lances and homemade shotguns, the peasants overpowered the better-armed but outnumbered guerrillas, capturing and decapitating nine of them. The incident occurred three days after peasants from the neighboring village of Comas captured four Shining Path guerrillas, including one woman, and cut off their heads. Police in Huancayo, 120 miles east of Lima, said the peasants put the heads into bags and sent them to the provincial army commander in Concepcion, 12 miles northwest of Huancayo. They also sent weapons and propaganda confiscated from the rebels. Military officials in Concepcion would not comment. The civil defense groups, called ``rondas,'' are organized by the army to defend remote villages from guerrilla incursions. Often the peasants are armed only with crude weapons and are no match for the guerrillas, many of whom carry automatic weapons and explosives. Many of the peasant groups complain they receive little support from the army. Confrontations between the rondas and rebels have become more frequent in recent months, and dozens have been killed on both sides. The Shining Path says it wants to create a worker-peasant state patterned on the ideas of Mao Tse-tung, but in its 10 years of armed struggle it has not gained wide support among Peru's peasants. Police said the villagers in Comas and Cochas complained the rebels had been harassing them, stealing their food and ordering them to stop shipping farm produce to the cities. Part of the rebels' announced strategy is to choke off food shipments from the Huancayo region, Peru's breadbasket, to the population centers on the coast, mainly the capital city of Lima and its port, Callao. The Shining Path guerrillas began fighting to overthrow Peru's elected governments in 1980, launching its first attack in the southern Andes highlands. The rebels now operate through most of the Andes and the coca-producing jungles of the northeast, where drug traffickers pay them for permission to operate. The guerrillas also occasionally launch attacks in Lima and other cities along the coast where the majority of Peruvians live, conducting hit-and-run assaults and dynamiting electrical substations. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the decade of violence, most of them unarmed civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Banned Parties Stage One-Day Nationwide Strike
DOC.TEXT: A one-day nationwide strike called by two banned political parties to press demands for multiparty democracy ended Friday with little of the violence that marked earlier protests. The strike was the second called by the Nepali Congress Party and the Communist Party of Nepal since they began their campaign Feb. 18 for restoration of a multiparty system in the national Assembly. State-run radio reported that life was ``almost normal'' in the Himalayan kingdom but did not elaborate. In Katmandu, riot police patrolled the nearly deserted streets of the capital, shops were closed and students stayed away from school. Buses leaving Katmandu were escorted by armed police in jeeps, but few passengers traveled. Buses coming into the capital were half-empty. Witnesses said demonstrators set a car on fire downtown and smashed the windshields of some state-owned buses during the protest, but there were no other reports of violence. A one-day strike called by the banned parties on Feb. 19 led to violence throughout the country and several people were killed. The government says at least 12 people have died in clashes between police and demonstrators since the protest campaign began last month. Opposition activists say the death toll is nearly double the government figure. ``The government is bent upon unleashing widespread violence to provoke the peaceful demonstrators like they did on Feb. 19,'' Ganesh Man Singh, a top Nepali Congress Party leader who is under house arrest, said in a telephone interview. A Home Ministry statement said the government ``would never lag behind legal action against those who attempt to disrupt public life.'' It said communist extremists have been active in the protest campaign. The banned parties are demanding the lifting of a 29-year-old royal decree that prohibits all of the political parties in the kingdom, one of the world's oldest monarchies. Membershiop in the national assembly, known as the Rashtriya Panchayat, is non-partisan. Nepal's two-year experiment with Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when King Mahendra, father of the present monarch, King Birendra, dissolved the government of the Nepali Congress Party, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. The government of King Birendra says the campaign to lift the ban on political parties runs counter to a 1980 referendum that narrowly retained the Rashtriya Panchayat's system of non-partisan membership. It also says the country already has its own form of democracy and does not need a multiparty system. Power in Nepal is shared between the king and the assembly. One-fifth of the Panchayat's 140 members are nominated by the king and the rest are elected.

DOC.HEAD: Parachutist May Not Have Known President Was in Town
With AM-Bush-Japan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A skydiver who was fired at by a Secret Service agent after parachuting into the parking lot of the hotel where President Bush was staying may not have known the president was in town, authorities said Friday. Bush was inside the Century Plaza Hotel during the episode Thursday that ended with the arrest of Charles Sweeney, 47, of the Los Angeles suburb of Santa Clarita. Sweeney, arrested at his home hours after the incident, was booked for investigation of assault with a deadly weapon on a law officer, said police Lt. Al Moen. He was freed on $3,000 bail on the charge, which stemmed from alleged attempts to run down officers in the getaway car. ``There was no threat to the president. He didn't know the president was in town,'' said Secret Service Agent Jim Miller. He said his information was based on a Los Angeles police interview with Sweeney attended by a Secret Service agent. Miller said he didn't know if anyone told Bush about the incident. A Secret Service agent fired two shots at the car as the man sped away after jumping from a 36-story building under construction near the hotel about 6 a.m. Thursday. After landing, Sweeney packed up his parachute, jumped into a car and sped through the parking lot, ignoring orders to stop, Miller said. ``I'd estimate there was about 60 feet of rubber. Then he made a U-turn and headed right for the officer,'' he said. ``The agent fired two shots and the vehicle swerved to the right and missed the officer.'' The parachutist, who was alone in the car, was uninjured. Illegal urban skydiving from highrises is an occasional practice among some parachutists. Bush was in Los Angeles for two days of politicking and anti-drug speeches before heading to Palm Springs for his summit meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Promise Investigation of Lethal Train Crash
DOC.TEXT: The government Friday promised a public inquiry into why a passenger train struck a car at a crossing northwest of Belfast, killing three people and injuring 27. Two of the three cars on the Belfast-to-Londonderry train derailed after it sliced the car in half Thursday night at the crossing 25 miles from Belfast, police said. Kevin and Marion Fowler, who were in the front-seat of the car, were crushed to death under the front of the train. Mrs. Fowler was six months pregnant. Their two young sons in the back seat were badly injured and reported in serious condition Friday at Waveney Hospital in nearby Ballymena. A passenger in the train, 17-year-old Julie Rock, died after being trapped in the wreckage for three hours. Fourteen of the 27 people injured remained hospitalized. It was not known why the car was on the crossing. Northern Ireland's transport minister, Peter Bottomley, visited the scene of the crash and met with accident investigators. He pledged a thorough inquiry and said its findings would be made public. There have been four accidents at Northern Ireland's grade-crossings in recent years. The mayor of Londonderry's city council, Tony Carlin, demanded an immediate review of crossing standards, particularly those with no gates. ``Obviously the time is now for an urgent review because there cannot be a continuation without some sort of inquiry,'' he said.

DOC.BYLINE: Hazelwood Nurses Flu While Prosecution Seeks Admission of More Evidence ^By LINDA DEUTSCH
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood's flu forced postponement of his trial Friday, while prosecutors petitioned the judge to reject the Exxon Valdez skipper's claim that evidence about his ship's potential sinking is irrelevant. Lawyers defending Hazelwood on criminal charges stemming from the nation's worst oil spill have contended it was impossible for the skipper to move his giant tanker off a reef once it was impaled. Thus, they say, it makes no difference whether he tried to move it. They seek to bar evidence on what might have happened if the ship moved. Expert witnesses have speculated that the ship could have sunk, but the state has not yet offered specifics. The prosecution wants to present the results of accident simulations it conducted to show scientifically why the tanker was in danger of capsizing or sinking. Friday morning, the judge summoned jurors, told them of Hazelwood's illness and ordered them to be especially careful to avoid news reports on the case during the weekend recess. Lawyers said Hazelwood should be ready to resume Monday. ``It seems we're missing the star player _ Captain Hazelwood has the flu,'' attorney Dick Madson told Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone. He reported that Hazelwood got dressed to go to court, but felt too sick to leave his hotel room. The 43-year-old Hazelwood from Huntington, N.Y., is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could receive 7\ years in prison and fines of $61,000. The Exxon Valdez ran aground on Bligh Reef on March 24, spilling 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound, killing countless birds, fish and other marine animals and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. On Friday, Johnstone told lawyers to begin thinking about jury instructions in the case, although he said the trial's end might be two to three weeks away. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole then said he was filing a legal memorandum asking Johnstone to admit testimony that the Exxon Valdez might have sunk if Hazelwood had succeeded in moving the grounded tanker. ``Captain Hazelwood is arguing that because it was impossible for the Exxon Valdez to come free, there was no risk involved,'' said the memorandum. But it argued that the defense reliance on ``the impossibility doctrine'' was misplaced. ``The issue is not whether it was possible for the vessel to come free, but whether Captain Hazelwood's mistakes in not realizing the vessel was firmly aground and not recognizing the danger in refloating were reasonable,'' the document said. It argued that Hazelwood made a mistake in thinking he could remove the impaled tanker from Bligh Reef. ``In fact, the vessel would have sunk had Captain Hazelwood been successful,'' Cole argued. A parade of prosecution experts testified this week that Hazelwood's orders in the hour after the disaster indicated he was trying to drive the tanker back into the sea. The skipper's lawyers maintain he was trying to stabilize the vessel on the reef. The spill of crude oil killed countless birds, fish and other marine animals and blackened hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. The prosecution memo suggested that Hazelwood's intent would be a key issue in the jury's deliberations. ``The state agrees that it was not Captain Hazelwood's intent to damage property of another when he tried to remove the vessel,'' said the document. ``However, at the time he was attempting to remove the vessel he had sufficient information to know that such action would risk damaging property of another.'' To be found guilty of second degree criminal mischief, the felony, the jury must determine that Hazelwood recklessly risked the property of another in an amount exceeding $100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Relatives of Polish Victims Demand Truth From Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of some of the 15,000 captive Polish officers killed at Katyn and elsewhere in the Soviet Union in World War II demonstrated at the Soviet Embassy Friday demanding the truth about the deaths. Soviet Ambassador Vladimir Brovikov met with a three-member delegation from about 40 relatives of the Katyn victims who gathered outside the embassy gates. They gave him a letter demanding to know how the soldiers died. ``We were received very kindly. The ambassador expressed understanding for the families ... and said the Katyn crime had to be explained thoroughly,'' said Zdzislaw Dyduch, one of the three delegates. His father died at Katyn. The killing is believed to have taken place at the end of April or early May 1940. The demonstration Friday was in preparation for the 50th anniversary. The Katyn massacre was long blamed officially on Nazi Germany, although most Poles believed it was carried out by the Soviet secret police. The officers had been interned at three camps in the Soviet Union after Poland was partioned between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union early in the war. An official panel of Polish historians agreed last year with the popular conclusion of Soviet guilt. A parallel group of Soviet historians has made no public assessment, saying it lacks proof. The invading German army found the remains of about 4,300 Polish officers at Katyn, near Smolensk, in 1943. Nazi Germany immediately made the crime public for propaganda purposes. The final resting place of the remaining officers, who had been held at two other camps, is unknown to this day. ``We would like to discover the truth and for them to admit what they have done, and apologize,'' said demonstrator Krystyna Kryszkowiak, whose father was interned at Ostaszkow. Relatives of the murdered officers have formed an organization called the Katyn Family, which has about 1,000 members in Warsaw alone. ``We feel moral satisfaction that at least we can talk about it openly now,'' said Maria Osieja, whose father was killed at Katyn. ``It is only a pity that my mother did not live to witness this.''

DOC.HEAD: Retired Officer In Coma After Ambush In Basque Country
DOC.TEXT: Doctors said a retired naval officer was in a coma Friday after he was shot in the head and neck during an attack blamed on Basque separatists. Lt. Aureliano Rodriguez, 65, was shot Thursday by two men outside his home in this northern Basque city. Police suspect the attackers belong to the armed Basque separatist group ETA, Spanish National Radio said. Rodriguez suffered brain damage and remained in ``very serious'' condition after five hours of surgery, doctors said at San Sebastian hospital. ETA has claimed responsibility for killing more than 600 people in its 21-year-old drive for independence of the three-province Basque region. A single ETA member is believed to have mailed four package bombs this week, including those that seriously wounded a national court judge Tuesday and an employee at Madrid's main post office the next day, the daily El Pais said. The initials ETA stand for Homeland and Liberty in the Basque language.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershock Triggers Rock Slides, Keeps Residents on Edge
DOC.TEXT: A strong aftershock to this week's big Southern California earthquake triggered rock slides onto a mountain road, forced evacuation of a college dormitory and jarred already tense nerves. The morning tremor, which measured 4.7 on the Richter scale, was widely felt in Los Angeles, Riverside, San Bernardino and San Diego counties. It also shook Orange County three hours before President Bush delivered an anti-drug address there. ``It was scary and I'm shaking. But nothing fell or flew this time,'' said Melina Manning of Ontario, two miles south of the epicenter near Upland, which is 35 miles east of Los Angeles. ``It was mild compared to the other day but very scary, especially because your nerves are shot from the other day,'' Ms. Manning said. In addition to the big aftershock, which struck at 9:26 a.m., at least two other noticeable temblors were recorded Friday, according to scientists at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. They measured 2.5 and 2.4 on the Richter scale and were among dozens of aftershocks to rattle Southern California since Wednesday, when the region was hit by a 5.5-magnitude quake centered three miles northwest of Upland. Wednesday's quake, the biggest to hit the region in more than two years, toppled scores of chimneys, shattered hundreds of windows and collapsed one building's wall. Nobody was killed but the big quake did at least $12.7 million in damage in the largely residential region that straddles the Los Angeles and San Bernardino county lines east of the city. Friday's tremor caused rock slides that closed two sections of little-traveled Mount Baldy Road, in the mountains about 35 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles, said Anthony Hughes of the California Department of Transportation. Students were evacuated from a dormitory at La Verne University after the jolt ruptured a natural gas line, said assistant La Verne City Manager Jeff Allred. Several water lines elsewhere in the city a few miles from the epicenter also broke, he said. In Pomona, the landmark First Baptist Church, already hard-hit by Wednesday's quake, may have sustained more damage Friday, Police Sgt. Ron McDonald said. Engineers were examining the bell tower and support columns of the church, which was built in 1910, McDonald said. Los Angeles County declared an emergency that made all cities eligible for state emergency assistance, said Constance Romero, assistant manager of the county's Office of Emergency Management. The proclamation also could allow victims to apply for Small Business Administration loans or property tax relief, Romero said Friday. Wednesday's quake spurred renewed calls for Californians to prepare for the so-called ``Big One,'' a catastrophic earthquake measuring between 7.5 and 8 on the Richter scale of ground motion. A 1988 U.S. Geological Survey report said there is a 60 percent chance of a quake that size on the southern San Andreas Fault by the year 2018. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage and a 6 can cause severe damage. The earthquake that did widespread damage in the San Francisco Bay area in October measured 7.1 on the Richter scale. The great San Francisco quake of 1906, which occurred before the Richter scale was devised, has been estimated at 8.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Protest, Students Retaliate With Rampage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to RAISE developments on cocoa and coffee markets, background, other price rises; DELETES final two grafs to trim
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary troops broke up peaceful protests Friday with tear gas and smoke grenades, and students retaliated by hurling firebombs, stoning cars and looting a supermarket. Hundreds of civil servants went on strike and joined university students outside downtown ministry offices yelling: ``Houphouet: thief! Houphouet: corrupt!'' Prices for coffee and cocoa, this West African country's two primary exports, surged Friday in London and New York exchanges as traders worried about the unrest and fears of a general strike. Demonstrators calling for President Felix Houphouet-Boigny to step down pose the strongest challenge the 84-year-old leader has faced since he took control of this nation of 11 million when it gained independence from France in 1960. The government announced Friday evening it was closing all schools and the university in Abidjan, along with boarding school dormitories and student residences. University students have been boycotting classes since they began protesting Feb. 19, and pupils from schools joined them in demonstrations Friday morning. Hundreds of university students packed their belongings and waited for taxis after the government said it was closing schools for ``security concerns'' and that police would enforce the decree. A few armed soldiers and police stood about, but no violence was seen. The government accused an unidentified ``group of individuals'' of ``spreading trouble'' and said students responsible for vandalism would be ``severely punished'' under the law. The student protests have gained support since the government proposed pay cuts and higher taxes to defuse an economic crisis that has grown over the past 10 years. The recession came with slumping prices of cocoa, Ivory Coast's main export. The Ivory Coast is the world's largest producer of cocoa and fifth-largest producer of coffee. Student protesters also blame lavish lifestyles of government officials and corruption. They are demanding the repatriation of millions of dollars they charge have been skimmed from state coffers and banked abroad. A similar call was made this week by the General Union of Workers. The usually docile federation is affiliated with the ruling Democratic Party but is posing unprecedented opposition to the proposals to cut civil servants' salaries by 15 percent to 40 percent and increase a tax on all wage earners from 1 percent to 11 percent. The civil servant strike has put even more pressure on Houphouet-Boigny, who already had postponed from Friday to Monday a National Council meeting to discuss the austerity measures. World Bank officials say the government has little choice but to carry them out. In addition to a foreign debt of $12 billion, unserviced since 1987, the government has run up an internal debt of more than $14 million. In London, cocoa prices went up from $1,052 a ton two weeks ago, to $1,127.44 a ton Thursday and $1,183.81 Friday. Cocoa futures sold in New York ended $35 to $50 higher for March delivery at $1,123 a ton. Futures in coffee settled 2.25 cents to 5 cents higher at 99 cents a pound. Brokers were reported concerned about the delivery of Ivory Coast's 800,000-ton crop of cocoa _ nearly a third of world supplies. It has nearly all been sold and awaits delivery. The worst violence Friday was in Yopougon, a working-class suburb seven miles from downtown where the protests began Feb. 19. A peaceful protest by several hundred students and civil servants in the city center was halted by paramilitary forces who fired tear gas and smoke grenades.
