Witnesses said students then hurled homemade firebombs at police who attacked with tear gas and smoke grenades. Reporters at the scene later found burned tires and shards of glass from stoned cars and buses. Protesters who may have been joined by criminals also ransacked a Yopougon supermarket, smashing its windows with rocks while the store was closed for the lunch-hour siesta. Women with stalls nearby blamed ``thugs and hooligans.'' Youths from high schools, wearing distinctive khaki pants and navy skirts, stoned cars on a highway into the city after they fled tear-gas grenades. Police and soldiers dispersed them with tear gas, a stun grenade and smoke grenades. Paramilitary forces also used tear gas and smoke grenades to break up other protests in at least four suburbs of the capital. Banks and other businesses closed Friday, and it was not clear whether more workers were joining the strike. Many of the cities open-air markets were shut. Others did a half-hearted business.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders Hope Bush-Kaifu Will Lead to Trade Summit Later
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6th graf; ``Economists of,'' to point out Japanese restrictions are not the whole story
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush-Japan Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American business leaders said Friday they expected no major breakthrough on contentious trade issues in the weekend talks between President Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. However, they held out hope that the discussions could set the stage for a full-fledged trade summit between the two leaders later in the year. The hastily arranged two days of talks between Bush and Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., were being viewed by many industry officials as a promising development for separate trade talks which had bogged down in recent weeks. The talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, aimed to attack the underlying causes of the huge $49 billion trade imbalance between America and Japan by dealing with such areas as Japan's exclusionary business practices and America's low savings rate. However, the discussions so far have produced no movement and American negotiators were openly pessimistic about the chances of success following the conclusion of the third round of talks last week in Tokyo. Economists of all persuasions and the Bush administation agree that even if Japan eliminated all restrictive practices about which the United States has complained, most of the $49 billion imbalance would remain because of the American appetite for Japanese cars, electronic equipment and other goods. Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, the largest trade group for U.S. manufacturing companies, said Bush deserved a lot of credit for trying to get the stalled discussions back on track. ``Bush has put his prestige on the line to emphasize the importance of these talks,'' Jasinowski said. ``We were dead in the water and this is an opportunity to breathe some life back into the effort.'' Jasinowski said that while the meeting between Bush and Kaifu was not expected to resolve any of the major issues between the two countries it would serve to highlight the importance both leaders saw in making progress. He said Kaifu may offer at the session to appoint a high-level official of his government to oversee the discussions in Japan and to coordinate responses in the massive Japanese bureaucracy. He said another possible outcome was agreement by both Bush and Kaifu to meet again in the fall for a longer session examining the whole range of trade disputes between the two countries. Separately from the summit, in addition to the review of underlying trade barriers, there are talks about specific products which the Bush administration has charged are being unfairly restricted. These talks cover American lumber products, supercomputers and satellites. John Swenson, a spokesman for Cray Research Inc., the leading manufacturer of supercomputers, said his company had heard of no breakthrough in the discussion on supercomputers. A congressional source, who spoke on condition that his name not be used, said that Kaifu was expected to announce on Saturday lower tariffs on a portion of U.S. finished wood products although the reduction would cover only a small portion of U.S. lumber sales to Japan. William Archey, top trade expert at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said that Kaifu would be following the pattern of past Japanese leaders if he offered small concessions in trade. ``The historical approach of other Japanese heads of government has been to offer these limited morsels. We then get excited because they threw us a nibble,'' he said. Pressure is growing in Congress to see results in the Japanese discussions. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, in a letter to Bush last week urged the president ``to press (Kaifu) with all the formidable persuasion at your command to open the Japanese market.'' Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. and the chairman of a Senate trade subcommittee, prepared legislation that would force the administration to retaliate if there has been no progress by the June 16 deadline in the talks covering wood, supercomputers and satellites. Baucus scheduled a hearing of his subcommittee for Monday at which time various administration witnesses were scheduled to appear to report on the developments in the discussion to date.

DOC.HEAD: Cyprus Talks End Without Progress
DOC.TEXT: Four days of talks ended in failure Friday between representatives of breakaway Turkish Cypriots and the Greek Cypriot government, and the Turks claimed the other side was not serious about a settlement. Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash told reporters that Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar found out after four days of U.N.-sponsored direct talks ``that both sides are not ready to proceed on these talks because of several difficulties.'' Denktash said his demand for self-determination for the Turkish Cypriots on the northern part of the Mediterranean island was not why the talks collapsed. He called that ``an excuse created by the Greek Cypriot side'' led by Cypriot President George Vassiliou. ``The same game which has been played over the years, having talks, continuing talks, and then destroying it and saying the Turks are guilty,'' Denktash said. Earlier, Vassiliou reported no progress in the talks. When asked if the talks were near collapse, he responded by saying: ``Did the talks start?'' The two sides have met four times since the first round of talks under U.N. auspices in August 1988. Cyprus has been divided since the Turkish army invaded in 1974 following a short-lived, Athens-backed coup by supporters of union with Greece. The Turks seized the northern third of the island. The General Assembly has recognized the Greek Cypriot side as Cyprus' legitimate government. Only Turkey recognizes the breakaway Turkish Cypriot region.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
New Zealand Court Bars TV Documentary in U.S. Child Custody Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with legal action in New Zealand. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer representing 7-year-old Hilary Foretich, the American girl caught up in an international custody battle, obtained an injunction Friday to prevent broadcast of a TV documentary on her. In Washington, a three-judge appeals court panel ruled Friday that Hilary's mother, plastic surgeon Elizabeth Morgan, can have her passport back so she can come here to fight a lawsuit filed by her former husband. Morgan went to prison for 25 months for refusing to reveal Hilary's whereabouts and refusing to comply with a court order allowing the father, dentist Eric Foretich, unsupervised visits with his daughter. Morgan contended that the girl was sexually abused by Foretich during their marriage. He denied it and claimed Morgan was mentally ill. Morgan and Foretich separated before Hilary was born. Christchurch lawyer Peter Woolley said he asked the High Court to bar the TV program from being broadcast on instructions from Isobel Mitchell, the lawyer appointed to represent Hilary's interests. Television New Zealand (TVNZ) has not decided whether it will appeal the decision that kept it from presenting ``Hilary's in Hiding'' on Friday night on its ``Foreign Correspondent'' program. In granting the temporary injunction, the judge ruled that showing the TV documentary could amount to a case of invasion of privacy. He noted that the application for an injunction was supported by an affidavit from Foretich, who is now in New Zealand. ``I look with some degree of suspicion as to what is said by either parent at this present stage in relation to this dispute where it appears that both parents have for some years participated in a public exposure to the news media of allegations and counterallegations in their disputed claims for custody of the plaintiff (Hilary),'' the judge said. Foretich traced his daughter to Christchurch last week. The girl has been living there with her maternal grandparents for nearly two years and attending school under the assumed name of Ellen Morgan. The District of Columbia Court of Appeals panel released Morgan's pasport on Friday, freeing her to travel to New Zealand to visit Hilary. Superior Court Judge Herbert Dixon had seized the passport in August 1987 when he jailed Morgan for failing to reveal Hilary's whereabouts. On Thursday, Dixon said he was satisfied the return of the passport was ``in the best interests'' of the little girl. He noted, however, that Morgan remained in contempt of court.

DOC.HEAD: Norwegian Study: Coffee Drinking Increases Risk of Death
DOC.TEXT: Heavy coffee drinking, especially by men, increases the risk of dying from heart disease, according to a Norwegian study published Friday in the British Medical Journal. The study of 38,564 men and women by the National Health Screening Service in Norway found that coffee drinking by men was ``significantly related'' to death from coronary heart disease, even after allowing for other important risk factors such as heavy smoking and high blood pressure. Women were at risk but to a lesser extent, the researchers said. Heavy coffee drinkers had higher levels of cholesterol than those who drank moderately, but the researchers concluded that ``coffee may affect mortality from coronary heart disease over and above its effects in raising cholesterol concentrations.'' The Norwegian researchers studied 19,398 men and 19,166 women ages 35 to 54 from 1977 to 1982. They reported no symptoms of cardiovascular disease or diabetes and later were followed until the end of 1986. During the follow-up period, 168 men and 16 women died of coronary heart disease, the researchers said. Of the men, 130 drank between five and nine cups of coffee a day. There were six deaths among men who drank one or two cups a day and three deaths among men who drank less than one cup, the study found. Among women, the researchers said, an excess risk was found only for those who drank seven or more cups of coffee every day. The researchers said the major uncertainty in previous studies has been whether the apparent relation between coffee and death from coronary heart disease might be caused by lifestyle. A related study showed that dietary habits and lifestyle could not explain the association of coffee and cholesterol. The researchers said a follow-up study relating dietary habits and lifestyle to death from coronary heart disease has not yet been done. ``We conclude that coffee consumption is fairly strongly related to death from coronary heart disease, but a potential causal role is weakened by the varying strength of the relation in different groups,'' the researchers said. ``To verify the observed effect of coffee on deaths from coronary heart disease over and above the effect on cholesterol concentration, cholesterol concentration must be determined more accurately than by a single measurement,'' they said. The researchers from the National Health Screening Service were epidemiologist Aage Tverdal, research fellow Inger Stensvold, deputy director Dr. Per Lund-Larsen and director Dr. Kjell Bjartveit. Kari Solvoll of the Institute of Nutrition Research and Dr. Olav P. Foss, deputy director of Ulleval Hospital, Central Laboratory also participated.

DOC.HEAD: Auditors Cite Risk of Earthquake Damage at Nuclear Arms Site
DOC.TEXT: The Savannah River nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina is inadequately protected against severe earthquakes and won't be fully protected for several years, federal auditors said Friday. The report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said the vulnerability to earthquake damage at Savannah River has been known for many years. But it said the government only recently made serious corrective efforts. The plant, situated along the Savannah River near Aiken, has nuclear reactors to produce tritium, a radioactive gas needed to make nuclear warheads. The installation also contains other nuclear-related buildings, including a fuel processing center for the Navy and a radioactive waste treatment building. The three reactors have been closed for nearly two years because of safety problems. One of the three is expected to resume production by the end of this year. The auditors, in a report requested by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on the environment and energy, said seismic improvements at Savannah River would not be completed for several years. Planning of improvements is under way, but ``it will take several years to accomplish adequate seismic protection at Savannah River,'' the report said. ``Numerous systems and structures in the reactors and other nuclear facilities may not withstand the worst earthquake reasonably expected at the site and, in the event of such an earthquake, could threaten employees and the public with releases of radiation,'' the report said. Catherine Kaliniak, an Energy Department spokeswoman, said the department had not seen the report and would not comment until it had reviewed the conclusions. The earthquake potential at Savannah River is based mainly on the fact that a large earthquake _ estimated to have been the equivalent of about 7 on the Richter scale _ occurred in South Carolina in 1886. It was centered about 80 miles from where the weapons plant now stands, and it caused extensive damage and loss of life. The San Francisco earthquake last October was measured at about 7.1 on the Richter scale. Each whole number increase on the Richter scale means an ground motion increase by a factor of 10.

DOC.HEAD: For Seabrook Locals, The Fight Is Never-Ending
DOC.TEXT: People gathered Friday at Fowle's Soda and Cigar could say this much about their two decades of opposition to the Seabrook nuclear power plant: Popular sentiment doesn't always win, but it dies hard. ``It's frustrating to fight the odds, but we think of the children and then keep on,'' said David MacWhinnie, a longtime resident who stopped off at the store Friday to reminisce about past battles over the plant 6 miles up the coast and wonder what the future holds. Over the years, a vocal core of citizens in about a half-dozen cities clustered around the New Hampshire border have signed petitions, held bake sales and marched against the plant. But despite their protests, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved licensing for the reactor. The federal panel's long-awaited decision Thursday came as no surprise to residents here. Some have supported the facility, whose start-up is 11 years behind schedule, and the promise of clean and efficient energy for 1 million homes. ``The government wants to do it, so we have to put up with it,'' said Everett Bridges, 87. For others, the fight continues. Opponents, including officials of the state of Massachusetts, have pledged to appeal the decision in the courts. ``We never got a vote or any influence,'' said Jane Wickers, one of a few dozen regulars gathered for morning coffee at Fowle's, a fixture here since 1940. ``You start to feel like you can't make any difference ... but you've got to try.'' People around here say they don't regard themselves as the protesting kind. They live quietly in old coastal towns where boarded up ice cream stands are part of the off-season charm. No one much wants to get arrested or stand with picket signs in the shadow of Seabrook, which is perched on a bluff over one of several popular summertime beaches. But many citizens have joined the Clamshell Alliance and have been united since the early 1970s behind an anti-nuclear banner. They say the government hasn't established an effective evacuation plan and fear there would be chaos on the narrow streets out of town if a nuclear emergency occurred. ``Seabrook has been the acid test for the national agenda for nuclear power,'' said James Dougherty, a vocal Newburyport realtor and father of two. ``We are the caretakers of our own safety. ... We have to keep driving the issue.'' Seabrook was proposed in 1972 as a twin-reactor plant costing less than $1 billion. Construction delays and cost increases forced the cancellation of one reactor in the mid-1980s and plunged lead owner Public Service Co. of New Hampshire into bankruptcy reorganization in 1988. The plant became a symbol of the anti-nuclear movement, and its foes claimed a broader victory, contending that no utility would now risk the costs of trying to build and open another nuclear plant. In the early going, a lot of area residents saw a silver lining in the Seabrook plan. There was talk of new jobs, lower taxes and cheaper energy. And some people still stand by those things. ``I live right here on the beach,'' said Diane Burke of Seabrook, N.H. ``I prospered when the nuke was being built and I think a lot of locals felt that was good. I still don't really see the problem.'' Burke and other proponents said they might feel differently if an accident occurred, but for now they're willing to wait and see. Diehard opponents said, however, they would not willing to concede defeat despite the NRC's decision. Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon has promised to take the activists' case to the courts. ``It's begun to wear people down. Life has to go on. You can't just keep picketing,'' said Marie Capello, a Seabrook resident. But she said she would probably end up doing just that. ``We've been trying to buck something so big and so powerful _ not only the plant itself but all the muckety-mucks who run it,'' she said. ``But I don't see how I can stop doing any little thing until the bitter end.''

DOC.HEAD: Weicker Running As Independent For Governor
DOC.TEXT: Former Republican Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the maverick lawmaker who made a career of bucking his party and championing liberal causes, said Friday he would run for governor of Connecticut as an independent. ``You're going to get one hell of a race,'' declared the former three-term senator. ``I think I'm going to win it. I don't think it's any gamble at all.'' Weicker, 58, told reporters, supporters and onlookers in a packed Capitol conference room that his unsuccessful bid for a fourth Senate term in 1988 ``took me down a peg or two and probably deservedly so. I've taken my licks.'' ``It's now 1990 and I believe that, as never before, we need each other,'' he said. The announcement capped weeks of intense speculation about Weicker, who in 28 years of political activity cultivated a reputation for aggressive, independent Republicanism. He became a national figure in the mid-70s as one of the first Republicans to take on President Richard M. Nixon during the Watergate scandal. Weicker would say nothing negative about Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill or Rep. Bruce A. Anderson, a four-term congressman challenging O'Neill for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Nor would he criticize any of the four Republicans now in the running. Weicker was elected to the Senate in 1970 in a three-way race in which the Democrats were badly split. Of his bid to make it a three-way race in the November election, he said: ``The ironies are not lost on me, I can assure you.'' Weicker said he expects he'll need campaign funds of $1 million or $2 million, less than half of what the other major party candidates are talking about spending. The Greenwich millionaire said he wouldn't spend any of his own money on the race. Democrats hailed his decision to run, saying it would divide the GOP and throw the party into chaos. State GOP Chairman Richard Foley said that with Weicker's announcement, ``the race is over. We just won,'' but his voice didn't carry conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Marilyn Monroe's Swimsuit Sold at Auction for $5,810
DOC.TEXT: The swimsuit worn by Marilyn Monroe in the 1954 movie ``There's No Business Like Show Business'' sold for $5,810 in London Thursday at an auction to help Vietnamese boat people, the organizers reported. Rock singer Elton John, who collects such stage and movie items, donated the black-sequined swimsuit to the auction of show business memorabilia. The event raised more than $19,920 to help Vietnamese boat people held in camps in Hong Kong, the charity Rock Against Repatriation reported. Model Jerry Hall, the girlfriend of Rolling Stones singer Mick Jagger, was the auctioneer for the event. The auction was held at Sticky Fingers, a cafe owned by Bill Wyman, another member of the Rolling Stones, in west London's swank Kensington district. The swimsuit was bought by a record company promoting the music career of a 22-year-old Monroe lookalike, Pauline Bailey. Rock Against Repatriation was launched by guitarist Steve Hackett of the rock group Genesis to raise money for boat people. The group, which recently released a single of the old Rod Stewart hit ``Sailing'' for the appeal, opposes the British government's policy of forced repatriation of the boat people to Vietnam. The policy has been temporarily suspended following objections from Vietnam, the United States and elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Greyhound Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at Greyhound Lines Inc., the Dallas-based company that operates the only nationwide bus system. The company's 6,300 drivers are on strike principally over wage issues.
DOC.HEAD: HISTORY:
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. is the descendant of a bus operation that began in 1914 when Swedish immigrant Carl Eric Wickman established the Jitney Line in Hibbing Minn., charging 25 cents for a round trip on the company's lone Hubmobile between Hibbing and the Alice saloon. The current company was formed in 1987 through a leveraged buyout of the bus operations of Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. Fred G. Currey, a career bus executive, led an investment group that paid $270 million for Greyhound. Four months later, Currey's GLI Holding Inc. bought Trailways Lines Inc. of Dallas for $80 million and merged the two bus lines.
DOC.HEAD: UNIONS:
DOC.TEXT: Most of the company's 11,825 employees are represented by the striking Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. The union has all 6,300 drivers, plus 1,660 office workers and 1,475 maintenance workers. There are another 690 maintenance employees represented by the International Association of Machinists, who agreed to a four-year contract last fall. The United Auto Workers also represents employees at the company's Eagle Bus Manufacturing Inc. in Brownsville, Texas. There are 1,700 employees not subject to collective bargaining.
DOC.HEAD: STRIKE ISSUES:
DOC.TEXT: The main issue revolves around pay. Before Currey's group bought the company in 1987, the union agreed to a 22 percent wage cut, although the company says its drivers are the highest paid in the industry, except for some small regional companies in the Northeast. The company says drivers averaged $24,743 in 1989, a $1,080 increase over 1987. The 1,500 highest paid averaged $33,218 and its highest paid driver made $48,800. Greyhound says its offer would give drivers a $14.1 million, or 6.9 percent, raise in the first year and 13.5 percent over the life of the 3-year contract. The union says those figures are misleading, because of the inclusion of incentive bonuses. The union claims its offer would cost $17 million in the first year and $15 million each of the next two years. The company, however, says the union's offer would cost more than $200 million. Other issues involve pension plan contributions, and regional pay rates for mechanics.
DOC.HEAD: OPERATIONS:
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound operates three businesses: intercity passenger service, charter service and small package delivery. Its 3,938 buses serve about 9,500 locations, and are the only public intercity transportation in about 9,000 of those areas. The company says it has improved each year since the buyout, with revenue passenger miles, the most meaningful traffic measure, rising from 6.09 billion in the year before the buyout to 7.48 billion last year. In all, about 22 million passengers traveled an average of 335 miles each on Greyhound last year. The company says its traffic has grown faster than other modes of transportation, up 9.8 percent last year, versus 4.3 percent for cars, 4.2 percent for Amtrak and a 0.1 percent loss for airlines.
DOC.HEAD: FINANCES:
DOC.TEXT: After losing $20 million in its first two year, Greyhound expects a $730,000 profit for 1989 on $1 billion in revenue. The company has about $340 million in long-term debt, but no significant principal payment due until 1992. Greyhound plans to spend $103 million over the next three years to upgrade equipment and terminal operations. Capital expenditures have totaled $183 million in the last three years.

DOC.HEAD: Feds File Sex Discrimination Lawsuit Against VMI
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department filed a sex-discrimination lawsuit Thursday to try to force the all-male Virginia Military Institute to admit women. Federal authorities filed the lawsuit on behalf of an unidentified female high school student from northern Virginia who complained last spring that she had been prohibited from attending the 150-year-old, state-supported school in nearby Lexington. The lawsuit argues that the school's male-only admission policy violates the Civil Rights Act and the 14th Amendment. It urges the U.S. District Court in Roanoke to order the state of Virginia and the school ``to remedy fully their discriminatory policies and practices.'' The Justice Department also is reviewing complaints from two women who want to attend The Citadel in Charleston, S.C., the nation's only other public military college that admits males only. Among those named in the lawsuit were Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder and the state Council of Higher Education, along with the institute's superintendent, John W. Knapp, and board of visitors president, Joseph M. Spivey. The Justice Department wrote Wilder and Knapp last March warning them they would face a lawsuit if they did not agree by Feb. 20 to begin admitting women. But state Attorney General Mary Sue Terry and the school's private fund-raising organization came back with two lawsuits asking the federal court in Roanoke to declare the college's admission policy constitutional. The Justice Department also filed motions Thursday asking the court to dismiss the lawsuits filed by the state and the foundation. Spokesman Tom Joynes said school officials would have no comment on the federal government's action. The governor's and state attorney general's offices both declined to comment. The lawsuit said the institute is a public body and ``the defendants have engaged in discrimination on the basis of sex'' by refusing to consider qualified females for admission to the four-year undergraduate degree program. The institute received $11 million in state aid this year, almost half of its $25 million budget. Congress decided in 1976 to begin admitting women to the federal service academies. All of the school's 1,200 cadets live in a three-story dormitory in spartan rooms with standardized cots, shelves and desks. They wake to reveille and shower in common stalls. Freshmen, referred to as ``rats'' by other students, go through a year's initiation of psychological and physical pressure. The VMI foundation lawsuit argued that ``the forced admission of women will eliminate the option of a unique undergraduate experience for men, while providing no increased educational opportunities for women.''

DOC.HEAD: $10,000 Contract Out On Life Of 60-Year-Old Drug Fighter, FBI Says
DOC.TEXT: Crack cocaine dealers have put out a $10,000 ``contract'' to kill anti-drug crusader C.W. Roddy, a 60-year-old woman shot in an attack at her home New Year's Day, the FBI said Friday. Roddy, who has been speaking out against drugs at schools and urging police to rid her neighborhood of crack dealers, said she asked the FBI to make the latest threat public. The small woman defiantly refused to move from her home and promised to continue fighting drug dealers. ``I have no fear. I am concerned, but I am not fearful,'' Roddy said at the FBI news conference in front of City Hall. ``It won't do them any good to kill me. ``There are people in the community and the surrounding communities who have decided they are going to speak out against drugs. And if they kill me that will just (put) more pressure on the people who are picking up the baton, so to speak,'' she said. William E. Smith, who heads the FBI's Palo Alto office, said the agency and the nearby Menlo Park Police Department received information there was a $10,000 contract on Roddy's life because of her anti-drug efforts. ``The contract was put out by those involved in drug activity in and around this particular city,'' Smith said. ``They're street dealers. We're talking about local talent.'' The FBI _ which got the tip more than a week ago _ is working with local authorities because of the violation of Roddy's civil rights. In the New Year's Eve attack, gunmen sprayed her small stucco home with at least 35 rounds of semiautomatic weapons fire, but the retired telephone company worker suffered only a minor wound to her abdomen. For two years, Roddy has complained about drug dealers in the neighborhood where she's lived for 22 years. She appealed to the City Council repeatedly and even ordered dealers to move their cars away from her home. News of the shooting brought promises of manpower and money to help local police cope with pushers in the drug-plagued and financially strapped community. Members of the Guardian Angels crime-fighting group have been standing watch outside her home. East Palo Alto Police Chief Dan Nelson said investigators have pursued a number of leads in the attack. His department put up a $5,000 reward and San Mateo County added $5,000 to the pool. ``So far we've had zilch information,'' Nelson said. ``We've had fairly decent leads,'' Smith said. ``The difficulty we've had is this community has been paralyzed by the drug activity and the fear of coming forward.'' The FBI's Smith appealed for help from the public, adding he was appalled that ``someone would have the audacity to say they're going to take the life ... of a 60-year-old woman who says, `this is my right, don't sell drugs in front of my home, my kids, my nieces, they have a right to feel free from drug activity.' I think it's time that we get involved.'' Nelson said his department and the Menlo Park Police are patrolling Roddy's block as much as possible, and he has given her a police radio for her home.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Sierra Nevada, Rain in South
DOC.TEXT: A winter storm brought rain and snow to northern and central California and snow to the Sierra Nevada on Friday, while rain fell across much of the South. Snow was expected to continue into Saturday in the Sierra range in California and Nevada, with winter storm warnings posted overnight and accumulations up to 18 inches forecast for some spots. Rain extended from southern Oregon across the northern half of California. A few snow flurries fell in northern Michigan. In the South, rain fell across a broad area from northern Mississippi and Tennessee east to northern Florida, the Carolinas and Virginia. The weather front that brought the rain was forecast to move out toward the Atlantic Saturday, leaving sun in its wake in the South but bringing rain to most of the East Coast. Residents of Valdez, Alaska, finally got a break from unusually heavy snow that piled up 21 inches deep on Thursday. The season's accumulation is 40 feet. It was a cold February in Nome, Alaska, even by Nome standards. The average temperatures was 21 degrees below normal, and the low dipped to 10 below zero every day but one. The Northeast was unseasonably warm Friday. The high temperature in St. Johnsbury, Vt., was 52 degrees, breaking by three degrees a record that had stood since 1902. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 17 at International Falls, Minn., to 81 degrees at Key West, Fla. The low temperature for the nation Friday was 2 degrees below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Gets No. 2 ANC Post; Officials Concerned About His Health
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS 12th graf, `The ANC...' to DELETE garble; pickup 13th graf, `On Feb. ...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela on Friday took over the second most senior post in the guerrilla-backed African National Congress after a two-day meeting of the organization's top policy-making body. The 35-member national executive committee said it elected Mandela as deputy to President Oliver Tambo, who is recuperating from a stroke in a Swedish clinic. The statement said the committee resolved to make contact with the South African government to settle dates and details for a preliminary meeting to clear obstacles in the path of full-scale constitutional negotiations. The ANC also indicated it was concerned about Mandela's health, and would be selective about accepting foreign trips and future engagements for the 71-year-old black nationalist leader. Mandela, along with fellow longtime political detainees Walter Sisulu and Govan Mbeki, resumed seats on the national executive they held when they were arrested more than two decades ago, said the statement read at a news conference by acting President Alfred Nzo. Nzo said the ANC leaders, meeting with Mandela for the first time since President F.W. de Klerk lifted a 30-year ban on the ANC on Feb. 2, also decided to open headquarters offices in Johannesburg, South Africa immediately. While the ANC was outlawed in South Africa its political and guerrilla leaders have operated their headquarters from Zambia. Asked to elaborate on his new role in the ANC, Mandela was non-commital. ``I am prepared to serve in any role the national executive instructs me to fill,'' said Mandela, who was freed Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison. He said he was optimistic about a political settlement but said he was unwilling to predict any time frame for negotiations or the return of exiles. ``We are already making progress. There is no reason why we should not be able to make further progress,'' he said. ``I am optimistic that the process of removing all obstacles (to negotiations) is on. I will be surprised if we don't succeed in removing the obostacles.'' The ANC is demanding the lifting of the state of emergency and the release of all political prisoners as preconditions to talks aimed at ending the apartheid system that denies South Africa's 28 million blacks a vote in national life. On Feb. 16, the ANC said it was prepared to send a delegation to South Africa for talks with de Klerk on how to proceed. Mandela said the ANC welcomed wide-ranging reforms so far by de Klerk but the ANC sought only to negotiate on an equal footing with the ruling National Party. ``As long as political prisoners are not released and the state is emergency is not lifted in its entirety, we are not on equal terms,'' he said. Of his own release, Mandela said ``the release of one prisoner when there are 3,000 others can't be such an important development.'' The veteran black leader said the national executive would ``in due course'' announce the names of delegates it wants to travel to Cape Town for the preliminary talks with de Klerk. South Africa says it wants the ANC to abandon its commitment to guerrilla hostilities and there have been calls from South African church leaders and President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia for guerrillas to suspend their operations inside South Africa. ``If the government gives us the opportunity, we will move away from confrontation ... but it is up to the government to decide,'' Mandela said. The ANC has waged a bombing and sabotage campaign since 1961 but there have been few attacks recently and the guerrillas have had little military impact. By his election as the ANC's No. 2, Mandela effectively becomes the organization's top leader. Tambo suffered a stroke in August and is widely believed unable to resume an active political life as the ANC sets about establishing a political framework in South Africa for the first time. Amid concerns for the health of Mandela, ANC officials said he had a full schedule and been followed everywhere by hundreds of journalists since his release from prison. Mandela has received many foreign invitations. A senior ANC official said Mandela, treated in prison for tuberculosis two years ago, receives a daily checkup from a physician. ``We have just got him back'' from prison, the official said. ``The last thing he should see now is hospital walls.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge East, West German Leaders To Merge Treaties On Poland
DOC.TEXT: A third of the Senate appealed to the leaders of East and West Germany on Friday to merge their countries' existing border treaties with Poland in order to allay Polish fears. The bipartisan group of 34 senators called on West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow to come up with a single treaty that would bind a unified Germany to honor the present border with Poland along the Oder and western Neisse rivers. The joint treaty would be initialed by the two leaders now but would only be ratified by a united German parliament once unification is achieved, the senators proposed. ``We believe, as you do, that inviolability of the post-war European borders is a cornerstone for world peace and stability...,'' the senators wrote. The move was initiated by Senator Paul Simon, D-Ill., a member of the Foreign Relations Committee. ``Any remaining ambiguity about German intentions concerning the present German borders with Poland should be eliminated as soon as possible,'' the senators said. As steps toward uniting East and West gather momentum, Poland has become increasingly nervous that the territory it was given after World War II, comprising one-third of present-day Poland, might be claimed by a united Germany. Kohl has dismissed such fears as groundless and said this week that he would favor the two German parliaments making formal statements that recognize Poland's western border. But despite repeated pressure from opposition parties at home and from foreign leaders, he has refused to commit himself to a binding position on the subject, saying only a unified German government and parliament could make such a pledge. Some analysts have seen his reluctance as motivated by a desire to avoid giving an issue to the very small extreme nationalist groups in West Germany. Each Germany has a separate treaty with Poland defining their borders. In their cable to the two leaders, the senators said a unified treaty would ``put to rest legitimate concerns of Poland and would facilitate the process leading to German unification.'' ``It also would respond to Chancellor's Kohl's concern that the present treaty between Poland and the Federal Republic of Germany could not be legally binding on a united Germany,'' the cable said. President Bush has also urged Kohl to commit a unified Germany, of which he might be the first leader, to an agreement about Poland's existing borders. The two leaders discussed the problem at a summit meeting last weekend in the presidential retreat at Camp David. The Potsdam conference of July 1945 of the principal victors over Hitler's Germany _ the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union _ put German territory under Polish administration, pending a final peace treaty, as compensation for Polish territory further East claimed by Russia. The German provinces of Pomerania and Silesia and half of East Prussia were given to Poland, and millions of Germans fled to Germany. Much of the area in question had been seized from Poland in the 18th century extinction of Poland by Prussia, Austria and Russia.

DOC.HEAD: Drifter Gets 10 Years for Robbing Disabled Man
DOC.TEXT: A drifter from Minnesota was sentenced to 10 years in prison for robbing $25 from a disabled mute who is bound to a wheelchair and forcing him to drink cheap wine. Scott Johnston, 25, an English major at Palo Alto College who suffers from cerebral palsy, pointed to words and letters glued to a board on his wheelchair to communicate at a non-jury trial Thursday. He testified he was on his way to a K mart store last July to make a payment on a radio when Curtis Claymore and a second man came up to him and Claymore allegedly robbed him of the cash and payment receipts for the radio. He alleged that Claymore, a 31-year-old drifter from Guthrie, Minn., then wheeled him to a nearby Handy Andy grocery store, bought a bottle of cheap wine and tried to pour the wine down Johnston's throat. Johnston claimed he was bundled out of his wheelchair and his communication board was tossed aside. He said he spent six hours with Claymore and was afraid of leaving because Claymore had a lock-blade knife in his knapsack. Claymore claimed he did not harm Johnston but was protecting him from another man. The student said the second man threatened him but did not help Claymore take the money. Claymore denied he showed Johnston the knife but admitted he used it to clean his fingernails in front of him. ``That's not showing a knife,'' he said. When Johnston's father and two neighbors arrived at the shopping center that night, they called police. A police officer said when he came on the scene, Johnston pointed out two words on his board _ ``book him.'' State District Judge Sharon MacRae took only moments to convict and sentence Claymore, denying his request for probation.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Quake Strikes Area Near Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake rattled communities northeast of Tokyo early Saturday, the Central Meteorological Agency said. Local police said no casualties or damage were reported. The quake occurred at 12:22 a.m. and the agency located its epicenter at 32 miles beneath the earth's surface in southwestern Ibaraki state, about 38 miles northeast of Tokyo. The temblor had a preliminary reading of 4.5 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake that measures 4 can cause moderate damage, and one which measures 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Second American Confirmed Dead, Cairo Hotel Death Toll at 17
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs To CLARIFY that Sheraton's statement said unconfirmed reports put number of dead at 18. Picks up 3rd graf, Morgue officials ..., SUBBING grafs 14-15, Sheraton's statement . .. to CONFORM and SUBBING 19th and penultimate graf, El-Saadani said ... FIXING garble
DOC.TEXT: The body of a 31-year-old American was found Friday in the debris of a luxury hotel fire, bringing to at least 17 the number of people killed, officials said. Sheraton Corp. said in a statement issued from its headquarters in Boston that according to unconfirmed reports, 18 people were killed in Thursday's fire at the Heliopolis Sheraton Hotel. It gave no details. Morgue officials said 17 people died in the blaze, ignited by sparks from a clay bread oven in a tourist restaurant tent next to the hotel. A 67-year-old retired accountant from Houston was among the dead and a third American was reported killed. Two others and three Britons remained missing. The fire raged for nine hours through the lobby and many of its 630 rooms. About 70 people were injured. Authorities blamed strong winds, common this time of year in Egypt, and the lack of an alarm system or sprinklers for the fire's rapid spread. Sheraton said in its statement that there were fire alarms in the building. ``The alarm was sounded, and fire fighting authorities were promptly contacted,'' it said. Frantic guests at the six-story hotel jumped out windows and slid down bedsheets that were tied together. Maj. Gen. Adel Negm, chief of the Cairo fire brigade, charged that Sheraton officials broke the law by erecting the tent. ``They are illegal because they are fire hazards,'' he said. Sheraton's statement said the hotel ``had received all required permits to operate the hotel and restaurants. The Heliopolis Sheraton was in compliance with all local codes and regulations.'' The hotel chain's director of Middle East operations, Sami Zogbi, said in Cairo that the hotel was never warned about using tents. ``If that's true, how come the authorities didn't pull it down?'' he said. ``We had firefighting equipment, at least 20 large extinguishers in the tent, but the winds were very strong.'' Canvas tents and marquees are used widely in Egypt for weddings, funeral gatherings and entertainment. Sheraton's statement said unconfirmed reports put the number of deaths at 18, but the director of Cairo's central morgue, Dr. Kamal el-Saadani, said he had received 17 bodies, including five women who had not been identified. He said the others included a Greek, a Briton, a Chilean and three each from France, Finland and the United States. A U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said only two Americans were confirmed dead and that two remained unaccounted for. She said she could neither confirm nor rule out the death of a third American, as claimed by police Col. Harb. At the morgue, the third American victim was said to be an elderly man. The embassy spokeswoman said on condition of anonymity that American authorities were ``pretty certain'' the body found Friday was that of Stephen Mohnike, 31, of California. His hometown was not immediately available. El-Saadani said the remains of another American, Robert D. Cresap, 67, of Houston, had been identified at the morgue. The embassy spokeswoman said it was possible that the two missing Americans also had died, but documented proof was lacking and some bodies were too badly burned for prompt identification.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Books Recovered after Theft from Penn Library
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `If convicted ...,' to CORRECT that Wilkerson would face three to five years in prison on each count.
DOC.TEXT: A part-time employee of the University of Pennsylvania library was charged with stealing more than 100 books and documents, including a 1611 copy of Shakespeare's ``Hamlet'' worth $1 million, authorities said Thursday. The works, valued at more than $1.45 million, were recovered, officials said. City police Wednesday night charged Kathleen Wilkerson, a part-time worker in the Van Pelt Library's rare books department, with one count each of theft and receiving stolen property, said Wayne R. Gilbert, the FBI's top agent in Philadelphia. If convicted, Wilkerson, 33, would face three to five years in prison on each count. No other arrests were imminent, but the investigation was continuing, said James Clark, first deputy commissioner of the Police Department. The books were spotted Saturday at the Bauman Rare Books store in Philadelphia by book dealer Steven Lowentheil of Baltimore. Suspecting they were from the library, he notified university officials and the FBI. Nineteen of the books and documents, including the slim ``Hamlet'' volume, were recovered Tuesday and Wednesday at the book store, officials said. More than 100 others were found Wednesday at Ms. Wilkerson's home and her parents' home, authorities said. The store cooperated in the investigation, Gilbert said. Ms. Wilkerson had worked in the rare books department for several years, Gilbert said. He did not know whether she had any association with the bookstore. There was no answer at her home telephone Thursday. The bookstore's owner, Natalie Bauman, was believed to be at a book show in Texas, police said. It was not clear whether Ms. Wilkerson had acted alone, how long the books had been missing and whether other books had passed into private hands. ``There may be other books missing, but that's part of the continuing investigation,'' Gilbert said. ``Apparently this has been going on for a while,'' said Paul Mosher, the Ivy League university's vice provost and director of libraries. At a news conference, the FBI displayed the 19 books found at the bookstore. Besides ``Hamlet,'' one of eight such copies known to exist, other Shakespearean works were a 1600 edition of ``Merchant of Venice'' valued at $100,000; a 1608 edition of ``Henry V,'' $100,000; and a 1664 folio, $35,000. Works by other authors included a 1491 edition of Dante's ``Divine Comedy,'' $25,000; a 1719 edition of Isaac Newton's ``Optice,'' $25,000; three copies of Thomas Paine's ``Common Sense,'' worth $10,000, $5,000 and $2,500; a 1542 edition of Geoffrey Chaucer's ``The Canterbury Tales,'' $1,000; and a 1497 Bible, $25,000. The remainder were books and letters by the English romantic poet, Lord Byron, the most valuable of which was an 1807 copy of ``Hours of Idleness'' valued at $15,000. The FBI originally believed the case involved interstate transportation of stolen books, but investigators later determined the case was limited to Philadelphia, Gilbert said. Mosher said the investigation was hampered by the theft of index cards used to keep track of many books and documents along with the works. About 60 percent of the library's 20 million volumes and documents are cataloged by computer, but the rest are on cards dating back to the 19th century. Mosher said the library has been reviewing security procedures, and has removed its most valuable items from shelves and put them in a vault. The procedures for hiring part-time employees in the library also have been strengthened.

DOC.HEAD: Family Cries Foul Over Handling of Case by Prosecutors
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a black teen-ager slain in a racial attack in Brooklyn said Thursday that the disappearance of an important witness in the case makes them feel betrayed by prosecutors. ``They can take that sign down in the courthouse that says, `And Justice for All,''' Diane Hawkins, the mother of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, said at the Apollo Theater in Harlem after appearing on a WLIB radio program. Hawkins was shot to death Aug. 23 when he and three black friends were surrounded by a gang of young whites shortly after arriving in the predominantly white Bensonhurst neighborhood to look at a used car. On Wednesday, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes announced that John Vento, 21, has been missing since Christmas. Vento, who allegedly participated in the attack, had agreed to testify before a grand jury and at any trial as part of deal in which he would not be charged. The trial was to start Monday, but prosecutors plan to ask state Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens to adjourn the proceedings for a month if Vento is not found in the next few days. Vento's attorney, Gerald DiChiara, said Thursday that his client's brother told him that the family was also looking for Vento. ``They don't know where he is,'' DiChiara said. The brother said the family wants to persuade Vento to give up, the lawyer said. Hawkins' father, Moses Stewart, said he felt betrayed by former District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman, who was replaced in January by Hynes. ``So he was given immunity by Holtzman and slipped through the fingers of Hynes,'' Stewart said. Hynes spokesman Patrick Clark said the district attorney was prepared to meet with the family. ``He's a father, too, and knows how much the Stewart family is grieving,'' Clark said. ``He regrets they are disappointed, but he's going to do everything in his power to do justice to their son.'' The Rev. Al Sharpton, one of the family's advisers, said Mrs. Hawkins would lead a rally through Bensonhurst on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: South African Minister Visits Angola on Peace Mission
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Pik Botha of South Africa held talks with Angolan officials Thursday, officially ending 15 years of rancor between their countries. Botha's one-day swing was the first official visit to Luanda by a South African minister since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975 and South Africa sent troops to back guerrillas fighting its new Marxist government. The visit is the latest move in a diplomatic offensive by the white-dominated government of South Africa to improve relations with its black neighbors. Diplomatic sources in Luanda said President Jose Eduardo dos Santos pressed Botha during a one-hour meeting to use South Africa's influence with Angolan guerrillas to bring them to the negotiating table. South Africa agreed to withdraw its troops after 13 years of combat against government forces and to halt aid to the rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ UNITA_ in a 1988 peace accord signed in New York. Botha called on Thursday for cooperation and improved commerical links between Angola and South Africa and said, ``Unless we can put aside the ideological differences and do so quickly, Africa is in for a terrible economic situation.'' Botha's talks here also covered recent political reforms in South Africa, including legalization of anti-apartheid organizations and last month's release of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela after 27 years in jail. Foreign Minister Pedro de Castro van Dunem met Botha for 90 minutes. He praised South Africa for Mandela's release and for reforms of the apartheid system of racial segregation that were initiated by President F.W. de Klerk. Since assuming power in August, de Klerk has traveled to Zambia, Zaire, Mozambique and Ivory Coast to explain planned reforms of apartheid. South African-Angolan relations have improved since the New York accords, in which South Africa also pledged to accept a U.N. plan to grant independence to Angola's southern neighbor, Namibia. Under the accords, about 50,000 Cuban troops supporting the Luanda government are leaving Angola, with a complete pullout set for mid-1991. In Johannesburg, de Klerk pressed ahead with reform Thursday, saying he will not tolerate coverups and promising a thorough investigation into charges that security forces have killed anti-apartheid activists. ``The truth about crimes and malpractices has to be established and made public,'' de Klerk told Parliament in Cape Town. ``I am not asking anybody to cover up anything, let alone condone any crime.'' More than 60 unsolved killings of anti-apartheid figures have occurred in the past decade. Activists have long accused security forces of involvement in the deaths. A judicial commission appointed by de Klerk is to begin investigating next week the alleged police and military involvement in assassination squads. Twenty people were arrested Thursday in Cape Town while demonstrating in support of about 350 inmates on a 4-day-old hunger strike, activists said. Inmates at Robben Island Prison near Cape Town stopped eating Monday, saying they consider themselves political prisoners and should be released under the reforms. Many of the hunger strikers are supporters of the African National Congress or the Pan Africanist Congress, the two groups that wage guerrilla campaigns against the government.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Will Visit NATO to Discuss Situation in Germany
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl will meet officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization next week to discuss the situation in Germany, the alliance announced Thursday. In a brief statement, it said Kohl will meet on March 8 with NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner and ambassadors from the 16 NATO nations. It said the purpose of Kohl's visit was ``to inform and consult about the position of the Federal Government (West Germany) on Germany and security matters.'' It did not elaborate. But the visit apparently stems from Germany's desire to keep the allies up to date on the rapid pace of events in Central Europe. Some smaller countries, like Italy, the Netherlands and Belgium, have complained about being left on the sidelines. Elections will take place on March 18 in East Germany and are expected to spur the drive for reunification of the two Germanys. NATO officials have said a united Germany should remain part of the Western alliance, but that Soviet troops could be temporarily stationed on the current territory of East Germany. More than 380,000 Red Army troops are assigned there now. The Soviet Union has said the new state should be neutral, belonging to neither military alliance. East Germany now is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. West Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has proposed that a united Germany continue in NATO but only the territory of West Germany would be tied to its military structure. NATO would not extend its forces into East Germany. NATO ambassadors on Thursday discussed the 35-nation summit expected to be held late in the year on the future of a new Europe, including unification of the two Germanys. Raymond Seitz, assistant U.S. secretary of state, presented the American views of the meeting of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The discussion centered on the preparation and mechanics of the conference and not on the substance of the proposed meeting, according to a NATO official, demanding anonymity. The alliance said in a statement that the talks ``provided momentum to consultations among the allies in preparation for the summit. Allies are working intensively to develop basic elements of a common approach.'' No date or place has yet been set for the summit, which will draw together leaders from the United States, Canada and Eastern and Western Europe. At the gathering, leaders of the 16 NATO nations and the seven Warsaw Pact countries are expected to sign an arms control treaty to reduce troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear forces in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: $45,000 Reward Posted in Minister's Death
DOC.TEXT: The government has offered a $45,512 reward for information leading to a conviction in the death last month of Kenya's foreign minister. Police Commissioner Philip Kilonzo said Wednesday any information on Robert Ouko's mysterious disappearance and death would be treated confidentially. Robert Ouko's partly burned body was discovered four miles from his family farm in western Kenya on Feb. 8, three days after he was reported missing. He had been shot in the head. Ouko's death led to violent demonstrations by university students and mourners demanding an impartial investigation. President Daniel arap Moi has invited three British detectives to join Kenyan police in the investigation, apparently to allay fears of a coverup. The minister was the fourth politically prominent figure to die violently since Kenya gained independence from Britain in 1963. In each of the previous three deaths, the government of the late President Jomo Kenyatta was accused of a coverup. Ouko was the highest-ranking politician from the Luo tribe, one of four major ethnic groups that vie for power in Kenya's single-party government and engage in ancient rivalries. Some students protesters have suggested Moi should resign to take responsibility for Ouko's death.

DOC.HEAD: Trio Reindicted in Howard Beach Race Assault Case
DOC.TEXT: Three youths convicted of riot in the 1986 Howard Beach racial attack were arraigned on the same charge Thursday, two months after an appeals court overturned their prior convictions because of trial judge error. A grand jury in the borough of Queens also indicted the trio on a civil rights violation charge, said Matthew Greenberg, spokesman for state Special Prosecutor Helman R. Brooks. Both are misdemeanor counts carrying a possible one-year jail term. The three suspects were arraigned Thursday before state Supreme Court Justice Charles J. Thomas and released on their own recognizance. The charges stem from the second of two trials after the Dec. 20, 1986, attack in a predominantly white Queens neighborhood. A gang of bat-wielding local teens chased a 23-year-old black man to his death on the Belt Parkway and badly beat another black. Three teens were convicted of manslaughter in the first trial after the incident, and those verdicts were not overturned. Three defendants in the second trial _ William Bollander, Thomas Farino and James Povinelli, all 18 and from Queens _ were convicted in 1988 of the misdemeanor riot count and acquitted of a more serious felony riot count. State Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Demakos sentenced the three on Sept. 19, 1988, to 34 days in jail to be served on weekends over a four-month period. But they were granted a stay pending appeal and spent no time in jail after their conviction. The Appellate Division of state Supreme Court ruled Dec. 27, 1989, that Demakos had made two errors in charging the jury. Demakos, ``over strenuous defense objections,'' furnished the jury with verdict sheets that improperly described some of the alleged crimes, the panel said. The judge also erred by refusing a defense request to instruct the jury on disorderly conduct as a lesser offense of second-degree riot, they said. On Feb. 1, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals Sol Wachtler rejected a prosecution motion for the state's highest court to rule on the lower court reversal.

DOC.HEAD: College Drug Use Won't Hurt Politicians of Certain Era, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' attorney general, who advocates a tough approach toward casual drug users and is up for re-election, said Thursday that his confession to using marijuana in college had caused no political fallout. ``It's a generational thing,'' said Attorney General James M. Shannon, 37, the state's top law enforcement officer. On Wednesday, Shannon said in an interview with television station WHLL in Worcester and a subsequent news conference in Boston that he had used marijuana while in college but didn't use it in law school. Shannon graduated from Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore in 1973 and from George Washington University in Washington in 1975. Shannon, a Democrat who has called for stronger penalties for casual drug users, said he believes voters this year will respect his candor. ``I think people will see it for what it was. An honest answer to a legitimate question,'' he said. Shannon said college friends had called him. ``Their main concern was that I'm not naming names,'' he said. Following Shannon's disclosure, two leading Republican candidates for lieutenant governor, state Rep. Sen. Paul Cellucci and state Rep. Peter Torkildsen, said in interviews that they, too, had smoked marijuana in college. State Rep. Marjorie Clapprood, a Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor, said in an interview Thursday night that she had not smoked it. She said she was distressed that the issue was being raised about candidates so long after the fact. ``It seems to be me to be out of context,'' the lawmaker said. Political analysts said they doubted the disclosures would hurt candidates. They said voters probably accept the fact that a generation of young politicians who grew up when drug use was common on college campuses experimented with drugs. ``Clearly, you've got several issues here. One is a question of morality, which, if it was done 15 or 20 years ago, I find to be ridiculous,'' said Norman Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, a public policy research organization in Washington, D.C. In 1987, Douglas Ginsberg withdrew as President Reagan's nominee for a Supreme Court seat when former colleagues said he smoked marijuana. But subsequent admissions of student drug use by Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., and former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt had little impact on their 1988 presidential campaigns, political analysts said. ``I didn't see it making much of a difference,'' Ornstein said. Todd Domke, a Republican political consultant, agreed. ``Based on poll results following the Doug Ginsberg revelations, it would seem that most poeple just aren't interested,'' Domke said. ``I think people are willing to forgive the indiscretions of youth,'' Domke said.

The head of the military tribunal that condemned Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu to death has committed suicide, officials said today. Lt. Gen. Gica Popa killed himself Thursday at the Ministry of Justice, said Nicolae Dide, the spokesman for the interim government. A source said he had received death threats, apparently by Ceausescu loyalists, for more than two months. Dide said he did not know how Popa died, but other sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he had shot himself in the head. News of Popa's death came on the first scheduled day of trials in Timisoara of army and police officers accused of complicity in the shooting of anti-Ceausescu demonstrators there.

Draftees in the Sandinista-controlled army are deserting their ranks and the military is reportedly hiding arms ahead of next month's swearing in of an opposition government. Sandinista officials on Thursday acknowledged the desertions but denied weapons and ammunition were being squirreled away. Also Thursday, President Daniel Ortega called on the United States to resume aid on the day he steps down to the opposition coalition that upset his leftist party in Sunday's election. ``The best that could happen would be for the Contras (rebel guerrillas) to be demobilized by April 25 and for the United States to lift the embargo and send the aid it has promised starting that day,'' Ortega told Nicaraguan journalists.

A new agreement on sweeping air pollution controls is expected to ease Senate passage of the measure, although the accord with the White House is prompting criticism from environmentalists and industry _ not to mention some senators. Senate leaders and the Bush administration announced agreement Thursday on the most contentious parts of the bill, including controls on acid rain, automobile emissions and toxic chemical releases by industry. ``We have reached agreement on sound and comprehensive legislation that expands and strengthens the clean air laws and have done it in the most cost-effective way possible,'' declared Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Mitchell said he plans to bring the bill to the Senate floor Monday.

The Seabrook nuclear plant overcame two decades of protests, legal challenges, ballooning costs and the financial ruin of its chief investor to capture the ultimate prize: a license to operate. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3-0 Thursday to grant the $6.5 billion reactor a full-power license. But the appeal process will hold up the license for at least two weeks, and Seabrook opponents pressed on. About 125 anti-Seabrook demonstrators waved signs, chanted and blocked plant gates after the decision. More than 70 were arrested. At the NRC meeting in Rockville, Md., utility executives hugged each other after the ruling, and maintenance workers at the 1,200-plus employee plant hoisted a sign reading, ``Startup '90: We Have the Power.''

The administration is letting ``rhetoric outrun the reality'' by proposing spending cuts in forestry programs needed to implement President Bush's plan to plant a billion new trees, Sen. Wyche Fowler says. The Georgia Democrat, chairman of the Senate agriculture subcommittee on conservation and forestry, told administration officials Thursday that Bush's ``America the Beautiful'' tree-planting proposal won't succeed without the support of private landowners. Those landowners, he said, won't support the program if they're hit by new expenses that were covered by the forestry assistance programs the administration wants to cut. ``One thing we cannot do is let the rhetoric outrun the reality,'' Fowler said. ``If we tell people we're going to plant a billion trees, the resources have to be there.''

Banished to a remote prairie 130 years ago, the Santee-Sioux Indians are rising again, this time with playing cards in their hands. The tribe plans to build a $67 million hotel-casino in Council Bluffs that would dwarf all other gaming operations between Nevada and New Jersey. ``I'm tired of government handouts and dependency,'' said Don LaPoint, the tribal council's chairman. ``One of the things we do have going for us is gaming. I'm very optimistic this is going to succeed.'' The tribe has hired Harveys Resort and Casino near Lake Tahoe, Nev., to run the casino, which with a convention center and 450-bed hotel would employ up to 1,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Advocates Reaching Youngsters Through Comics
DOC.TEXT: The latest edition of Crisis is a first-class comic book _ readable, graphic and vibrant _ but it deals in human rights, not jokes or superheroes. The twice-monthly publication, with a print run of up to 40,000, was launched a year ago and has become one of Britain's most popular comic books, telling stories of animal rights, the environment and racism. For its latest issue, Crisis joined forces with Amnesty International, the human rights organization based in London, to bring youngsters the grim reality of such as the ``Upington 14'' in South Africa. ``We are going after a new, younger audience,'' said Dan Jones, head of campaigns at Amnesty. ``Part of our problem is that Amnesty International produces the most extraordinary stories, and then they are put into an inaccessible form.'' Most previous stories in Crisis were fictional, but the Amnesty International edition is presented as straight fact. ``The comic book tells the story clearly and dramatically without lowering Amnesty International's high standards for facts and details,'' Jones said. ``Our name is on the paper and our reputation goes with it.'' Life-like color drawings tell the story of the ``Upington 14'' and their confinement on death row in Pretoria Prison. Fourteen blacks were sentenced to death for the mob killing of a black policeman in Upington, northwestern South Africa, in November 1985. They were not proved guilty as individuals, but were sentenced under a doctrine called ``common purpose,'' which held them responsible as part of the mob. On the last page of the story are statistics of executions in South Africa and a statement that says: ``Amnesty International is opposed to the death penalty. ... In the case of South Africa it asks that a judicial enquiry be appointed to look into the use of the `Common Purpose' doctrine.'' Jones said a paragraph was added at the last minute to inform readers that President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa suspended the death penalty Feb. 2. Pat Mills, a senior Crisis scriptwriter, and artist Sean Phillips, prepared the edition, using Amnesty files. ``When Amnesty International came along with specific cases, I realized I didn't have to hide behind fiction,'' Mills said. ``I could come straight out with it because it is based on real life, not made up in any way, and it blows away any movie.'' The second story in the Amnesty issue is about the humiliation and suffering of young Palestinians engaged in the uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``Amnesty International has recorded a wide range of severe violations of human rights by the Israeli security forces,'' says the message at the end. ``Over 540 Palestinians have been shot dead by the military, including many children.'' In the last story, a young woman is shown trying to stir an apathetic comic-strip addict into caring about human rights. ``I didn't know you were into lefty political groups,'' he says, with a sneer on his face. She retorts: ``The whole basis of Amnesty International is that it's a non-political organization! And we get results. What do you ever do except complain about how screwed up the world is?'' The comic book tells readers how to write de Klerk and what points to make about the death penalty. ``Although you might feel angry,'' it suggests, ``it is more effective if letters are courteous.'' On the back cover is an advertisement for Amnesty International socks, T-shirts and posters sold by mail. Britain is the primary market for Crisis, but it also goes to North America and Australia, publishing director Jon Davidge said. It costs $1.70. Jones said future editions will contain other human rights cases. ``Issue No. 44 will illustrate Amnesty International's cases of asylum seekers from Sri Lanka and a later issue will include the case of a tortured Iraqi,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Artist Tries to Save Lighthouse
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The whistling winds off the Atlantic once carried sailing ships to this tiny island and the welcoming sight of the Sankaty Lighthouse. Now those winds are ripping away the sand and soil that anchor the beacon, and soon its light, like the whalers, will be gone. But Sankaty may have a savior in a 75-year-old painter named Robert Perrin. The pink-cheeked, silver-haired maverick, who has made the island his home, has painted the lighthouse and is donating 20 percent of the proceeds from the sale of each $150 print to an effort to save the lighthouse. His fund raising may amount to little more than a drop in an ocean, but to Perrin, it doesn't matter. His time as a painter is running short. Glaucoma has claimed most of the sight in his right eye, and weakened blood vessels in his left may steal what sight remains. With his fading vision, he has seen many Nantucket landmarks torn down to make way for developers wanting to open up the island for more summer visitors and tourists. Sankaty's light, he said, won't be extinguished. ``Everyone says it can't be done,'' Perrin said of his efforts to save the lighthouse. ``But I'm a stubborn cuss.'' The odds against him are daunting. The 140-year-old lighthouse must be moved back from its eroding 110-foot bluff or be swept out to sea in the next decade. A U.S. Army Corps of Engineers study estimated it will cost $840,000 to move Sankaty. So two years ago, Perrin painted a majestic seascape of the beacon rising over the stormy Atlantic. The undertaking was no piece of cake. Perrin wanted the work to be a view from the sea, but after clambering down the bluff to the beach, easel and brushes in hand, he realized the lighthouse wasn't visible from that vantage point. Visiting seabirds didn't make the task any easier. ``I got divebombed by terns when I was walking along the beach,'' Perrin recalled. ``Then I couldn't see anything when I got there. Boy, was I mad.'' The painting, in the end, had to be created from the artist's imagination. So far, sales have been slow. But Perrin also plans to lobby Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., who secured $1.2 million in federal money to reconstruct Nantucket's Great Point Lighthouse, which washed into the sea in a storm in 1984. Sankaty is one of a handful of the 139 New England lighthouses run by the U.S. Coast Guard that will fall into the sea in the next decade if steps aren't taken to save them, according to Coast Guard Lt. Paul Reid in Boston. Reid said despite modern navigation systems, lighthouses still help ships at sea find their way to shore. ``Lighthouses are major aids to navigation. They're on all navigational charts,'' Reid said. ``And even in the biggest ships, electronics can always go on the fritz. Sailors like to have the lighthouses there, something that's always dependable.'' Pottering around his gallery, scattered with easels, canvasses, yellowing photographs and artifacts from the island, Perrin jokes about his fading sight and his work. ``I could be a great abstractionist with my right eye. Or I could turn to sculpture. Of course, I'd have to do it by feel, and it would have to be with female models,'' said Perrin, still a bachelor. His Nantucket paintings, many filled with half-visible, ghostlike images of people and landmarks long gone, provide a sort of visual history of the old Nantucket. ``You can go anywhere and see brand-new buildings, brand-new this, brand-new that,'' Perrin said. ``But old places and things have their own character.'' Like, he hastens to add, the Sankaty Lighthouse. ``I could say, to heck with it, and not take my medication, and maybe I'd be blind in a few years,'' Perrin said. ``But the lighthouse is still there. Let's save it before something happens.''
