DOC.HEAD: Securitate Chief Arrested After Failing Loyalty Tests, Brucan Says
DOC.TEXT: The chief of Nicolae Ceausescu's secret police changed sides at the height of the rebellion against the communist dictator, but was arrested after failing loyalty tests, a leader of the uprising says. Silviu Brucan, a member of the army war council that fought Ceausescu, said his greatest contribution to the December revolution was exposing the treachery of Gen. Iulian Vlad, who had been Brucan's own most cunning interrogator when he was under arrest in 1989 for criticizing the dictator. Brucan, a Stalinist who became a dissident, spoke of events in the days when the revolution's outcome remained in doubt. He said he went to the Defense Ministry on Christmas Eve, as Securitate secret police and snipers attacked strategic targets in Bucharest, and found Vlad to be one of two men directing military operations for the rebellion. ``What a shock!'' he said in an interview. Two days earlier, Vlad had offered to cooperate with the army, which was supporting the popular uprising against Ceausescu, Brucan said. The dictator was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed Dec. 25. ``I was afraid he might use his attributes to deceive, to take in the generals,'' said Brucan, 74. ``So we decided to test him, asking him to make a public statement on the radio and TV, and the key sentence of the statement was _ and I wrote it with my hands _ an explicit order to his troops and snipers to cease fire and surrender themselves.'' Vlad did not include that sentence in the statement he read, and at a meeting of the war council that night, Brucan demanded to know why. ``Gen. Vlad showed once more his slippery manner,'' Brucan said. ``He insisted that his statement was a categorical commitment to the revolution and that this was much more important because it gave a new political orientation to his troops.'' When Brucan persisted, Vlad ``got very irritated, angry, and said it was the first time that someone questioned his loyalty to the revolution.'' After Brucan reminded Vlad of his ``brutal methods'' in forcing Brucan to repudiate his letter challenging Ceausescu, he asked why Vlad had not told the army immediately about Securitate ammunition dumps, communications centers and underground tunnels. ``Everyone around the table could then see how Gen. Vlad grew red,'' he said. ``He asked for a glass of water and took some pills, and finally he denied the existence of such a plan. ``But since I put the screws on him, he eventually retorted that if there ever was such a plan, he didn't know about it. I then said that it is inconceivable that in a military organization the commanding officer should know nothing about the plan involving the troops under his command. ``I asked the other generals to say whether this was conceivable, and all of them answered negatively. ``At last, Gen. Vlad asked for a final test, a final trying to prove his loyalty to the revolution. He promised to organize an action the next day that will end with the capture of a great number of terrorists under his command. ``The generals decided to give him that last chance, but in fact, the important result of that meeting was that the generals lost confidence in that man. The next day, since the actions promised by Vlad did not materialize, the commanders of the army decided to arrest him.'' No date has been set for Vlad's trial. Gen. Stefan Guse, who had shared command responsibility with Vlad, was sent to a provincial city because his support for Vlad had made him suspect, Brucan said, and ``Thus, the most dangerous chapter in the war against terrorism was closed.'' Anti-government protesters have claimed the Securitate still operates in another guise, supported by a government either unable or unwilling to clean out Ceausescu's vast security apparatus. Brucan said an unknown number of Securitate agents remain at large. He also said he did not consider the 700,000 people who acted as Securitate informers to be dangerous. The National Salvation Front, which took power during the revolution, decided the army should merely weed out the worse of the group ``because it didn't make sense to consider all these 700,000 as lawbreakers,'' he said. Most of the 15,000 Securitate operatives served throughout Ceausescu's 24 years in power and were retired after the revolution, Brucan said, and ``the most dangerous ones are the snipers who are still at large.'' ``They usually have keys to two apartments,'' Brucan said. ``They have two identities. They have in their apartments civilian and military clothes, plenty of food in their freezers and refrigerators, and they can endure. ``Snipers wait for the occasion, and they are not going to waste their ammunition on second-class people.''

DOC.HEAD: Ireland's Long Dispute Over Abortion Becomes a Censorship Issue
DOC.TEXT: Irish editions of Cosmopolitan, the glossy women's magazine, appear with blank spaces that should contain classified ads for British abortion clinics. More than six years after a 2-1 referendum vote to enshrine a ban on abortion in the constitution of Ireland, which is 93 percent Roman Catholic, it has become a censorship issue. In December, the national student union had to stop circulating its official handbook because it contained information on abortion services. Student leaders talk of defying a Dec. 19 court injunction and smuggling copies in from Northern Ireland. Abortion is banned in the British province too, but not information on abortion. Ruth Riddick, a feminist who ran a pregnancy counseling service, still gets anxious calls at home, most of them from men with pregnant girlfriends. ``The debate has become both more one-sided and more trivial,'' said Ms. Riddick, a 35-year-old arts administrator. ``It has shifted from deep moral issues about whether women have a right to choose. ... A woman's abortion experience is being reduced into a simple question of `Where the hell do I get a phone number?''' Marie Vernon, a campaigner against abortion, countered: ``You don't have an absolute right to information. A primary right is the right to life, and all other rights are secondary.'' Abortion always has been illegal in Ireland. The ban was reinforced by the 1983 decision to write it into the constitution. In March 1988, and again last December, the Supreme Court ruled that giving information on how to get an abortion in a foreign country violates the constitution. That does not make it a criminal offense, but it enables anti-abortionists to win injunctions. Violators of the injunctions can be jailed for contempt of court. Now the battle has moved to European courts, which must rule whether the ban violates the rights of the 3.5 million people in Ireland to get the same information as other West Europeans. The Irish rulings climaxed lengthy civil actions brought by the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, the main anti-abortion lobby outside the Catholic Church, against two pregnancy counseling services and the student union. Ms. Riddick closed her counseling service, but still provides information from home, risking contempt proceedings. The Dublin Well Woman Center, a general health clinic that ran the other counseling service, no longer gives information. Ireland is the only European country with a total ban on abortion. Divorce and homosexuality also are illegal, contraception was banned until a decade ago and the church runs most schools and hospitals. In Ireland, the abortion issue seems at once starker and more complicated than the customary arguments about women's rights and respect for human life. Even liberals don't expect to see abortion legalized within a generation, and acknowledge the opposition is deep-rooted and widespread. They say the controversy about informaton has increased women's fear and guilt, prevented proper counseling and made late abortions more likely. ``In 1983, we packed halls with people fighting publicly for legal abortion; now many are afraid to call for a right to information,' said Pauline Ryder, head of the Well Woman Clinic, which is privately financed. Each year, at least 4,000 Irish women go to Britain for abortions. Most pay about $340 at private clinics. The annual figure, based on abortions performed in Britain on women who gave addresses in Ireland, has changed little in five years. Moving the dispute into the realm of free speech has increased support for the pro-choice lobby. An attempt last year by the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child to jail four student leaders over the handbook provoked large demonstrations outside the court. In January, students voted 3-1 to support the Union of Students in Ireland, which has 60,000 members, in its refusal to stop giving information on abortion clinics in the handbook or by telephone. ``I wouldn't say the population supports abortion, but there is sympathy for our fight against censorship,'' said Karen Quinlivan, a 23-year-old law graduate who is the women's rights officer at the student headquarters. ``In the ballots, the students voted contrary to what we've been taught all our lives,'' she said. ``There's a feeling that SPUC is carrying things too far. ... these people are extreme and dangerous.'' Mrs. Vernon, spokeswoman for the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, is a cheerful housewife in her mid-40s with five children. Her youngest child, 8-month-old Sean, is adopted. His natural mother, an unmarried teen-ager, lived with the Vernon family during pregnancy. ``He's just the sort of baby who might have been terminated, as they like to call it.'' Mrs. Vernon said, then laughed and added: ``But I feel a bit guilty using him as a sales point.'' On the walls of the society's one-room headquarters in a well-to-do Dublin suburb are a disturbing picture of a late-term abortion and one of Pope John Paul II cuddling a baby. The society, founded in 1980, says it is non-sectarian and ha itself a policeman of the constitution, and sends agents posing as abortion-seekers to check on the Well Woman Clinic and other suspect organizations. Cosmopolitan was censored after a citizen complained to the Censorship and Publications Board, a government agency. The board, which can ban any publication it feels ``advocates the procurement of abortion,'' told Cosmopolitan last year to drop the ads. ``We agonized over it,'' said Simon Kippon, the American magazine's publisher in Britain. ``In the end, we decided ... we'd make the point with the blank space.'' The magazine, owned by the Hearst Corp., sells 13,000 copies a month in Ireland. Another Hearst women's magazine, Company, pulled an eight-page supplement on abortion from the March issue of its Irish edition because it included clinic addresses. ``The Cosmopolitan initiative was serious and Company's self-censorship was even more so,'' Ms. Riddick said. ``Once you put those kind of precedents in place, they can be applied across the board.''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Snowiest Town Awaits Spring At Bottom Of Drift
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the nation's snowiest town are proud of how they've shoveled, burrowed and bulldozed through this winter's record snowfall of more than 40 feet. But after more than three months of steady snow, even the most devoted fans of winter start pining for that distant rumor called spring. ``I don't think it's ever going to melt,'' airplane scheduler Nettie Pike said recently while waiting out yet another storm at the Valdez airport. ``This is the new Ice Age.'' Streets have become trenches, walled in by 10-foot snowbanks so enduring that kids paint graffiti on them. Drifts reach halfway up second-floor windows, and six snow-heavy boats have capsized in the harbor. Valdez, crowded onto a narrow plain by Prince William Sound, forms an ideal catch basin for the ocean-spawned snow storms that stall against the steep-walled Chugach Mountains behind town. At last official count, snow on the ground measured 105 inches, though depths vary throughout town. In the lee of hills, the branches of buried trees claw up through snowdrifts. Downtown, bulldozers push icy boulders a ton at a time into mountains 45 feet high. Residents don't let it keep them from their business. Interrupt their shoveling for a moment and most will say, a bit defensively, that they don't mind the snow. ``At least it's not cold,'' Gene McDaniel said as he tried to start his snow-blower at 20 degrees. ``Over the mountains in the interior, it really gets cold. I'd much rather have this snow than 45 below.'' That's not to say there aren't inconveniences. McDaniel figured it was time to shovel his roof one night when a mass of snow sloughed off, blocking his front door and trapping him and his guests. His snow-clearing bill this season stands at $700. Workers at the state Department of Environmental Conservation office ran out of room while plowing the parking lot, so they started pushing snow up onto a nearby pile. An angry neighbor soon arrived, shouting: ``You're putting your snow on my pile. Take it off!'' Ed Nielsen, maintenance man at the Village Inn motel, said he's been shoveling steadily for a month, tunneling down to fire exits and fighting a losing battle to keep drifts from walling up the windows. ``It feels like you're in a dungeon,'' Neilsen said. ``People start getting itchy feet and getting cranky at each other.'' ``People are kind of schizophrenic,'' said Bob Donald, director of the Valdez National Health Center. ``In the summer, everyone's busy as a bee. In the winter, a lot of people sleep longer. They come home from work, eat, watch some TV and are in bed by 9 o'clock. And they still feel like they're not getting enough rest. It's kind of a self-imposed hibernation.'' Attendance is up at the public library, where travel books about Hawaii are popular. Last fall, many Valdez residents were looking forward to the slower pace winter brings. The town's population of 3,000 more than doubled last summer after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, the largest in U.S. history. But when Exxon suspended its cleanup Sept. 15, the crowds thinned, and Valdez was left to face its snow alone. The first measureable snow fell Oct. 23. By the end of December, it was halfway up first-floor windows. January's snowfall of 158 inches broke the local one-month record, and on Feb. 13, when snowfall topped 384.7 inches, it erased the modern-day seasonal record set in 1987. The National Weather Service didn't start recording the town's snowfalls until 1972. Last week, another storm pushed the snowfall toward the 500-inch mark, said weather service spokesman Lynn Chrystal. Chrystal, who doubles as Valdez' mayor, concedes the town's snows don't match nearby Thompson Pass, considered Alaska's snowiest spot. Nor does Valdez compare to Paradise Ranger Station at Mount Rainier, Wash., which set the nation's seasonal snowfall record with 93.5 feet in the winter of 1971-72. But those are isolated outposts, Chrystal said. Valdez, with an annual average snowfall of about 25 feet, qualifies as the nation's snowiest town, he said. For now, many residents hide in taverns like the Pipeline Club, where they can play a round of darts (a wintertime obsession here) or hear Louie the bartender brag for the hundredth time about the halibut he caught last spring. Ah, yes, spring _ when cars lost for the winter rise out of melting snowbanks and the mountains turn from white to brown to green. Chrystal's forecast, both as weatherman and mayor: ``There's optimism in the air. We know that winter is not too much longer.'' It stops snowing by May, and most on the ground melts by June, though patches persist well into July, Chrystal said. While that may seem a chilly springtime, it's the sweetest time of year to the snow-weary people of Valdez. ``There's something about April,'' Chrystal said dreamily. ``The sky is the bluest of any time of year. It's just breathtaking. I can't wait until the ice melts off my boat.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Martin Mull Fine, His New CBS Sitcom Not
DOC.TEXT: There are times you wish CBS would put on a Monday series with nothing but saxophone and violin concertos. Then critics could again gripe about all the sax and violins on TV. But no, it keeps putting on lame situation comedies, such as ``His & Hers,'' which premieres tonight. The show stars Martin Mull, whose last CBS sitcom, ``Domestic Life,'' expired after a short run in 1984. Here, he plays a marriage counselor beginning his second marriage after one ex-wife and two kids. His bride, played by Stephanie Faracy, also is a marriage counselor. They work together, trying to save marriages. Mull is a funny guy whose dossier of far better work includes ``The History of White People in America,'' the movie ``Serial,'' and ``Fernwood 2-Night.'' He's also a fine guitarist with a good ear for jazz. Were CBS wise, it would give him a half-hour variety series, tell him to do whatever the spirit moves him to do each week in music, comedy, art or just putting on airs, and then stand by. But no, it gives him another routine sitcom. The only really good thing about this one is that at dawn and at bedtime, he usually throws Fluffy the cat out the bedroom window. The bad part is that the bedroom is on only the second floor. It's easy to tell the show is set in Los Angeles. The premiere concerns the ceaseless craving of Mull's much younger second wife for a baby. This is not unusual. Hollywood is baby-crazed these days. Make-me-pregnant plots keep popping up on TV, in shows like NBC's new ``Grand'' and earlier in ``L.A. Law.'' The desire for tykes almost has replaced the plight of the Brazilian rain forest as Hollywood's No. 1 concern. Here, baby lust leads to a trip to a fertility clinic, predictable jokes about a low sperm count and wifely lines like: ``Your little guys aren't swimming. They're just kind of dog-paddling in place.'' Tonight's epic starts with our couple awakened at dawn by a phone call from a anguished patient. Seems he caught his wife messing around ``with Manuel, the pool man.'' They offer advice, hang up and the show gets to the plot point. Mull is pressed by his wife to render her pregnant. He says they've been trying for six months and ``you can't say it hasn't been fun.'' Says she: ``That's the trouble. You're not supposed to have fun. You need to concentrate when you're trying to have a baby.'' Right. We also learn that his teen-aged son (Blake Soper) lives with them, that his teen-aged daughter (Lisa Picotte) lives with his ex-wife (Randee Heller), and that the ex-wife comes by for dinner and one-liners. Also loose here is Mull's best friend (Richard Kline), a divorce lawyer who has five kids and cheats on his spouse _ although not with the wife of Manuel, the pool man. In all fairness, the debut show, written by the series' executive producers, Patricia Jones and Donald Reiker, does give Mull one good line. His predictably flaky secretary (Blair Tefkin) says one of his patients just called to report that her husband is a pervert. He likes to wear women's garter belts and stockings under his National Guard uniform. Mull shrugs. ``Well,'' he says, ``I suppose that's OK during peacetime.''

Elsewhere in television ... TWO MORE REASONS TO KEEP BREATHING: On March 21, CBS will premiere a pair of new comedy series. One is ``Sydney,'' starring Valerie Bertinelli as a private eye ``trying to meet the challenges of being young and single in Los Angeles.'' The other show is ``Normal Life,'' about ``a slightly off-center but very real household in the Hollywood Hills.'' Its stars include Dweezil and Moon Unit Zappa. They're offspring of rock star Frank Zappa, who last week did a three-day guest-host gig on a Financial News Network show.

DOC.HEAD: Interim Government's Ideologist Considers Its Roots and Impact
DOC.TEXT: Silviu Brucan put it in writing more than two years ago: By 1990, a new generation would be leading Eastern Europe. As he watched the dominoes tumble last year, however, the Stalinist-turned-dissident feared he had been wrong about his own country. ``When December came, I got frightened that I have only one month, and when Dec. 22 came I was relieved,'' he said with a broad smile. ``We did it.'' Brucan, 74, is the ``eminence grise'' of the National Salvation Front, which took over when Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed Dec. 25. He has resigned from its leadership but remains in his large office, giving advice and planning the Front's campaign for the May 20 election. Two months after a popular uprising ended Ceausescu's 24-year reign, the revolution in little Romania is having an impact on the two Communist giants, the Soviet Union and China, Brucan said. Millions of Chinese whose pro-democracy uprising was crushed by the army in June are fixated on the success of Romanian uprising, which the army supported, he said in an interview. ``It's a Romanian obsession in China, and that will topple'' the Communists, he said. ``And not only in China. I think it affected, perhaps even more so, the Soviet Union.'' Before December's events in Romania, he said, the decisions of the Soviet Communist Party's Central Committee, including relinquishing its monopoly on power, ``were inconceivable.'' Brucan has been a journalist, academic and ambassador _ to the United States in 1956-1959 and the United Nations in 1959-1962. Once a Stalinist and ranking Communist Party member, he broke with Ceausescu in 1965. Ceausescu put him under house arrest in March 1989, along with five others who signed an open letter criticizing the dictator. His re-emergence in revolutionary Romania has been controversial. Brucan has been denounced both as a Stalinist and as an advocate of the economic policies of Mikhail Gorbachev. By his own definition, Brucan rejected Stalinism long ago and is committed to multiparty democracy. Communist parties in Eastern Europe ``are doomed to extinction'' by a scientific and technological revolution that created distinct social groups and virtually destroyed the working class that was their base of support, he said. In an article published in September 1987 by the Boston monthly WorldPaper, and reprinted in the International Herald Tribune, he foresaw the collapse of the Soviet bloc dictatorships. ``Conservative leaders clinging to economic orthodoxy face a formidable challenge that is bound to accelerate the changing of the guard,'' he wrote. ``By 1990 a new political generation will be in command all over Eastern Europe.'' Brucan said the power of Romania's revolution was a surprise. ``I didn't expect a popular explosion of such magnitude,'' he said in the interview. ``Especially, I didn't expect the youth in Romania to have such a high political and civic conscience.'' As he watched the rise of Solidarity in Poland and signs of democratization in other Soviet bloc countries, Brucan said, his main concern was to keep from being killed by Ceausescu. Brucan was first put under house arrest after criticizing the dictator's handling of riots in Brasov in 1987. In October 1988, unexpectedly, he was offered a passport to go to the United States. Fearing a trap, Brucan said, he decided to stop in London and Moscow ``and make my name known so much internationally that the price of killing me was so high that Ceausescu could not pay.'' Pressure from the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union saved him from arrest on his return in late November 1988, he said. The Soviets made ``a very reluctant'' promise of support if Ceausescu fell, Brucan said, but he described Western press reports of a conspiracy to oust the dictator as ``trash.'' ``If there was a plot and we succeeded ... don't you think we should have boasted about it and made political capital about it?,'' he asked. ``It would have strengthened considerably our legitimacy, and political modesty has no place, particularly at a time of revolution.'' The National Salvation Front, a group of 150 intellectuals, dissidents and workers, initially pledged to stay out of the coming election, but reneged last month. Daily protests culminated in its agreement three weeks ago to share power with 37 political groups in a Council of National Unity that will govern until the election. Brucan said the most difficult thing ``was to convince people to share power with the other political parties and to get across the point ... that a strong opposition is essential in a democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Descendant of Confederate Leader Plans New Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version on financial wires.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Robert E. Lee is plotting an offensive this spring in Tennessee. But instead of leading a fight between Confederate and Union troops, Lee's battle involves spirits. Bob Lee IV, great-grandson of the Civil War general, is in the liquor business. As chairman of the tiny, privately owned A. Smith Bowman Inc. distillery, Lee is taking on a much bigger foe on the opposition's home turf _ Tennessee-based Jack Daniel _ in a bid to double sales of Bowman's Virginia Gentleman bourbon in that state. Lee, 65, says his company isn't setting out to become an industry giant, but in Virginia, it's as big as his family's name. ``We are the No. 1 alcoholic beverage label in the state,'' he said. That ranking was achieved largely because of Bowman's Virginia Vodka, which sells about 150,000 cases a year in the state. Bowman also has just gone international with an order from Poland for 50,000 cases of vodka, the largest single order for one product in the company's history. Bowman's mainstay, Virginia Gentleman bourbon, is No. 2 in the state behind national leader Jim Beam. Virginia Gentleman also is sold in seven other states from Pennsylvania to North Carolina and a pocket in Atlanta. Two years ago, Bowman introduced its own gin, which accounts for about 12,000 cases a year. Lee is a born salesman whose accent reflects his New York roots. His father was a Columbia University-educated doctor who practiced in the city. But Lee was sent to private school in Virginia and in 1949 graduated from Washington & Lee University in Lexington, where his great-grandfather served as president after the Civil War. After college, he moved to the West Coast and became an advertising executive for the San Francisco Chronicle. Twenty years ago, he joined Bowman when his brother-in-law, A. Smith Bowman Jr., asked him to take over sales and marketing duties at the company founded in 1935 by Bowman's father, A. Smith Bowman Sr. ``I basically like sales,'' said Lee, whose first decision at Bowman was to hire a public relations executive and begin traveling the state to give civic club speeches and newspaper and television interviews to promote Virginia Gentleman. ``I went down to Lynchburg one time and was on a cooking show,'' he said. ``I'd never cooked in my life. But we did it for half an hour and gave away recipes. It was fun.'' Lee, who eventually succeeded the Bowmans as chairman of the nation's oldest family-owned independent bourbon distillery, also played a role in the decision to diversify the firm's products. ``Here we had one product _ bourbon,'' he said. ``Nationally, bourbon was not going anywhere.'' Bourbon's share of the liquor market dwindled from 14 percent in 1978 to 10.8 percent in 1988. But the trend was evident early on, and Bowman got into the vodka business in 1982, Lee said. When the company's vodka went on the market, it got a boost from then-Gov. Charles S. Robb, who launched his ``We Have it Made in Virginia'' campaign at the same time. ``That was pure luck,'' Lee said. The company's gin came out two years ago. While Lee has been searching for new directions to take the company, Bowman is not ready to become a major national player in the liquor field, he said. Although sales of bourbon are slumping nationally, Lee said there still are plenty of bourbon drinkers to woo away from competitors. A dozen years ago, Bowman entered into a partnership with a wholesaler in Florida and Texas and attempted for 18 months to sell Virginia Gentleman in those two states. ``It just didn't work,'' Lee said. ``So having done that, we realize we can't go big league like Jim Beam,'' he said. ``We never would have known if we hadn't tried.'' Lee keeps a small bust of Gen. Lee in his office, but most of the family decorations are related to his children, He said people always want to hear stories about his great-grandfather. ``But we don't have any special anecdotes in the family about General Lee,'' he said. ``One of the major reasons is that everybody got married late in life. My father never knew his grandfather, and my father was in his 50s when I was born. ``We had a sense of history, but we didn't have anybody sitting in someone's lap telling about something that wasn't in Dr. Freeman's or Bruce Catton's books,'' Lee said of the Pulitzer Prize-winning biography of his great-grandfather by Douglas Southall Freeman and works by Civil War historian Catton. ``That's just the way it was.'' What Lee has in mind for the Tennessee offensive is a taste test, a battle of the bourbons. ``It's going to be Kentucky vs. Tennessee vs. Virginia,'' he said. How far is he willing to go to win? ``A Southern gentleman will go to any lengths to maintain the family honor,'' according to a Bowman brochure. ``A Virginia gentleman will go only to honorable lengths.''

DOC.HEAD: With BC-Eastern, b0651 of Feb. 28
DOC.TEXT: Here are key events in the Machinists union strike against Eastern Airlines: _March 3, 1989 _ President Bush refuses National Mediation Board request to use his authority under Railway Labor Act to delay strike 60 days. Machinists reject Eastern's latest contract offer. Talks collapse at midnight. _March 4 _ Strike begins, canceling almost 90 percent of Eastern flights, stranding passengers in the United Sates, Caribbean and Latin America. Eastern pilots and flight attendants honor strike. _March 6 _ Eastern idles 7,000 non-union workers and cancels nearly all flights. Airline asks federal judge to order pilots back to work. _March 7 _ Judge refuses to order pilots back to work. Eastern furloughs another 2,500 employees. _March 9 _ Eastern files for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York. _March 31 _ Developer Donald Trump completes a restructured deal to buy Eastern's Northeast shuttle service for $365 million. _April 6 _ A group led by former baseball commissioner Peter V. Ueberroth announces it will acquire Eastern and a 19.9 percent stake in the Sys One, its computer reservation system, to a General Motors Corp. subsidiary for $250 million. _Feb. 22 _ Eastern and unsecured creditors announce agreement on a new reorganization plan that would require Continental to step in and make some payments to the creditors. The plan would pay the creditors about 50 cents on the dollar. _March 1 _ A bankruptcy court examiner says Texas Air unfairly drained assets from Eastern and it has agreed to pay the subsidiary $280 million in compensation. The examiner's report supports a longstanding contention by Eastern unions that Texas Air was bleeding the airline.

DOC.HEAD: Colleagues Call Prosecutor One of Nation's Best Trial Lawyers
With BC-Poindexter Judge, b0645 of Feb. 27
DOC.TEXT: Dan Webb, the Iran-Contra prosecutor handling the case against John Poindexter, is described by colleagues as one of the finest trial attorneys in the country. When he was U.S. attorney in Chicago, he won convictions against crooked cops and corrupt judges. Webb's trademark, as former President Reagan found out two weeks ago, is his skillful cross-examination of witnesses. In videotaped testimony for Poindexter's trial, Reagan suggested it might have been all right to destroy documents in the Iran-Contra affair. Webb countered by pulling out a written answer Reagan had given two years ago to a federal grand jury saying that no destruction of documents had been authorized by the president. When one of Reagan's answers strayed far afield from the prosecutor's question, Webb angered the former chief executive by interrupting him to announce he had been unresponsive. ``If they wanted to find one of the best trial lawyers in America, they did,'' Republican Gov. James Thompson of Illinois, who has known Webb for 19 years, said of last summer's decision by Iran-Contra prosecutors to hire Webb for the Poindexter case. Webb, 44, is a partner at the Chicago law firm of Winston & Strawn. He grew up in Bushnell, Ill., and applied to become an assistant U.S. attorney in Chicago in 1971. An interviewer wrote the letters NBBR on his application, which stood for ``nice boy, but rural,'' recalls then-U.S. attorney William Bauer, who hired him immediately. Webb ``was highly motivated, sincere and he desperately wanted to be an assistant U.S. attorney; the combination made it so you couldn't turn him down,'' recalls Bauer, now chief judge of the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago. While running the U.S. attorney's office in Chicago, Webb personally tried the ``Marquette 10'' case. Ten Chicago police officers were accused of taking bribes from drug dealers to protect drug activity; and all 10 were convicted. ``I think that had not Dan Webb gotten involved, we would have had a better chance of convincing a jury'' that the police officers should be acquitted, said Chicago defense attorney Daniel J. Pierce. As a defense attorney, Webb developed a novel strategy in the fraud case of two sports agents who were representing college athletes. Through skillful cross-examination, Webb drew the jury's attention away from his client and focused it on the gross disregard some of the nation's major universities have had for NCAA rules and academic standards. Webb ``has a baby face which has every mother on the jury nodding when he talks,'' says Thompson. The governor of Illinois calls the prosecutor in the Poindexter case ``smart ... tough ... he very strongly believes in the integrity of law and the integrity of law enforcement.''

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter's Attorney Has Often Had Prominent Clients
With BC-Poindexter Judge, b0645 of Feb. 27
DOC.TEXT: Richard Beckler, who is defending John Poindexter in the Iran-Contra affair, has handled some of the most high-profile cases Washington has had to offer. At the Justice Department in the 1970s, Beckler supervised criminal investigations of major U.S. corporations making overseas payoffs to get business with foreign governments. A number of companies entered guilty pleas in connection with the bribes. As a defense attorney, Beckler represented Reagan campaign official and subsequent CIA director William Casey in the controversy known as Debategate, in which aides to Ronald Reagan gained possession of documents from the camp of then-President Carter in 1980. During the congressional hearings into the Iran-Contra affair, Beckler was seen on national television forcefully defending Poindexter. Beckler has obtained videotaped testimony from Reagan for Poindexter's trial. He also won a court ruling that limits the scope of potentially damaging testimony by Oliver North, Poindexter's former subordinate who ran the secret Contra resupply network and was at the heart of the Iran arms-sale initiative. Beckler's handling of Poindexter's case is typical of the lawyer's style _ ``a thoughtful, carefully planned defense in which he is paying a lot of attention to detail,'' says Washington attorney John J. Cassidy. Beckler, who grew up in Brooklyn, is characterized by colleagues in the defense bar as a ``scrapper'' and a ``street-fighter.'' Detractors say he is unnecessarily bombastic. But ``if I were in a tough situation and I had an opportunity to put together my team, he'd be on it, and I wouldn't want him to be on the other side,'' said Hank Schuelke, a partner in a Washington law firm. ``Assuming he's got the skills and the intellect, which he does, Dick Beckler is my notion of what a trial lawyer ought to be,'' said Schuelke. Beckler has operated effectively in defending corporate clients in grand jury investigations. He is cast with some frequency in the role of trying to persuade the government not to bring criminal charges. ``If one word describes Dick Beckler it's `relentless,''' said Washington attorney A. Raymond Randolph. ``He turns over every stone and never gives up.'' ``He is a man of very high integrity and he has a reputation for that,'' said Randolph. ``If he deals with government officials, they know they are dealing with a straight shooter.'' A product of Williams College and Fordham Law School, Beckler spent four years as a prosecutor in the office of then-Manhattan district attorney Frank Hogan and worked for six years in the Justice Department's fraud section, eventually becoming its chief. In 1979, he joined the Washington office of Fulbright & Jaworski, specializing in white-collar criminal defense work, although he has handled some civil litigation as well.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, March 4

DOC.TEXT: The U.S. manufacturing economy slowed in February for the 10th consecutive month, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers. The National Association of Purchasing Management said Thursday its index rose to 48.3 percent in February from 45.2 percent in January. A reading below 50 indicates the U.S. manufacturing economy generally is declining; above 50, that it generally is expanding.

Construction spending rose 1.8 percent in January, the biggest increase in more than a year, the government said. The Commerce Department said Thursday construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $424 billion in January after falling 0.1 percent in December. The gain was the largest since a 2.3 percent advance in December 1988. Analysts said a warm January caused the improvement.

Personal income rose 0.8 percent in January despite a new tax bite from Social Security, the government said. The Commerce Department report also said Thursday that consumer spending climbed 0.6 percent, a pace which analysts attributed to caution in the face of mounting inflation.

Some major chain stores reported good February sales growth but 1990 is expected to be another tough year for the retailing industry. Walter Loeb, a New York-based retail consultant, said Thursday that unusually warm weather in the first half of the month boosted business. Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc., said: ``We remain somewhat cautious'' given continuing high consumer debt levels and sluggish trends in the financial and real estate markets.

Bank of New England Corp. said it had signed federal orders forcing it to withhold dividends, reshape lending practices and submit to tight government controls as it tries to recover from massive losses. ``We regard these orders as cooperative plans we undertake in partnership with federal regulators,'' H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman, said Thursday. ``They all speak to running a better bank.'' Under the orders, Bank of New England will need federal approval to declare stock dividends, conduct financial transactions with its subsidiaries and pay benefits to former employees.

The Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant won federal permission to produce commercial electricity after two decades of protests and legal struggles that made it a symbol of the national anti-nuclear movement. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3-0 Thursday to grant a license for Seabrook to operate at full power but delayed issuing it for two weeks _ to allow an expected appeal in federal court.

Texas Air Corp. has agreed to pay Eastern Airlines more than $280 million to settle a bankruptcy examiner's findings that it bought the subsidiary's assets at unfairly low prices, participants in the case said. The findings Thursday by examiner David I. Shapiro supported a key contention by striking Eastern workers, who claimed Texas Air stripped their company of its most valuable assets to bolster the parent company's non-union carrier, Continental Airlines. However, Shapiro did not agree with the union's request that Eastern be run by an outside trustee, which the unions had sought as protection against further predations by Texas Air during Eastern's bankruptcy reorganization.

An attorney for Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. said that the company is not siphoning money from its brokerage subsidiary, which is liquidating billions of dollars in securities and other assets. Creditors of the collapsed Wall Street firm raised concerns Thursday that money available to satisfy what they said were about $500 million in claims against the brokerage subsidiary was being reduced. The brokerage firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is not subject to the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings of its parent. Drexel has liquidated more than 86 percent of some $47 billion in securities holdings as well as other assets since the bankruptcy filing Feb. 13.

The stock market's mild reaction to the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. showed that federal regulators were right to let the securities firm fail, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said. In the government's first public testimony about Drexel's slide into bankruptcy, Greenspan told a House panel Thursday that ``our concern was not with the fortunes of a particular firm'' but with ``the orderly operation of the financial markets.''

Prices closed higher on Wall Street Thursday, and the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 8.34 to 2,635.59. Bond prices retreated broadly for the second consecutive session. The dollar continued its climb against most major foreign currencies. Petroleum futures prices tumbled; coffee futures surged to new 7{-month highs; precious metals advanced; grain and soybean futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Strong February Sales Gains For Some Major Retailers
With BC-Retail Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Respectable sales growth last month at some of the country's leading chain stores partly reflected unusually warm weather and a good response to new spring merchandise. But industry analysts foresee another tough time for retailers in 1990 as competition continues to eat into profitability. Fewer general merchandise chains, discounters and department stores issued their results Thursday than usually do on the first Thursday of the month because of differences in sales-reporting calendars. Monroe Greenstein, an analyst at Bear Stearns & Co. Inc., said retailers probably will have a mediocre year in 1990, similar to 1989. February marks the start of the fiscal year for many retailers. Jeffrey Feiner of Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc., said: ``We remain somewhat cautious'' given continuing high consumer debt levels and sluggish trends in the financial and real estate markets. Some analysts believe ``rolling recessions'' have been rippling through parts of the manufacturing sector, such as the automobile industry. A widely watched barometer of manufacturing health showed a 10th straight monthly decline in the sector during February. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index stood at 48.3 percent in February, up from 45.2 percent in January. A reading below 50 indicates that the U.S. manufacturing economy is generally declining. Analysts were reluctant to attach too much significance to the retail results because February is typically a slow time for business. January and February are transition months as winter merchandise is cleared out to make room for fresh spring lines. In contrast to the chains that did well last month, Sears, Roebuck and Co., the country's biggest retailer, continued to struggle. The giant Chicago-based general merchant, which began a new merchandising strategy a year ago hoping to reverse years of market-share losses, had a ho-hum February. Sales were virtually flat, at $2.127 billion in the four weeks ended Feb. 24, vs. $2.126 billion a year earlier. Sales at Sears stores open a year or longer edged up only 1.5 percent. Retailers and industry analysts prefer to focus on sales comparisons for stores operating at least a year, called same-store or comparable-store results. Newly opened stores typically enjoy a period of unusually brisk business that isn't sustained over time. One standout among the retailers reporting Thursday was Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The big Bentonville, Ark.-based discount chain said its February sales surged 33 percent to $1.95 billion from $1.47 billion a year earlier. Sales at Wal-Marts open a year or longer posted a healthy 17 percent gain. By either measure, Wal-Mart consistently has been a star performer as it expands across the country. Currently ranked No. 3, there is widespread speculation in the industry that Wal-Mart this year could overtake Sears and K mart Corp. in merchandise sales volume in the United States. K mart, based in Troy, Mich., recently stepped up efforts to respond to the challenge.In a bid to boost sales and profit, K mart will accelerate its store opening and renovation program, taking a $422 million after-tax charge to carry out the plan. K mart's report on last month's sales will be released March 8. Many of the retailers who in recent years have reported their monthly results on the first Thursday of every month will be reporting later in March. There is an effort being made within the industry to reach a compromise on a single monthly reporting date for the rest of 1990. Here are some reports released Thursday: Dallas-based department store operator J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said sales at its stores and through its catalogs rose 8.1 percent in February to $880 million from $814 million a year earlier. Sales at stores open for at least a year were up 7.2 percent. Melville Corp., the Harrison, N.Y.-based owner of off-price and other retailers, said February sales rose 11.7 percent to $503.2 million from a year earlier's $450.6 million. Montgomery Ward & Co., based in Chicago, reported a 2.5 percent February sales gain to $299 million from $291.8 million. Last year's figures were restated to exclude discontinued lines. Woolworth Corp., the New York-based parent of numerous specialty stores including the Foot Locker sports shoe chain, said its domestic February sales jumped 13.7 percent to $330 million from $291 million. Same-store sales rose 11.7 percent. Harold E. Sells, chairman and chief executive officer, said: ``February's double-digit percentage gains in total and domestic sales were the highest for that reporting period in over 10 years.''
