DOC.HEAD: 14-Year-Old Toy Exec Gets Paid For Her Ideas
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For Mary Rodas, playing with toys is just another day at the office. But as vice president of a company that expects more than $20 million in sales this year, the 14-year-old Ms. Rodas is not just playing around. The eighth-grader is an executive for Catco Inc., a Manhattan-based company that develops and licenses toys. Other companies use kids to test their products, but Catco says none of them have reached the executive ranks like Ms. Rodas. She takes taxis or limousines from Union City to her office in nearby Manhattan three times a week. Her high school and college education is already paid for. And she has a stock portfolio that includes investments in IBM, Walt Disney Co., General Electric Co. and the Hershey Co. ``If an idea's good enough, I say so,'' Ms. Rodas said, explaining her job. ``If there's something to improve, I say what needs to be done to fix things up.'' Kidstuff? ``It's more than that,'' said Catco president Barbara Carver. ``Most kids can't say specifically what their problem with the toy is. They'll just say `I don't like that,' or `This isn't fun.' With Mary, she'll say it needs more colors or more of this or that. ``She's just very bright,'' Ms. Carver said. ``She's very perceptive and willing to speak her mind.'' Ms. Rodas said her consulting career began at age 4 when her father, a Salvadoran immigrant working as a custodian, brought her along as he made repairs to a neighbor's apartment. There, she noticed a man laying tile. ``Since I was a little kid my father used to take me from apartment to apartment so I used to see how it was done,'' Ms. Rodas said. ``I knew my father never put tiles in that way. I criticized him and told him he wasn't doing the job right.'' The man was Donald Spector, who lived in the same building as the Rodas family. Spector struck up an acquaintance with the girl and became so impressed with her ideas, he decided to make her vice president when he founded Catco, a subsidiary of Catalyst Applied Technologies, which he co-founded. Ms. Rodas won't say how much her stock is worth, but it's more than she would make setting up a lemonade stand. She doesn't draw a salary, and she can't touch the stock Catco has put in trust for her until she turns 18. For Catco, paying for the stocks and limousines and the office is worth it. ``She's able to tell us which way to develop things early on,'' Ms. Carver said. ``That way we don't get all the way to the end of the road and find we should have done something different.'' Her latest project is Balzac, a balloon in a patented cloth sack. It can be hit with a racket, bat or stick, and can even be sat on without busting. When Ms. Rodas first bounced it around, the sack was made of white muslin. ``I told them it was too plain,'' she said. ``They needed something to liven it up. I told them to put on some neon colors.'' The sack now is a patchwork of brilliant colors. The job aside, Ms. Rodas said she's like any other 14-year-old girl. ``I still have an ordinary life,'' she said. ``I'm an ordinary kid. The only thing different is I have a job.''

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Probe Finds Texas Air Victimized Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Texas Air Corp. has agreed to pay Eastern Airlines more than $280 million to settle a bankruptcy examiner's findings that it bought the subsidiary's assets at unfairly low prices. The findings released Thursday by examiner David I. Shapiro supported a key contention by striking Eastern workers, who claimed Texas Air stripped their company of its most valuable assets to bolster the parent's non-union carrier, Continental Airlines. However, Shapiro did not agree with the union's request that Eastern be run by an outside trustee. The unions had sought the move as protection against further predations by Texas Air during Eastern's bankruptcy reorganization. Texas Air rejected Shapiro's findings about the sale of assets but said it would make the settlement payment in order to help bolster Eastern. ``Texas Air and Eastern categorically reject any conclusions in the Shapiro report that intercompany transactions between Eastern and its affiliates formed the basis for any material liability,'' the two companies said in a statement issued after a court hearing on the report. The statement said Shapiro's report is full of ``faulty analyses, hearsay evidence, statements taken out of context and misstatements of fact.'' Union attorneys said the report vindicated the workers' position, but they insisted that a trustee still needs to be named to run the company. ``The wrongdoers are simply to be slapped on the wrist,'' Bruce Simon, an attorney for the Air Line Pilots Association, told the hearing. Approval of the settlement by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland could remove a main obstacle in the airline's effort to emerge from bankruptcy, because some of the compensation would help satisfy creditor claims against Eastern. Lifland said the proposed settlement can be viewed, in some ways, as ``Texas Air buying Eastern again.'' The proposed settlement includes $150 million to $250 million that Eastern would recover from Texas Air for the transfer of the System One computer reservation system, and $61 million for Texas Air's acquisition of Eastern in November 1986. In addition, Eastern would receive a 25 percent share in System One and the right to buy 40 Boeing 737-300 jets at cost from sister carrier Continental. The settlement's total value is estimated at more than $280 million and includes $133 million in cash. Separately, Lifland approved Eastern's request that $60 million be taken from escrow funds to help finance its operations this month. The funds contain about $550 million raised by the sale of Eastern assets since it sought bankruptcy court protection last March 9. Shapiro issued his findings following a lengthy investigation into the dealings between Texas Air, Eastern and Continental as part of Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy case. The company sought protection from creditors five days after the beginning of a strike by machinists, flight attendants and pilots that virtually grounded it. Eastern has been reorganizing as a smaller carrier and has hired replacements for many of the strikers. The pilots and flight attendants unions abandoned the strike in November but Machinists remain on strike. In the 300-page report, Shapiro said that in 12 cases out of 15 there was substantial evidence Texas Air transferred ssets worth between $285 million and $403 million from Eastern without adequately compensating the airline. In Miami, where Eastern has its headquarters, President Phil Bakes said the settlement would help expedite the airline's emergence from bankruptcy court protection, which he expected by the end of June. The unions had long demanded the bankruptcy court appoint a trustee to run Eastern instead of Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo, but Shapiro said in his investigation that the request might cripple the airline. Nonetheless, Shapiro recommended the appointment of a special monitoring committee, with much less authority than a trustee, to scrutinize how Texas Air deploys assets among its businesses. The examiner had been investigating Eastern, its finances and relationships with Continental and Texas Air since early September because of conflict of interest questions raised by the unions and Eastern creditors. This issue became particularly significant after Eastern proposed a reorganization plan that did not include full repayment for its creditors. If Texas Air had taken Eastern planes, routes and other assets from the airline and given them to Continental, they theoretically would be out of reach of Eastern's creditors. Eastern sold the System One computerized reservation system to Texas Air in April 1987 for about $100 million. Last week, Texas Air said it would sell half of System One to a General Motors subsidiary for $250 million, suggesting it was worth far more than what Texas Air had paid to Eastern. As part of the settlement worked out by Shapiro, Eastern would get a 25 percent share in System One, with 50 percent to be owned by the GM subsidiary, Electronic Data Systems Corp., and the remaining 25 percent by Continental.

DOC.HEAD: Transactions Between Eastern, Texas Air and Continental Scrutinized
With PM-Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Here are the most significant transactions between Eastern Airlines, parent Texas Air Corp. and non-union sister Continental Airlines studied by court-appointed examiner David I. Shapiro: Texas Air's acquisition of Eastern in November 1986. Eastern's sale of the System One computer reservation system to Texas Air in April 1987. A $16 million Texas Air debt to Eastern, mostly concerning legal fees and investment banking fees. Management fees paid by Eastern to Texas Air. Transfers of aircraft from Eastern to Continental. Notes issued by now-defunct People Express which Texas Air sold to Eastern. Texas Air's fuel management arrangement with Eastern. Strike contingency fees paid by Eastern to Continental. A $40 million loan from Eastern to Continental. Eastern's payment of cash dividends on preferred stock guaranteed by Texas Air.

DOC.HEAD: Bank To Withhold Dividends, Submit to Tight Government Control
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. is now working under the official guidance of the federal government, with orders to tighten lending practices, withhold stock dividends and review the competence of senior managers. Federal regulators had been scrutinizing the bank for months because of its mountain of bad real estate loans, which forced the company to post massive losses last year. On Thursday, Bank of New England announced it had signed federal consent orders outlining steps the bank must take to restore its financial health. ``We regard these orders as cooperative plans we undertake in partnership with federal regulators,'' said H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman. ``They all speak to running a better bank.'' The consent orders do not include plans to cut the company's work force, but Bullock confirmed the bank expects to lay off thousands of workers, saying, ``We have to downsize our operation considerably.'' Under the orders, Bank of New England will need federal approval to declare stock dividends, conduct financial transactions with its subsidiaries and pay benefits to former employees. The bank also is required to tighten its lending practices and not make any commercial real estate loans without following prescribed guidelines. Furthermore, the bank must review the performance of its senior managers and report any proposed changes to the government. The bank's board already has dismissed several top executives, including former chairman Walter Connolly, who presided over the bank's rapid growth before its problems surfaced last year. Bullock said the bank hoped to name a permanent chairman within a week. Lawrence Fish, a former Bank of Boston Corp. executive, was expected to be named the new chairman, but Bullock declined to confirm that. The consent orders cover the bank holding company and its Boston-based subsidiary, Bank of New England NA. Bullock said the company's four other affiliate banks, which are based elsewhere in New England, were expected to sign consent orders soon. The Boston branch also was ordered to raise its equity capital to 3 percent of total assets by May 31, and develop a plan to reach 5 percent. The bank, however, has told the federal Comptroller of the Currency that it does not expect to meet the May 31 deadline, and Bullock said the bank hopes to get an extension. Bullock said he expects the bank to operate under the consent order for a year or more. Until late last year, Bank of New England was the region's second-largest bank behind Bank of Boston. But the company took a dramatic fall as a real estate slump forced the bank to boost its reserves against bad loans. Bank of New England reported 1989 losses exceeding $1 billion, and the company says it is studying whether it should have made larger provisions against bad loans earlier in the year. In the meantime, Bank of New England has lost an estimated $5 billion worth of deposits, forcing the company to borrow money from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston while it tries to sell assets to raise cash. The bank's borrowing is estimated above $1 billion, but Bullock said he hopes Bank of New England ``will be out of the Fed by April.'' ``People look at borrowing from the Fed as a trend line to obscurity. I disagree,'' he said. Instead, Bullock described the borrowing as ``bridge financing'' as the bank sells about $6 billion worth of assets. Because of the cash crunch, the bank cannot afford to pay stock dividends, Bullock said, adding that he would have expected the bank to withhold payments regardless of the federal consent order. ``I don't expect to be able to pay dividends on common stock or preferred stock for some time,'' he said. Bullock said the bank still hopes to find buyers for its troubled loan portfolio, but he added, ``they have been harder to find than buyers of other assets.''

DOC.HEAD: Saab, Wall Street Journal Pick New Ad Agencies
DOC.TEXT: The importer of Saab automobiles has picked one of the newer advertising agencies, while The Wall Street Journal picked one of the oldest in a pair of high-profile moves on Madison Avenue. Saab-Scania of America Inc. said Thursday it had selected Angotti Thomas Hedge Inc. of New York to handle its $25 million advertising account. The agency was created only five years ago, and the new job boosts its total billings by more than 50 percent from about $45 million. Its other clients include KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Wild Turkey bourbon, Kirin beer and Barron's, the weekly business and financial publication that, like the Journal, is published by Dow Jones & Co. Barrie Hedge, president of the agency, said the agency would get to work immediately on advertising for the model 9000S that Saab plans to introduce in mid-April. The appointment is effective April 2. Saab-Scania, based in Orange, Conn., said it picked Angotti Thomas over two other New York-based agencies, Kirshenbaum & Bond and Slater-Hanft & Martin. The account had been handled for the past 2{ years by the agency Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, an even younger agency that got the account shortly after it was created. Lord Einstein is headed by several executives who abruptly quit their old agency, Lord Geller Federico Einstein, in March 1988 after it was acquired by the British advertising conglomerate WPP Group PLC. ``It was time for a change,'' said Roy Steinwolf, ad manager at Saab-Scania, said Thursday in explaining why Saab-Scania launched a search for a new agency in January. He said Saab sales in the United States have slipped over the past three years, including a 12 percent decline in 1989, after showing steady gains for the previous six years. Sales of European imports generally have been weak. Saab-Scania has been using the ad slogan, ``The most intelligent cars ever built,'' for several years and Steinwolf said whether to continue that slogan is under discussion. The Wall Street Journal, meanwhile, said Thursday it had selected an agency that celebrated its 125th birthday last year, J. Walter Thompson, to handle its advertising sales and circulation advertising account. The daily newspaper declined to disclose how much it planned to spend on advertising this year, although one trade publication estimated it was $7.5 million. Thompson, also owned by WPP Group, was ranked the eighth-biggest U.S. ad agency in 1988, handling worldwide advertising billings of more than $3.8 billion and creating advertising for products such as Kodak film and Kellogg cereals. The Journal's former ad agency was GSD&M of Austin, Texas, which had been hired in August 1988. Recent ads from GSD&M described the Journal as ``Faster, Tougher, Smarter.'' GSD&M had been hired to handle advertising during the Journal's centennial celebration in 1989 and to promote and posiution the newspaper's reorganized, three-section format in 1988. ``As business becomes ever more global, we foresee enormous opportunities for the Journal in the '90s and beyond,'' said publisher Peter Kann. He said Thompson ``has demonstrated that it can help us to capitalize on these opportunities in the years ahead.'' Thompson was believed to have been one of two finalists considered for the job. Insiders who spoke on condition that they not be identified said the other agency was Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, the agency that broke away from WPP Group.

DOC.HEAD: Futures Regulators Approve Stricter Rules on Trading Cards
DOC.TEXT: Federal commodities futures regulators have taken another step to blunt the congressional criticism they have weathered in the wake of a fraud scandal at the nation's two largest futures exchanges. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the industry, unanimously approve a change in rules governing the trading cards that brokers and traders use to record commodity futures and options transactions. The tougher rules will make it difficult to fabricate or alter trading records, one of the allegations made in the fraud scandals that rocked the two largest Chicago futures exchanges last summer. More than 40 traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade were indicted on charges ranging from racketeering to fraud for numerous alleged schemes to defraud customers. During hearings for a CFTC reauthorization bill last fall, members of Congress were very critical of the CFTC for allowing the exchanges to police themselves on recording trades and other record-keeping functions. A General Accounting Office study of four futures exchanges last September found that at three of them, much of the record-keeping is left to the traders and brokers themselves. The rules changes will require: _ the collection of trading records within a specified schedule; _ time-stamping the cards; _ using pre-printed, sequentially numbered cards that will be unique to each exchange member _ recording trades on both trading cards and order tickets in non-erasable ink. One of the allegations in the Chicago probe was that traders would illegally alter records to correct costly errors or change the time of a transaction to take advantage of a later, more favorable price. The new rules also would require each exchange to submit a written report to the commission _ no later than nine months after the effective date of the regulation _ detailing the systems they have put in place to meet the new requirements. Exchanges could seek exemption from the new rules if they can demonstrate members are using hand-held computer terminals or other automated means to recrod trades and eliminate fraud. Both the BOT and CME are developing hand-held computer terminals that will replace paper trading cards but they are not expected to be operative in the near future.

DOC.HEAD: President of Exxon Shipping Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The departing president of Exxon Shipping Co. called the wreck of the Exxon Valdez a tragedy that never should have happened but said the huge Alaskan oil spill did not prompt him to leave Exxon. Frank J. Iarossi said Thursday that although environmental concerns for Prince William Sound were justified, criticism of Exxon's cleanup efforts were sometimes unwarranted. ``One regret I had in that first week or so is that we didn't have the opportunity to really show the human side of what people were doing to try to bring that situation under control,'' Iarossi said. ``There were people out there working for 22 hours.'' In a telephone interview from his home in Houston, Iarossi said he was leaving Exxon to become president of the American Bureau of Shipping, an international ship classification society. He had been in charge of the shipping division since 1982. In the first few days after the spill, Iarossi said press coverage was ``reasoned and really trying to understand what had happened. But somewhere after day five or six, when it hit the beaches ... there was no way to balance or bring rationale to the story.'' News reports didn't emphasize that Exxon offloaded 1 million barrels of oil from the Exxon Valdez ``without spilling a drop,'' he said. ``We were told by the state that the priority was to save five hatcheries, which, in fact was done.'' Exxon was unable to do much about the oil that had already spilled out of the ship and fouled shorelines, though. ``It was clear that we won a lot of the battle, but as far as the public was concerned, we lost the war,'' said Iarossi, who was the first high-level Exxon official to arrive on the scene to coordinate cleanup after the spill. The announcement of Iarossi's departure comes two days after a federal grand jury in Anchorage indicted Exxon Shipping and its parent, Exxon Corp., on criminal felony and misdemeanor charges stemming from the March 24, 1989, spill. If convicted on all five counts, the company could face fines exceeding $600 million. Exxon says it already has spent more than $2 billion to clean up the effects of the nation's worst oil disaster, which spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude into Prince William Sound. The skipper of the Valdez, Joseph Hazelwood, is on trial in Anchorage on felony, criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges that include operating the vessel while intoxicated. If convicted, he faces up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Les Rogers, a spokesman for Exxon in Houston, said Iarossi's departure from the company was unrelated to the spill. ``In answer to the question, did Exxon fire him, no we did not,'' Rogers said. Iarossi said he received ``a whole bunch of nasty letters'' about the spill, condemning him as anti-environmentalist. ``I think there was a very emotional side to some of the reaction that didn't benefit anybody except for a venting of anger,'' he said. ``It certainly was a tragic incident and it never should have happened. But I think Exxon Valdez became the lightning rod for a lot of emotion that was already there, a lot of energy that was already there,'' he said. Because of the spill, several members of Congress are proposing that some tankers be required to have double hulls to protect against oil spills. But Iarossi said double-hulls diminish tankers' capacity, which would require the building of more tankers and possibly increase environmental risks. Iarossi had been negotiating with the shipping bureau for several months and was elected by the New Jersey-based group on Feb. 26 to the posts of chairman of the board and president, Rogers said. Iarossi's last day at Exxon will be March 30. After serving in the U.S. Coast Guard, Iarossi joined Exxon's tanker division in 1968. From 1972 to 1976, he managed a tanker construction program for Exxon in Japan. He later was a marine advisor to Exxon and became assistant manager of Exxon's corporate planning department in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: LONDON (AP ) _ London shares were higher at midday Friday, assisted by gains made on Wall Street and renewed confidence following the successful sale of a large number of brewery shares. At about noon London time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was 12.9 points, or 0.6 percent, higher at 2,251.3. The index was above its morning low of 2,240 and off its high of 2,252.7. Volume came to a moderate 378.9 million shares by midday, compared with 193.7 million shares at the same time Thursday. The biggest event in Friday morning's session was the sale of 86.7 million shares in Scottish & Newcastle breweries. The stake was previously owned by Elders IXL Ltd., an Australian conglomerate. Traders said, however, that interest in London equities remains disappointing, with many of the large institutional investors holding off while fears of higher global interest rates prevail. ``I would not be putting large amounts of money in this market,'' said one dealer. In the absence of substantial market-stirring news, traders said London shares are again likely to follow Wall Street's lead.

DOC.HEAD: California Accuses Keating of Fraud, Seeks Millions in Penalties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed by source until 11:30 a.m. EST. News conference starts at 1 p.m. EST.; also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: The State of California today accused Charles H. Keating Jr., the central figure in the Lincoln Savings & Loan scandal, of casting a web of fraud to snare investors who paid $200 million for now-worthless ``junk bonds.'' The civil investment-fraud lawsuit, which also names two Keating associates, is the toughest action yet against Keating, whose high-flying lifestyle and soured investments came to symbolize the excesses of the S&L industry in the 1980s. The lawsuit seeks repayment for the investors, many of them elderly people who lost their life savings in the high-yield, high-risk bonds. It could lead to millions of dollars in civil and criminal judgments and years of prison time, officials said in remarks prepared for a news conference today. They said files supporting the lawsuit had been turned over to the district attorneys of Los Angeles and Orange counties for possible criminal prosecution. Keating's Los Angeles attorney, James Ham, did not immediately return a phone call seeking comment on the lawsuit. ``This is a shocking story of predatory sales practices engineered from the top and carried out in Lincoln Savings branches where every promotion and every bonus earned by employees created an atmosphere of `sell, sell, sell,''' said Christine Bender, commissioner of the state Corporations Department. Keating headed Lincoln's parent company, Phoenix-based American Continental Corp. The lawsuit was filed late Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court. It is the first such charges filed against Keating by any federal or state agency, said Ms. Bender. Lincoln's collapse is expected to be the most costly S&L failure ever, with taxpayers footing a $2 billion bailout bill. Keating already was targeted in a class-action lawsuit on behalf of 22,000 Lincoln investors. That action, like the state's lawsuit, contends they were led to believe their investments in ACC bonds were federally insured, like regular deposits at S&Ls. Ms. Bender said interviews with more than 100 American Continental bondholders and Lincoln employees and analysis of thousands of documents showed: _That prospectuses describing the bonds were routinely withheld from customers; _That investors, many of them elderly, disabled and on fixed incomes, were never told the bonds were uninsured; _That many investors were told the junk bonds were insured and risk free. Ms. Bender said it may be hard to collect restitution because American Continental is mired in bankruptcy proceedings in Phoenix, but she said her department would ``pursue every avenue in seeking restitution.'' Also named as defendants are Judy J. Wischer and Andrew Ligget, both of Phoenix, who held a variety of titles at American Continental. The lawsuit also listed 200 ``John Doe'' defendants, to be named later if additional evidence surfaces. The defendants are accused of fraud and misrepresentation in connection with the offer and sale of securities; making false filings with the Corporations Department; using unapproved advertising in connection with the securities; and selling the bonds in clear violation of the qualification requirements of state law.

DOC.HEAD: Production Ends at Campbell's Oldest Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be led after 9 a.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Workers at Campbell Soup Co.'s oldest manufacturing plant pick up their final paychecks today as production halts at the 121-year-old birthplace of condensed soup. The last can of pork and beans was scheduled to roll off the production line at midnight. ``By 3 o'clock it will be a ghost town after 121 years,'' said company spokesman James Moran. A skeleton crew will remain to dismantle equipment and ship inventory from the warehouse. Moran said it's likely that the plant, too, will be razed, along with the four huge soup cans that have long dominated the skyline on the Delaware River across from Philadelphia. The closing is part of a worldwide restructuring Campbell announced last August that will eliminate 2,800 jobs in Camden and at plants in Maryland and Tennesee. The move is expected to save the company $15 million during fiscal 1990 and $150 million during the next four years. The closure comes at a crucial time for this city of 85,000 residents, which is struggling to revitalize its business sector. Many of the blue-collar employees at the plant have worked for Campbell most of their lives and their future is uncertain. Employees, some garbed in drab green Campbell uniforms, gathered in front of the eight-story building Thursday, shaking hands and bidding farewells. ``Today is the funeral. Tomorrow is the burial,'' said Alvin Apple Still, president of Local 80 of the United Food and Commercial Workers, which represents about 640 of the hourly employees in the plant. ``We've been let down.'' Still, who worked at the plant for more than 40 years, is among about 230 employees who qualify for a pension plan. The others aren't as fortunate, he said. ``The rest of them will have to root for what they can find,'' Still said. ``There's no job market in the city.'' The union and Campbell have agreed on severance payments, but an arbitration hearing still has to be held on the pact. Production from the plant will be moved to facilities in Napoleon, Ohio; Paris, Texas and Maxton, N.C. ``I'm glad I worked here. Campbell Soup has given us a lot,'' said 57-year-old Merliane Parker, who worked at the plant for 25 years. ``But I'm glad I'm leaving.'' Mrs. Parker and a handful of other workers who lingered outside the building Thursday said they plan to take advantage of early retirements, although they said they'll have to curb their spending. ``They have to go _ they have to go,'' Lucy Dematao said shrugging her shoulders. ``They were good to everybody.'' Campbell said it would have cost millions to renovate the plant. The company is trying to improve its performance and pacify some members of its founding family who are pushing for a sale of the entire food-products giant. During its heyday in the 1930s, the Camden plant produced 10 million cans of red and white labeled soup varieties daily. In recent times, output has averaged about one million cans a day of Prego spaghetti sauce, Franco-American pasta and beans. For years, John T. Dorrance Jr., son of the chemist-turned-entrepreneur who invented condensed soups, was reluctant to close plants or lay off workers. But Dorrance Jr. died last April and since then, the company has undergone major changes, including a split in the founding family that has sparked speculation about the company being sold. Earlier this year, David Johnson became the first outsider brought in to head the company. Despite the internal upheaval, Campbell has said it will maintain its economic commitment to Camden. The plant had an annual payroll of $48 million and pumped about $13 million worth of goods, services and supplies into the regional economy yearly. Campbell has said it will build a $35 million headquarters on the city's waterfront, but some state and local officials are skeptical. Johnson said this week that between 100 and 500 employees would be cut from the headquarters staff within the next several months, Moran said. The spokesman also said the plans for the 200,000-foot international headquarters remain under review.

DOC.HEAD: Caffeine-Free Coca-Cola Classic Going Nationwide
DOC.TEXT: The first shipments of a caffeine-free version of Coca-Cola Classic, the drink that appeared following the ``new Coke'' uproar five years ago, will begin hitting stores this week. The nationwide rollout follows a successful market tryout in 10 cities, Coca-Cola USA officials said Thursday. Spokesman Bob Bertini said the new product should be available across the nation by the end of the month. An advertising campaign with the slogan, ``It's the real thing ... only caffeine free,'' also is under way, Bertini said. Caffeine-free Coke Classic is the Atlanta-based soft drink company's fourth caffeine-free version of an existing product. There are already caffeine-free versions of Coca-Cola, diet Coke and Tab. ``The caffeine-free cola segment is one of the fastest growing in the soft drink industry,'' Bertini said. Coke's best-selling caffeine-free product is Caffeine-free diet Coke, which currently has a 7.8 percent market share. Bertini said the appearance of caffeine-free Coke Classic did not mean the company was giving up on Caffeine-free Coca-Cola, which is a companion to the ``new Coke,'' that was introduced in 1985 to a wave of consumer complaints over the disappearance of the original formula Coke. The company subsequently brought back the original formula under the Coke Classic label, which became the nation's No. 1 soft drink and overwhelmingly outsold new Coke. Caffeine-free Coke similarly has been a relatively weak performer. Bertini said it has a ``very small share'' of the market.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Over Among Brokerage Officials
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. officials said talks have ended about a possible merger of the company's Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. subsidiary with Primerica Corp.'s Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. unit. American Express and Primerica executives held discussions over the weekend about a variety of combinations of the two Wall Street firms _ including Shearson acquiring Smith Barney. But American Express Chairman James D. Robinson III and Shearson Chief Executive Howard L. Clark Jr. reportedly told Shearson's 10,000 brokers in a conference call Thursday that talks were terminated. An American Express spokesman confirmed that talks had been held between Robinson and Primerica Chairman Sanford I. Weill about various combinations of the firms. Officials said the talks were conceptual and the executives never came close to a deal. A deal would have reunited old colleagues. Weill built up Shearson in the 1970s before selling it to American Express in 1981. He left American Express in 1985 and took over Primerica, a diversified financial services company, three years later. Shearson recently has been wracked by turmoil that culminated with the ouster by Robinson of chairman Peter A. Cohen in January. American Express this week said it would pump $750 million in capital on top of $250 million announced earlier to shore up the firm and avoid a credit downgrading. Shearson also announced it would lay off 2,000 of its 35,500 employees by the end of March as part of a broad reduction program. ``We are proceeding with our $750 million capital infusion plan for Shearson Lehman Hutton. Shearson Lehman Hutton is proceeding with its strategic review,'' American Express said in a statement late Thursday. Officials declined further comment on the Primerica talks. Shearson has 10,000 stockbrokers in about 600 branches while Smith Barney has 2,600 brokers in 95 branches.

The stock market headed higher across a broad front early today as the blue chips extended this week's advance. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which has gone up 71.40 points over the past four sessions, added an additional 21.62, rising to 2,657.21 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Advancing issues outdistanced declines on the New York Stock Exchange by about 7 to 3, with 853 up, 370 down and 519 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 58.76 million shares after 90 minutes of trading. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common stocks moved 1.37 higher to 184.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 1.01 to 355.05. Market analysts said today's advance was made possible by momentum built up during four straight winning sessions. A new government reading on the economy released before the start of trading had little direct impact on stock prices. But it did reinforce the feeling that the economy isn't about to slump into a recession, analysts said. Reporting on the main government gauge of the economy's future, the Commerce Department said the Index of Leading Economic Indicators showed no change in January. The flat reading followed a revised 0.6 percent gain in December and a 0.1 percent advance in November. In the early going, Philip Morris led the Big Board's list of actively traded issues, rising ~ to 36~. Among other heavily traded blue chips, General Electric gained { to 61[, Sears rose \ to 41\, International Business Machines jumped 1[ to 105[, and General Motors moved ahead by ~ to 45~. Ford spurted 1\ to 47[. Exxon, heavily sold earlier this week in the wake of an indictment stemming from last March's oil spill off the Alaskan coast, rose | to 47[.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 429.98 up 2.77 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: K mart Acquires Florida, Virginia Stores
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. said Friday it has acquired Sports Authority Inc., a sporting goods and apparel chain of Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., for an undisclosed amount. K mart said Sports Authority, which currently has eight stores featuring brand name apparel and sporting equipment, will operate as a separate subsidiary. At least 10 additional Sports Authority stores are planned for 1990, the giant discount retailer said. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. ``The financial resources of K mart will support an aggressive expansion program for the Sports Authority,'' said Jack Smith, president of the sporting goods store chain. Two Detroit-area Sports Giant stores, which K mart opened last year, will become part of the Sports Authority group this year. Sports Authority now operates seven stores in Florida and one in Woodbridge, Va., near Washington. K mart has more than 4,000 outlets nationwide and in Puerto Rico and Canada operating as K mart stores, Pay Less Drug Stores, Builders Square, Waldenbooks and PACE Membership Warehouse Clubs.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Recovering; Other Crop Futures Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with wheat higher, corn fractionally lower and soybeans narrowly mixed. The wheat market appeared to be recovering from Thursday's steep drop, partly in reaction to the Agriculture Department's approval of a sale of 140,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to China at subsidized prices. Wheat for March delivery fell 4 cents a bushel Thursday amid concerns about slack export demand and improved crop weather for U.S. winter wheat. A slow export pace continued to weigh on corn and soybean prices, with further selling linked to the beginning of the South American harvest season. The corn harvest in Argentina is underway and producing better yields than last year. Soybean harvesting in Argentina and Brazil will begin later this month. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.92\ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to } cent lower with March at $2.46\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with March at $1.44 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with March at $5.67} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .07 cent lower to .18 cent higher with April at 76.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .10 cent higher with March at 80.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .25 cent higher with April at 50.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .12 cent lower to .25 cent higher with March at 50 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mostly higher on Thursday while pork futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: U995
DOC.TEXT: The spot month contract for West Texas Intermediate crude was $21.23 per barrel at 12 p.m. EDT Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: BBC to Expand in Eastern Europe, US
DOC.TEXT: British Broadcasting Corp. announced plans on Friday to expand its programs in eastern Europe, especially Romania, and in the United States. ``One of the main principles behind the success of our international broadcasting is that we broadcast to our friends as well as those who, until recently, were enemies,'' said John Tusa, managing director of the BBC World Service. Tusa, who was born in Czechoslovakia, said eastern European countries still need to hear controversy, comment and news from a broad international viewpoint. He said non-Communist leaders in eastern Europe, including Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, have asked the BBC to continue and are giving it facilities for local rebroadcast of its programs. Mazowiecki is a former contributor to BBC programs. Broadcasts to Romania were increased by two hours during the Christmas uprising that overthrew the government of President Nicolae Ceausescu. Tusa said another hour and a quarter will be added soon. ``We have reallocated funds to eastern Europe through the internal budgeting process _ more money for Russian, Bulgarian, Romanian,'' he said. He explained that special emphasis has been put on broadcasting to Romania because of the intensity of the crisis there last Christmas and difficulties now in finding stability and a way toward transition to a new political system. To show the influence British broadcasts have had, Tusa held up a photograph taken last June in Tiananmen Square before Chinese tanks put down the pro-democracy movement. Students were carrying the Chinese flag and a sign in both English and Chinese. In English it said: ``Thank you BBC.'' Tusa added that BBC officials are asking Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government for more money but declined to say how much. He insisted that government funding does not lessen BBC independence. ``The Foreign Office does not even attempt to tell us what to say,'' Tusa told reporters. ``If they did, they know from long experience what the answer would be.'' In the United States, Americans later this month will be able to dial up the latest BBC news program by telephone at any time ``for less than a dollar a minute,'' he said. One cable television service, C-Span, is devoting an audio channel to a 24-hour relay of BBC news and Tusa expects it to grow from its present 1 million subscribers. He said 150,000 have been added recently in a suburban Washington area. He added that he also hopes for growth in an arrangement with American Public Radio that permits any of its stations to relay all BBC world service material from midnight to six in the morning.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Sues Ernst & Young in Failed Thrift Case
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators have filed a suit against the Ernst & Young accounting firm, seeking $560 million regulators say was lost because the auditors failed to detect illegitimate activities of Dallas-based Western Savings Association. The suit, filed Thursday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., means the nation's largest accounting firm becomes ineligible for most work with the FDIC, an agency spokesman said. The FDIC can only use Ernst & Young if there is a ``compelling argument'' for doing so, said agency spokesman Alan Whitney. Ernst & Young general counsel Carl Liggio was out of town this morning and unavailable to comment, a woman answering the phone in his office said. Western Savings' September 1986 failure is expected to cost the government more than $1 billion. The government continues to own and operate Western Savings, which was combined with seven other failed Texas thrifts in 1988 to form Sunbelt Savings of Dallas. Between 1982 and 1986, Western Savings operated under the control of developer Jarrett E. Woods Jr., who bought Gatesville Savings and Loan Association, renamed it Western Savings and began making high-risk loans for construction and development. Federal regulators became interested in the thrift when they noted its high rate of growth, and in 1984, supervisors for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board forced Western to agree to a series of restrictions, including the hiring of a new outside auditor, Arthur Young & Co. Arthur Young merged with Ernst & Whinney in 1989. Young performed outside audits for Western Savings in 1984 and 1985, but failed to ``plan and conduct its audits in accordance with (generally accepted accounting standards) in numerous respects,'' the FDIC alleges. The agency said Arthur Young failed to assess the risks of irregularities, assigned personnel with inadequate training, and relied unreasonably on the representations of Western Savings' management. Specifically, the FDIC said Arthur Young should have reported bogus profits from property sales, including property foreclosed by the thrift, with many of the sales going to parties who received their entire financing from Western Savings. It also alleged the accounting firm should have reported inadequate provisions for losses from loans and investments. The suit names Arthur Young & Co. and Ernst & Young.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Jury Awards Liggett Group $148 Million In Anti-Trust Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal court jury today awarded Liggett Group Inc. of Durham $148.8 million in an anti-trust case against Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. over generic cigarettes. The verdict came after more than seven months of testimony in U.S. District Court. ``The jury fully evaluated the case on the merits and ruled in favor of fair competition,'' said Liggett President K. v.R Dey. ``The message is clear: unfair competitive conduct in the marketplace is contrary to American law.'' The lawsuit was brought in 1984 by Liggett, which had introduced generic cigarettes in 1980. Liggett charged that B&W tried to bring about the demise of Liggett's low-price cigarettes by illegally copying Liggett's trademark and trying to prevent expansion of generic sales. B&W said the case was one that should be tried by the marketplace and not the courts.

DOC.HEAD: 6,300 Greyhound Drivers Go on Strike; Passengers Stranded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Besides the...' to CORRECT that 3,075 refers to those among the company's office and maintenance workers whose contract expires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BF1, CX3
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound's 6,300 drivers went on strike early today at the country's only nationwide bus company, stopping their buses outside terminals and stranding thousands of travelers. The walkout over wages began after contract talks in Scottsdale, Ariz., between Greyhound Lines Inc. and the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions failed to reach an agreement by the 12:01 a.m. MST strike deadline. No new negotiations were scheduled. Stranded passengers complained that they were unaware that a strike was looming and criticized Greyhound for selling them tickets when it was likely they wouldn't be able to complete their trips. ``They haven't even apologized,'' said Lisa Olkon, who was stuck in Atlanta while trying to get home to St. Paul, Minn., from Florida. ``I called about an hour before I went to get on the bus'' and was told nothing. About 200 passengers had been stranded at the Atlanta terminal early today, but by late morning only three dozen or so remained. The others apparently got out on the few buses that did depart or on a southbound Amtrak train that left at midmorning, or found lodging to wait out the strike. ``We went on strike because the company has refused to bargain in good faith, and we have struck because the company insisted on imposing'' its original offer, said union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson. Besides the 6,300 drivers, the strikers include 3,075 of the company's office and maintenance workers whose three-year contract expired at midnight. Dallas-based Greyhound carried 22 million passengers last year, an average of about 60,000 a day. The union told its drivers to continue only as far as their next destination as the strike deadline passed. The company said it didn't know how many passengers were stranded, but estimated the number in the thousands. Greyhound said it would operate a limited schedule today using replacements trained during the past few weeks. ``We are starting with our main line schedule first, and continue to add routes as drivers become available,'' spokeswoman Liz Hale said from the company headquarters. She said at least 16 of the 60 bus schedules that the company normally runs in Dallas were operating as of 6 a.m. Hale also said some drivers had crossed picket lines, but didn't know how many. Later, she said she had received ``spotty reports'' of harassment on picket lines, but ``nothing involving passengers.'' She said she could not confirm any of the incidents. Amtrak told ticket agents to honor Greyhound tickets when buses are unavailable, said railroad spokeswoman Sue Martin in Washington, D.C. Greyhound serves about 9,500 destinations, including about 9,000 where it is the only intercity transportation. It offers a $68 one-way ticket anywhere in the country and generally caters to people seeking the cheapest form of mass transit. Only nine of the normally scheduled 40 Greyhound buses left the Port Authority terminal in New York City between 6 p.m. and midnight, so that all passengers would reach their final destinations, said Greyhound spokesman Bill Kula. In Dallas, more than 40 pickets encircled the downtown bus terminal and blocked two incoming Greyhound buses, cheering when the drivers abandoned their vehicles. A handful of pickets blocked a departing bus for about 20 minutes in Minneapolis. The bus, marked ``charter,'' pulled out of the terminal onto a side street just before 8 a.m. when one picket, Mike Vervanac, pulled open the door and told the driver, ``We can't guarantee your safety down the road.'' Another picket, Joyce Wegener, called the driver a scab. She said later, ``The man's got my job.'' A security guard said police would be called and told the driver to continue. The bus halted again when pickets walked in front of it and didn't step aside until they saw police arriving. No arrests were made. Rob Wilkins, 22, of London, said the strike had disrupted his plans to tour America by bus. He was trying to get from Minneapolis to Memphis, Tenn. ``I'm not going to see Elvis,'' he lamented. ``I come to bloody America and they're on strike.'' Several buses also were delayed in Cleveland, where pickets jeered and pounded their fists on departing and arriving vehicles. Police blocked pickets from approaching two buses that left the Philadelphia station without passengers. Company officials would not say where the buses were going. In Pittsburgh, where violence broke out during a bus strike seven years ago, six workers picketed peacefully while stranded passengers snoozed. Sharon Kois, a senior at West Virginia University in Morgantown, W.Va., was trying to get to Bozeman, Mont., for a job interview Saturday. She said a ticket agent asked her, ``Don't you read the papers?'' when she arrived to catch her bus. She then reserved seats on an Amtrak train bound for Montana. The company said it was unsure if the picket lines would be honored by other unions, including drivers at urban mass transit systems the company operates in various cities. Greyhound drivers, who according to the company earned an average of $24,743 last year, took a 22 percent pay cut three years ago in negotiations prior to a leveraged buyout of the company. The company is offering a first-year raise of 6.9 percent, but the union says this is misleading. The company says the union is demanding a 33 percent increase in the first year; the union says that is a distortion. Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey led an investment group that paid Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. $270 million to buy out the company in 1987. The group later bought Trailways Lines Inc. of Dallas for $80 million and merged the two companies.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Ailing Waterford Crystal Maker Finds Minority Partner
DOC.TEXT: Waterford Wedgwood Group PLC said Friday that a New York investment bank and an Irish company would acquire a minority stake under a plan to raise more than $150 million for the ailing Anglo-Irish crystal and china maker. The 50-50 partnership formed by the Irish industrial company Fitzwilton and Morgan Stanley & Co. would take a maximum 29.9 percent stake in Waterford, which in turn would raise 102 million Irish pounds, or $158 million, in cash. Waterford also announced it an after-tax loss of 29 million pounds, or $45 million, in 1989, compared with a loss of 5.2 million pounds, or $8.1 million, a year earlier. The deal ends widespread speculation in recent months that Waterford was searching for a partner to help it reduce about $186 million in debt. The company said a major portion of he cash raised would go toward reducing that debt. Waterford said Investco, a new company set up by Fitzwilton Holdings PLC, which is headed by H.J. Heinz Co. Chairman Tony O'Reilly, and a Morgan Stanley & Co. affiliate called Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund II LP, would buy 212 million new Waterford shares for 37.5 pence, or 58 cents, each. The sale is expected to raise about $123 million. Waterford also said it would sell 82.8 million shares, representing about 7 percent of its enlarged stock capital, to existing shareholders, excluding Investco. Waterford said it would offer one share for every five held, at a price of 27.5 pence, 43 cents, each. That sale would raise an additional $35 million. ``This is an excellent opportunity to take a significant, long-term position in one of the world's pre-eminent luxury goods companies,'' Donald Brennan, chairman of Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund II LP, said in a statement. ``We believe current management have correctly identified the causes behind the production problems in the company's crystal business and this investment provides the prudent capital structure that will give management time to solve them,'' he said. Waterford has been hurt badly in recent years by a slump in sales in Britain and the United States and by the climb of the Irish pound against the dollar. The company was rocked when a 1988 audit revealed that accounting errors were made that overvalued its crystal inventories by up to $33 million. Former Waterford Chairman Paddy Hayes resigned in the aftermath of these revelations. Waterford's shares rose 2 pence, or 3 cents, to close at 50 pence, or 78 cents, on Dublin's Stock Exchange Friday. Under the deal, Fitzwilton and Morgan Stanley each named two members to Waterford's board of directors, raising the number to 14. O'Reilly is one of Fitzwilton's two. Detailing its results, Waterford said that it lost $32 million before taxes in 1989, compared with a a $4.2 million pre-tax profit a year earlier. Sales rose 16 percent to $541 million from $467 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: California Accuses Keating of Fraud, Seeks Millions in Penalties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Keating spokesman, include reference to previous lawsuit; DELETES 8th graf pvs, `It is ..., to remove erroneous reference to no previous charges; pick up 9th graf, `Lincoln's collapse ... Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: State officials today accused Charles H. Keating Jr., the central figure in the Lincoln Savings & Loan scandal, of casting a web of fraud to snare investors who paid $200 million for now-worthless ``junk bonds.'' The civil investment-fraud lawsuit, which also names two Keating associates, is the toughest action yet against Keating, whose high-flying lifestyle and soured investments came to symbolize the excesses of the S&L industry in the 1980s. Keating and Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp. already have been sued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in a $1.1 billion civil fraud lawsuit. The FDIC says it is the largest depository institution suit in history. The suit announced today seeks repayment for the investors in the high-yield, high-risk bonds, many of them elderly people who lost their life savings. It holds Keating and the others personally responsible and could lead to millions of dollars in civil and criminal judgments and years of prison time, the officials said in statements released this morning. They said files supporting the lawsuit had been turned over to the district attorneys of Los Angeles and Orange counties for possible criminal prosecution. ``I say the suit has been filed by the very people who allowed it to happen and it's politically motivated to divert attention,'' said Keating's Los Angeles attorney, James Ham. ``It's also a huge waste of taxpayer dollars because Mr. Keating is already being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the U.S. attorney's office, in grand jury proceedings, the Federal Election Commission, and by both houses of Congress,'' he said. He said he had not seen the lawsuit, but ``I'm sure it's just a rehash of what everybody else is in line for.'' ACC's spokesman, Brad Boland, did not immediately return a telephone message seeking comment. ``This is a shocking story of predatory sales practices engineered from the top and carried out in Lincoln Savings branches where every promotion and every bonus earned by employees created an atmosphere of `sell, sell, sell,''' said Christine Bender, commissioner of the state Corporations Department. Keating headed the Phoenix-based American Continental Corp. The lawsuit was filed late Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court. Lincoln's collapse is expected to be the most costly S&L failure ever, with taxpayers footing a $2 billion bailout bill. Keating already was targeted in a class-action lawsuit on behalf of 22,000 Lincoln investors. That action, like the state's lawsuit, contends they were led to believe their investments in ACC bonds were federally insured, like regular deposits at S&Ls. Ms. Bender said interviews with more than 100 American Continental bondholders and Lincoln employees and analysis of thousands of documents showed: _That prospectuses describing the bonds were routinely withheld from customers; _That investors, many of them elderly, disabled and on fixed incomes, were never told the bonds were uninsured; _That many investors were told the junk bonds were insured and risk free. Ms. Bender said it may be hard to collect restitution because American Continental is mired in bankruptcy proceedings in Phoenix, but she said her department would ``pursue every avenue in seeking restitution.'' Also named as defendants are Judy J. Wischer and Andrew Ligget, both of Phoenix, who held a variety of titles at American Continental. The lawsuit also listed 200 ``John Doe'' defendants, to be named later if additional evidence surfaces. The defendants are accused of fraud and misrepresentation in connection with the offer and sale of securities; making false filings with the Corporations Department; using unapproved advertising in connection with the securities; and selling the bonds in clear violation of the qualification requirements of state law.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed-Rate Home Mortgages Down
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.23 percent, down from 10.31 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.48 percent this week, up from 8.44 percent the week before.

DOC.HEAD: Frantic Pace Marks Asia's Fastest Growing Stock Market
DOC.TEXT: Mothers and hooky-playing college students are rushing to brokers around Bangkok, hoping one of the world's fastest growing stock markets will extend its winning streak in 1990. ``Most of the people who come to our trading floor are women. Many are housewives who come in the morning after dropping their kids off at school,'' said Mark Greenwood, broker at First Pacific Asia Securities. ``On a day when there's a lot of movement, I can hear great bursts of cheer coming out of the trading room,'' he said. At cocktail parties, lunches and during rounds of golf, conversations these days invariably come around to stock prospects, profits and losses. While Greenwood says many use the market here like a casino, he and other analysts predict that more serious long-term investors will make big gains on the Securities Exchange of Thailand over the next few years. With economic growth rate expected to reach 8 percent to 10 percent in 1990, analysts predict Thailand's stock market will grow by more than 25 percent. Its 137 listings are expected to increase by 40 to 50 during the year. Fueled by the economic boom and large amounts of money from abroad, the stock exchange registered the best performance in Asia last year. At the beginning of 1989, the market's total shares were valued at $9 billion, vs. $25.6 billion at yearend. George Robinson, broker at W.I. Carr Far East Ltd., said a main reason was the $1.2 billion worth of foreign investment pumped in the market last year. At the same time, speculation is widely seen as a major force in the Thai market. Many investors have been lured by the prospect of profits from buying then quickly selling. Sunisa Kriyharasan, chief researcher at CMIC Finance and Securities Co., said Thai investors did not fully understand the ``young market,'' and often bought stocks on short term speculation rather than looking for fundamentals behind a company. ``Speculation is a good thing for a young market such as Thailand's because it spurs activity and gets people into the market,'' Greenwood said. But some believe speculation has gotten out of hand. Finance Minister Pramual Sabhavasu recently said the stock exchange was becoming a ``gambling den,'' and a series of measures have been taken since Dec. 1 intended to curb excessive speculation. In many alleged cases, heavy speculation has been riding on the coattails of manipulation by large brokerages. One of these, Chao Thai Securities, was suspended from trading Jan. 12 for charges of manipulation, along with another company that was cleared the subsequent day. Chao Thai is still under investigation. ``Manipulation occurs right throughout the Asian continent. It is something that people have to live with,'' said Greenwood. Others said the government scrutiny had made a difference. ``It's getting better,'' said one broker who declined to be identified by name. ``The ministry of finance is now tightening control. Eventually we'll see an independent authority to check this.'' Although the stock exchange is 14 years old, it remained obscure only until a few years ago. From 1979 to 1986, the market struggled because of the collapse of one large securities firm, Raja Finance. Interest in the stock market picked up in 1986 with a large influx of foreign investment, drawn by Thailand's speedy industrial modernization. Since then the stock exchange has blossomed, apart from two major slumps caused by the ``Black Monday'' stock market crash in the United States in 1987 and the resignatiom of Thai Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda in 1988. Both were followed by rapid recoveries. The market has been experiencing a downturn since Jan. 10 after a dramatic 20 percent increase since Oct. 13 from an index of 650 to 925. Analysts have seen the slump as a long overdue correction as well as a result of drops in stock markets worldwide. ``I can see short term dislocation in the market. However, I think there is nothing that can stop the market when the economy is growing at 8 to 10 percent,'' said Greenwood.

DOC.HEAD: French Aviation Authority Clears Airbus A320
DOC.TEXT: France's civil aviation authority has ruled the Airbus A320 jetliner fundamentally safe despite an accident last month in Bangalore, India, in which 90 people were killed, a spokeswoman for the authority said Friday. The Direction Generale de l'Aviation Civile (DGAC) sent its judgment in a message this week to other countries operating the short-to-medium range plane, the spokeswoman said. Henri Martin, president of Aerospatiale SA, one of four European aircraft manufacturers comprising the consortium Airbus Industrie, said: ``The fact that the certification of the Airbus A320 wasn't withdrawn after the Bangalore accident makes us think that the plane isn't at fault.'' Aviation industry sources said the note stated information given French investigators concerning the accident proved the airworthiness of the aircraft as certified by DGAC. The country that certifies a plane airworthy can order aircraft belonging to the same series grounded if mechanical failure is suspected as the cause of an accident. Some French and Indian pilots have criticized the A320's sophisiticated computer-guidance system as removing too many decisions from the pilot's control. The investigation into the causes of the accident is still under way. India has grounded Air India's 14 other A320 aircraft until its inquiry is completed, but other carriers have continued to fly the 53 remaining A320s in operation. Airbus Industrie is a consortium of Aerospatiale of France, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm GmbH of West Germany, British Aerospace Plc and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA of Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Aggressively, Gold Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose aggressively against other major currencies in Europe Friday, shrugging off a reported intervention by the West German Bundesbank, the U.S. Federal Reserve and the French and Spanish central banks. Gold prices fell more than $5 an ounce. The dollar did retreat from its session highs against the West German mark on a series of Bundesbank interventions late in the afternoon, dealers said. But the U.S. currency recovered after the market interpreted the intervention as warning rather than a serious effort to bring the U.S. currency lower, dealers said. The dollar still was underpinned by jitters over German unification, they said. A dealer with a U.S. money center bank said the Bundesbank's action was ``clearly a signal to the market that the dollar had moved too far too fast.'' The Fed didn't surface until much later in European dealings when it sold dollars between 149.90 Japanese yen and 150.10 yen, dealers said. But the action had little effect on the U.S. currency, they said. In London, the British pound fell to $1.6515 from $1.6655 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.7200 West German marks, up from 1.7145; 1.5130 Swiss francs, up from 1.5060; 5.8065 French francs, up from 5.7935; 1.9365 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9307; 1,268.00 Italian lire, up from 1,266.00; and 1.1939 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1899. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.03 yen to a closing 149.75 yen. But later, in London, it was quoted at 150.28 yen. Bullion dealers attributed the decline in gold prices to a wave of technical selling in light trading, which brought the prices below a key support level. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $403.25 a troy ounce from $407.75 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $402.50 from $407.75 bid late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.02 to close at a bid $406.61. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $5.12 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.16.

DOC.HEAD: Ryder Executives Predict No or Slow Growth in 1990
DOC.TEXT: Ryder System Inc. executives Friday predicted flat or only slight growth in 1990 as the transportation services company seeks to rebound from a 77 percent earnings decline last year. Ryder officials told a meeting of industry analysts they hope streamlined operations and growing European operations will improve business, but said a quick turnaround is not expected, in part because of the nation's slowing economy. ``We continue to see a difficult environment for significant improvements in earnings,'' said M. Anthony Burns, Ryder's chairman and chief executive. Burns said Miami-based Ryder should post a first-quarter loss and will be lucky to show an improvement over last year's operating income, which was affected by a $90 million charge for a restructuring, an increase of workers compensation reserves and vehicle sales. Last year, Ryder's net earnings were $46 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with $197 million, or $2.40 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose slightly to $5.1 billion from $5 billion in 1988. Ryder blamed the earnings decline on reduced demand for commercial truck rental, no aircraft sales by its aviation division, increased fuel costs and a slowdown in new car sales that hurt its vehicle transportation unit. Ryder, which has sold off three slow-growing divisions since last year and reduced its work force by nearly 3,000 to 42,000, shares about 80 percent of the truck-rental market with Phoenix-based U-Haul International Inc. Ryder's Vehicle Leasings & Services division, which posted a pre-tax loss of more than $110 million last year, has sold off about 10,000 trucks, many in poor condition. Leasing division chief David Parker said Ryder's school bus leasing operations and expansion into Europe are potential growth areas. Ryder operates several truck facilities in the United Kingdom and one in West Germany. No aircraft sales and a decline in the market for used aircraft parts last year hurt Ryder's Aviations Services division, which leases and sells used aircraft, repairs engines and distributes parts. A Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by Orlando-based Braniff Inc. in September also cost Ryder business. But Ryder officials are competing for former customers of United Airlines, which has left the jet engine repair business. European expansion is also a target of Ryder's Automotive Carrier Division, which transports new cars, division head Terence Russell said. Russell attributed much of the division's $22.6 million pre-tax losses last year to a slump in new cars sales, which he said should rebound.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Closed Mixed After Choppy Session
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat finished slightly lower, soybeans were modestly higher and corn futures were mixed. The close reflected a squaring up of positions before the weekend after a choppy session in which both corn and soybeans traded on either side of unchanged. Wheat drew strength early in the session from news that the Agriculture Department had approved a sale of 140,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat to China at subsidized prices. Soybeans rallied back from modest losses posted at midday when soybean meal futures fell to 2{-year lows, reflecting continuing slack export demand and ample near-term supplies. Soybean meal for delivery in March finished $2.10 lower at $159.30 a ton, the lowest close for a near-month meal contract since September 1987. At the close, wheat futures were \ cent to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.88} a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with March at $2.45} a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with March at $1.44\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 5\ cents higher with March at $5.69 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: To Motivate, It's Money That Matters, Some Quality Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: U.S. workers lack enthusiasm and don't enjoy their jobs, and the best way to motivate employees may be to offer them more money, according to most of the quality control engineers responding to a recent survey. The Institute of Industrial Engineers, after examining responses to a survey of its members' opinions on workplace productivity and quality issues, said corporations must invest more in motivating employees and making the workers feel they can share in the company's success. The alternative could be declining productivity and quality, said Gregory Balestrero, executive director of the IIE, based in Norcross, Ga. ``It's affecting corporations very rapidly,'' Balestrero said Friday from Miami, where he was attending a conference. Balestrero said 27 percent of the IIE's 40,000 members responded to the annual survey, with 75.2 percent of the respondents saying they did not think employees were enthusiastic about their jobs or enjoyed coming to work. In a 1987 survey, 54.9 percent of those responding said employees were enthusiastic and enjoyed coming to work. Balestrero said some major corporations, notably Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co. and Ford Motor Co., have instituted successful programs to provide employees with incentives for the improved performance of the company as a whole. Such ``gain sharing'' programs, he said, set corporate rather than individual goals, which when exceeded provide benefits to everyone. But relatively few corporations are making such an effort, he said. Asked the primary motivation for employees to increase productivity, the greatest percentage of respondents _ 29 percent _ listed financial reward, followed by personal recognition, increased responsibilities and pride in the job. Balestrero said in 1980, recognition topped the list, but money began returning to prominence around 1985. IIE members include engineers and managers involved in quality control, personnel and productivity. About 68 percent of the members are in manufacturing businesses, Balestrero said. Among the other responses: _91 percent said they believe companies are more interested in short-term financial gain than in long-term investment in productivity and quality programs. _71 percent said management does not seek employee input on decisions regarding things about which the employee has knowledge. _62.7 percent said employees are less productive than 10 years ago and don't work as hard. _67.9 percent disagreed with the statement: ``Employees take more pride in their work than they did 10 years ago.'' _85.1 percent disagreed with the statement: ``Employees are more loyal and dedicated to the company than they were 10 years ago.'' _58.6 percent disagreed that with the statement that workmanship is better than 10 years ago.
The stock market was broadly higher in late trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 22.07 at 2,657.66 with five minutes left to go in the session.

The stock market headed higher across a broad front today and the blue chips extended their advance to a fifth straight session. Market analysts said the strong performance was made possible in part by momentum building up all week. Confidence in U.S. financial markets got a boost when stocks managed to shrug off the rout that rocked Tokyo on Monday, causing the Japanese market's second-biggest point loss ever. ``I think our market clearly has de-coupled from the Japanese market,'' said Gordon L. Smith, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. ``This week demonstrated that is the case.'' A new government reading on the economy released before the start of trading today reinforced the feeling that the U.S. economy isn't about to slump into a recession, analysts said. Reporting on the main government gauge of the economy's future, the Commerce Department said the Index of Leading Economic Indicators showed no change in January. The flat reading followed a revised 0.6 percent gain in December and a 0.1 percent advance in November. ``The numbers all week for the most part indicate the economy's kind of OK. That has been of some encouragement to people,'' Smith said. A rally in bonds, meanwhile, injected some zip into the stock market. In late afternoon dealings, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose more than a half point, or around $5 per $1,000 in face value, while its yield tumbled to 8.55 percent from 8.60 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: B&W Ordered To Pay Liggett $148.8 Million in Antitrust Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, `Brown &... to UPDATE with B&W comment; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `Liggett was...; K.v.R. in 5th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A federal jury on Friday ordered Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. to pay $148.8 million to Liggett Group Inc. for attempting to put Liggett's generic cigarettes out of business through illegal pricing. The award followed a seven-month antitrust trial in U.S. District Court on allegations that B&W illegally tried to stifle expansion of generic cigarette sales by its competitor in the early 1980s. B&W was convicted of selling generic cigarettes at below their cost of manufacture, giving illegal discounts to undercut Liggett sales and organizing a plan to displace Liggett in the generic market. Brown & Williamson, based in Louisville, Ky., was acquitted of trademark violation. Attorneys for Durham-based Liggett said they would seek a new trial on that issue. ``The message is clear: Unfair competitive conduct in the marketplace is contrary to American law,'' Liggett President K.v.R. Dey said. Liggett introduced generic cigarettes in 1980 and sued B&W in 1984, charging it tried to bring about the demise of Liggett's low-price brand by illegally copying Liggett's trademark and trying to prevent expansion of generic sales. The trial began last July. B&W maintained the case should be tried in the marketplace and not the courts. Liggett sought $89.6 million in compensatory damages, the amount the company said it lost as a result of predatory practices by B&W in violation of federal trade and antitrust laws. Liggett contended that it pioneered the plain-label, generic cigarette market in 1980 in a successful effort to carve its own niche at a time when sales of its regular brands were flagging. Brown & Williamson, a larger tobacco company, said it engaged in customary tactics in the highly competitive cigarette trade in seeking a share of the generic market. Josiah Murray, general counsel for the Liggett Group Inc., said B&W sought to bring down Liggett ``because Liggett's low-price cigarettes were interfering with Brown & Williamson's high profits on their branded cigarettes.' B&W said in statement it believed the verdict would be overturned because of ``overwhelming evidence that competition was not in any way injured by Brown & Williamson's sale of low-priced cigarettes.'' Liggett was owned by Grand Metropolitan PLC when the lawsuit was filed. It was sold to a group of private investors in 1986 and went public a year later. When GrandMet sold Liggett, an arrangement was made for Liggett and GrandMet to share equally in any proceeds of the Brown & Williamson litigation after reimbursement of expenses. Under an agreement, GrandMet's share in any recovery will not exceed $16.5 million, plus reimbursement of all expenses relating to the lawsuit paid or reimbursed by GrandMet, or by Liggett while it was owned by GrandMet. The balance of a recovery will be Liggett's. Since last June, GrandMet has reimbursed Liggett for 50 percent of Liggett's expenses in connection with the case.
