DOC.HEAD: Gannett Agrees to Buy Great Falls Tribune for $41 Million
DOC.TEXT: Gannett Co. Inc. said Friday it had agreed to buy the Great Falls Tribune in Great Falls, Mont., from Cowles Media Co. for $41 million. The Tribune, Montana's second-largest newspaper, has a circulation of 34,000 Monday-Saturday, and 41,000 on Sunday. The purchase is Gannett's first in Montana, and raises its number of daily newspapers to 83, including USA Today. ``We are pleased to be coming into Great Falls and the state of Montana,'' said John J. Curley, chairman, president and chief executive of Gannett. David C. Cox, president and chief executive officer of Cowles Media, which is based in Minneapolis, said, ``We value very highly our 25-year association with the Great Falls Tribune and are proud of the leadership role it has played in Montana.'' The newspaper traces its roots to the Sun River Sun, first published in 1884. It began publishing as the Great Falls Tribune in 1885. Montana is the 41st state in which Gannett will have operations. Other Gannett activities include 10 television stations, 16 radio stations, Gannett News Services and the largest outdoor advertising company in North America.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Currency Benefiting From Other Nations' Turmoil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with New York dollar, gold figures.
DOC.TEXT: Concerted central bank intervention helped moderate the dollar's rise on Friday, following the currency's recent foreign exchange surge that analysts credit to economic and political turmoil in other nations. Some of the sharpest gains have come against the currencies of West Germany and Japan, both of which are undergoing times of economic uncertainty. The dollar closed at 1.7200 West German marks Friday in Europe, up sharply from the 1.6545 marks of Feb. 7. Against the Japanese currency, the dollar closed at 150.28 Japanese yen Friday in London, inciting a round of dollar selling by the central banks of several countries, including the Federal Reserve. On Feb. 19, the dollar was quoted at 144.52 yen. ``It's not so much that the dollar is going up, but other currencies are going down,'' said Kevin Logan, chief economist with Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. David Wyss, chief financial economist with DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass., said the yen failed to rally as expected after Japan's parliamentary elections last month. The mark, which soared after the border between East Germany and West Germany was opened in November, also has run into trouble. The Deutschemark has dominated foreign exchange trading since the barriers between the two Germanys began falling on Nov. 9. The dollar closed at 1.8475 marks that day, but the West German currency shot higher on speculation that the country's economy would boom as a result of the political changes in Eastern Europe. But some of the euphoria has begun to wear off and is being replaced by the jitters. The outcome of this month's East German elections is unclear and there is concern that the planned unification of the East German and West German currencies may lead to an oversupply of marks _ increasing the danger of runaway inflation. ``All the uncertainty ... has increased the risk of holding Deutschemark assets,'' Logan said. Investors have begun selling some of their marks to preserve their profits and the dollar has advanced as a result. The dollar's close of 1.7200 marks in Europe compared with Thursday's level of 1.7145. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7150 West German marks from 1.7194 Thursday. In Japan, disappointment over the yen's failure to rally has been compounded by increasing fears that interest rates will rise further as the government attempts to contain inflation. As more and more traders believe a rate hike is likely, they are selling yen in favor of the dollar. The yen's decline has been swift and startling. During a six-day winning streak in late February, the dollar soared 4.51 yen and reached its highest level since last June. Analysts say the dollar could go higher, but the central banks of the big industrial countries will try to stop it, especially against the yen. Friday's intervention _ which succeeded in taming the dollar somewhat on U.S. markets _ was a statement by the banks that they want to see currency rates stable, Wyss said. The dollar fell 0.03 yen to close at 149.75 yen Friday in Tokyo. But later, in London, it was quoted at 150.28 yen, and it closed in New York at 150.15 yen, up sharply from Thursday's 149.85. With traders growing uneasy about the German political and economic situation, currencies like the British pound and the Swiss franc _ whose countries have high interest rates _ were seen as relatively safe havens and also have advanced against the mark, Logan said. But in recent sessions the European currencies have fallen with the mark, allowing the dollar to gain sharply, he said. On Feb. 23, the pound traded at $1.7145, its highest level since April 1989. But sterling has dropped since then. In London Friday, it closed at $1.6515, compared with $1.6655 late Thursday, and in New York it fell to $1.6485 from $1.6640. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5085 Swiss francs, down from 1.5095, 5.7910 French francs, down from 5.8070; 1,264.50 Italian lire, down from 1,267.25; and 1.19225 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19095. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.5130 Swiss francs, up from 1.5060; 5.8065 French francs, up from 5.7935; 1.9365 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9307; 1,268.00 Italian lire, up from 1,266.00; and 1.1939 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1899. Gold prices fell sharply Friday. Dealers attributed the decline to technical selling in light trading. In New York, gold fell $3.20 to $403 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, and Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $403.25 a troy ounce, down $3.45 from Thursday. Gold fell earlier in London to a late bid of $403.25 a troy ounce from $407.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $402.50 from $407.75 bid late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.02 to close at a bid $406.61. Silver fell 2.8 cents to $5.126 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. In London earlier, silver fell to a late bid of $5.12 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.16.

DOC.HEAD: Cigna Bowing Out of Personal Auto Insurance
DOC.TEXT: Cigna Corp. said Friday it was dropping personal auto insurance coverage because the division generates little business and is only marginally profitable. Cigna's specialty is commercial insurance coverage and is rated one of the nation's largest in that area. Cigna has only 0.8 percent of the national business in personal auto insurance. The insurance giant had annual premiums of $11.5 billion last year, of which personal auto insurance accounted for only $215 million. ``The personal auto insurance is only marginally profitable at best and therefore we have decided to stop,'' Cigna spokesman Jim Beattie said. Beattie said the problem stems from higher repair bills, medical bills and legal expenses. Cigna does not generate enough business to offset those costs and could not in the near future, he said. Cigna has decided to concentrate on its commercial coverage lines as well as continue restructuring its agency division. The company sells to individuals and small businesses through independent agents. Cigna said it would be severing exclusive contracts with 220 independents by the end of next year. Two weeks ago, the head of the division handling the independents, David J. Prentiss, resigned. Beattie said the company will generally quit writing new auto policies and agents will be asked to renew existing policies with other carriers as the policies come due. Because of the change, Beattie said so-called ``umbrella'' policies Cigna has offered for complete insurance coverage through one company would not be renewed. But he said the company will continue to write homeowner insurance, even though it is also a very small part of Cigna's business. Commercial vehicle coverage also will continue to be available. Beattie said some personal auto insurance policies will be honored and sold by agents who hold exclusive contracts with Cigna. ``We will meet or exceed all state regulations and honor all contractual agreements,'' he said. Cigna said no layoffs are expected because of the personal auto coverage decision.

Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 199.83 million shares. Market analysts said the strong performance was made possible in part by momentum building up all week. Confidence in the U.S. financial markets got a boost when stocks managed to shrug off a series of severe setbacks in Tokyo. ``I think our market clearly has de-coupled from the Japanese market,'' said Gordon L. Smith, a managing director at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. ``This week demonstrated that is the case.'' A new government reading on the economy released Friday morning reinforced the feeling that the U.S. economy isn't about to slump into a recession, analysts said. Reporting on the main government gauge of the economy's future, the Commerce Department said the Index of Leading Economic Indicators showed no change in January. The flat reading followed two months of increase. ``The numbers all week for the most part indicate the economy's kind of OK. That has been of some encouragement to people,'' Smith said. DOC.HEAD: Ivory Coast Unrest Fuels Surge In Coffee, Cocoa Futures
DOC.TEXT: Coffee and cocoa futures prices rose sharply Friday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, fueled by fears that unrest in the Ivory Coast could disrupt shipments of Ivorian cocoa and coffee, the country's two main exports. On other commodity markets, copper futures also rose sharply; precious metals retreated energy futures advanced; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Coffee futures settled 2.25 cents to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at 99 cents a pound; cocoa futures ended $35 to $50 higher with March at $1,123 a ton. Both markets have been in upward trends since at least the beginning of the year after falling sharply last year to their lowest levels in more than a decade. The depression of coffee and cocoa prices has been disastrous for the economy of the once-prosperous Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer and fifth-largest coffee grower. Civil discontent in the African nation erupted Friday as police faced protesting high school and college students demanding the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, who has led the Ivory Coast since it gained independence from France 30 years ago. Market analysts said the leap in coffee and cocoa futures reflected fears that the tesnions could escalate into a general strike, although there were no reports of shipping interruptions on Friday. Analyst Arthur Stevenson of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the markets may have overreacted to the reports of unrest simply because the Ivory Coast has been quiet for so long. ``The Ivory Coast has been an island of stability in a part of the world where stability is a rare commodity,'' he said. Bert Ruiz, a vice president of the commodities brokerage Balfour Maclaine Corp., also said traders had overreacted. ``Right now, there's only the potential for supply problems and I think that spooked the markets,'' he said. Copper futures soared on New York's Commodity Exchange amid growing concerns about tightening supplies and a possible squeeze in the March contract, which is approaching expiration. After the close, the Commodity Exchange reported a 175-ton increase Friday in copper stocks in exchange-registered warehouses but traders expect the London Metal Exchange to report a sharp drop in copper stocks in its weekly report on Monday. Copper futures settled 2.4 cents to 4.6 cents higher with March at $1.198 a pound. Gold and silver futures prices sagged on the Comex amid selling linked to gains in the stock market and the dollar's strength. Gold finished $3.20 to $4 lower with April at $405.60 a troy ounce; silver futures were 2.8 cents to 3.3 cents lower with March at $5.126 a troy ounce. Most petroleum futures rallied on the New York Mercantile Exchange in a partial rebound from sharp losses earlier in the week. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures ended 8 cents lower to 18 cents higher with April at $21.35 a barrel; heating oil was .34 cent to 1.24 cents higher with April at 55.87 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent to .96 cent higher with April at 56.47 cents a gallon. Livestock futures were narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork-belly futures fell sharply in selling inspired by weak price indications and heavy hog slaughter levels during the week. Live cattle futures settled .07 cent lower to .33 cent higher with April at 76.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .15 cent lower with March at 80.47 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent lower to .35 cent higher with April at 50.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.37 cent to 1.90 cents lower with March at 48.75 cents a pound. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures settled { cent to 2 cents lower with March at $3.88} a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with March at $2.45} a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with March at $1.44\ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 4\ cents higher with March at $5.68} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Higher
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose Friday, bouncing back from a two-day tumble after the government said sales of new homes fell in January to the lowest level in nearly a year. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond rose 11-16 point, or about $7 for every $1,000 in face value after losing nearly 1} points over the past two session. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, dropped to 8.54 percent from 8.60 percent late Thursday. Bond prices moved higher after the Commerce Department reported that new home sales dropped 7.1 percent in January, suggesting the economy remains weak. ``The market used that basically as an excuse to start buying (bonds),'' said Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. A weak economy increases prospects that the Federal Reserve would ease interest rates to keep growth from stalling. Lower interest rates boost the value of bonds. But there still is considerable confusion on the state of economic health. The market's retreat earlier in the week was attributed to speculation that the economy may not be as sluggish as many analysts have suggested. Indeed, prices finished below their highs of the day on Friday as some traders took profits on the price runup before the weekend. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues rose 3-32 point, intermediate maturities advanced between 7-32 point and ] point and long-term issues jumped as much as 11-16 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.67 to 1,154.08. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 1-16 point to 91~. The average yield to maturity slipped to 7.43 percent from 7.44 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills declined to 8.00 percent as the discount slipped 5 basis points to 7.75 percent. Yields on six-month bills were unchanged at 8.17 percent as the discount remained at 7.75 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 8.23 percent as the discount rose 3 basis points to 7.67 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 5-16 percent, unchanged from late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Seizure Leaves Only Four Independent Thrifts in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: Regulators on Friday seized a large Arizona savings institution, leaving only four thrifts operating independently in the economically troubled state. Pima Savings and Loan Association, Tuscon, was taken over by the Resolution Trust Corp., an agency created last August to sell or close insolvent thrift institutions. Its seizure brings the number of government-controlled thrifts in Arizona to seven. Three small S&Ls and only one major institution, First American Savings Inc. of Tuscon, still operate under private control. According to the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, Pima had assets of $2.7 billion at the end of 1989. It lost $106.5 million last year and was $16.1 million in the red at the end of December. The office rejected as unrealistic Pima's plan to raise capital to meet the more stringent requirements of last year's S&L law. In Arizona's depressed real estate market, Pima had little chance of replenishing its capital without government assistance, said thrift office spokesman William Fulwider. Pima embarked on a rapid-growth strategy in the mid-1980s emphasizing risky loans, Fulwider said. For a time, it reported above-average profits, but extraordinary sour loan problems destroyed its earnings, he said. The S&L will maintain normal business hours and all 170,000 deposit accounts are protected up to the $100,000 insurance limit, the RTC said. According to Sheshunoff Information Services, Pima was the fourth largest S&L in Arizona and the 76th largest in the nation at the end of September. Before Friday, the Resolution Trust Corp. was managing 333 institutions with $175 billion in assets. In addition to Pima, the RTC on Friday also seized North Carolina Federal Savings and Loan Association, Charlotte, N.C.; Haven Federal Savings and Loan Association, Winter Haven, Fla.; New Athens Savings and Loan Association, New Athens, Ill.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Recover
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices recovered Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after three straight days of declines. Analysts said prices were due for a rebound after bearish sentiment in recent days. Gasoline futures had borne the brunt of the decline, amid speculation centering on ample supplies of fuel and relatively weak consumption. On Friday, unleaded regular gasoline for April delivery jumped 0.66 cent to finish at 56.47 cents a gallon. Contracts for delivery further in the future also advanced. ``Some people were just buying it back,'' said Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc. ``There were a lot of oversold pressures that had to be relieved.'' Among other refined petroleum products traded on the exchange, home heating oil for April delivery soared 1.24 cents to 55.87 cents a gallon. Later contracts also were up, but less strongly. The April contract for West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 18 cents to close at $21.35 per 42-gallon barrel. Later contracts for delivery further in the future made smaller gains.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Suspends Marine Operations in New Jersey After Two Spills
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. on Friday suspended all tanker and barge operations in New Jersey indefinitely after spills at a refinery and a distribution terminal this week. Exxon President Lee Raymond said marine operations in the state would be halted while Exxon evaluated procedures at its Bayway refinery in Linden and Bayonne distribution terminal. The refinery is the only one Exxon operates on the East Coast. The company said alternate supply arrangements were being made for gasoline, heating oil, propane and other products, and no interruptions were expected. ``We deeply regret the recent accidents at our New Jersey facilities and the impacts and concerns they have caused,'' Raymond said in a statement. ``We are seriously committed to conducting our operations in a safe and environmentally responsible manner and we are taking this measure to demonstrate that commitment,'' he said. The Bayway refinery and the distribution center have been the site of three oil spills since Jan. 1. Exxon also has come under criticism and faces a federal criminal indictment in connection with a large oil spill in Alaska last year. On Wednesday, a leaking barge owned by a private contractor spilled 30,000 gallons into the Kill Van Kull waterway while taking on a loan of heating oil at Exxon's Bayonne terminal. While crews were trying to contain the previous day's spill, a fuel line broke free while a Texaco barge was being filled at the Bayway refinery Thursday, resulting in a 4,800-gallon spill in the Arthur Kill waterway. A ruptured pipeline at the Bayway refinery on Jan. 1-2 dumped 567,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill. Exxon was blamed for the January spill and Eklof Marine Corp. of Staten Island, N.Y., took responsibility for Wednesday's mishap. Coast Guard Capt. Robert North said officials haven't determined who was to blame for Thursday's spill. He said the spill largely was contained by booms and did not appear to have spread into the harbor. Rep. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J., said he had written Exxon Chairman and Chief Executive Lawrence Rawl requesting that the company voluntarily impose emergency procedures at the two New Jersey facilities. ``This is either an extraordinary coincidence of accidents or Exxon is simply not doing a good job of meeting minimum standards,'' Torricelli said. He called on Exxon to voluntarily place booms around all vessels during oil transfers, and temporarily halt night operations until they the company reviewed its procedures, but Exxon went further. Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York called on Exxon to submit to an independent environmental audit of the company's operation in New York and New Jersey. Abrams said that ``in light of the cumulative adverse impact of these repeated spills, resolute and extraordinary action on Exxon's part is overdue.''

The government's main economic forecasting gauge held steady in January, offering signs of an aimless economy with little growth but little chance of a recession either. Economist Kevin Logan of the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York said Friday the report on the Index of Leading Economic Indicators means the economy ``is moving sideways. ... There is not a lot of strength but neither is there pervasive weakness.'' The index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance, and has risen for the previous two months.

The government said sales of new homes fell 7.1 percent in January to their lowest level in nearly a year, despite incentives to builders to offset industry weakness and encourage buying. The Commerce Department said Friday new, single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 589,000 units in January, the worst performance since sales fell to 556,000 homes on an annual basis last March.

Federal regulators are investigating $260 million in employee bonuses paid by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. shortly before collapsing, Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard C. Breeden said. Breeden also said Friday he did not believe that $650 million in fines and penalties extracted from Drexel to settle civil and criminal securities fraud charges last year pushed the firm's parent company into bankruptcy court. Breeden told the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee the SEC was looking into whether there was any wrongdoing in the cash and stock bonuses Drexel paid employees in the months leading to the Feb. 13 bankruptcy filing.

Cigna Corp. said it was dropping personal auto insurance coverage because the division generates little business and is only marginally profitable. Cigna's specialty is commercial insurance coverage and is rated one of the nation's largest in that area. Cigna has only 0.8 percent of the national business in personal auto insurance. Its plans were disclosed Friday.

A bipartisan commission recommended a $66 billion plan to provide health care coverage to nearly all Americans but drew criticism from Congress and some of its own members for failing to recommend a way to pay. The U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care voted Friday to send Congress proposals to provide universal health insurance, phased in over five years, and a proposal to ensure long-term health care to Americans.

The government told the nation's airlines to end discrimination against the handicapped, but barred people who are blind, frail, obese, disabled or under 15 from sitting in rows with emergency exits. The Transportation Department order was sharply criticized Friday by the Air Transport Association, which said it would dimish safety. The National Federation of the Blind blasted the exit-row rule as discriminatory.

Regulators seized a large Arizona savings institution, leaving only four thrifts operating independently in the economically troubled state. Pima Savings and Loan Association, Tuscon, was taken over Friday by the Resolution Trust Corp., an agency created last August to sell or close insolvent thrift institutions.

The nation's largest banking trade group endorsed a plan to reform deposit insurance and force uninsured depositors to accept some losses in bank failures. The American Bankers Association's plan disclosed Friday would continue $100,000 per account coverage, but it would eliminate the current practice of treating some banks as ``too big to fail.''

A government advisory council said Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Co., Japan's telecommunications giant, should be split into three separate companies within five years. The recommendations Friday by the Telecommunications Council concluded a two-year study that contended NTT's current virtual monopoly on telephone service has hindered free competition in Japan's telecommunications market and hurt efficient management.

Renewed confidence in the economic outlook and in U.S. financial markets propelled stock prices higher Friday for a fifth straight session. The Dow Jones industrial average rallied 24.77 points to finish at 2,660.36, its best closing level since mid-January. The blue-chip indicator climbed 96.17 points in its five-day winning streak. The dollar finished mixed. Bond prices bounced back from a two-day tumble. Coffee, copper and cocoa futures prices rose sharply; precious metals retreated; energy futures advanced; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Mobil To Pay $500,000 Fines for Kerosene Spill
DOC.TEXT: Mobil Oil Corp. has agreed to pay $500,000 in fines and submit to a review of its operations after it spilled 50,000 gallons of kerosene into the ground in Brooklyn, state officials said Friday. Mobil also must reimburse the state for cleaning up the mess left when the kerosene leaked a Mobil facility, state Department of Environmental Conservation Commissioner Thomas C. Jorling said. In addition, the company must test all product plumes under the facility, not just the one resulting from the Feb. 3 spill, he said. The spill did not reach a creek that feeds into New York's East River, officials said. The $500,000 fine is the maximum penalty under state environmental conservation and navigation laws. The state accused Mobil of violating laws by failing to report the spill for several days and failing to test the kerosene storage tank before it was put back into service after reconditioning. The 100-year-old tank was reconditioned and returned to service Jan. 29. On Feb. 5, Mobil notified the DEC that 80 gallons of kerosene had leaked from the tank two days earlier. The company raised the estimated size of the release to 50,000 gallons the next day, the DEC said. Mobil later claimed to have recovered 37,000 gallons of kerosene through an underground drainage and treatment system, the DEC said. Mobil spokesman Mark Cohen said the company would work with state and local agencies to take ``whatever corrective action necessary to prevent such incidents from occurring in the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Texas Air, Eastern Threaten Action To Clear Names
DOC.TEXT: Texas Air Corp. and its Eastern Airlines subsidiary threatened unspecified action Friday to clear their names after a court report said Texas Air short-changed Eastern when it bought the airline and some of its assets. Texas Air agreed earlier this week to pay Eastern more than $280 million to settle the findings by court-appointed bankruptcy examiner David I. Shapiro. He concluded that Texas Air owes Eastern $285 million to $403 million for assets it purchased at unfairly low prices. Shapiro's findings supported a key contention by striking Eastern workers, who claimed Texas Air stripped the airline of its most valuable assets to bolster the parent's non-union carrier, Continental Airlines. Eastern and Texas Air said Thursday they rejected the validity of Shapiro's conclusions. In a statement Friday, they also threatened to take ``serious and considered actions'' to vindicate themselves. ``We find ourselves in the intolerable position where our commitments to rebuild Eastern are being improperly used to imply that Texas Air somehow agrees with this amateurish report, and that our assistance to Eastern somehow constitutes payment to settle any such liabilities,'' the statement said. Texas Air spokesman Art Kent declined comment on what form the action might take. He said discussions on various options are under way and a decision would be made soon. Richard Seltzer, an attorney for the Air Line Pilots Association, said it was difficult to see what the companies might do, other than file an objection with federal bankruptcy court. Shapiro didn't return a telephone call seeking comment. Shapiro said in the report that he did not agree with the unions' request that Eastern be run by an outside trustee, which was sought as protection against further asset sales by Texas Air during bankruptcy reorganization. Union attorneys insisted a trustee still should be named to take over management of the company. Approval of the settlement by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland could remove a main obstacle in Eastern's effort to emerge from bankruptcy, because some of the compensation would help satisfy creditor claims against the Miami-based airline. Shapiro concluded, for example, that Eastern should recover $150 million to $250 million from Texas Air for the transfer of the System One computer reservation system, and $61 million for Texas Air's acquisition of Eastern in November 1986. Under the proposed settlement, Eastern also would receive a 25 percent share in System One and the right to buy 40 Boeing 737-300 jets at cost from sister carrier Continental. The settlement's total value is estimated at more than $280 million and includes $133 million in cash. Shapiro issued his findings following a lengthy investigation into the dealings between Texas Air, Eastern and Continental undertaken as part of Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy case. The airline sought protection from creditors five days after a March 4, 1989, strike by machinists, flight attendants and pilots that virtually grounded it. Eastern has been reorganizing as a smaller carrier and has hired replacements for many of the strikers. The pilots and flight attendants unions abandoned the strike in November but Machinists remain on strike.

DOC.HEAD: Too Many Car-Truck Plants in North America, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: The North American auto industry continues to have too much capacity and will need to shut five or six more plants in addition to the five closed down in recent years, according to an independent study. ``All the announced plant closings will not be enough to close the gap,'' said William R. Pochiluk, president of AUTOFACTS, an independent consultant. The firm's study, released Thursday, also said Ford Motor Co. made more efficient use of its manufacturing plant capacity last year than other major automakers. In 1989, the study found a total industry capacity of 14.3 million cars and light trucks, down 1 percent from 1988. Overall, the industry used 88 percent of its plant capacity last year. Manufacturers used 82 percent of capacity to make cars and 101 percent of capacity for light trucks. For the second year, Ford led the way, with a 90 percent capacity utilization for cars and 107 percent for light trucks. Capacity utilization refers to how many vehicles a manufacturer actually produced. A manufacturer producing at more than 100 percent of capacity had to operate at overtime, Pochiluk said. Foreign-based producers manufactured at 94 percent of capacity, with cars at 93 percent and light trucks at 101 percent. Chrysler Corp. achieved 86 percent capacity utilization overall, reflecting below average performance of 76 percent for cars and 97 percent for light trucks. General Motors Corp. recorded the lowest overall results in 1989 _ an 82 percent overall capacity utilization rate with a low 76 percent rate in cars offset by a light truck rate of 99 percent. AUTOFACTS counts 79 automotive plants producing cars and light trucks in the United States and Canada currently, with a straight-time capacity of 14.4 million vehicles. Actual 1990 car and light truck production is scheduled to total 11.8 million, 7.2 million cars and 4.6 million light trucks. Five assembly plants are projected to open and five to close permanently by 1995, the study said, but the industry's rated capacity will grow to 15.7 million units. While domestic capacity should average 15.4 million units from 1992 to 1995, production of light vehicles is projected to average 13.4 million, Pochiluk said. ``There are approximately 5 to 6 plants of excess capacity for the 1990-95 planning window,'' the study said. Foreign manufacturers, primarily Japanese, accepted the challenge to produce more in America, the study said, but the strategy backfired on domesitic automakers as exchange rates resulted in lower manufacturing costs for the ``transplant'' vehicles. The study listed several auto plants it considered ``vulnerable'' for closure in the next five years, including some where a shutdown is already pending. They included GM plants in Lakewood, Ga.; Lordstown, Ohio; Scarborough, Ontario; Van Nuys, Calif.; Linden, N.J.; Lansing, Mich.; Arlington, Texas; Wentzville, Mo., and Orion, Mich. Also on the list was Ford's Fox plant in Dearborn, Mich.; Chrysler plants in St. Louis; Brampton, Ontario, and Pillette Road, Ontario; and a GM-Toyota joint venture in Fremont, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears Way for Channel One in North Carolina
DOC.TEXT: A Superior Court judge Friday cleared the way for Channel One, a daily news show with commercials aimed at teenagers, to begin beaming into North Carolina classrooms. The news show, being produced by Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., is set to begin nationally on Monday. After an allday hearing, Judge Donald Stephens ruled that the State Board of Education has the authority to ban the 12-minute news program, but did not follow the correct procedures in imposing a ban Feb. 1. His order dismisses a lawsuit brought by the State Board of Education against the Thomasville school system and Whittle Communications. It also reverses a decision by the State Board that contracts signed for Channel One before Feb. 1 are void and that no new contracts can be signed. ``After a careful review, the court concludes that the State Board of Education has the authority to make rules concerning supplemental materials that contain advertising,'' Stephens said. But he said the State Board must follow procedures for rulemaking by state agencies. The board's ban had been imposed immediately as an emergency rule while the board pursued procedures to make it permanent, but Stephens ruled because there was no evidence of an immediate threat to the public welfare by allowing Channel One to proceed. The 12-minute news program contains two minutes of commercials and more than 2,700 schools have signed up for the service nationwide. About 30 school boards in North Carolina have signed up for the service, which loans local schools video equipment in exchange for a guarantee that the news show will be shown to students every day. Edwin Speas, representing the State Board, argued that the required viewing of Channel One amounted to exploitation of students who are required to be in school under the state's compulsory attendance law. But Stephens ruled that the contracts with Whittle do not violate public policy or the state constitution because no valid rule against the contracts in effect. ``We think it's a victory for children and teachers in North Carolina,'' said Max Walser, superintendent of the Davidson County schools. Davidson County's school board, which had signed a contract with Whittle prior to the ban, had filed a countersuit against the State Board of Education. ``We are certainly pleased that the judge ruled, as we have felt, that the State Board acted improperly,'' said Gene Causby of the state School Boards Association. ``Those contracts are back in force.'' Speas said after the ruling that it did not amount to a total victory for Channel One supporters. `` The court has confirmed their (the State Board's) authority in this area, which was very important,'' Speas said. ``The judge said that a rule can be made, it just has to follow the regulations of the Administrative Procedures Act.'' Speas said an official notice that the State Board intends to impose the ban already has been given and a public hearing required by rulemaking regulations has been scheduled for April 2. ``The existing contracts are valid and Channel One will premiere in North Carolina schools on March 5,'' said Ed Winter, president of Whittle Communications. ``Those school systems that have not yet signed contracts, but would like to, are now free to do so.''
